webTitle: Review: A Drink with Shane MacGowan by Victoria Mary Clarke and Black Vinyl, White Powder by Simon Napier-Bell

fields.headline: The sound and the fury
fields.standfirst: Shane MacGowan isn't the only pop phenomenon in terminal decline, laments  Ian Penman after reading Shane's biography A Drink with Shane MacGowan and Simon Napier-Bell's history of pop gossip Black Vinyl, White Powder
fields.trailText: Shane MacGowan isn't the only pop phenomenon in terminal decline, laments Ian Penman after reading Shane's biography A Drink With Shane MacGowan and Simon Napier-Bell's history of pop gossip Black Vinyl, White Powder
fields.body:
Black Vinyl, White Powder
Simon Napier-Bell
390pp, Ebury Press
£16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A Drink With Shane MacGowan
Victoria Mary Clarke and Shane MacGowan
360pp, Sidgwick & Jackson
£15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Simon Napier-Bell can probably look forward to an obituary - man who took Wham! to China! - that marks the apotheosis of a life spent pulling: strings, strokes, the other one. From 1950s trad-jazz gadabout to international pop guru, Napier-Bell has seen it all and remembered most of it: he has seen superstars when they were simpering wee lads, and shared blowjob secrets with the great gay-UK pop sodality (Larry Parnes, Lionel Bart, Tom Watkins). On the surface, he's pure surface; but anyone familiar with Napier-Bell's previous 1960s summa ("You Don't Have to Say You Love Me") won't be surprised to learn that Black Vinyl, White Powder isn't just a name-drop glide through limo-land. Napier-Bell can tell spontaneous pop gold from titanic fraud, and sets down his patented form of higher gossip with a (kind of) moral purpose.

If you're itching for the drug revelations his latest title seems to promise, you may be disappointed: there is little here that a reasonably aware scumsurfer couldn't have gleaned over the last decade - a period when all the dirty secrets previously kept by attorneys or dealers became public domain via the tabloidisation of the music press, various tell-all autobiographies and the advent of list TV ("The 20 Greatest ODs of All Time!"). Napier-Bell's cockily Manichaean title is just good PR come-on: showbiz has always been a snow biz, just as it has always been shaped by the ambisexual nous of gay managers and shored up by a hinterland of shadowy accounts (the offshore kind).

This isn't a drugs book. Napier-Bell is not always accurate and accepts too many of the narco-mythologies at face value; but he's also canny enough to realise that, finally, all this shock-horror drug stuff is essentially a blind - an Apocalypse Now whizz-bang behind which greater crimes are carved out. Pop's real scandals involve low-end financial and contractual practices, but such is their small-print nature that they tend to fall all too conveniently between the business pages and the tabloid splash, and are rarely aired.

Thus, the real insider revelations here concern the business of business. Napier-Bell is good on the inelegantly Byzantine clauses of early-1960s pop and how the major labels have always used self-serving sharp practices (like chart-rigging) to "police" themselves. He's also good on how 1960s pop was shaped - both in the boardroom and the studio - by unsung gay pioneers: there are incisive portraits of Kit Lambert, Joe Meek, Brian Epstein. (It is also heartening that the few things that still get his old heart racing - Pulp, Massive Attack, Daniel Miller's Mute label - are far from the Brits-approved norm.) Even at his most scurrilous, Napier-Bell is never knowingly nasty; he doesn't moralise, and has a truly sane acceptance of drugs and sex and their place in a hedonistic world.

Napier-Bell reserves his real bile for our current Popstars moment, seeing in it not just a failure of creative nerve, but a wider, more worrying trend: the total eradication of personality in the name of profit. He's no Theodor Adorno, nor meant to be, but even Napier-Bell - arch scam-artist, king of the hype frontier - thinks things have gone too far in an industry in which the virtues of long-game creativity have been binned in favour of quick-hit global niche marketing.

The only MacGowan in Napier-Bell's index is Cathy; but Shane MacGowan - in his own devil's-tune, dishevelled way - is as much a part of postmodern pop as H from Steps. If the boyband universe represents the triumph of product over personality, then MacGowan represents a strange Adults Only version which is all personality and - polite cough - never mind the music; his floggable persona has become the product, replacing anything so quaint as an actual CD of new material.

Even a generous reading of MacGowan's career can't sidestep the fact that his best work was a long, long time ago. His true role is to keep all us old rock bores diverted - "Ooh, did you hear the latest about Shane!" - while the real business of pop business goes on. Is Shane a rebel heart way "outside the system" or one of its worst manifestations? The last bard in town or a lyric souse increasingly nearer late Jeffrey Bernard than mid-period Gram Parsons?

It is probably safe to say that if MacGowan - a self-described "alcoholic junkie Republican" - didn't exist, the music industry wouldn't go out of its way to invent him. But he has done pretty well off the back of his role as ravaged ghost at pop's sushi feast. A gift for a dirt-hungry media with urgent space to fill, Shane is good X-rated copy, a 21st-century blarney stone for whom the pub- bound Q&A has become an easy supper song. (In his shaky confessional hands, sex and drugs and rock'n'roll has been reduced to drugs and drugs and more drugs.) If you want to be bright-side pretentious, he's taken on a kind of shamanic/storyteller role; if you want to be cynical, he's just a proxy low-life Calvary for all the little middle-class hacks.

From John Lennon to the Gallagher Brothers, taking in John Lydon, Shaun Ryder and MacGowan, little England has had a weird on/off love affair with bolshy Irish boys: junkies, misogynists and thieves, anarchists and IRA supporters. The best and most revealing part of A Drink With . . . concerns the Irish in Britain: the early chapters covering MacGowan's upbringing on an Irish farm and his parents' subsequent unhappy move to Brighton have the vividness of good fiction. (Or of old Shane MacGowan songs.)

It's also the only part that adds anything new to our perception of the man. Only latecomers will be shocked by well-read MacGowan, just one of the many selves he stores behind that perma-slur exterior, which may itself be the ultimate - and fussily contrived - snow job. (As in Willie Nelson's cogent line: "Hell, I only drink so much so people won't think I'm a dope fiend.") MacGowan's flock will find little that's new - and would anyway prefer stormin' new work from your man rather than one more helping of an increasingly stale gonzo mythology.

MacGowan is still an involving - if inconsistent - anecdotalist. In the space of a few pages he remembers himself as greasy rocker, punk, soulboy, freak, faux -rentboy and self-proclaimed enemy of all of the above. A canny (or simply awake) editor would have excised a central section which is hapless repetition, pub trivia and a large helping of interruptive vanity on Ms Clarke's part. Even her quasi-marital status doesn't stop MacGowan losing his temper when her questions slip below an acceptable baseline of dim-wittedness. Her intermittent "scene setting" is truly gruesome in its ineptness and, more crucially, she can't interview to save her (or his) life. There are moments when MacGowan's mask begins to slip, revealing a world of pain and perplexity, but Clarke (deliberately?) fumbles them, apparently more concerned with showing herself in a good Rock Girlfriend light. As such, A Drink With . . . is as nauseatingly cosy as any Hello! interview. I mean: how would we react to any other rock star being "profiled" by their live-in lover?

There are hints that MacGowan is less than happy with either the book or his wider station, and flashes of a truly fearsome anger that suggest a substantially different Shane from the one Clarke prepared earlier, and offers us here. Still, by choosing not to exercise his seigniorial veto, MacGowan shows in A Drink With . . . that he is happy to carry on with his attenuated role as rock's jaundiced jester: a role he plays, if not with good grace, then with a kind of weary alcoholic stoicism. "They all buy me drinks - what can I do?"

Well, he could lock himself away in a cottage somewhere and come up with a truly redemptive comeback, like his friends Nick Cave and Steve Earle, or his hero Tom Waits. Except that there are people like Clarke ready to facilitate the myth, while the media is happy to accept his bleary disingenuousness at face value. Everyone just shrugs and says, ah well: that's Shane!

Or you might just wonder at how dehumanised both he and we have become if our idea of entertainment is overseeing the macabre spectacle of this man burying himself alive. You need only compare the ferocious industry of Charles Bukowski, say, with the befuddled last words of Kurt Cobain to realise how crucial, still, is the demarcation between art "about" privation and real, lived despair. With Shane MacGowan, the Orphic function seems to have been shucked off a way back, leaving only a faintly terminal form of jive.

It is probably safe to say that if MacGowan - a self-described "alcoholic junkie Republican" - didn't exist, the music industry wouldn't go out of its way to invent him. But he has done pretty well off the back of his role as ravaged ghost at pop's sushi feast. A gift for a dirt-hungry media with urgent space to fill, Shane is good X-rated copy, a 21st-century blarney stone for whom the pub- bound Q&A has become an easy supper song. (In his shaky confessional hands, sex and drugs and rock'n'roll has been reduced to drugs and drugs and more drugs.) If you want to be bright-side pretentious, he's taken on a kind of shamanic/storyteller role; if you want to be cynical, he's just a proxy low-life Calvary for all the little middle-class hacks. From John Lennon to the Gallagher Brothers, taking in John Lydon, Shaun Ryder and MacGowan, little England has had a weird on/off love affair with bolshy Irish boys: junkies, misogynists and thieves, anarchists and IRA supporters. The best and most revealing part of A Drink With . . . concerns the Irish in Britain: the early chapters covering MacGowan's upbringing on an Irish farm and his parents' subsequent unhappy move to Brighton have the vividness of good fiction. (Or of old Shane MacGowan songs.) It's also the only part that adds anything new to our perception of the man. Only latecomers will be shocked by well-read MacGowan, just one of the many selves he stores behind that perma-slur exterior, which may itself be the ultimate - and fussily contrived - snow job. (As in Willie Nelson's cogent line: "Hell, I only drink so much so people won't think I'm a dope fiend.") MacGowan's flock will find little that's new - and would anyway prefer stormin' new work from your man rather than one more helping of an increasingly stale gonzo mythology. MacGowan is still an involving - if inconsistent - anecdotalist. In the space of a few pages he remembers himself as greasy rocker, punk, soulboy, freak, faux -rentboy and self-proclaimed enemy of all of the above. A canny (or simply awake) editor would have excised a central section which is hapless repetition, pub trivia and a large helping of interruptive vanity on Ms Clarke's part. Even her quasi-marital status doesn't stop MacGowan losing his temper when her questions slip below an acceptable baseline of dim-wittedness. Her intermittent "scene setting" is truly gruesome in its ineptness and, more crucially, she can't interview to save her (or his) life. There are moments when MacGowan's mask begins to slip, revealing a world of pain and perplexity, but Clarke (deliberately?) fumbles them, apparently more concerned with showing herself in a good Rock Girlfriend light. As such, A Drink With . . . is as nauseatingly cosy as any Hello! interview. I mean: how would we react to any other rock star being "profiled" by their live-in lover? There are hints that MacGowan is less than happy with either the book or his wider station, and flashes of a truly fearsome anger that suggest a substantially different Shane from the one Clarke prepared earlier, and offers us here. Still, by choosing not to exercise his seigniorial veto, MacGowan shows in A Drink With . . . that he is happy to carry on with his attenuated role as rock's jaundiced jester: a role he plays, if not with good grace, then with a kind of weary alcoholic stoicism. "They all buy me drinks - what can I do?" Well, he could lock himself away in a cottage somewhere and come up with a truly redemptive comeback, like his friends Nick Cave and Steve Earle, or his hero Tom Waits. Except that there are people like Clarke ready to facilitate the myth, while the media is happy to accept his bleary disingenuousness at face value. Everyone just shrugs and says, ah well: that's Shane! Or you might just wonder at how dehumanised both he and we have become if our idea of entertainment is overseeing the macabre spectacle of this man burying himself alive. You need only compare the ferocious industry of Charles Bukowski, say, with the befuddled last words of Kurt Cobain to realise how crucial, still, is the demarcation between art "about" privation and real, lived despair. With Shane MacGowan, the Orphic function seems to have been shucked off a way back, leaving only a faintly terminal form of jive.

fields.headline: Is it destiny then, Glenn, that Gordon was born to scuttle?
fields.trailText: Glenn's reign starts at Spurs ... he'll tackle it head-on ... that'll be him out for the rest of the season!
fields.body:
'We want our Tottenham back!"... Glory glory days, hmm? ... isn't it? ... the silky skills ... the self-inflicted injuries ... Glenn's reign starts at Spurs ... it's a massive job ... but he'll tackle it head-on ... that'll be him out for the rest of the season!

But already ... after watching his "football connoisseurs" take a 2-0 trouncing from the clogged philistine plodders of boring, boring Arsenal ... Glenn's turned the form book on its head! ... 2-1 ... the scoreline's got a one in it! ... ho ho! ... he might work in mysterious ways ... but under Glenn's calm tutelage ... watch them return to their spiritual home ... mid-table mediocrity!

Glenn's identified the problem! ... "Too many disjoinments" ... is that a word? ... it is now!

"It's ironic how Arsene's a strange name, but the way it's spelt is very close to Arsenal ... why, of all the clubs in the world? ... perhaps he was destined to coach there." ... ho ho! ... Hodspur? ... hmm? ... er ... Hoddersfield?

Well, there's been a few wrong 'uns at the Lane of late ... but the year's got a one in it ... and now the hot seat's got a right one in it! ... even David Pleat's all misty-eyed! ... reminiscing about his own days in the driving seat ... Friday night was chess night! ... Saturday night ... ho ho!

Let's have a reader's letter! ... Cornelius of Athens writes "We want our Enic back! Heh heh - only joking, peeps!"

And now ... Ron dips his toe in the Nationwide ... Top of the table clash midweek, as the runaway leaders take on "the best team in the First Division" ... Blackburn! ... under the ... er ... calm tutelage of Graeme Souness ... Beaten in the second minute of injury-time ... Graeme's ... er ... mildly furious!

"We have been punched on the nose in the cruellest possible way!" ... ho ho! ... as opposed to being stamped on in midfield in the cruellest possible way ... hmm? ... marvellous!

Mohammed Al Fayed's Fulham! ... hmm? ... lolly in a brown paper bag? ... No! It's a toothpick! ... it's Jean Tigana! ... chewing ruminatively ... is that a word? ... er ... nickname "The Masticator" ... reminiscent of Kojak in his pomp! ... "who loves ya, baby?" ... er ... Yes!

Portsmouth continue to plummet under the calm tutelage of Graham Rix ... don't worry, Pompey fans ... the manager's been round the block ... been there ... done that ... isn't it? ... watch him profit from the naivete of others! ... marvellous! ... er ...

Back to the Premiership! ... Man the lifeboats! ... It's Coventry! Trying to avoid the drop under the ... er ... not so calm tutelage of Gordon Strachan ... he's upbeat! ... "I still think the teams that'll go down will come from the bottom four" ... shrewd ... hmm? ... isn't it?

He might be playing his cards close to his chest ... but don't be surprised if he's right! ... he's taken a lot of criticism other managers might think below the belt! ... a man of Gordon's stature takes it on the chin! ... he's never considered walking away from the job ... ho ho! Gordon wasn't "born to run" ... Born to ... er ... scuttle ... wasn't he?

And the traditional escape act is underway! ... Coventry's season starts here! ... Hartson! ... there's one in the eye for the doubters ... he's punching his weight! ... adding some clout to their attack ... there's a kick in the teeth for those who said he couldn't cut it in the Premiership! ... Right ho! ... let's have some more readers' letters! ...

Vinnie writes from the Hollywood Hills!: "Ron, why didn't Wycombe just kick Liverpool to bits?" ... Good question! ... but Heskey? ... hmm? ... he's a handful ... Pesky Heskey? ... isn't it? ... hmm? ... Heskey-Weskey ... Dostoevsky ... The Idiot ... ho ho! ... the jury's out ... but he's doing the business for Liverpool ...

The Brothers Kamarazov ... hmm? ... signed for West Ham ... wasn't it? ... what happened to them, 'Arry? ... not up to scratch? ... Ivan Ellovanich ... ho ho! ... isn't it? ... Let's have ... another reader's letter! ... a Monsieur Le Saux from west London writes: "Ron, why do flies and moths fly round lightbulbs? Is it because they think it's the moon?"

Er ... yes! ... at last! ... a natural history question ... next!

... And another! ... er ... it's Monsieur Le Saux again ... "Ron, scientists have discovered a way to turn fat into bone; do you think that would've rescued Gazza's career?"

Well ... once a "fathead" always a "fathead" ... as my grandmother used to say! ... ho ho! ... a clip round the ear and a sentimental song before bedtime ... marvellous!

Another reader's letter! ... great stuff! ... it's Mark Pitts of Chiswick! ... "Ron, I've done another one of them anagrams! Nwankwo Kanu: "Uno ..."

Go away, Mark ... where was I? ... er ... Let's leave the last word to a man of the cloth!

After lots of fierce debate on the website "discarded hotdog@nimby.com" - responding to Ron's talking point "should football 'stadia' be built out of town or would residents miss the drunken yobbos fouling the neighbourhood and urinating in public? ... hmm?" - the Rev J Spooner of Blackburn writes: "No! I used to dread Saturday afternoons - Ewood Park over the fence!"

fields.headline: God squad who didn't have a prayer
fields.trailText: The half-time teamtalk is seen by managers as the most important 15 minutes of their jobs, the catalyst which can change the course of a game, so what exactly did Tunoa Lui, the coach of American Samoa, say to his lads at the interval?
fields.body:
Football managers will tell you it is the most important 15 minutes of their jobs, the brief window they have to re-invigorate resolve, alter tactics or simply remind their main striker that the goal is the thing with the netting in it. The half-time team talk is credited by television commentators as the catalyst which has altered the course of many a game. "Ho, ho, Trevor," Motty will often say. "You have to wonder what the manager said at half-time to make his team play like this."

In which case, what exactly did Tunoa Lui, the coach of American Samoa, find to say to his lads as they trooped into the dressing room after 45 minutes against Australia in their World Cup qualifier on Wednesday, halfway as they were towards record international defeat?

"No worries, fellas, we can easily pull back 16 goals in the second half" would have sounded a little optimistic; "any chance of keeping a closer eye on their centre- forward, he's already scored eight" a little obvious; and shouting at the goalkeeper that "a dustbin placed in the middle of the goal-line would have saved more than you" a little harsh.

Apparently the team were all Christian fundamentalists and had spent a good 30 minutes before the game praying for guidance and success. After a first half like that it was probably advisable not to bother upstairs again. Besides, the Samoans' experience with prayer will no doubt be taken as proof of the notion often bandied in the bars of Sydney, that God, at least in his sporting guise, is an Australian.

Best, then, to have adopted the line used by Brian Clough - and now, we may speculate, put to good use by his disciple Martin O'Neill at Celtic.

Once, after an uncharacteristically shabby performance, Nottingham Forest were trailing 2-0 at half-time. Fearing a volcanic Cloughie bollocking, the players sheepishly shuffled into the dressing room to find no sign of the great man.

After five long, worrisome minutes he had still not put in an appearance. After 10, with the tea drunk and the Jaffa cakes polished off, Stuart Pearce and a couple of other senior players took charge and chivvied their team-mates as best they could. After 15 minutes, still with no sign of Cloughie, the Forest team could hear their opponents clacking down the corridor out on to the pitch and the referee stuck his head round the door to tell them it was time to return.

Then, just as his players were about to depart for the fray, Clough finally appeared. "Sorry lads, all my fault" was all he said. "I picked the wrong team."

Except in Tunoa Lui's case, he should have said: "Sorry lads, all my fault. Picked the wrong country."

And finally...

This is the last White's Week. It is customary for proper, grown-up columnists signing off for the last time to thank the many readers who have taken the trouble to write in. But frankly the news of imminent departure will come as a relief to the correspondent who wrote to suggest that, judging by the standard of my prose, long-term exposure to speculation, conjecture and wild generalisation had clearly rotted what little brain I started off with. Thanks for that, mum. I'm off to take up another role in the super soaraway Guardian sports section, whose expansion remains top secret. If you have been, thanks for reading. And if you haven't, you'll never know what you missed.

fields.headline: Ginola's revisionism breaks the monotony
fields.trailText: Ginola's revisionism breaks the monotony.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 1's website is currently carrying handy revision tips for students who may be worried about upcoming exams (www.bbc. co.uk/radio1/essentials/ student/). To lend some credibility to the exercise they roped in David Ginola - the obvious choice when you think about it. "Try to get out at least once a day for fresh air and exercise," he says. "Go on, get that football out!" Villa fans may not be surprised to find he also stresses the necessity to "schedule yourself in lots of breaks". Finally, if it's all getting too much, David advises: "Keep things in perspective - exams aren't everything!" After all, there is always a career as a millionaire footballer if you fail.

Helpful advice of a different sort from the Southampton captain Jason Dodd on the club's official website, where he has a Q and A column. "Doddsy, I'm planning to get engaged to my missus this year," writes Saints fan Ben West. "Any good ideas on how and where I should do it?" Unfazed by the unusual question, Doddsy replies: "Do not propose after you have had a few beers! When I asked my missus I had been out on a night out and suddenly asked. The next morning when I woke up everything had been booked! We went to America - it was a nice ceremony with a gazebo and everything and I am still a happily married man! How about proposing at the last game at the Dell or the first game at the new stadium? Now that's romantic!" Maybe so, but there's the lack of the gazebo to consider.

Further news of Bath City's chaplain who, as mentioned last week, chose the Velvet Underground's slice of street realism (let's put it no stronger than that) Waiting For The Man as his favourite half-time record. He writes to explain: "In a sense, aren't we all waiting for our Man? I know I am." In a very real sense I think we probably are.

Inevitable, really, but Fair Play Day in the French First Division did not go entirely according to plan last weekend. In fact, it turned into the second least fair day of the season, with referees showing 42 yellow cards and two red ones. And this despite the fact that players had been paraded in T-shirts reading "Peace and Foot" (in English) and team captains read out messages about fair play before kick-off. If that didn't get through, what on earth can they try next?

On the very same page as last week's Diary we printed a picture of Arsenal's Sylvain Wiltord, wearing a training bib mysteriously inscribed "D.H." Can it really be that the Gunners' state-of-the-art facilities at London Colney have not been restocked with fresh bibs since David Hillier left? Hard to believe of a man so devoted to detail as Arsene Wenger.

Kevin Lynch, a former League referee, has a new job. He is "soccer's first disciplinary flying doctor". He claims to have saved Derby a hefty fine after advising their players to grow their hair rather than adopt the aggressive shaven-haired look which "could lead to them being prejudged by the referee and opponents as being aggressive". Middlesbrough, he feels, could use the same approach to improve their record, which is the worst in the Premiership. Are you listening Christian Karembeu?

mike.ticher@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Ipswich put Robson on pedestal
fields.trailText: His hyper presence on the touchline at the age of 68 may suggest eternal youth but, 19 years after leaving Ipswich Town, Bobby Robson is set to achieve immortality in Suffolk.
fields.body:
His hyper presence on the touchline at the age of 68 may suggest eternal youth but, 19 years after leaving Ipswich Town, Bobby Robson is set to achieve immortality in Suffolk.

This afternoon the Newcastle manager makes his first competitive visit to his former club since leaving to manage England in 1982. Last night he met with Sean Hedges-Quinn, the sculptor whose statue of Sir Alf Ramsey was unveiled at Portman Road last year, to discuss a permanent reminder of his 13-year managerial tenure in East Anglia. Ipswich are to have their idol back.

"We put Ipswich on the map because of the football, not the tractors," says the former Barcelona and Porto coach, who won the FA and Uefa Cups with the Suffolk side. "I turned a Cinderella club into a team that was well respected throughout Europe.

"The biggest regret of my life was not winning the championship. If I could have bought two more players in 1981 we would have done it. We played 66 games and used only 21 players - they got us to the semi-finals of the FA Cup, the sixth round of the League Cup and won the Uefa Cup, but Aston Villa pipped us for the league on the last day of the season."

Prior to taking the England job, Robson had been courted by other clubs hoping he might reproduce his Ipswich magic on a bigger stage. "The night we won the Uefa Cup I got a call from Martin Edwards asking me to take over at Manchester United," he recalls. "I told him he'd given me a headache and I wished he'd never called. It crossed my mind that I'd passed up a chance of a lifetime, but you can never tell what's around the corner."

On that subject, even he did not anticipate Ipswich's startling progress this season. Supposed lambs to the slaughter, they are on the verge of the Champions League and it has all been masterminded by a man signed by Robson.

"I staged a private trial match in Ayrshire," he says. "When we arrived there were 300 people in the ground, including managers and scouts from other clubs. George Burley played and I told them to take him off after 20 minutes. He was devastated, but I didn't want all those other buggers to see him."

Burley made his debut as a 17-year-old at Old Trafford, charged with marking George Best. Backed up by the stability of a club that has employed 10 managers since turning professional in 1936, he has approached Premiership management with an equally unfazed assurance.

"George has found what I found, that it's a great club to work for," says Robson. "The manager's name is never written on the door in white chalk with a sponge hanging below. They always had a Corinthian attitude."

How the native north-easterner must crave similar success at Newcastle, where his Tyneside revolution has temporarily stalled. "It'll take two years to clean this club up," he adds. "But I'm still enthusiastic and motivated. I just wish I was going back to Ipswich with my strongest team. It will be an emotional day."

This afternoon the Newcastle manager makes his first competitive visit to his former club since leaving to manage England in 1982. Last night he met with Sean Hedges-Quinn, the sculptor whose statue of Sir Alf Ramsey was unveiled at Portman Road last year, to discuss a permanent reminder of his 13-year managerial tenure in East Anglia. Ipswich are to have their idol back. "We put Ipswich on the map because of the football, not the tractors," says the former Barcelona and Porto coach, who won the FA and Uefa Cups with the Suffolk side. "I turned a Cinderella club into a team that was well respected throughout Europe. "The biggest regret of my life was not winning the championship. If I could have bought two more players in 1981 we would have done it. We played 66 games and used only 21 players - they got us to the semi-finals of the FA Cup, the sixth round of the League Cup and won the Uefa Cup, but Aston Villa pipped us for the league on the last day of the season." Prior to taking the England job, Robson had been courted by other clubs hoping he might reproduce his Ipswich magic on a bigger stage. "The night we won the Uefa Cup I got a call from Martin Edwards asking me to take over at Manchester United," he recalls. "I told him he'd given me a headache and I wished he'd never called. It crossed my mind that I'd passed up a chance of a lifetime, but you can never tell what's around the corner." On that subject, even he did not anticipate Ipswich's startling progress this season. Supposed lambs to the slaughter, they are on the verge of the Champions League and it has all been masterminded by a man signed by Robson. "I staged a private trial match in Ayrshire," he says. "When we arrived there were 300 people in the ground, including managers and scouts from other clubs. George Burley played and I told them to take him off after 20 minutes. He was devastated, but I didn't want all those other buggers to see him." Burley made his debut as a 17-year-old at Old Trafford, charged with marking George Best. Backed up by the stability of a club that has employed 10 managers since turning professional in 1936, he has approached Premiership management with an equally unfazed assurance. "George has found what I found, that it's a great club to work for," says Robson. "The manager's name is never written on the door in white chalk with a sponge hanging below. They always had a Corinthian attitude." How the native north-easterner must crave similar success at Newcastle, where his Tyneside revolution has temporarily stalled. "It'll take two years to clean this club up," he adds. "But I'm still enthusiastic and motivated. I just wish I was going back to Ipswich with my strongest team. It will be an emotional day."

webTitle: Stewart sets his sights on Europe

fields.headline: Stewart sets his sights on Europe
fields.trailText: The Premiership's top scorer has proved his doubters wrong and is confident Ipswich can mount a European challenge.
fields.body:
Marcus Stewart swallows a mouthful of bangers and mash and pictures himself in a deckchair. "That's when it will sink in," the Ipswich striker says. "When we are sitting down on holiday somewhere in the summer thinking 'We'll be playing in Europe next season'."

The 28-year-old is talking of ifs rather than whens, but his voice is laced with expectation. For months Ipswich have brushed aside talk of Europe with an alacrity which suggested Martin O'Neill was giving them lessons, yet finally the mood is changing.

Where once Premiership survival was seen as an achievement, now failure to make the Champions League or Uefa Cup would be a blow. "Most definitely," says Stewart, who saw Ipswich drop to fourth yesterday with Leeds' 2-1 win at Anfield. "If we don't get into Europe we'll be disappointed."

The run-in suggests they will make it. Today sees the visit of Newcastle, whose manager Bobby Robson was the last man to qualify Ipswich for Europe in 1982. After that there are home matches against Coventry and Manchester City and trips to Middlesbrough, Charlton and Derby. Rivals must feel the only team missing are American Samoa.

Stewart is not expecting to find the net 13 times in one game but the Premiership's leading scorer does have his eye on personal as well as club glory. Like Sunderland's Kevin Phillips last term, he intends to win the golden boot in his first top-flight season.

"My original goal was to be in the top five scorers in the Premiership," says Stewart, whose 18 goals put him one ahead of Chelsea's Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. "My goal now is to win the golden boot."

Despite his gleaming convertible Mercedes, the personable Stewart does not come across as a superstar. Perhaps it is the west country accent or the fact that he is devouring sausages and potato rather than broccoli and grilled fish. Maybe it is the CV which shows Bristol Rovers and Huddersfield as his former clubs.

Yet his form encapsulates what George Burley is achieving at Ipswich. Where others ignored Stewart because of a perceived lack of pace, Burley paid Huddersfield £2.5m a little over a year ago and has been vindicated. John McGreal, Matt Holland and Jermaine Wright have taken similar, cheaper routes.

"We are proud of the way we improve players," says Burley, who has spent around £8m since winning promotion last May. "And that's not luck, it's a day-in, day-out situation. We like to work on areas of the game where we think we can improve them. People always questioned that lack of pace with Marcus but I think he's got quicker and sharper since he came to the club.

"He's always had a great football brain, but playing with good players, training the way we do and being in this environment has improved him. His all-round game has been exceptional. He's not just a goalscorer, he does a lot with his work-rate and hold-up play."

The hat-trick Stewart scored at Southampton recently illustrated his striking instinct. He knows, though, that a tougher test lies ahead. "I think it will be a lot more difficult next season," he says. "People will know what we're like as a team and what I'm like as a player."

Kevin Phillips has found life harder second time around, yet Stewart is hopeful of continuing in the vein which makes Burley suggest he "has to be considered" for England. A former schoolboy international and under-21 squad member, Stewart's self-confidence is plain.

"I always felt I could play at this level," he says. "I just needed someone to have the belief in me like the manager now and the chairman. They have given me the chance to play and to settle a few scores. That's what I've done this season; I've shut a few people up. I'm not going to name names, but they know who they are."

That hunger is common among the cast-offs and bargains Burley has mixed with local talent. It cannot have gone unnoticed at Middlesbrough that Alun Armstrong, sold to Ipswich for £500,000 in December, got the equaliser against Liverpool on Tuesday to take his Premiership tally to five. That would make him Boro's second top scorer.

Burley's eye for a player is augmented by training which concentrates on technique, organisation and repetition that makes Ipswich's passing and team pattern instinctive. Throw in the flexibility to play 4-4-2 or 3-5-2 and to use the aerial threat of James Scowcroft when necessary, and their success looks more than a flash in the pan.

"I think George Burley's the best manager I've worked with," Stewart says. "Every player goes out knowing their job and how to achieve a win, and as a man-manager he's fantastic. He treats people like adults and I respect him for that because I've come across one or two managers who think you're an eight-year-old and try to treat you like one."

A unity and sense of purpose is fostered from the top, with the chairman David Sheepshanks holding a pre-season meeting with the players to explain plans and canvass opinion. With increased revenue looming from the stadium expansion, and probably Europe, the future looks bright. "We wanted to get to this standard within five years," Stewart says. "We've achieved it in six months."

He expects signings in the summer and believes the club could cope with European competition. "If we stay clear of injuries, yeah. We've managed that quite well this year - touch wood - and we've done okay."

Okay? As understatement of the year, that takes some beating.

webTitle: Arthur Daley's spirit lives on at Saltergate

fields.headline: Arthur Daley's spirit lives on at Saltergate
fields.trailText: The Chesterfield case has further emphasised the enormous financial gulf that lies between the wealth in the upper reaches of the Premier League and the small change at the fag-end of the Nationwide.
fields.body:
There have been some grubby goings-on at Chesterfield. All right, so most of the charges alleging financial irregularities at the club have not been proved but those that have leave a nasty smell.

After a three-day hearing the joint Football Association and Football League disciplinary panel found the Nationwide Third Division leaders guilty of fiddling gate receipts and giving a player, Luke Beckett, two contracts in order to reduce a fee set by a transfer tribunal.

While no individual was condemned it was decided that Chesterfield had broken eight League regulations, had brought the game into disrepute and had misled the tribunal over Beckett.

For this the panel has ruled that Chesterfield should lose nine league points and be fined £20,000, a punishment which has to be ratified by the Football League board. The club are appealing despite the fact that the loss of points will delay their promotion rather than prevent it.

Yesterday Brendan Batson, the deputy chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association, felt that taking points away from Chesterfield was too harsh. A heavy fine alone, he said, would punish those responsible. Deducting points penalised the supporters.

This is an argument often heard when clubs who have broken the rules are relegated or, as in the case of Swindon Town in 1990, not promoted. Swindon, who had won the old Second Division play-offs, pleaded guilty to 36 charges of irregular payments to players and were originally sent down to the Third before being restored to the Second on appeal.

Chesterfield, who denied everything, have been found guilty on a handful of counts out of 90, so hardly come into a similar category. Yet they could have fared much worse, given the charges against them which have stood up and a growing feeling within the game that football should be seen to keep its house in impeccable order. A 50-point deduction, even banishment to the Nationwide Conference, had been feared.

The prevailing feeling among the supporters, players and officials of Chesterfield should be one of considerable relief. Their season stands to suffer a nasty hiccup but at least it has not had a fatal convulsion.

The immediate reactions of John Green, the club's chief executive, and their manager Nicky Law would appear to share this view. But, when Darren Brown, who was the Chesterfield chairman until he stood down last month, continues to insist the charges should never have been brought, he is surely guilty of inappropriate chutzpah.

Not proven is hardly the same as not guilty. Chesterfield should be reflecting, not rejoicing - and so should the rest of football.

The Chesterfield case has further emphasised the enormous financial gulf that lies between the wealth in the upper reaches of the Premier League and the small change at the fag-end of the Nationwide.

Manchester United collect £1.67m in gate receipts every time they play at home, whereas at Saltergate, the inquiry was told, three turnstiles were not connected to the computer recording attendance figures but still took admission money. It is nice to know that somewhere the spirit of Arthur Daley lives on.

There have been and will continue to be worse instances of financial misbehaviour than those proved against Chesterfield. It is the air of small-time wheeler-dealing which offends more than anything, the willingness of one little club to do another (Chester City) down over what, in the general scheme of things, was a piddling transfer.

With the Derbyshire fraud squad investigating the way Chesterfield have been run as well as sending a file to the Crown Prosecution Service concerning possible charges of witness intimidation, the Saltergate affair may not be over yet. The football authorities, meanwhile, will surely redouble their efforts to set up a more effective system of keeping the right checks and balances on the running of clubs and the way they are financed.

The 29-year-old Brown denies that he has done anything wrong. Fair enough, but the financial state of some of his other sporting interests, such as the Sheffield Steelers and Sheffield Sharks, ice hockey and basketball teams respectively, would seem to suggest that recently little has gone right.

In another sense Chesterfield may merely be victims of what some would say is a greater financial scandal in football, namely its inability, through greed, to share out the income more fairly. There is a fat chance of this, with the majority of Premier League clubs already mortgaging the next TV windfall in order to add a few more twists to the upward spiral of players' wages.

Yesterday Geoffrey Richmond, the Bradford City chairman, reckoned that being relegated to the First Division would cost the club £20m in lost revenue. Is it any wonder that, lower down the league, the occasional black economy bordering on black comedy comes to light.

Meanwhile Chesterfield fans might consider relieving David Elleray, the referee who denied them a crucial goal against Middlesbrough in the 1997 FA Cup semi-finals, of the title of Spireite bogeyman-in-chief. But they probably won't.

fields.headline: Curbishley angry after rare Bradford victory
fields.trailText: This was a game almost entirely without merit between a team that has long since accepted its fate and a team that, having performed above itself all season, is desperate for a break.
fields.body:
For over an hour this match gave new meaning to "going through the motions". It simply did not matter. The players knew it and, within five minutes, so did the crowd.

The occasional - very occasional - incident aside, this was a game almost entirely without merit between a team that has long since accepted its fate and a team that, having performed above itself all season, is desperate for a break.

In fact Charlton, after the intensity of their effort in trying to contain Manchester United on Tuesday, looked utterly shot, and this despite their manager Alan Curbishley making four changes to the team so comprehensively overrun at Old Trafford, when the 2-1 scoreline was one of the most misleading of the season.

"I have told the players they have five games left and it's up to them to nail down their positions because in the summer we will be looking to strengthen," a less-than-happy Curbishley said later. "They have got to make up my mind."

The game drifted from the start, a run and shot well wide by Robbie Blake being the sum total of the opening quarter. With nothing to lose, and figuring they might as well get their money's worth out of Benito Carbone before he and his wages are off-loaded in the summer, City have switched to a 4-3-3 formation to accommodate the little Italian but it was making little difference here.

In fact Charlton should have taken the lead when Mattias Svensson met a John Robinson corner unmarked. The City goalkeeper Gary Walsh, often referred to as a "good shot-stopper" - in other words, a bag of nerves when called upon to do anything else - made a remarkable save from the point-blank header.

Twenty minutes later the crowd were stirred out of their chilly torpor when Robinson picked up a poor Gunnar Halle clearance and crossed low. Jonatan Johansson's glancing header looked to be going in until it was inadvertently stopped by Svensson.

The pace of the game did pick up after the break, though if it had gone any slower it would have ground to a halt.

Carbone was busy but as ever inclined to over-elaborate, Ashley Ward bustled and Stuart McCall did his best to bring order to proceedings before Eoin Jess produced a moment of class, running from the halfway line and curling a right-foot shot around Sasa Ilic and on to the post.

At the other end the promising Scott Parker had just produced a fair 20-yard drive to test Walsh when, unexpectedly, City broke the deadlock. Wayne Jacobs' chipped pass beat the Charlton offside trap but Halle seemed to have lost control when Ilic knocked him to the ground.

The referee Peter Jones, who was closer to the incident, did not react but the linesman did, flagging for a penalty which Blake converted.

Johansson could have equalised within seconds but after Walsh's save there was still time for a party piece from Carbone. Ilic's headed clearance from well outside his area looped invitingly up and Carbone simply sidefooted it back over his head and into the net from 25 yards.

That was enough for Charlton, and Ward might have made it the best result of the season for City when Richard Rufus deflected his shot against the post. "Our standards have been higher than that over the last four months," added Curbishley, ruefully. "We let ourselves down today."

Despite a first win since New Year's Day and only the fourth of the season, one fears for Bradford. There was much talk beforehand of Charlton, who came straight back up after relegation two years ago, being the example for Bradford to follow. On this evidence it is hard to see that happening to a team carrying too many ageing journeymen.

webTitle: United fans lose out as council takes a stand

fields.headline: United fans lose out as council takes a stand
fields.trailText: Sections of Old Trafford will be closed if Manchester United reach the European Cup semi-final after supporters ignored the local council's repeated warnings not to stand during games
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson told Manchester United fans they have only themselves to blame after learning parts of Old Trafford may have to be closed down.

Sections of the ground are likely to be roped off after supporters ignored the local council's repeated warnings not to stand during games. Trafford Borough Council says parts of the West Stand second tier must be closed for United's European Cup semi-final, if they qualify by overhauling Bayern Munich on Wednesday.

Ferguson is angry about the council's stance but also disappointed that fans ignored a series of warnings - including several from himself. "I suppose you have to say that the fans have let themselves down," he said. "It's disappointing for the team but we were warned about it enough times."

"I was at Manchester City for their game against Arsenal on Wednesday and their fans were standing up for the whole game. We're not being treated the same as other clubs but when were we ever treated the same as everyone else?"

Councillor Barry Brotherton said the decision would apply only to European fixtures. He said: "If there is another match at Old Trafford, then because of the standing that took place at the last match we will look to reduce the capacity. Just where or how many has yet to be decided."

David Beckham will be missing yet again today as Manchester United look to close in on their seventh Premiership title in nine years. The England captain, who is suspended from Wednesday's game, will be on the bench against Coventry as Ferguson wants to pick the team that will play in Munich.

David Beckham will be missing yet again today as Manchester United look to close in on their seventh Premiership title in nine years. The England captain, who is suspended from Wednesday's game, will be on the bench against Coventry as Ferguson wants to pick the team that will play in Munich.

webTitle: Livingston carry a torch for the age of enlightenment

fields.headline: Livingston carry a torch for the age of enlightenment
fields.trailText: The Scottish First Division leaders have their eyes set on the Premier League - and the Uefa Cup.
fields.body:
There will be supporters of the non-league club Edinburgh City who will wish ill upon Livingston when they line up against Hibernian in today's Tennent's Scottish Cup semi- final. But they will be about the only "neutrals" to do so.

Though Livingston were founded in 1995, they owe their place in the Scottish Football League to a controversial relocation. Meadowbank Thistle's owner Bill Hunter moved the club west and changed their name as their fans decamped en masse to Edinburgh City vowing never to give Hunter's brave, new creation - Livingston - a second glance.

Fast forward six years. Hunter has long gone, forced to sell to the club for a single pound. And, to all but a few, Livingston now evoke widespread affection.

Were Celtic to defeat Dundee United in tomorrow's other semi-final and Livingston to pull off a shock today, the First Division club would find themselves in next season's Uefa Cup. The main aim, however, is to be in the Scottish Premier League next season. Despite a rough patch a month ago and Ayr United's relentless pursuit, Livingston sit on top of the First Division, their new stadium fit and poised to welcome Premier League opposition.

Their manager Jim Leishman is a larger-than-life character. He has long been known as a scribbler of McGonagall-esque verse. He has had some downs as well as ups since he took Dunfermline into the Premier Division in 1987 and repeated the feat two years later after a season back in the First, and is an ideal front man for the club. Good with the media, charming to visitors, the "bard" of Scottish football is an embracer of people.

Behind the scenes, meanwhile, the club is being moulded into something of a football experiment. The chairman Dominic Keane used to be a director of Celtic. Now playing with his own chemistry set, he is putting long-held beliefs about the game into action.

His desire to effect change has him leading a group of First Division clubs hoping to forge closer links with the SPL, viewed as a more dynamic and astute organisation than the Scottish Football League.

Keane's very language is unconventional. He talks about winning people's trust, about deriving as much satisfaction from the club's youth development programme as he does from the first team's promotion push, about Livingston becoming the envy of not only Scottish clubs but European ones.

"Our watchwords are care, solid foundations, trust and community involvement," says Keane. "With regard to youth, we are having people from all over Scotland wanting to be with us and that is because I think we are trusted. We have already begun work on a youth academy. You need all the components working together; you need the kids, you need the teachers and you need the facilities. Having two out of three won't do.

"It has been too easy to dismiss Scottish players and Scottish kids as not being as good as the players from abroad we see on television. You would be astonished at the quality of young players we have in this country. But you will only short-change them if you don't provide properly for them."

In an unfortunate twist Keane will be quoted in the programme for this afternoon's match saying football is every bit as important to Scotland as its computer hardware and software industry, known as Silicon Glen. Earlier this week the mobile communications company Motorola, one of Silicon Glen's largest employers, warned of a possible 3,000 redundancies. But Keane does not regret the observation.

"Football is our national game. It is our relaxation, our inspiration. It is the most talked-about thing, the most argued-about thing, the most written-about thing."

Doubly ironic, Motorola is the club's shirt sponsor. "When I and my fellow directors took over three years ago, Motorola were the first company to come to us offering support. They have been, and are, a rock. We feel for the company and we feel for the people working for it.

"The football club is at the heart of the community and we feel its pain, worry and anguish and, hopefully, by what we are doing in the First Division and in the Scottish Cup, we can give the community a lift. It's been a hard week. It's not in my nature to be negative and I hope the club can cheer people up." Most neutrals hope so too.

webTitle: Nilsson plays it cool with fiery Scot

fields.headline: Nilsson plays it cool with fiery Scot
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan, the all-screaming, all-dancing thrombosis in the making, has taken on the former Coventry player Roland Nilsson as coach, a man who is as cool as a mountain stream
fields.body:
There seems to be a growing pattern among football managers to appoint a No2 with an emotional make-up that is the opposite of their own.

Thus Liverpool's cerebral Gerard Houllier is able to spend his match days sitting in the dug-out while Phil Thompson does his tap dances in the so-called technical area for 90 minutes and literally acts as his master's voice. And at Old Trafford, it's a red-faced Sir Alex Ferguson who stands banging his watch face in front of the referee while his assistant Steve McClaren quietly makes notes.

Now Gordon Strachan, who on match days at least is an all-screaming, all-dancing thrombosis in the making, has taken on the former Coventry player Roland Nilsson as coach, a man who is as cool as a mountain stream. Chalk and cheese are soul brothers compared to those two.

Nilsson, 37, who clearly doubts that anyone - outside of a doctor armed with strong sedatives and a strait-jacket - could cure Strach in a match-day strop, says calmly: "If I can take the pressure off him, that's great. But if I can't. I can't."

Nilsson, perhaps appropriately, was thinking of taking up a career in insurance in his native Sweden before a surprise call from Strachan a month ago, asking if he would like to help extend the club's 34-year no-claims bonus on their relegation protection policy in the top flight.

He says: "I was coming to the end of my playing career at Helsingborgs and was at a loose end. I felt I had achieved everything that I could in my playing career and was thinking maybe I would like to coach, but Coventry's offer was a complete surprise."

It came out of the Sky Blue, you could say, and though he has yet to be given a job title, it is fair to assume that he spends much of his time working on a Coventry defence that, like any side in relegation trouble, had been letting in too many goals too easily.

No one is better qualified to remedy that than Nilsson, who won 112 Sweden caps, including playing in the team that beat Bulgaria 4-0 to claim third place in the 1994 World Cup in the United States. He also so brilliantly marshalled the defence in the semi-final that year against Brazil that it was only after the sending off of Jonas Thern that the Brazilians secured their 1-0 win.

Ron Atkinson was a massive admirer of his footballing talent, paying £375,000 to secure his services for Sheffield Wednesday in 1989. Atkinson, who described him as The Legend, had moved upstairs as director of football at Coventry when Nilsson signed as a player four years ago, but he had no doubt bored Strachan silly about his defensive talents.

As a coach, he is already proving a lucky charm. Having seen Coventry first lose their match at Tottenham, he has now watched them beat Derby County and Leicester, their first back-to-back wins since August.

One cannot say, of course - and Nilsson certainly would not - that he was responsible for those victories. He says: "When you arrive in a situation like this, you can normally feel that the atmosphere is not right as soon as you walk into the dressing room.

"But I was surprised how good it was here, and after those wins it's even better. The lads are flying and you can see that they are enjoying themselves. John Hartson has been brilliant. The other players are starting to find him the right way and he's not just a big lad. He's got two good feet and, for a big lad, he's quite technical."

Nilsson was denied the excitement of a relegation tussle during his two years as a player at Highfield Road, when the club finished an embarrassingly high 11th and 15th. And though he knows about all the Houdini acts of the past, he does not like to use the R-word, preferring to say that, having signed a two-year contract, he will be there next season "whatever happens".

A career selling endowment policies, however, might have seemed compellingly attractive if he had flicked through the fixture list before agreeing to take the job. After today's game against Manchester United at Old Trafford, Coventry must attempt to spike the Champions League ambitions of Sunderland, Ipswich and Liverpool in successive matches.

His familiarity to the players has, it seems, bred confidence rather than contempt. He says: "If you get a new face in, it can do more harm than good. But because I've been here before, the players know me and what I stand for."

They also know what he will not stand for, and that is sloppy defending. "When you are not scoring enough goals, it is important to minimise the mistakes because one bad error can cost you the game. It's a very tough run in, but we know we can stay up if we can keep doing what we've been doing in the past two games."

Coventry have looked adrift for much of the season. But the importance of the successes against Derby and Leicester is that they have put the club within one win of overtaking Middlesbrough. The Teesside club took an even more dramatic step by bringing in Terry Venables as team manager and giving Bryan Robson a more general role.

Should Coventry pull off another unlikely win today, however - and with United more focused on next week's Champions League quarter-final against Bayern Munich, who knows? - Venables could find himself back in the bottom three.

fields.headline: Linesman's call has Francis fuming
fields.trailText: Fulham were denied the pleasure of a mathematically assured place in the Premiership as Bolton collected a point, but a draw at Huddersfield today will dispense with that particular formality.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
Fulham's staff, watching from the aptly named "Party Suite", were denied the pleasure of a mathematically assured place in the Premiership as Bolton collected a point last night, but a draw at Huddersfield today will dispense with that particular formality.

Two of the crop of clubs below Fulham currently doing their best to earn the right not to join them at least served up a contest which made up in excitement and endeavour what it lacked in quality. Four explosive minutes early in the second half saw Bolton fight back from a first-half deficit to take the lead, only to lose it immediately afterwards.

An angry Birmingham manager Trevor Francis disputed Bolton's second goal. "I have seen the replays and spoken with the TV people and they say it was definitely not a goal," he said.

"I don't attach any blame to the referee, it was his assistant who quickly raised his flag and you cannot do that as hastily as he did unless you are absolutely sure."

The Bolton manager Sam Allardyce said: "We had a great chance to put more pressure on Blackburn and we've let them off the hook. It's disappointing because it has been in our hands for such a long time."

Indeed, the real winners of the evening were Bolton's neighbours, who can move five points clear in the second automatic promotion place should they win at Stockport this afternoon.

Whether last night's participants have the mental or physical acumen to regroup for the play-offs after their respective recent slumps remains to be seen. Francis's side started the encounter suggesting they are the better bet to advance via post-season play, taking a deserved lead after 14 minutes with Martin O'Connor's superbly struck shot.

But Bolton then began to exert control and scored twice in four minutes early in the second half, first with Gudni Bergsson looping his shot - which actually came off his shoulder - over Ian Bennett.

There was an equal measure of fortune in Bolton's second goal, plundered by their substitute Dean Holdsworth. His header, from Michael Rickett's deep cross, struck the underside of the bar but was judged to have crossed the line.

Bolton's poor defending was highlighted again within minutes, this time by Marcelo who appeared at the far post to connect with Jon McCarthy's pass and place the ball beyond Matt Clarke's despairing dive.

fields.headline: The Secret Society debate
fields.trailText: The government's failure to amend the antiquated British secrecy laws came under fire at the RSA fringe debate 'Secret Society', held in association with The Observer and Prospect magazine.
fields.body:
The government's failure to amend the antiquated British secrecy laws came under fire at the RSA fringe debate 'Secret Society', held in association with The Observer and Prospect magazine.

The panel argued that the lack of a public interest defence for whistleblowers - which had been Labour's grounds for opposing the official secrecy legislation while in opposition - had a corrosive effect on good governance, democracy and public trust.

With David Shayler's trial, due to begin on April 24th, John Wadham, the Director of the Liberty pressure group and Shayler's lawyer, said that the trial would be a defining moment for those who believed that the Official Secrets Act was incompatible with the Human Rights Act.

Wadham argued that the issue of freedom of information was vital to demonstrating whether voting for a political party made any difference. While political parties in opposition promoted reform, every government had been wedded to maintaining as much secrecy as possible - as with Labour doing nothing to change the official secrets act. While the data protection act had changed the relationship between individuals and those who held files on them, it included double and triple layers of exemptions on national security grounds.

Over two million security service files had been exempted, not because the content of the files could be shown to be damaging, but because the government continued to inhabit an 'Alice in Wonderland' world where it was considered damaging to disclose whether or not the files existed at all.

Historian David Vincent of Keele University argued that the Labour government had been 'wrestling with its own best self" on the secrecy issue. The government's own 1997 White Paper had marked a genuinely historic attempt to come to terms with the history of official secrecy, and had marked a major breakthrough in three central areas:

Whereas Britain had traditionally measured its freedom against the tyranny of its neighbours, the white paper accepted that Britain had ceased to be the teacher and had become the pupil, needing to follow rather than to lead other democracies. The white paper had also signalled that the era of unwritten control had to come to an end - a significant shift for a polity which had pioneered 'double secrecy', being secretive about the existence of secrecy itself.

The white paper accepted the need to talk about secrecy and to make distinctions based on a test of harm. And it recognised the erosion of the 'honourable secrecy' tradition - where those in power operated with restraint and a growing electorate accepted the right of office holders to make decisions. The post-Suez decline in faith in the integrity and competence of government had accelerated and made this untenable - only a refusal to trust could enable a culture of trust to be re-established.

But Vincent argued that the government had missed its opportunity to deliver the reform which the white paper promised. A belief that the electorate did not care, the stubborn power of tradition and the tendency to keep rules as general as possible to provide catch-all had diluted reform heavily.

Robert McCrum, Literary Editor of The Observer, joined criticism of a 'parody of a freedom of information act'. He had written a novel in the early nineteen-eighties, based on the ABC trial, seeking to capture the paranoid climate of those times. But what was striking was how little had changed in this debate: why did democracy require so much secrecy and that the governed be subordinate to the governed? McCrum argued that the issue was of profound importance to democratic politics, because 'secrecy is a virus which corrupts the body politic'.

Nigel West, the writer and former Conservative MP, argued that the government's refusal to participate in the debate demonstrated that they were frightened of the truth. The deep-rooted culture of British secrecy failed to protect vital secrecy adequately - for example, in cases of informants in terrorism cases - because it did so much to protect political embarassment and incompetenct administration.

West regarded the Labour government's record as hypocritical, especially in the continued use of Public Interest Immunity Certificates, which went to the heart of justice and of an individuals right to defend themselves. West argued that it was difficult to recognise the Robin Cook who had performed so impressively in criticising the government over the Scott Report and the Matrix-Churchill case, or to reconcile Jack Straw's positions in opposition with his actions in power.

The debate, chaired by broadcaster Sheena MacDonald, included floor contributions from participants in many recent cases - including David Shayler, Nigel Wylde (who had been involved in the Tony Geraghty case), and Martin Bright of The Observer, who criticised the government's failure to send any representative to defend their actions.

While the government was heavily criticised, the fundamental importance of the Human Rights Act as being a catalyst for reform was recognised while the instability of the current system meant that further reform would prove inevitable. David Vincent argued that backing away from reform could prove highly damaging to a second Labour term - a failure to rebuild a relationship of trust with citizens would scupper effective progressive governance. Yet the blueprint for effective reform had been set out by the government itself before losing their nerve on this issue.

A central issue to judging the effectiveness of reform was whether it shifted the burden of proof - so that the onus was on government to show why it would be necessary to withhold specific pieces of information, rather than requiring those seeking information to make a case for obtaining it.

Central areas of discussion included the dangers of the security services expanding their remit into the criminal justice system without clear rules and of the nature of oversight. John Wadham argued that Tom King, having been defence secretary and Northern Ireland secretary, had been the wrong choice to head the oversight committee and that his successor should not be somebody so closely associated with the system. Nigel West argued that resources for oversight were deeply inadequate.

Reform would also depend on shifting the issue of freedom of information from the political margins to the mainstream. Polls showed large majorities in favour of reform but this had not been channelled into an effective coalition to bring about political pressure for reform, without which power-holders were unlikely to cede ground easily.

The debate, chaired by broadcaster Sheena MacDonald, included floor contributions from participants in many recent cases - including David Shayler, Nigel Wylde (who had been involved in the Tony Geraghty case), and Martin Bright of The Observer, who criticised the government's failure to send any representative to defend their actions. While the government was heavily criticised, the fundamental importance of the Human Rights Act as being a catalyst for reform was recognised while the instability of the current system meant that further reform would prove inevitable. David Vincent argued that backing away from reform could prove highly damaging to a second Labour term - a failure to rebuild a relationship of trust with citizens would scupper effective progressive governance. Yet the blueprint for effective reform had been set out by the government itself before losing their nerve on this issue. A central issue to judging the effectiveness of reform was whether it shifted the burden of proof - so that the onus was on government to show why it would be necessary to withhold specific pieces of information, rather than requiring those seeking information to make a case for obtaining it. Central areas of discussion included the dangers of the security services expanding their remit into the criminal justice system without clear rules and of the nature of oversight. John Wadham argued that Tom King, having been defence secretary and Northern Ireland secretary, had been the wrong choice to head the oversight committee and that his successor should not be somebody so closely associated with the system. Nigel West argued that resources for oversight were deeply inadequate. Reform would also depend on shifting the issue of freedom of information from the political margins to the mainstream. Polls showed large majorities in favour of reform but this had not been channelled into an effective coalition to bring about political pressure for reform, without which power-holders were unlikely to cede ground easily.

fields.headline: St Matthew Passion
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
For those who love Bach, Easter means the St Matthew Passion. Surprisingly, this was the first time the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and its sister choir have presented the work in London; given the reputation of these performers and the popularity of the work, it was hardly unexpected that the concert would sell out. But, safe bet though it may be, the work still presents a challenge: how can one make people really listen to such a familiar piece, make them experience something new?

Roger Norrington knows how. The conductor was no domineering physical presence; he never even stood up. But his relationship with the musicians worked two ways: he trusted them to perform without being spoon-fed, giving minimal, if any, direction; they in turn accepted that the indications he did give were worth an unquestioning response. Any nuances his gestures described were immediately audible in the music.

Norrington conducted the opening chorus with a slow beat, half the usual speed, encouraging his players to shape the music into seamless lines. A conductor renowned for his fast tempos, he looked remarkably as though he were directing in slow motion.

While Norrington paced this dramatically convincing reading, pushing onward yet taking time when it counted, Mark Padmore vocalised it. His performance as the Evangelist was expressive, at times conspiratorial, and intensely moving. Andrew Foster-Williams was a young but authoritative Jesus. Other solos were taken, as was the practice in Bach's day, by members of the choir, the arias shared with consistently good results between nine of them. The rich voices of mezzo Frances Bourne and bass Richard Burkhard, alongside the cleaner tones of mezzo Alexandra Gibson and tenor Andrew Carwood, brought a variety of timbres but a similar level of commitment.

Many of the instrumentalists also made individual contributions. Susan Sheppard (cello) and Paul Nicholson (chamber organ) carried the recitatives, while Sarah Cunningham tackled the viola da gamba pieces heroically. Alison Bury's springy violin solo energised Judas's aria, warmly sung by Burkhard. The choir, ranged behind them, produced an intense wall of sound. Bringing the four ripieno singers around to the front ensured that the important chorales of the first part did not fade into the background. No detail eluded Norrington, and every listener will have heard something new in this Passion.

fields.headline: Politics you can dance to
fields.standfirst:
Antibalas
Band on the Wall, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Antibalas
Band on the Wall, Manchester
***
fields.body:
Antibalas hail from Brooklyn, and their mission is to continue the pioneering work of Nigerian musical agitator Fela Anikulapo Kuti. They do this by pumping out energetic Afrobeat-style funk and occasionally talking to us about how bad the world is. The band's latest album, Liberation Afrobeat Volume 1, is a hard-edged proposition, simmering with urban tribal rhythms and diatribes against the American government. So it's slightly surprising to discover that in concert Antibalas are a party band, best enjoyed when dancing with your eyes closed and a smile on your face.

The musicians in the rhythm section - drums, bass, guitar and assorted percussion - have a relatively easy task: they simply start playing a groove and keep playing it until it's time for a round of applause. Chord changes do not occur during songs but between them, an approach that induces compulsive dancing. The meat of the band's sound is provided by the four-piece horn section, which shrieks and hollers through various solo passages and tightly knitted ensemble sections. On top of this comes a layer of vocals, consisting in the main of rugged African-style chanting, which often makes the hairs on the back of your neck stand on end.

The band's explicit political agenda is more problematic. There is no law stating that subversive music must sound angry - if there were, Bob Marley and Burning Spear would not have the reputations they do. However, Antibalas's grooves are so blatantly hedonistic that the political message feels awkwardly grafted on. Additionally, frontman Martin Balas is a less than rousing orator, and his wake-up calls contain all the fire and brimstone of a weather forecast. He talks to us about the American presidential elections being hijacked by political coups, the prevalence of internet pornography, and the existence in the world of starving children. Then he asks us to put our hands in the air and chant: "Yeah, yeah." Might it not be a more energising act for us all to shout "No, no"?

If Antibalas genuinely want to use their party to change the world then they need to find a more arresting way of doing it. Otherwise they could consider just handing out leaflets at the start of the show and getting on with the music.

 At the Jazz Cafe, London NW1 (020-7344 0044), tonight.

Callers will be asked for their name and address, and to give their five fund choices which will make up your portfolio.

Entrants must also predict the closing level of the FTSE 100 index on April 30, 2002, which will be used only in the event of two or more entrants tying in first place.

Individual entries must select five funds for their portfolio and a tie-break number. fields.trailText: If you pick the best funds, you could be celebrating with a cheque or a holiday - and, even if you lose, a children's charity gains, writes Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Fancy making a small fortune on the stock market without having to invest a penny? Pick the fastest rising investment funds over the next 12 months in our fantasy league and you could be walking away with a cheque for £10,000 - and help make £100,000 for Barnardo's, the UK's largest children's charity.

Is the UK stock market about to bounce after its recent worrying falls, or should you be picking defensive bond funds to protect your fantasy portfolio? Will technology be the best recovery bet after the price collapses following the dot.com blowout? Or will Japan be the surprise star in world markets over the next 12 months? Enter the Guardian/Barnardo's Investment Challenge and you will be able to play the City at its own game.

All you have to do is to pick five funds from the list of unit trusts and investment trusts below, which you believe will grow most rapidly over the 12 months from May 1, 2001 to April 30, 2002.

If on April 30 your portfolio has soared to the top of the league, you will be walking off with the top prize, while the runner up will enjoy a luxury tropical holiday for two. In the event of a tie, the winner will be the entrant who most accurately predicted the closing level of the FTSE 100 index on April 30, 2002.

Last year's £10,000 winner in the Investment Challenge, Michael Barron from Carlisle, saw his selection of funds rise in value by nearly 10% during 2000, a remarkable achievement during one of the worst years for stock market investment in decades.

But the real winner is Barnardo's. In a unique tie-up with the biggest names in the investment business, the Investment Challenge is aiming to raise £100,000 for children's charity Barnardo's.

Every unit trust and investment trust listed below has generously pledged to invest £50 per month into their fund over a period of three years, which will be donated to Barnardo's crucial childcare projects.

The Guardian/Barnardo's Investment Challenge opens for entry this week; all you have to do is ring 0906-753-4414 and follow the instructions given. But keep this page handy - you will be asked to give your selections from the funds numbered below. Calls will be charged at a premium rate of 75p per minute, with the income used to cover administration costs only. Any surplus will be donated to Barnardo's. There is no stake required to enter, and each individual can make up to five entries.
