webTitle: Power - but can you wait for glory?

fields.headline: Power - but can you wait for glory?
fields.standfirst: As German giant e.on bids for Powergen, Rupert Jones asks if it's worth banking on the deal
fields.trailText: After enduring a rollercoaster couple of years, many of the 700,000 investors holding shares in Powergen will probably welcome this week's £7.65 a share offer for the company as a pretty fair deal.
fields.body:
After enduring a rollercoaster couple of years, many of the 700,000 investors holding shares in Powergen will probably welcome this week's £7.65 a share offer for the company as a pretty fair deal.

German utility giant e.on has unveiled an agreed bid for Powergen, the electricity generator and supplier privatised by the government in 1991. It would see the typical small investor receive a cheque for around £1,032 in return for their average holding of 135 shares.

That's pretty good going when you consider 135 Powergen shares were worth only £820 in mid-January, and just £443 at one point in March last year. Someone who invested back in 1991 would have paid £236 for 135 shares.

But while most commentators were agreed that £7.65, paid in cash, is a fair price, the downside is that you will have to wait a whole year to get your money, and approval for the deal is by no means a certainty.

Jobs & Money canvassed the views of two experts. One said Powergen shareholders were getting a very good deal but, faced with waiting until next spring for what was only a likely rather than a definite payout, some may want to consider selling if the share price nudges up very close to the offer price.

Our other expert said that, while more cautious investors will probably do best to stick with the stock, for more active investors there is definitely an argument for selling and taking the profits following its strong run over the past year.

It was almost exactly 10 years ago that 60% of Powergen (created from the privatisation of the Central Electricity Generating Board) was sold to the public. Under the share offer the minimum investment was £200 which equated to 114 shares. Around 1.5m people took the plunge and signed up. In February 1995 the government sold its remaining 40% stake in Powergen. The offer price then was £5.12, payable in three instalments.

The company now has 552,000 shareholders who own between one and 250 shares, while another 145,000 individuals hold more than this number.

On Monday, after almost three months of talks, e.on unveiled its £9.6bn agreed bid for the company. The offer represents an 8.4% premium to Powergen's closing price of £7.06 on Friday April 6, and a 25.8% premium over January 16, the last trading day before the two companies confirmed they were in talks, when it closed at £6.08.

The deal will require the consent of regulators in both the UK and America, and provided they give the go-ahead it is expected to be completed in the spring of next year. Once approval is given e.on will launch its formal offer for Powergen, and at that point shareholders will have the choice of accepting or rejecting the share offer. If the vast majority (probably 95%-plus) of people accept, e.on will be entitled to compulsorily purchase the shares of the small minority who say no.

The UK group's board are urging shareholders to back the bid, saying it is "a good deal" for them, employees and customers.

Powergen says those investors worried about the capital gains tax (CGT) implications will be able to receive their payment in the form of loan notes - a sort of IOU that allows you to take your cash at a later stage. Loan notes are often used where people are worried that a payment or windfall will exceed the annual CGT allowance (currently £7,500).

Powergen's share price has gyrated wildly over the past two years or so. At the start of 1999 it topped £9 but within months it ended up one of the Footsie's biggest fallers, plunging 44% that year. It tumbled to a low of £3.28 last March but over the past 12 months has staged a remarkable comeback, outperforming the FTSE All-Share index by a staggering 98.7%.

So what do the experts say? Simon Cawdery at Barclays Stockbrokers reckons Powergen investors are "getting a damn good deal". However, he adds that the takeover is not done and dusted by any means. He points out that Powergen will pay a dividend of about 5% to its shareholders in the interim, which he says will compensate them for having to wait a year to get their money.

However, he reckons that if the shares get very close to the offer price over the next couple of months and hit around £7.30, "you are probably better-off selling those shares in the market". But he adds that for stock market novices who bought the shares at privatisation, holding them until the deal is approved means you don't have to pay any sharedealing fees, which you would of course have to fork out if you sell now.

At NatWest Stockbrokers, Jeremy Batstone says small investors holding Powergen will be "pretty chuffed" about its performance over the past 12 months, during which it has been seen as a relatively safe haven in a storm. He also points out that there are regulatory hurdles to overcome, and says the £7.65 a share offer was slightly below its original expectations of around £8.20 a share.

While NatWest Stockbrokers' official house view of the share is that they are a "hold," Mr Batstone says he would not have a problem with people selling now and banking their profits. It all comes down to your attitude to risk, he adds. If you're relatively risk-averse there is definitely an argument for sitting on the stock and awaiting developments. If you're a more active investor it is very tempting to take the money now.

Plus point: e.on chairman Ulrich Hartmann's bid could mean windfalls - but not yet

But while most commentators were agreed that £7.65, paid in cash, is a fair price, the downside is that you will have to wait a whole year to get your money, and approval for the deal is by no means a certainty. Jobs & Money canvassed the views of two experts. One said Powergen shareholders were getting a very good deal but, faced with waiting until next spring for what was only a likely rather than a definite payout, some may want to consider selling if the share price nudges up very close to the offer price. Our other expert said that, while more cautious investors will probably do best to stick with the stock, for more active investors there is definitely an argument for selling and taking the profits following its strong run over the past year. It was almost exactly 10 years ago that 60% of Powergen (created from the privatisation of the Central Electricity Generating Board) was sold to the public. Under the share offer the minimum investment was £200 which equated to 114 shares. Around 1.5m people took the plunge and signed up. In February 1995 the government sold its remaining 40% stake in Powergen. The offer price then was £5.12, payable in three instalments. The company now has 552,000 shareholders who own between one and 250 shares, while another 145,000 individuals hold more than this number. On Monday, after almost three months of talks, e.on unveiled its £9.6bn agreed bid for the company. The offer represents an 8.4% premium to Powergen's closing price of £7.06 on Friday April 6, and a 25.8% premium over January 16, the last trading day before the two companies confirmed they were in talks, when it closed at £6.08. The deal will require the consent of regulators in both the UK and America, and provided they give the go-ahead it is expected to be completed in the spring of next year. Once approval is given e.on will launch its formal offer for Powergen, and at that point shareholders will have the choice of accepting or rejecting the share offer. If the vast majority (probably 95%-plus) of people accept, e.on will be entitled to compulsorily purchase the shares of the small minority who say no. The UK group's board are urging shareholders to back the bid, saying it is "a good deal" for them, employees and customers. Powergen says those investors worried about the capital gains tax (CGT) implications will be able to receive their payment in the form of loan notes - a sort of IOU that allows you to take your cash at a later stage. Loan notes are often used where people are worried that a payment or windfall will exceed the annual CGT allowance (currently £7,500). Powergen's share price has gyrated wildly over the past two years or so. At the start of 1999 it topped £9 but within months it ended up one of the Footsie's biggest fallers, plunging 44% that year. It tumbled to a low of £3.28 last March but over the past 12 months has staged a remarkable comeback, outperforming the FTSE All-Share index by a staggering 98.7%. So what do the experts say? Simon Cawdery at Barclays Stockbrokers reckons Powergen investors are "getting a damn good deal". However, he adds that the takeover is not done and dusted by any means. He points out that Powergen will pay a dividend of about 5% to its shareholders in the interim, which he says will compensate them for having to wait a year to get their money. However, he reckons that if the shares get very close to the offer price over the next couple of months and hit around £7.30, "you are probably better-off selling those shares in the market". But he adds that for stock market novices who bought the shares at privatisation, holding them until the deal is approved means you don't have to pay any sharedealing fees, which you would of course have to fork out if you sell now. At NatWest Stockbrokers, Jeremy Batstone says small investors holding Powergen will be "pretty chuffed" about its performance over the past 12 months, during which it has been seen as a relatively safe haven in a storm. He also points out that there are regulatory hurdles to overcome, and says the £7.65 a share offer was slightly below its original expectations of around £8.20 a share. While NatWest Stockbrokers' official house view of the share is that they are a "hold," Mr Batstone says he would not have a problem with people selling now and banking their profits. It all comes down to your attitude to risk, he adds. If you're relatively risk-averse there is definitely an argument for sitting on the stock and awaiting developments. If you're a more active investor it is very tempting to take the money now. Plus point: e.on chairman Ulrich Hartmann's bid could mean windfalls - but not yet

fields.headline: Credit union talks stall
fields.standfirst: Camberwell accounts were frozen in August but there is still no end in sight, says Phillip Inman
fields.trailText: Camberwell accounts were frozen in August but there is still no end in sight, says Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
One of the country's largest community based credit unions faces closure or takeover after a financial crisis that has prevented savers from withdrawing their cash for eight months.

The Camberwell Credit Union in south London, which has more than 2,500 members, was effectively frozen last August following an investigation that discovered mismanagement and a lack of controls to protect its assets.

Efforts to revive the business, which offers savings and loans to low income groups, have so far failed to satisfy the regulator, the Financial Services Authority.

But if plans for a takeover by a neighbouring credit union, which failed at the first try in December, or a full recovery of outstanding loans are not achieved, savers face the prospect of losing up to 15% of their capital.

The problems are a blow to the government, which wants credit unions to be a central plank of its plans to protect low income groups from loan sharks and finance companies that offer crippling interest rates. Chancellor Gordon Brown believes credit unions could do more than offer savings and loans and are well placed to promote a range of banking services to local community groups in hard pressed areas of the country.

The FSA is consulting with credit unions, banks and other interested parties about regulations due to take effect next year that will strengthen regulations and offer credit union members greater protection.

At the moment credit unions can count on 300,000 members and £180m of assets. They are run largely by volunteers and rely on the active involvement of members to maintain probity.

They must purchase insurance to protect members from fraud and embezzlement. However, shortfalls arising from mismanagement or incompetence are not covered.

The new regulations will protect credit union members for the first time. They will get the first £2,000 of their money back in full and 90% of the next £31,000, bettering the current arrangement for bank customers, who can recover 90% of the first £18,000. FSA chairman Howard Davies said last December: "We aim to develop a practical and proportionate regulatory system for credit unions which should meet the needs of the credit union movement and its members.

"We are confident these proposals will improve consumer confidence in the financial soundness of credit unions, and that this will help to provide the positive environment credit unions need in order to grow and to pursue their social objectives."

The rules are likely to come too late for the Camberwell members when they come into force in summer 2002.

Peter Bussey, a director of the Camberwell credit union, said it was in a position to repay savers 63% of their cash at the moment and expected to recover 85%-90% when all loans had been recalled.

A credit union running normally would expect to have 70% of its assets out on loan and only 30% in the bank. Despite already exceeding these levels, negotiations designed to reopen the business, between the union and the FSA have stalled.

fields.headline: Artists formally known for prints
fields.standfirst: They're original but not unique: Stewart Dalby reports on a sale of affordable pictures
fields.trailText: They're original but not unique: Stewart Dalby reports on a sale of affordable pictures.
fields.body:
As the London Original Print Fair approaches its 16th consecutive year, it can once again claim to be the longest-running event of its kind. With one possible exception it is the largest showcase of original prints to be presented in the world, its one possible rival being a similar event which takes place in New York, usually around November.

The LOPF is nevertheless the largest in the UK and Europe and 26 dealers will show works, which will attract collectors and curators from everywhere. The artists on show, and for sale, range from Rembrandt onward and include Picasso, Degas and Chagall through to British greats such as Lucian Freud, David Hockney and Bridget Riley. Contemporary print-makers in the fair include Gillian Ayres, Terry Frost, Julian Opie, John Bellamy and Estelle Thompson.

A major claim made for prints is their affordability. Frankie Rossi at the Purdy Hicks gallery says: "There is a surprisingly widespread misapprehension that prints are reproductions. They are not, of course."

There are such things as monoprints, and they can confuse the issue, but print collectors are of course buying pictures which mostly do not come singly, as with paintings, but in editions. Dealer Alan Cristea puts it succinctly when he says: "Prints are original but not unique works of art."

Printmaking developed at first to give artists such as Rembrandt a wider currency among a greater public. It started as the art of producing multiple images from an engraved plate. Many Old Masters, such as Rembrandt, were etchers on copper plate or wood. Aquatints are variants of etching. There are also linocuts.

At the end of the 18th-century the process of lithography was invented - in 1798 by Alois Senefelder in Austria - although the methods were not perfected until much later. Since then, other ways of making prints such as silkscreen, plate lithography, photography, photocopy and - most recently - the computer printing process have been invented.

Affordability will be a theme pursued in the speech by Alistair Hicks at the Fair. He is responsible for collecting "Works on Paper" for Deutsche Bank. These include photographs and drawings but also many prints. Deutsche Bank has some 40,000 works on paper, including some 3,000 in the UK.

Alistair Hicks says: "Deutsche Bank decided it wanted to buy works of art, not as an investment but to support artists and to put them on the walls of its offices for the benefit of its staff. Prints are ideally suited." He collects only living artists, so many at the fair will be out side his scope, but he will be looking at prints starting at around £200 for a Tom Hammick monoprint to several thousand for a Lucian Freud.

Alan Cristea also dislikes the idea of prints as investments. "In a sense I am outside buying for investment because most of the pieces I will be offering are new work. I am a publisher rather than a dealer," he says.

He will have on offer Howard Hodgkin in sets of 50 from around £2,000 to £4,500 each. The American Jim Dine's pieces will be on sale at $2,000 to $5,000, while Julian Opie's works are expected to fetch £1,200 to £2,000 each.

Since these are new they will not have appreciated in value. But Cristea adds: "If prices had not gone up since I started 25 years ago, then I would presumably not still be in business." He also has Picasso prints with prices from £7,500 to £90,000, and they have certainly risen.

As with all art, prices have varied according to fashion. Christopher Mendez, who specialises in Old Masters, has a Giovanni Piranesi (1770 to 1778) etching for £1,500 and a Canaletto for £3,000. He says: "If I thought the Canaletto would sell for £4,000 next year I would hang on to it. But prices here rise steadily. You would not see a dramatic change in identity as for Lucian Freud, say."

Marlborough Graphics is offering some Freuds. Nicola Togneri at the gallery claims prices for Lucian Freud's work have exploded in recent years. She says: "Look at one piece, 'The Garden', the view from his Holland Park apartment. When it was first offered in 1999 it was priced at £12,000, now it is expected to fetch £45,000."

The London Original Print Fair will be at the Royal Academy of Arts from April 26 to 29, tel: 020-7300-5959. For information from dealers, contact: Cawdell Douglas, 020-7439-2822; Christopher Mendez, 020-7253-9699; Alan Cristea Gallery, 020-7439-1866; Marlborough Graphics, 020-7629-5161, Purdy Hicks 020-7401-9229.

fields.headline: Rokia Traore charms again
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Rokia Traore may be the finest new female singer in Africa, but she's had a rough time performing in Britain. Last year she made a triumphant debut at the Barbican, but only as the opening act for the Orchestre National de Barbes. She missed her slot on the main stage at the Womad festival because she arrived late. Now, rewarded at last with a major headlining concert, she must have been astonished to find that the hall was not full - Cuba's best-known female singer Omara Portuondo was performing across town at the Royal Festival Hall. If that was unfortunate, so was the bizarre choice of opening act.

Kimmo Pohjonen is not the sort of performer you would expect at an African show. He's an accordion player from Finland, and although his use of traditional styles in his playing ensures that he is branded with the catch-all "world music" tag, he is really more of an avant-garde performance artist with echoes of Devo and mid-period Pink Floyd. Using a box of electronic gadgets, he sat alone on the stage orchestrating noises. The instrumental work was impressive, veering from the lyrical to the frantic, but he was at his worst when he put the accordion down to make vocal noises, which he sampled and played back, adding effects such as the sound of pounding waves. Some passages were excellent, others indulgent.

His infuriating but patchily brilliant set was not an easy act for the charming Rokia Traore to follow, but she proved once again why she stands out even in Mali, that land of musical celebrities. She came on like a hip folk-singer who just happened to have walked into an African village, wearing hot-pants and a long white robe and carrying a guitar. She began playing solo, matching her delicate vocals with gently sturdy acoustic guitar work, then brought on the village band, playing those ancient, rousing instruments, the lute-like n'goni, the calabash percussion and the giant African xylophone, the balafon.

International success has had its effect. Her performance was slicker than in the past, and she even spoke some English, greeting the late-night crowd with "Good afternoon", before explaining some of her Malian fables. But her gentle, n'goni-backed ballads were fine as ever, and so was the wild and lengthy finale in which she threw off her shoes to dance across the stage, arms and legs flying. Her band cheerfully broke into an extended, percussive series of dance riffs and solos, sounding as if they wanted to keep playing all night.

webTitle: Few set out on road to ethics

fields.headline: Few set out on road to ethics
fields.standfirst: Despite activists' clamour, key pension funds have yet to move towards socially responsible investment. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: Despite activists' clamour, key pension funds have yet to move towards socially responsible investment. Tony Levene reports.
fields.body:
Most of Britain's biggest pension funds have proclaimed that they are taking on board ethical issues, amid the continuing success of protesters who have targeted the financial backers of Huntingdon Life Sciences.

But in a report due to be published later this month, campaign group Friends of the Earth will reveal that few of these top pension funds have so far made concrete moves towards social responsible investment (SRI) - the blanket term for environmental and ethical investment.

Since last July, pension funds have been obliged to give members a "statement of investment practice". This tells scheme members of the fund's SRI attitudes, and whether they have a policy - or not - of screening out shares in "dirty" companies which pollute, have a bad record on human rights, or are in industries such as tobacco or pornography which are seen by many as morally reprehensible.

From next July, pension funds will also help in the shape of FTSE4Good, a new index which will only include UK companies which meet SRI criteria.

Many of the funds have seen the way the SRI winds are blowing. Last Thursday demonstrators waved placards urging mining group Rio Tinto to "Put Principles Before Profits" at its annual general meeting.

Mirrar aboriginal people and supporters distributed leaflets opposing the Jabiluka uranium mining project in northern Australia.

"We need a guarantee that this project will not go ahead... community opposition is not going to go away. They [Rio] assert they are a corporate responsible citizen, we want to see some evidence," says Jacqui Katona, spokeswoman for the Mirrar.

But instead of the protesters being ignored or thrown out, Rio Tinto did at least re spond to concerns. It said the project could not go ahead legally without the consent of traditional land owners.

Whatever fund managers may think of the Mirrar protest, one factor is uppermost in their minds - the underperformance of Rio Tinto shares this year.

It is not the only company under attack from SRI activists who increasingly "engage" with companies to bring about change rather than simply selling the shares.

FoE has spent £30,000 on shares in construction group Balfour Beatty which is leading the consortium hoping to build the controversial Ilisu dam in Turkey.

It has put down a resolution for next month's annual meeting calling on Balfour Beatty to recognise the World Commission on Dams report which is critical of the Turkish project.

FoE's Tony Juniper says: "This is a significant step forward to show big business how serious we are in wanting to reform corporations. Balfour Beatty should put the planet on its bottom line. It's about changing a company's culture."

Change could come fast. Morley Fund Management, owned by insurance giant CGNU and controlling assets worth around £100bn - around 2.5% of the UK stock market's total value - says it will vote against FTSE 100 company annual accounts unless firms include an environmental report. So far only 37 do this although a further 21 say they intend to start doing so.

Other fund managers are likely to follow this lead as pension fund trustees put on pressure.

From July, the FTSE4Good index series will allow investors to see which All Share Index constituents pass SRI tests. Besides the UK index, other FTSE4Good benchmarks will take in Europe, the US and the world.

The index will also offer new facilities for ethical tracker funds - those currently run by Legal & General and NPI suffer from the lack of a widely accepted index.

FTSE will announce which companies are in and which are out every six months. Except for total "no-no" sectors such as tobacco, armaments and animal testing for cosmetics, the object is to be inclusive - unlike the narrowly based rival Dow Jones Sustainability indices which rejects around nine in 10 firms.

FTSE wants to encourage companies to qualify - on day one around 60% of major companies will be included. The baseline will be good practice backed by measurable environmental performance. "Hurdles" for entry will be increased over time - and companies in high environmental impact industries such as mining or agriculture will have to conform to higher benchmarks.

But FTSE realises it has a potential hot potato on its hands. "We don't expect activists to abseil our office block. But we do expect controversy," FTSE says. "Besides pressure groups, the companies themselves could complain if they are excluded. We shall have transparent rules and firms will be allowed to challenge decisions."

Other potential problems include:

 What to do with one-off events such as a major environmental disaster.

 Criteria for throwing companies out of the index - firms may argue they are being treated more harshly than others.

 Takeovers - will there be a pain threshold based on the proportion of the "dirty" business in the new entity or will the index continue to recognise good management?

 Targeted companies - some firms have been spotlighted by activists when rivals are ignored even though they might be worse.

 Investors will be able to compare the performance of the new index against the market as a whole. But there are no plans for a FTSE4Bad index.

But in a report due to be published later this month, campaign group Friends of the Earth will reveal that few of these top pension funds have so far made concrete moves towards social responsible investment (SRI) - the blanket term for environmental and ethical investment. Since last July, pension funds have been obliged to give members a "statement of investment practice". This tells scheme members of the fund's SRI attitudes, and whether they have a policy - or not - of screening out shares in "dirty" companies which pollute, have a bad record on human rights, or are in industries such as tobacco or pornography which are seen by many as morally reprehensible. From next July, pension funds will also help in the shape of FTSE4Good, a new index which will only include UK companies which meet SRI criteria. Many of the funds have seen the way the SRI winds are blowing. Last Thursday demonstrators waved placards urging mining group Rio Tinto to "Put Principles Before Profits" at its annual general meeting. Mirrar aboriginal people and supporters distributed leaflets opposing the Jabiluka uranium mining project in northern Australia. "We need a guarantee that this project will not go ahead... community opposition is not going to go away. They [Rio] assert they are a corporate responsible citizen, we want to see some evidence," says Jacqui Katona, spokeswoman for the Mirrar. But instead of the protesters being ignored or thrown out, Rio Tinto did at least re spond to concerns. It said the project could not go ahead legally without the consent of traditional land owners. Whatever fund managers may think of the Mirrar protest, one factor is uppermost in their minds - the underperformance of Rio Tinto shares this year. It is not the only company under attack from SRI activists who increasingly "engage" with companies to bring about change rather than simply selling the shares. FoE has spent £30,000 on shares in construction group Balfour Beatty which is leading the consortium hoping to build the controversial Ilisu dam in Turkey. It has put down a resolution for next month's annual meeting calling on Balfour Beatty to recognise the World Commission on Dams report which is critical of the Turkish project. FoE's Tony Juniper says: "This is a significant step forward to show big business how serious we are in wanting to reform corporations. Balfour Beatty should put the planet on its bottom line. It's about changing a company's culture." Change could come fast. Morley Fund Management, owned by insurance giant CGNU and controlling assets worth around £100bn - around 2.5% of the UK stock market's total value - says it will vote against FTSE 100 company annual accounts unless firms include an environmental report. So far only 37 do this although a further 21 say they intend to start doing so. Other fund managers are likely to follow this lead as pension fund trustees put on pressure. From July, the FTSE4Good index series will allow investors to see which All Share Index constituents pass SRI tests. Besides the UK index, other FTSE4Good benchmarks will take in Europe, the US and the world. The index will also offer new facilities for ethical tracker funds - those currently run by Legal & General and NPI suffer from the lack of a widely accepted index. FTSE will announce which companies are in and which are out every six months. Except for total "no-no" sectors such as tobacco, armaments and animal testing for cosmetics, the object is to be inclusive - unlike the narrowly based rival Dow Jones Sustainability indices which rejects around nine in 10 firms. FTSE wants to encourage companies to qualify - on day one around 60% of major companies will be included. The baseline will be good practice backed by measurable environmental performance. "Hurdles" for entry will be increased over time - and companies in high environmental impact industries such as mining or agriculture will have to conform to higher benchmarks. But FTSE realises it has a potential hot potato on its hands. "We don't expect activists to abseil our office block. But we do expect controversy," FTSE says. "Besides pressure groups, the companies themselves could complain if they are excluded. We shall have transparent rules and firms will be allowed to challenge decisions." Other potential problems include:  What to do with one-off events such as a major environmental disaster.  Criteria for throwing companies out of the index - firms may argue they are being treated more harshly than others.  Takeovers - will there be a pain threshold based on the proportion of the "dirty" business in the new entity or will the index continue to recognise good management?  Targeted companies - some firms have been spotlighted by activists when rivals are ignored even though they might be worse.  Investors will be able to compare the performance of the new index against the market as a whole. But there are no plans for a FTSE4Bad index.

fields.headline: Beware of forms promising gifts
fields.trailText: Inland Revenue attempts to simplify self assessment forms have failed where they should have succeeded most - in their treatment of elderly people, many of whom find the DIY tax regime difficult.
fields.body:
Inland Revenue attempts to simplify self assessment forms have failed where they should have succeeded most - in their treatment of elderly people, many of whom find the DIY tax regime difficult.

The latest problem - spotted by Guardian Jobs & Money reader Tony Scull, a retired TV producer - centres on potential confusion around the extra "age-related" tax allowance paid to those aged 65 or more with incomes under £17,000 in the last tax year.

This follows Inland Revenue embarrassment last week over Rita 500 letters - as revealed in Jobs & Money - which told taxpayers they were late in responding to statements demanding tax due - even though the statements had yet to be posted.

"The heading on one page of the tax calculation guide implies age-related personal allowances are due if you or your spouse are in the over-64 age group. But that is nonsense. This has nothing to do with a spouse - it is purely individual," he says.

"You could easily get confused with Married Persons Age Allowance which is paid to couples where only one qualifies on age," he adds.

To compound matters, from this year onwards the age-related personal allowance is paid to those reaching 65 but the marriage allowance goes only to those where one partner was born before April 6, 1935.

"You can easily get confused," says tax expert John Whiting at accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers. "I can see why they have done it but only up to a point. The two allowances are separate."

Mr Scull contacted the Inland Revenue helpline. "They were surprised at the potential for misunderstanding and aghast at the implications this might have among older people. If they get something wrong, that's fine. But if you get it wrong, they fine you," he says.

The Inland Revenue believes Mr Scull's confusion results from their simplification process. "It's not misleading. We have cut the number of pages in the guide this year. There is further guidance in another booklet sent out with the return. The idea is to lead people in this age group from one page to the next," it says, declining to comment on its own helpline.

But it admits the forms are far from perfect. "We are always reviewing every policy to see if we can improve. We have a Working Together initiative along with the accountancy bodies. We are listening," it adds.

webTitle: When a lender slips up over the repayments

fields.headline: When a lender slips up over the repayments
fields.standfirst: Richard Colbey has a cautionary tale of arrears created when the Woolwich charged too little
fields.trailText: Richard Colbey has a cautionary tale of arrears created when the Woolwich charged too little.
fields.body:
The mess institutions can get themselves into when calculating mortgage repayments is well illustrated by the case of Oxford woman, Joy Hawthorne, who took out a £45,000 mortgage with the Woolwich in 1989.

She was one of the sensible people who didn't fall for the spiel about endowments, so common in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and decided on a mortgage where she would repay the capital on a regular basis.

For the first three years everything went fine, then in 1992 when interest rates soared to around 12% she briefly fell into arrears. Soon afterwards she started repaying the arrears by increasing her monthly payment and by

1998 thought she had put that problem completely behind her.

Indeed, she had been pleasantly surprised when in 1996 the Woolwich told her to drop her monthly payment substantially. She assumed this was just in line with the general downwards trend in interest rates around that time, and that the Woolwich was being a little more generous than most in the run up to its demutualisation.

Like most mortgage holders she did not look very closely at her annual statement. Had she done so, she might have realised that in fact the Woolwich was no longer taking any capital repayment from her, and that this reduction meant she was only paying interest.

Although the statements did show the outstanding sum was no longer reducing, they, incorrectly, continued to describe the mortgage as being on a repayment basis.

The problem only came to light last year when, having decided to study for an MBA, she enquired about transferring to a new flexible mortgage the Woolwich was offering, which would have enabled her to vary her repayments.

She was outraged to then discover that her present repayment arrangements meant the outstanding debt would never go down, and that at the end of the 25-year term she would owe just as much as when she started.

"I thought this was totally unfair," she said, "I had a contract to pay what they demanded in return for them treating the mortgage as repaid in 2014."

While this is Ms Hawthorne's gut reaction, rather than a reasoned legal argument, it is probably right. The amount that should be paid at any given time to repay the mortgage is not written in tablets of stone. The Woolwich was entitled to charge its standard rate but, if it charged less, that simply amounted to a bonus for the customer.

Commercial organisations that undercharge can rarely recover the resulting arrears. One of the cases best known to English lawyers concerned a block of flats known as High Trees House. The landlords reduced the rent payable during Second World War from the level they were entitled to.

After the war they tried to sue for the full amount. The principle was stated by Lord Denning, deciding the claim, that once someone has undercharged, and another person has relied on that under- charging, that means the full amount is no longer payable.

When Ms Hathorne put her reaction to the local branch, and later the centre in Bedford which deals with mortgage calculations, the point was rather lost on the staff.

After a close examination of the records they did accept she had never consented to her mortgage being transferred to an interest-only basis.

However, Ms Hawthorne says: "Their attitude was still one of: the problem will go away by itself. The only solution they would suggest was that I pay an extra £100 per month to catch up."

When Jobs & Money contacted the Woolwich, it readily accepted the problem was rather more complicated than that. Indeed, it took more than a week to gather up all the papers relating to her case and then a senior analyst spent three days working out what had gone wrong.

The Woolwich then agreed Ms Hawthorne was entitled to redress. Its provisional calculation was that she had deserved to be credited by £1,829 with a further ex gratia payment of £421.

It used a completely different - and totally incomprehensible - formulation to mine, but the net result was about the same. Although there may still be some haggling to be done, she was eventually treated fairly.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Everlast
fields.body:
If Everlast and Eminem ever come to blows - which they nearly did last autumn when Eminem recorded a song attacking the former House of Pain frontman as a "punk pussy bitch" - the smart money says Everlast would wipe the floor with his rival. Em may own a chainsaw, but Ev is a weightier proposition in the ways that count.

Despite a near-fatal heart attack three years ago, aged only 28, the former Eric Schrody has engineered a career manoeuvre that has vaulted him from rap has-been to acclaimed wild-hearted blues belter. So much for the idea that rappers sing like elks. Everlast steers his songs' minor-key melancholy with the gravelly beauty of Tom Waits. Coming from someone whose only hit with House of Pain, Jump Around, owed its hookline to the Osmonds' Crazy Horses, this is impressive.

Inevitably, Jump Around made an appearance in this set, and its homeboy euphoria induced mass wobbling in the stuffed Astoria. One supplicant even waved a pair of crutches over his head. But its good-time foolishness was an anomaly in an evening devoted to Everlast's two solo albums, the 3m-selling Whitey Ford Sings the Blues and last year's Eat at Whitey's. Even as Jump Around trumpeted to a halt, Everlast was climbing behind an acoustic guitar for the painfully lovely torch song Black Coffee. Definitely not the All Saints number, it commanded rapt attention as the band quieted to a whisper, and Ev sighed, "She's like a junkie, just like a junkie," echoed by guest diva Carleen Anderson.

Whoever "she" was, she disturbed Everlast as much as the "they" who crop up in the country-blues melodrama Black Jesus ("They call me white devil, black Jesus"), which he sang as if half-consumed by fire and brimstone. These paled, though, beside the shock of Painkiller, which employed disjointed hip-hop to record his feelings at waking up after his heart attack. "Can't believe it, I'm in a wheelchair," he rapped, terse and unforgiving.

Although nothing like House of Pain's raucous escapism, Everlast's new incarnation is striking a chord. His promotion from the tiny cellar he played last time he was in London to the larger Astoria testifies to his public's willingness to embrace him, angst and all.

fields.headline: Rates down again
fields.standfirst: Search hard for the best paying accounts, advises Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Banks and building societies have embarked on a fresh round of savings rate reductions following the quarter-point bank base rate cut earlier this month.
fields.body:
Banks and building societies have embarked on a fresh round of savings rate reductions following the quarter-point bank base rate cut earlier this month.

Egg, NatWest and Standard Life Bank are among the players that have been quick to pass on the rate cut to their savers. The reductions coincide with new research which claims that apathy is costing the UK's savers billions of pounds in lost interest a year.

Egg this week trimmed its rates yet again, with the standard savings account and internet-only account now paying 5% and 5.75% respectively (they previously paid 5.25% and 6%). Its recently-launched Investor account has suffered a bigger hack - it now pays 6.5% on balances from £1 to £25,000, down from 7% before.

A spokesman says the cuts "reflect market conditions". But he points out that unlike many of its rivals Egg has put in place a number of base rate-linked guarantees which promise that the account rates will not fall below specified levels this year.

NatWest has reduced rates on a number of its accounts by a typical 0.25%. So its Savings Direct phone and postal account sees the rate for balances of between £1 and £4,999 fall from 4.5% to 4.25%. For balances of £5,000-£9,999 the new rate is 4.4% (from 4.65%), and for balances of £10,000-£24,999 savers will receive 4.7% (from 4.95%).

NatWest's Diamond Reserve and Reward Reserve accounts also see their rates for balances of £2,000-plus fall by 0.25%.

Standard Life Bank has opted to lop 0.3% off its personal savings rates. So its popular Direct Access account sees its rate for balances of between £1 and £4,999 fall from 5.55% to 5.25%, while for balances of £5,000-£11,999 the rate drops to 5.3% from 5.6%.

A new survey from Yorkshire Bank shows that Brits will happily leave a total of £3.4bn languishing in their current accounts at the end of this month, just as they do every month, where it generally earns next to nothing in interest. Yet people could earn 5%-plus interest if they moved some of this money to one of the decent-paying savings accounts still out there.

This figure is based on its calcuation that 90% of people regularly have at least £75 left by the time they get their next pay cheque, and a quarter of the population have more than £200 left over at the end of each month.

The researchers also found that 68% of people have no idea what rate of interest their savings are earning, and almost a third (29%) haven't checked the interest rate they are receiving since the day they opened their account.

So where can you go to get a fairly decent rate of interest? According to financial data provider Moneyfacts, the best rates on instant access-style accounts are currently being offered by, among others, internet and phone bank Intelligent Finance (6% from £1), Scottish Widows Bank (5.65% from £100, though this rate includes a 0.5% bonus for six months - account operated by post or phone), and Sun Bank (5.55% from £500, account operated by post).

On mini cash Isas, internet bank Smile is offering 6.5% from £1, while Northern Rock is paying 6.55% from £1, though this product is a 30-day notice account and the rate includes a 0.55% bonus for the first six months. Chelsea building society is offering 6.5% from £10, though this rate includes a 1% bonus for the first year. Cheltenham & Gloucester is paying 6.45% though the minimum balance is £100.

Looking at internet-only accounts, Bristol & West and Newcastle building society are each paying a hefty 6.6%, though to get this rate you would have to have at least £1,000 and £10,000 invested with them respectively. The Newcastle Net Savings account pays 6.10% from £1,000 to £9,999.

These rates were correct this week but could change.

fields.headline: Loans with novelty value
fields.standfirst: As fierce competition brings their rates closer together, lenders are resorting to gimmicks and quirky extras to win trade, writes Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: As fierce competition brings their rates closer together, lenders are resorting to gimmicks and quirky extras to win trade, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
As the mortgage price war continues to rage, banks and building societies are increasingly turning to quirky deals and novel added extras in an attempt to make themselves stand out from the crowd.

The Woolwich this week unveiled an intriguing new mortgage which enables parents to use their savings to help reduce their offspring's monthly home loan payments without actually handing any money over to them.

Legal & General has launched a flexible mortgage designed to help homeowners cover the costs of educating their children.

And mortgage broker Charcol has brought out a novel deal which offers borrowers double the benefit if interest rates fall - so if the Bank of England base rate falls by 0.25%, your mortgage rate is cut by 0.5%.

Offbeat offers such as these reflect the fact that mortgage lenders are being forced to find new ways of attracting borrowers' attention.

"In the current market, innovation is critical," says Siobhan Hotten at Charcol. "There is so little differential price-wise between one product and another, so lenders are going to have to get a little bit clever."

The Woolwich deal is called open plan offset together. It offers a way for families to help reduce their children's mortgage bills or cut years off the loan, by offsetting their savings against their youngster's borrowings.

How it works is that the son or daughter takes out an open plan offset mortgage with the Woolwich, where the rate they pay is set at 0.75% above the Bank of England base rate for life (currently 6.25%). This deal allows people to offset savings against debts, and you can borrow up to 95% of the value of your home.

Then the parent opens a Woolwich open plan account for savers, which they can link to the mortgage. The value of the money in this account is then offset against the mortgage, saving interest on the home loan.

However, the parent's (or grandparent's) money is kept completely separate and they control the account, enabling them to add or withdraw money at any time. They simply make a phone call to link their account.

The mortgage holder saves money by only paying interest on the difference between the amount borrowed and the amount in the linked savings account. For example, someone with a £70,000 mortgage whose parents or grandparents offset £10,000 of savings will only pay mortgage interest on £60,000 all the time that the savings are in the account, which would save the borrower £52 a month.

Existing offset mortgage customers can also benefit from this new option. And offset together isn't restricted to family members. "Anyone can offset funds against someone's offset mortgage, for example siblings or partners," says a spokeswoman.

"Also, the offsetting doesn't have to be a long-term arrangement - it can be changed at any time. Parents in receipt of a windfall or pay bonus could offset it against the mortgage until they have decided what to do with it," she adds.

It means parents can help ease the financial strain that many young people go through when setting up their first home without actually having to give their money to them.

Many parents already give children a helping hand with their mortgage. A survey has shown that 27% of first-time buyers were given their deposit by a family member.

Also this week, Legal & General launched the "in-tuition mortgage", a flexible package designed to enable parents to plan for a range of costs associated with schooling such as nursery fees, private education and university costs. It also enables parents with children already at fee-paying schools to release funds to pay the ongoing fees.

The deal is based around L&G's flexible reserve mortgage and allows people to borrow up to an agreed limit over and above the amount needed for the mortgage on their home. It also allows parents to make overpayments and then draw down on the reserve they've built up to pay for educational costs when they arise.

There are two varieties of the loan, one with a variable rate of 6.35% and the other with a rate of 6.45%, though in both cases there is a 0.5% discount for the first two years. webTitle: Theatre review:  The Far Side of the Moon

fields.headline: A giant leap for Robert Lepage
fields.standfirst:
Playhouse, Newcastle
****
fields.trailText:
Playhouse, Newcastle
****
fields.body:
The timing is perfect. Forty years after the first manned orbit of the earth Robert Lepage brings us a one-man show about space exploration. But, being a Lepage show, it is as much about inner as outer space. Part of its magic lies in its combination of emotional fervour and technical wizardry.

In a sense two stories are being told. On a public level Lepage recalls the competitive Soviet-American moon-race, which he sees largely as an exercise in national vanity. In the private sphere, Lepage tells of two warring Quebec brothers brought together by their mother's death. One is a shy philosopher struggling with a thesis on the influence of space exploration on popular culture; the other is a gay, extrovert TV weatherman who takes a pragmatic view of the galaxy's mysteries. And, just as the 1975 joint Apollo-Soyuz mission brought together the rival nations, so the fractious brothers are finally reconciled.

I sometimes feel with Lepage that his theatrical legerdemain outstrips his ideas. But here style and content work in perfect harmony as he explores the notion that individuals and nations can offer mirror images of each other. The show's key metaphor is of reflecting surfaces and it reaches an astonishing climax in a scene where Lepage simulates an astronaut floating in space without his body leaving the ground. He creates magic by simple means and lends everyday objects a transforming poetry. He starts in a laundromat, where a spin-drier's circular aperture becomes the equivalent of Alice in Wonderland's rabbit hole and in time transmutes into the dead mother's prized goldfish bowl, an aeroplane window and a revolving moon.

The ingenious effects, however, are always at the service of an idea: in particular, that contraries can be synthesised and that emotional loss can be turned into spiritual gain. The most affecting scenes are those in which Lepage shows the two brothers coping in different ways with their mother's death. The introspective Philippe nervously dons her dress while the bumptious weatherman goes down to the gym. Just as they are harmonised, so too Lepage suggests that all life is about the reconciliation of apparent opposites. In one scene he suggests that even doctor and patient are two sides of the same moon.

Lepage, as performer, not only taps into his own multi-facetedness but even revealed, on the first night, a surprising ability to deal with a heckler. Technically this is a one-man show, but it is reinforced by the poignant mystery of Laurie Anderson's music, by Pierre Bernier's puppeteering skill and by the proficiency of numerous technicians. After recent disappointments, this is Lepage at his very best, showing his talent for forging unexpected connections and appealing simultaneously to hearts and minds.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 0191-230 5151. Then at the Tramway, Glasgow (0141-287 5511), from Thursday.

fields.headline: Simon Munnery, comedy messiah
fields.standfirst:
Soho Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Soho Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
Someone needs to put a bomb under the ingratiating conventions of British comedy. The success of Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned can only mean that comedy has now become a ritual of community, something that doesn't need jokes so long as it makes us feel we're all mates.

You can see why Simon Munnery with his League Against Tedium looks to some like the answer. Munnery is different - very. What kind of catchphrase is "Attention Scum"? Instead of making you feel you belong, you wonder why you're spending time with this weirdo.

He comes on like the comedy messiah. Appearing in a puff of smoke, he is robed in bright orange, with a cardboard beak and a helmet around which his spectacles are Sellotaped. He could be a medieval penitent, a Ku Klux Klansman or a Tango ad. The solitary prophet of the League Against Tedium begins addressing us in a superior language of his own invention. Around his neck he wears a computer keyboard, also painted orange, with a miniature camera on which he films himself, accompanying his live presence with his own face on screen, alternated with aggressive slogans and cartoons. For a while he even disappears behind the screen.

Munnery remains masked until the end of the show, when he emerges into the light blinking myopically like a vulnerable boy. He takes the character comedy so popular over the past decade and explodes it. He presents a marginal, deviant declaimer of fascistic aphorisms, somewhere between an unemployed actor and Hitler. But you can't even fix Munnery as a character, because he is a set of avant-garde allusions: if he attacks modern comedy's chumminess, he also repudiates its middle-browness, quoting dadaism (the costume), constructivism (the combination of live and filmed images) and futurism, with a plea for war to be pursued for its own sake.

Then again, anyone can throw in high allusions and Munnery doesn't abandon the conventions he wants to subvert. This is entertainment. He is, after all, produced by Avalon, just like Baddiel and Skinner, with tickets a whopping £12 for a 50-minute show. The flashes of genius are dissipated by a presentation that is not extreme enough; at no point does he make you anxious, make you squirm. He does, however, have a sublime encore, a personification of Bob Dylan in which he plays a one-note stringed instrument and whines incoherently - not a parody but an alter-Dylan. Munnery is not the messiah, he's a very naughty boy.

 Until April 28. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

webTitle: FA signs deal with agent's son

fields.headline: FA signs deal with agent's son
fields.trailText: The FA has signed a minimum four-year contract to deliver websites and a national administration system for grassroots football with Nick Roach, the son of an agent under investigation by the FA.
fields.body:
The Football Association yesterday signed an agreement with InterClubNet, a communication company whose chief executive Nick Roach is the son of Dennis Roach, the agent whose transfer dealings are under FA investigation.

InterClubNet has signed a minimum four-year contract to deliver websites and a national administration system for grassroots football.

The FA insists that the deal will not interfere with its investigation into two transfers conducted by Dennis Roach, namely Paulo Wanchope's move from Derby to Manchester City and Duncan Ferguson's return to Everton from Newcastle United.

"Nick is the chief executive and not Dennis," an FA spokesman said last night. "That's the important distinction. It's not going to affect the investigation into Dennis Roach and it won't affect our working relationship with InterClubNet.

"It's a project to help the grassroots of the game and does not involve player transfers. In terms of the area Dennis Roach operates in there's no crossover."

Dennis Roach was working as a consultant for InterClubNet late last year.

webTitle: How Mr Bean's team unravelled the financial web at Chesterfield

fields.headline: How Mr Bean's team unravelled the financial web at Chesterfield
fields.standfirst: FA's vigilance surprised the club, says  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary unravels the complicated myriad of allegations that have tainted the name of Chesterfield.
fields.body:
On a cold Wednesday morning in January a team arrived unannounced at Saltergate, home of Chesterfield Football Club. This team had not come to lock horns with the Third Division leaders on the pitch. It was more concerned with finance than football.

Led by Graham Bean, the Football Association's compliance officer who was accompanied by three investigators, surprised club officials were told to open their files and hand over all documentation to the joint FA/Football League team that had been dispatched to Chesterfield.

What was to emerge over the coming days as Bean and his men examined files, questioned players, managers and officials was a complex web of financial irregularities that implicated not only the club but the sports empire of its then chairman Darren Brown.

After seven days of exhaustive investigations Bean concluded that it was not just the spire of Chesterfield's famous church, close to the ground, that is crooked.

Rumours of financial irregularities had been buzzing around the football grapevine for several months prior to Bean's surprise visit. Football League officials had received several anonymous telephone calls warning them that not all was what it appeared in the way the club ran its affairs, from the method of paying players to the way it declared its gate receipts.

For at least two months prior to Bean's visit Football League officials began monitoring the gate receipts registered by Chesterfield. All league clubs have to file their attendance figures and gate receipts on a weekly basis to league headquarters in Preston, Lancashire. The league charges a 3% levy on all gate receipts, which goes into a central fund.

Despite the fact that Chesterfield were riding high at the top of the Third Division and enjoying healthy crowds, league officials noticed that this did not tally with the amount the club claimed to be taking in gate receipts. At times Chesterfield would register an attendance of 7,000 to 8,000 but would reveal gate receipts for a crowd averaging 4,000.

The shortfall, combined with growing gossip and the anonymous telephone calls, eventually prompted the FA and the Football League to form a team of investigators and send them to Chesterfield. The ensuing investigation led to around 90 charges being brought against 18 players, the team manager Nicky Law and Brown, who stepped down as chairman last month.

The majority were not proven by the inquiry panel at Hillsborough, such as illegal payments to players and an illegal payment of £10,000 to an agent.

The failure to report the right gate receipts and giving a player, Luke Beckett, two contracts, however, were proven and for this the club were found guilty of breaching Football League guidelines.

The whole affair has taken on more sinister and complicated tones with the involvement of the police, prompting two separate investigations: one by the Derbyshire police fraud squad into the running of Chesterfield and another into intimidation of witnesses.

This week Andy Marples, an acountant who worked for Brown and Chesterfield, was arrested at his home, where a number of documents and computer discs were seized. Marples was later released, pending further inquiries.

Derbyshire police have also sent a file to the Crown Prosecution Service about possible charges of witness intimidation. Officers were called in when it emerged that witness statements presented to the joint FA/Football League inquiry were distributed to Chesterfield fans at a local pub in the hope they would intimidate those giving evidence at the Hillsborough inquiry.

The role of Brown has been pivotal in the complicated myriad of allegations that have tainted the name of Chesterfield. But question marks over his management extend well beyond the world of football and, indeed, financial problems appear to be a hallmark of the charismatic chairman with almost every sports concern he has been involved in.

Brown, aged 29 and the head of a printing company, took over at Chesterfield last year. Throughout the affair he has denied any allegations of wrong doing. Since stepping down as chairman he has also stepped down as head of his UK Sports Group, which owns the ice hockey teams Sheffield Steelers and Hull Thunder.

Brown was recently banned by ice hockey's Superleague for his "total mismanagement" of the Sheffield Steelers, who are facing financial ruin, leaving behind a string of creditors. The Derbyshire police fraud squad is also investigating the running of the Steelers. The Sheffield Sharks basketball team, another former concern of Brown's, are also trying to overcome financial problems.

It is with Chesterfield, however, that Brown's presence has had the most devastating impact, given that it has cost the club so dear.

In statements that were presented to the inquiry, the club director Dean Newman revealed the deal surrounding Beckett's two contracts.

Beckett was signed from Chester City last summer after the tribunal set a fee of £150,000. At that hearing Chesterfield presented a contract for the player that showed he was to earn £500 per week and receive a £21,000 signing-on fee. However, this was just to reduce his transfer fee. Beckett's real contract showed that he earned £1,000 per week and received a £54,000 signing-on fee.

Newman said in evidence: "I asked Ian Banks [Law's assistant] why Beckett had two contracts. Ian said that when they were at the tribunal to set Beckett's transfer fee, Luke's agent had said that one of the tribunal's determining factors when setting the fee was the player's contract terms. If it looked as though Beckett was earning less that he actually was and there were no signing-on fees involved, this would significantly reduce the transfer fee Chesterfield would have to pay."

The commercial manager James Brown told the inquiry in his statement that players received cash in envelopes. He said: "I know of at least one cash bonus being paid to players." Ultimately the inquiry panel felt there was not enough evidence to convict on this charge.

Referring to a match with Exeter, his statement reads: "Sharon Wood, who was then manager of Blue on the Move [the Chesterfield lottery], used my office at half-time to count out some money and put it into envelopes. She told me, 'Darren Brown's got me doing this'. I understand at the time that each player was to receive about £600."

The inquiry also heard that at least three of the turnstiles at Saltergate were not connected to a main computer that records attendance figures and that cash was collected at these particular turnstiles. Wood ran Blues on the Move to raise money for a new stadium or to renovate dilapidated Saltergate. She told the inquiry in her statement: "I was involved in the payment of cash bonuses to the team managers and certain players and I knew that the cash used for that bonus came out of the gate receipts from a home match against Exeter."

fields.standfirst: Chesterfield to appeal over financial irregularities ruling
fields.trailText: Chesterfield face losing nine points and £20,000 in fines for irregularities in recording gate receipts and breaching regulations over the transfer of a player. The club is to appeal.
fields.body:
Chesterfield should be deducted nine points and fined £20,000 for irregularities in recording gate receipts and breaching regulations over the transfer of a player, a joint Football Association and Football League disciplinary panel ruled last night.

The panel, which was considering 90 charges against the club, mainly surrounding illegal payments to players, was unable to prove the majority of the allegations after a three-day hearing at Sheffield Wednesday's Hillsborough ground. In total, 18 players, the former chairman Darren Brown and the team manager Nicky Law had been charged with a number of financial irregularities.

Chesterfield, the Third Division leaders on 82 points, would have gained promotion with a win at Kidderminster on Saturday. They are to appeal against the fine and the points deduction on April 30. If the appeal fails then they could still be promoted because a nine-point deduction would leave them in third place with 73 points, five ahead of fourth placed Hartlepool.

After a full day of deliberations the panel, made up of the former Newcastle chairman Gordon McKeag, Mark Day, the former financial controller of the FA, and the former Nottingham Forest manager Frank Clark, delivered its surprise verdict. Most observers were expecting the majority of charges to be proven and a harsher punishment imposed.

McKeag warned the club over its future conduct and ordered that a transfer tribunal should be reconvened to determine a new transfer fee or compensation for Chester City and Barnsely over the controversial transfer of Luke Beckett.

The panel found that Chesterfield had drawn up two contracts for the player in an attempt to buy him at a cheaper price last summer.

Chesterfield were also found guilty of not reporting the correct gate receipts and were ordered to report to the Football League and FA within the next 14 days for "assistance and advice about installing procedures for a proper sysstem for accounting and to meet the costs incurred".

The league spokesman John Nagle said: "The panel has upheld a number of charges against Chesterfield relating to irregularities in transfer contracts and the under-reporting of gate receipts. There were serious breaches of our regulations and we believe the penalties imposed by the panel reflect this. We are surprised that some of the charges have not been upheld as we believe there was a very serious case to answer."

Chesterfield, who were represented by Jonathan Crystal QC, denied any allegations of wrong doing from the moment they were initally investigated by a joint FA and Football League team in January.

The club claimed the panel's outcome as a victory. Brown, who stepped down as chairman last month, said: "It's been a good day. We have shown we are innocent of the charges which I said we would be. I said the charges should never have been brought in the first place. It was a disgrace.

"It is good for myself, the players and Nicky Law that we've been cleared of the charges. I am confident that we will successfully appeal our nine points reduction and we will go up as champions. I've shown those who have doubted me and this is a big day in my life."

Law said: "I would lie if I said it hasn't affected our form and this is a weight off our shoulders. Whenever we have gone away from home we have consistently been called cheats. Banners have been paraded and it has affected us. We now know what we have got do. Our name has been cleared and we will get on with the job."

webTitle: Plot thickens in football's fringe theatre

fields.headline: Plot thickens in football's fringe theatre
fields.standfirst: David Lacey seeks an Easter twist in the season's tail
fields.trailText: If ever a football season needed a twist in its tail this one does. Yet those seeking a significant change of plot over Easter will surely search in vain. Fat chance - look to the bit players for end-of-term excitement.
fields.body:
If ever a football season needed a twist in its tail this one does. Yet those seeking a significant change of plot over Easter will surely search in vain.

There are five weeks to go in the Premiership but by teatime tomorrow Manchester United could be champions again in all but name. The Nationwide League programme will not be over until May 6 but, if Fulham win at Huddersfield tomorrow - or Bolton lose to Birmingham tonight - Craven Cottage will be assured of Premiership football in August.

So far as the main issues of the season are concerned, therefore, it is going to be hard to separate Easter from the epilogue. And for Arsenal and Manchester United any holiday activity will be merely a prologue to more urgent business next week in the Champions League quarter-finals.

The game's fringe theatre looks more interesting. Once more Coventry City are promising to bring a touch of Pearl White to their season's climax: tied to the relegation rails with Nationwide football bearing down on them but hoping to be snatched to safety.

Coventry are cutting it fine, but no more than usual. Three draws and two wins have brought Gordon Strachan's team within striking distance of Middlesbrough, now two points above them in 17th place.

While tomorrow's match at Old Trafford, where they have lost 14 times in 16 Premier League visits, offers Coventry little reason for optimism, Sunderland's visit to Highfield Road on Easter Monday could prove the pivotal moment of their latest leap towards safety.

So much depends on Middlesbrough and whether Terry Venables can prise his team out of neutral, starting at Highbury tomorrow. Since Venables arrived on Teesside his team have broken the habit of losing but have yet to rediscover the art of winning regularly.

Unless Arsenal, who defend a 2-1 lead in Valencia on Tuesday, throttle back to the point of stalling, Boro will not gain much comfort. Nor will the losers (if there are losers) at Upton Park, where West Ham and Derby County are both poised perilously close to the bottom three.

Should Arsenal fail to win and Coventry lose at Old Trafford, the championship will be over bar the counting because of Manchester United's vastly superior goal difference. United would doubtless insist on saving the victory parade until their home game against Manchester City tomorrow week but in reality the contest ended once Sir Alex Ferguson's side had taken an 11-point lead on New Year's Day.

Like Arsenal, Manchester United's immediate priorities lie in the Champions League and Ferguson will be anxious to keep legs fresh for Wednesday's game in Munich, where his side need to overturn Bayern's 1-0 win at Old Trafford.

Mentally at least, Leeds can afford to be a little more relaxed about taking a 3-0 lead to Coruna on Tuesday. Nevertheless David O'Leary has to concentrate on reaching next season's tournament not so much by winning the European Cup but through finishing third in the Premiership.

Today's visit to Anfield, then, is one of the more crucial holiday matches, with Liverpool needing a win to leapfrog above Leeds and Ipswich into third place on goal difference.

This will be Liverpool's fifth match in 12 days and their fixture jam does not end there. On Monday they face Everton at Goodison and three days later Barcelona visit Anfield in the second leg of the Uefa Cup semi-finals.

Having made six changes for the 1-1 draw at Ipswich three nights ago Gérard Houllier will presumably rotate his squad again today, with Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler among those set for recall.

A draw at Anfield would suit Ipswich, who will be looking to take at least four points from their matches at home to Newcastle United tomorrow and away to Middlesbrough on Monday.

This season George Burley set out simply to keep Ipswich in the Premier League. If, instead, he gets them into the Champions League and is not voted manager of the year, then the poll will be about as significant as a mafia raffle.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Ron Atkinson: Super-sub Solskjaer sets the modern benchmark

fields.headline: Super-sub Solskjaer sets the modern benchmark
fields.trailText: I can't help feeling that over the years the art of substitution has become easier. With more subs available the luck element has been reduced, but Solksjaer stands out as a modern master
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson's comment this week that Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was "the best substitute ever" set me thinking. David Fairclough would have plenty of fans willing to argue his case, and I can't help feeling that over the years the art of substitution has become easier.

First of all the number of substitutes you can use and choose from has increased substantially. I remember being able to name only one man on the bench for United in the 1985 FA Cup final and going for Micky Duxbury, who could cover in defence or midfield. Not until 1987-88 were two changes allowed in league matches.

On top of that, clubs in the Premiership benefit from carrying larger squads of quality players, which means the assets at a manager's disposal on the bench are better.

It's a different game replacing one player with another of equal ability rather than putting on a kid with potential or a lad who was seen as not quite good enough or was just coming back from injury.

At one time even the top sides worked with about 14 or 15 top players, with the rest of the squad made up of reserves or youngsters who were trying to force their way in. I remember having a young Mark Hughes in that position at Old Trafford.

Now the depth of squad is such that United, Arsenal and Liverpool have four top-class strikers. At Panathinaikos in the Champions League, Ferguson was able to take off Cole, throw on Solskjaer and Teddy Sheringham alongside Dwight Yorke and watch United get a last-minute equaliser. Arsène Wenger's Arsenal have ended games with four forwards.

The Liverpool management had to be spot on with their use of Fairclough, who was the original supersub in everyone's books. They couldn't bring him on and then reinforce that with someone else, so they had to make sure the point of impact was perfect.

Although Fairclough never seemed to get a regular place at Anfield he came on and scored some vital goals, most famously the winner against St Etienne in the European Cup quarter-final of 1977.

One of his great ingredients was the extra pace he could offer, which can be so important from a substitute. Obviously Sheringham offers something different, but that speed can catch out defenders who are tiring physically and might also mentally be going to sleep.

That's why I understand Glenn Hoddle and, to a lesser extent, Kevin Keegan's thinking in using Michael Owen as an international substitute while he is rounding off his all-round game. He can come on with fresh life and vitality and be a surprise package, as he showed by scoring against Romania at the 1998 World Cup and in Paris last year against France.

Of course, bigger benches make it easier for managers to keep players happy. I recall how disappointed Steve McCall, Garry Parker and others were be left out of the 13 for Aston Villa's 1994 League Cup final against United because I could only name two substitutes.

But even with only one change at your disposal a manager could turn a game, as Bob Paisley showed with Fairclough. I remember making a decisive substitution for United when we playing Everton in the sixth round of the FA Cup in 1983 at Old Trafford.

We were drawing 0-0 with 30 seconds remaining when we won a corner. As a last throw of the dice I decided to put on Lou Macari, who was in the veteran stage but still capable of an impact. Micky Duxbury came over to ask who was coming off and I said: "You are, you're the nearest."

Lou ran straight into the box, got up and won a header from which Frank Stapleton volleyed the winner. People were saying what a masterstroke it was, but it was more a bit of jam.

So many of Solskjaer's contributions from the bench have been less flukey. He picks up the pace of a game very quickly and when you talk to people at Old Trafford they will tell you he is the best finisher on the books.

He's not a great combination player and I'm not always sure United's play benefits in terms of overall quality when he's in the side. But if there are chances being made he's great to have around.

There's hardly a team Solskjaer wouldn't be the regular centre-forward for, and of course he's in United folklore for scoring what is probably the all-time substitution goal: the injury-time winner against Bayern Munich in the 1999 European Cup final.

At Arsenal Sylvain Wiltord has also made some vital contributions from the bench, sparking the comeback against Shakhtar Donetsk in the Champions League and nicking two goals to knock Chelsea out of the FA Cup.

But there's no question substitutions can misfire as well. When I took United to the 1983 Charity Shield, Joe Fagan made a change for Liverpool as we were preparing to take a corner. The replacement ran on and before he had got into position or picked up the tempo, Bryan Robson scored. That taught me not to change things when you're defending a set-play in the last third.

But the classic misfiring substitution came at the 1970 World Cup, when England were leading Germany 2-0. Alf Ramsey brought on Colin Bell and Norman Hunter for Bobby Charlton and Martin Peters with 13 minutes left. Somehow, by the end, England had lost 3-2.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Jake and Theresa
fields.trailText: Milford Haven on the south-west of the South Island is a must and the drive there from Queenstown is also unforgettable. Try to drive up the west coast from Queensland, and do have a look at the sperm whales on the north-east of the South Island. The north island is different with more people around but equally dramatic in its own way.
fields.body:
Milford Haven on the south-west of the South Island is a must and the drive there from Queenstown is also unforgettable. Try to drive up the west coast from Queensland, and do have a look at the sperm whales on the north-east of the South Island. The north island is different with more people around but equally dramatic in its own way.

If you dive check out the north east tip (one of Jacques Cousteau's top ten dives) and on land in the north-west, see the amazing giant Kauri trees (the oldest living things on the planet besides bristlecone pine trees in California) and the astonishing Kauri museum which was quite simply the best museum we've ever visited - and we saw a few during our twelve month trip!

Not much happening in Auckland, but Rotorua is spectacular with its thermal park. If you're going to the States or Canada let us know since we did a 27 states road trip and could give you a few ideas. There's a company called Driveaway which needs cars delivering all over the States - all you pay is the gas.

Happy travelling.......you not missing anything back home! Wish we were there!
