fields.headline: Tripping for a fall
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth has made MPs' holidays a highly sensitive issue, writes politics editor, Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth has made MPs' holidays a highly sensitive issue, writes politics editor, Julian Glover
fields.body:
Pity poor Alasdair Morrison. Not the best known of politicians, even in Scotland, a land whose parliament specialises in producing political obscurities, he has shot to sudden, red-faced celebrity. The cause? Not a sex scandal; not even an inadvertent parking ticket - only the publication of his holiday plans.

Last week, it has just been revealed, Mr Morrison travelled to Italy on holiday days after promoting Scotland as a tourist destination in the US. Recently he told the Scottish parliament that he would be staying in Scotland during the summer, in Dumfries and Galloway and the Isle of Skye. He made no mention of his Easter plans.

Now his ministerial career is on the line - and though Mr Morrison protests that he has "done more than anyone" to support Scottish tourism, he faces at least a dressing down when he flies home tomorrow.

For while the rest of us can flee Britain over Easter in massive numbers - 1.5m at the latest count - politicians have been forced to stay at home or suffer the headlines. Travelling abroad has become the new political sin, a bit like the indiscretions that led ministers to resign to "spend more time with their families" when the Tories were in power.

Perhaps it is a just punishment for all those proud little speeches asserting that the countryside is "open for business" when much of it clearly isn't. Or perhaps, like good chefs who eat only in their own restaurants, politicians should never expect to enjoy themselves abroad? Even so, the hounding of Mr Morrison seems cruel.

And it presents a problem for other politicians, too. Do any of them dare cross the immigration control lines at Heathrow? With the election put off until June, MPs on a two-week break, and the weather in the south of France warming up nicely, plenty of MPs and candidates had made plans to slip away somewhere sunny.

Now most have had to cancel - and few even dare confess to having had the impure thought of travelling in the first place. One or two brave Labour candidates are said to be venturing across the Channel (one at least misleading his constituency party as to his intentions). But John Reid, the Northern Ireland minister, is alone among senior ministers in admitting that he had plans to go to France.

Now he has cancelled and "will be boosting tourism in the province instead". No doubt it will be fun.

Tony Blair is said never to have planned to go abroad - though his office won't say what he'll do at Chequers, surrounded by barred footpaths. At least he has a tennis court and a heated swimming pool (installed by Ted Heath, so Mrs Thatcher kept it cold) to entertain him. Unlike Mr Morrison, most of the cabinet's Scots will be at home for the holiday. The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, will be in his Highland pile, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, at his North Queensferry home high above the Forth bridges and Alistair Darling with his family in Edinburgh. Paul Murphy, his Welsh counterpart, will be spending Easter in Dorset. While he is away, chief whip Ann Taylor and her family will be in Wales.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is going to Suffolk - foot and mouth-free so far - as is Geoff Hoon, whose troops are busy burying the disease's victims.

Margaret Jay, leader of the Lords, has a country cottage in Ireland, but another in the Cotswolds, as does Michael Meacher, the many-homed environment minister.

Jack Straw, whose rural retreat is in Oxfordshire, will have to do his Easter walking on tarmac too.

David Blunkett and his lucky education secretary and his deputy, Estelle Morris, will be touring teachers' conferences in Cardiff and Jersey.

And the benefit of all this? Doubtful. Far from being encouraged to stay in Britain by the example of our leaders, Britons, surely, will be driven abroad.

After all, France looks like being the only place where it might be possible not to meet an MP.

With the election put off until June, MPs on a two-week break, and the weather in the south of France warming up nicely, plenty of MPs and candidates had made plans to slip away somewhere sunny. Now most have had to cancel - and few even dare confess to having had the impure thought of travelling in the first place. One or two brave Labour candidates are said to be venturing across the Channel (one at least misleading his constituency party as to his intentions). But John Reid, the Northern Ireland minister, is alone among senior ministers in admitting that he had plans to go to France. Now he has cancelled and "will be boosting tourism in the province instead". No doubt it will be fun. Tony Blair is said never to have planned to go abroad - though his office won't say what he'll do at Chequers, surrounded by barred footpaths. At least he has a tennis court and a heated swimming pool (installed by Ted Heath, so Mrs Thatcher kept it cold) to entertain him. Unlike Mr Morrison, most of the cabinet's Scots will be at home for the holiday. The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, will be in his Highland pile, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, at his North Queensferry home high above the Forth bridges and Alistair Darling with his family in Edinburgh. Paul Murphy, his Welsh counterpart, will be spending Easter in Dorset. While he is away, chief whip Ann Taylor and her family will be in Wales. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is going to Suffolk - foot and mouth-free so far - as is Geoff Hoon, whose troops are busy burying the disease's victims. Margaret Jay, leader of the Lords, has a country cottage in Ireland, but another in the Cotswolds, as does Michael Meacher, the many-homed environment minister. Jack Straw, whose rural retreat is in Oxfordshire, will have to do his Easter walking on tarmac too. David Blunkett and his lucky education secretary and his deputy, Estelle Morris, will be touring teachers' conferences in Cardiff and Jersey. And the benefit of all this? Doubtful. Far from being encouraged to stay in Britain by the example of our leaders, Britons, surely, will be driven abroad. After all, France looks like being the only place where it might be possible not to meet an MP.

webTitle: Teachers suspend action over staff shortages

fields.headline: Teachers suspend action over staff shortages
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The National Union of Teachers agreed to suspend its industrial action over staff shortages by a narrow 23-19 majority last night on the eve of its annual conference in Cardiff.
fields.body:
The National Union of Teachers agreed to suspend its industrial action over staff shortages by a narrow 23-19 majority last night on the eve of its annual conference in Cardiff.

The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, the other union involved in the action had already said it would suspend its action if the NUT did so. Union members in 60 areas across England had refused to cover staff shortages caused by long term vacancies or illness, although only a handful of schools were effected.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, welcomed the move and confirmed he was commissioning an independent inquiry to "review and identify more clearly problems of excessive workload and suggest practical ways in which we can tackle them together".

Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, said the executive's vote to endorse the recommendation of its leadership "gives us an opportunity to get into discussions on the remit of the review".

But the government has rejected union demands for a full review of pay and working conditions, including their call for a 35-hour week.

The NUT conference is to debate a joint union motion demanding an improved inquiry which was passed on Monday by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and is also going before the conferences of NASUWT and the Welsh union UCAC. The NUT has threatened a new wave of industrial action in the autumn.

webTitle: Leader: Tony Blair's new goal is good for schools

fields.headline: The teachers' new friend
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair's new goal is good for schools

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday became the first prime minister to address a classroom teachers' conference in the 131-year history of state education. The language was ameliorative.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday became the first prime minister to address a classroom teachers' conference in the 131-year history of state education. The language was ameliorative.

Sensibly, early acknowledgment was paid to the "critical importance" of teachers in determining the nation's future prosperity. An equally early tribute was made to teachers' skills, dedication and sheer hard work. Praise was rightly given to the way that David Blunkett had steered the government's education reforms over the last four years. Indeed, a cynic might describe it as "a bog standard election speech" - but that would be unfair.

There are a number of achievements which Labour has every right to join forces with teachers in celebrating: the sharp rise in primary school standards; a two-thirds reduction in unsatisfactory lessons recorded by Ofsted's inspectors; the continued improvement in GCSE and A-level grades; and the 25% reduction in the proportion of pupils leaving school with no qualifications and perilously few employment prospects. Each was duly noted. But so were the new challenges: 40% of 14-year-olds still not reaching the expected standard in English, maths and science; only half of 16-year-olds achieving five GCSEs at grade C or above; and 33,000 pupils who still leave without any qualification.

But Mr Blair's audience had more domestic concerns. By far the most moderate of the three main teacher unions, even the Association of Teachers and Lecturers (ATL) voted unanimously on Monday for a motion allowing the union to call a work-to-rule ballot in the autumn if pay and conditions are not improved. The ATL has not taken industrial action for 25 years. Uniquely, the same motion is being put before all three main unions this Easter. Recruitment and retention has become so serious in teaching, it has united the fractious unions.

Mr Blair acknowledged the problem, but what was missing was an appreciation of the scale of the challenge. It has a long history and is happening all over the developed world. It needed to be spelled out. Teacher-pupil ratios in secondary schools have now sunk back to what they were 25 years ago. This is almost unbelievable for a government that has made education its first priority. To be fair, a 10-year decline was finally halted in the last year, but it will be a long haul getting back to its 1990 level - let alone meeting the prime minister's ultimate new goal of making state education "as good in its facilities and investment as the independent sector".

The good news is this new goal. It was as big a surprise as his 1999 pledge to abolish child poverty. That has already achieved major progress. Raising the status of teachers is equally important. They have seen their pay shrink from 37% above the white-collar average to virtually the average. This year's pay award failed to lift them at all. Conditions, which are even more important, have deteriorated even faster as teacher shortages have eroded class preparation and marking time. In the first four years of this government, education expenditure as a proportion of national income, wavered between 4.5% and 4.8%, levels which were exceeded by the Tories in five out of their last six years. Private schools are spending £5,800 per secondary place, compared to the state's £2,600. Scotland has pointed the way: a 23% pay award over three years; guaranteed 12 hours of preparation; and a 35-hour week. The last should be resisted. No profession has such restrictions, let alone one with 13 weeks' holiday. But the pay and preparation time are appropriate goals.

webTitle: Blair pledges big rise in school spending

fields.headline: Blair pledges big rise in school spending
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday set the government an ambitious goal of eventually delivering levels of spending on state schools to rival the independent sector.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday set the government an ambitious goal of eventually delivering levels of spending on state schools to rival the independent sector.

In a speech to the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' conference in Torquay, the prime minister called on delegates to help him persuade voters of the case for investment in public services rather than tax cuts as he pledged real term increases in education spending "year on year on year on year".

He said: "My aim and objective is to get to a situation where you have a state education system that's as good in its facilities and investment as the independent sector. I think that's really what children need."

The government would need to increase the £23bn spent on education in England to around £40bn this year to match levels in independent schools. Funding per pupil this year is at £3,690, compared with typical independent school fees of £5,700 for day pupils.

Mr Blair, a product of the Durham Choristers and Fettes College, Edinburgh, both independent schools, said: "I would never have become prime minister or an MP or anything like that if I hadn't had a decent education. I know I was lucky but I also know there are millions of our children and adults that haven't been so lucky and deserve the same life chance as I had."

He defended the public spending squeeze in the first two years of the government but said spending overall had increased by £540 per pupil in real terms since 1997 compared with an £80 cut in the final three years of the Tory government. Mr Blair went on: "For a century or more, Britain has educated the top 20% as well as anywhere in the world. But we have not yet managed to achieve the vital goal for any dynamic country: excellent education not for the few but for the many.

"The only way we will get consensus from people for this money to go in is if investment is matched by reform."

Mr Blair, the first prime minister to speak to a teachers' conference, was greeted with a standing ovation when he arrived but his speech met a subdued reception.

When ATL delegate Ruksana Hussain, a trainee, asked him to deliver a £20,000 starting salary for teachers, Mr Blair said there were other expenditure demands to meet as well.

He skirted away from a demand from Julia Neal, a teacher at Torquay grammar school for girls, that he apologise for the remark about "bog-standard comprehensives" made by his official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, when the government unveiled its schools green paper in February. "I think it's important that we don't get hung up on phrases," Mr Blair said as some in the audience groaned.

An extra £33m was announced yesterday to fund 50 more specialist schools, the green paper's centrepiece, by 2002. Some 1,500 will be created within five years, but Mr Blair confirmed that figure was "a stepping stone, not a ceiling". He also promised a "proper strategic review" of classroom bureaucracy, but did not promise to include pay in the review.

 The National Union of Teachers said last night it would suspend industrial action over teacher shortages to enter into talks over pay and conditions with the government and the local government association.

fields.headline: A school sweetener
fields.standfirst:
Education maintenance allowances and learning contracts are proving to be the magic formula to keep disadvantaged children in education

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Thousands more 16-year-olds are staying on in education thanks to new education maintenance allowances (EMAs). They have so far been paid in a number of pilot areas. Extended nationwide the scheme will make a dramatic impact on the life-chances of disadvantaged young people.
fields.body:
Thousands more 16-year-olds are staying on in education thanks to new education maintenance allowances (EMAs). They have so far been paid in a number of pilot areas. Extended nationwide the scheme will make a dramatic impact on the life-chances of disadvantaged young people.

If they remain in full-time education, an EMA of up to £40 a week is awarded to 16 to 19-year-olds whose parents' income is less than £30,000. An additional bonus (£50) is granted when learning targets are achieved. A new smart card will record points earned for achieving learning goals and entitle the student to a range of goodies - a free session at the swimming pool, even a fast food voucher. In exchange, the student must sign a contract pledging full attendance and completion of assignments. If the contract is broken, the payment is forfeited.

EMAs have encouraged on average an additional 5% of young people from low-income families to stay in full-time education. They have been extremely effective with boys - an additional 6% in urban and 10.9% in rural areas resisted the temptation to flee the classroom. The very poorest students seem to have benefited the most. An extra 7% of students eligible for the full award stayed on compared to 2.9% of students with higher parental income. EMAs have also reduced the number of drop-outs. One college reported a 92% retention rate among EMA students compared to the average rate of 85%.

The educational achievement of boys has been the subject of increasing concern. Their disaffection may be exacerbated by the perceived "feminisation" of education. Women outnumber men as teachers and girls are outperforming boys. The cash payment may mean that their masculine credentials are no longer compromised by staying at school while their mates celebrate their first pay packet. Cash payment has proved to be the most effective incentive for men to become teachers. The number of male applicants for teacher training courses has risen at approximately twice the rate of female applicants since the introduction of the £6,000 bursary.

The success of cash incentives may be linked to the increasing numbers of young people in part-time work while in full-time education. A recent survey puts the figure at 75-80% of 16 to 19-year-olds. A quarter of children under 13 and 35% of 13-year-olds have had paid jobs in the last year. The phenomenon is self-perpetuating. The "earning" majority will determine the income level required for the social activities of the peer group. Young people become rapidly accustomed to the extra money. Work has a more central role in the lives of young people than ever before.

The learning contract is often perceived as the stick to counter the cash carrot. But it may elevate the status of full-time study by officially recognising the value of what both parties contribute to the deal - the state's investment in the individual and the learner's efforts. The learning agreement mimics an employee contract, stating targets, defined expectations and stronger incentives.

The tight labour market has prompted many employers to promise relatively good career prospects to the young recruits they are eager to retain. So why should the young employee not only jeopardise a regular income and a promising career path but also incur thousands of pounds of debt to continue their education?

Risk is a key factor. Further or higher education is a much riskier option for the disadvantaged than the middle-class student. Research shows that most graduates are guaranteed a high wage premium. Yet rates of return carry little weight in the absence of successful graduate role models.

A degree may be a sound investment but its an unknown quantity for many young people. Uncertainty about standards expected at college and a profound lack of self-confidence compound the risk factor. The social and financial capital of the middle class provides a safety net and a second chance in case something goes wrong. For students from disadvantaged backgrounds, the stakes are much higher.

Although consumer debt has risen by 60% in past years, focus groups suggest that the majority are still highly averse to borrowing for learning. According to the Citizens Advice Bureau increasing numbers of people are experiencing difficul ties in managing their debts. The cruel irony persists that the most disadvantaged often acquire them on the least advantageous terms.

There are significant differences in perception of borrowing amongst different social groups. Debt is still stigmatised in many working-class communities while it is often viewed as investment or credit by the middle classes. The fact that loans with interest are effectively prohibited by Muslims for cultural and religious reasons may account for the fact that only 51% of Asian students took out a loan compared to the national average of 72%.

Debt aversion may be preventing the very groups that the government is targeting from pursuing their education. Two-thirds of the respondents to a recent survey for the Department for Education and Employment claimed that a member of their peer group had opted not to go into higher education due to worries about debt. This was asserted most strongly by black students and those from social classes IV and V. Such reports inevitably overestimate the extent of hardship. But irrespective of reality, the perception of student life as a financial struggle and confusion over student support deters the disadvantaged. The majority are not aware of the fact that almost 50% are exempt from fees.

The government's argument that individuals should take responsibility for investing in their own learning is persuasive. However, some groups face a powerful phalanx of deterrents and need much stronger support. Targeted financial assistance contingent upon a mutually agreed contract may be the magic formula.

 Wendy Piatt is research fellow in education at the Institute for Public Policy Research

webTitle: The rise and rise of Phoebe Philo

fields.headline: Pole position
fields.standfirst: For years she was Stella McCartney's collaborator at Chloe. Now she has been elevated to creative director. Charlie Porter on the rise and rise of Phoebe Philo
fields.trailText: For years she was Stella McCartney's collaborator at Chloe. Now she has been elevated to creative director. Charlie Porter on the rise and rise of Phoebe Philo
fields.body:
Until now, Phoebe Philo has only ever designed one collection of her own. In 1996, then aged 22, Philo left London's famed fashion college, Central St Martins, with a 2:1 degree and a graduation show of Latino influence and huge gold jewellery which showed her ability both to cut and to style. It has taken five years but Philo is starting to prepare her second presentation, only now it is for higher stakes. This week, it was announced that she is to take over from her friend Stella McCartney as creative director at Chloe.

These days, fashion houses usually want a big name to bring to the label their own widely-recognised style. When Alexander McQueen got the job at Givenchy, for instance, everyone knew to expect a version of his usual shock tactics and strong-shouldered trouser suits. In 1997, at McCartney's Chloe debut, the mix of contemporary and antique was no surprise, as she had already designed a couple of widely-publicised collections at her west London flat. But this time around, neither industry insiders nor the legions of women who buy the Chloe label knows what to expect, as Philo has never been tested in public.

Of course, anyone who has followed McCartney's rise will know of Philo, the trusted collaborator who joined her in Paris to help make the ateliers at Chloe feel like home. The pair stripped back the offices to the floorboards and stuck magazine cutouts on the wall to make their "crazy freak zone", which apparently included images of Isabella Blow and Karl Lagerfeld, and a photo of Phoebe and Stella captioned "Baby Spice and Ginger Spice on da piss".

They became friends at St Martins where McCartney had been in the year above Philo on the BA course in Fashion Design, Womenswear. From there, both graduated with the kind of accomplished collections destined to lead to jobs in the industry.

Though Philo's degree show was said to be beautiful, it gained no coverage, and the file on her work at St Martins has since gone missing. In contrast, McCartney's collection featured Kate Moss and Naomi Campbell, was attended by her mother and father, Linda and Paul McCartney, and the next day was splashed all over the national press.

Philo, from Harrow-on-the-Hill, was then heavily influenced by the ragga look or, as she has described it, "hardcore little LA bitches with black lipstick, the sort you wouldn't mess around with". At the time, she was sporting a set of gold teeth. "I wanted to get a council flat, wear sovereigns and have a laugh, and I did for a while."

McCartney, however, describes Philo as "a bit posher than me. I always take the piss out of her."

Philo shares McCartney's love of horses. "If I wasn't in fashion, then I'd like to be an Olympic showjumper. It takes more dedication than money. You have to be up at 3.30 in the morning, whatever the weather."

On graduating, Philo found work assisting Pam Blundell, half of the London label Copperwheat Blundell, before McCartney asked her to help out on her fledgling label. "We spent the afternoons in her garage, or if the weather was good we would work in the garden, wearing our bikinis," she says.

When McCartney was head-hunted by Chloe in March 1997, Philo was not expecting to go with her, but less than a year after her own graduation, she was in discussion with Chloe about her salary. "I remember going to see them about my contract and thinking, what are you doing? What are you going to say?" she says. "Breathe in through your nose and out through your mouth."

At the time, Philo's role with McCartney was described by The Face as "stylist, friend, casting adviser, therapist, muse and right-hand woman". But, she says: "I really put my heels down about being her PA."

Throughout her time at Chloe, there have been rumours about the size of Philo's contribution to the overall collection. Many have suggested her role at the label was more than that of just muse. Indeed, when Chloe president Ralph Toledano spoke about his new creative director earlier in the week, he seemed to back the rumours by stating: "On the one side, we all love Stella, but on the other it is important for the house to maintain its identity. With Phoebe, we will continue in the same direction."

During the pair's time to gether at Chloe, Philo was indignant about the stories. "I've heard those bullshit stories about designers who don't see the collection until five minutes before it comes out," she says. fields.headline: Is Viagra kosher for Passover?
fields.standfirst: Police inspect everything from food to pharmaceuticals throughout the Jewish holiday, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: Passover police inspect everything from food to pharmaceuticals throughout the Jewish holiday, writes Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem.
fields.body:
They call them the bread police, and they were out in force this week scouring cafes for the telltale crumbs that fall foul of the dietary laws governing the Jewish holiday of Passover.

The seven-day festival, celebrating the exodus of the biblical Israelites from slavery in Egypt, ends at sunset on Saturday. In tribute to the sacrifices made by their forefathers during their escape, observant Jews forego leavened bread, a definition that encompasses not only loaves, cookies and cakes, but pasta, beer, whiskey and even perfume.

It is not illegal to eat or even sell bread; but it is against the law to put hametz - or leavened goods - on public display. The Israeli government was never zealous about enforcement until this year, however, when inspectors turned up in commercial kitchens and at cafe tables.

They imposed fines of 100 shekels (£17) wherever they spotted hametz, and opened up a new round in Israel's culture wars.

"We are going towards a theocracy," said Joseph Partizky, a member of Israel's parliament from the fanatically secular Shinui party. "This is the first year that inspectors of the bread police have gone out to hunt down the famous criminals who eat bread during Passover. I can only hope that offenders will not be stoned in the city markets."

The man who ordered the hunt for hametz offenders was unmoved. "A law is a law and it has to be respected," said Eli Yishai, the interior minister from the Shas party, an amalgam of ethnic pride and ultraorthodox Judaism. "For some reason, these people only object to a law with religious connotations."

It is unsure how this week's battle royale between the ultraorthodox, who exert a disproportionate influence on the political and religious establishment, and fanatical secular Jews like Mr Partizky is viewed by the majority of Israelis.

One opinion poll this week claimed that 66% of Israeli citizens wanted to eat only kosher foods during Passover, but most were unconcerned what others did.

But the heat generated by the debate is telling of the exacting preparations required for the festival. So dedicated are the efforts to purge every last bread crumb from the holy city of Jerusalem that the water company switches the spigot on its usual source from the sea of Galilee to underground wells to safeguard against contamination.

Supermarkets tape white sheets of paper over shelves containing hametz, and pharmacies keep charts advising which medications are permitted for the festival week. On the eve of the holiday there was a vigorous debate in the Israeli press on whether Viagra was kosher for Passover.

Many restaurants close altogether; some put little baskets of matzot, the wafers that replace bread, on the table. And others are defiantly unkosher, serving up concoctions of meat and cheese, pork and seafood that manage to violate several dietary laws at once, and bread, the ultimate hametz.

The inspectors, who are normally engaged in enforcing minimum wage laws, have fined only a few dozen restaurants across the country. But that has not diminished Mr Paritzky's wrath, or the ire of secular militants.

This week, Shinui activists fanned out in Tel Aviv, Jerusalem, and other cities, handing out fliers reading: "Hametz is not a drug", and urging cafe owners to fight their fines in court.

Mr Paritzky claims the newfound vigilance of the Passover police is a result of the rising power of Shas, a party that successfully fused ethnic pride and ultraorthodoxy to become the kingmaker in successive coalition governments. Shas controls the interior ministry in the hardline coalition of Ariel Sharon. "It is pure religious coercion," he said. "There is really no other purpose to this law except in imposing ultraorthodox religious behaviour on people who are not believers."

Dudi Bar-Chen would agree. For the last five years, the owner of Trio, a cafe off the main pedestrian mall that has a cult following among young Jerusalemites, has elevated his sparring with the religious police into an amateur sport.

He has been fined repeatedly for such sins as playing music, or seating customers outside on the Jewish sabbath - although he is licensed for both on weekdays - and has managed on some occasions to successfully argue his case in court.

Mr Bar-Chen plans to do the same with his hametz fine. "They know I won't pay the fine, but we have a long romance, the religious police and I; this is a ritual."

But the defenders of the new regime are not so philosophical. Sloughing off criticism even from the ultraorthodox, who say the hunt for hametz is antagonising less observant Jews and strives for an impossible level of purity, Shas announced this week it plans to raise the fines to a hefty 3,000 shekels (£522).

"We live in a Jewish state, not in France or England," said Shas member of parliament David Azulai. "It is very serious that a small group, for reasons of greed, is willing to sell the few Jewish characteristics left in the state of Israel."

webTitle: Britten: Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings

fields.headline: Britten: Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings
fields.standfirst: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Benjamin Britten's Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Benjamin Britten's Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings
fields.body:
Britten: Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings

Benjamin Britten's music of the early 1940s was dominated by Peter Grimes, but there were other substantial pieces from this period too. The most important is Serenade, the setting of six English poems for tenor, solo horn and string orchestra that he completed in 1943.

It was the first large-scale work he had written specifically for Peter Pears, and it was also a response to the extraordinary artistry of the horn player Dennis Brain. The solo horn opens the work, adds perfectly imagined atmosphere to the songs, and then, in Pears's words, "winds the work into stillness".

Pears's own recordings are the benchmark. There are two available on CD - the earlier, recorded in 1944 with the Boyd Neel String Orchestra conducted by Britten (Pearl), also has Brain as soloist: his playing is little short of miraculous. Pears's voice is fresher than in the studio version with Barry Tuckwell and the London Symphony Orchestra, again under Britten, made 20 years later (Decca), but the later recording is superior.

Anyone not allergic to Pears's very English timbre need look no further than that Decca CD. For those who are, there is plenty of choice, for almost every subsequent English lyric tenor has recorded the work, not to mention distinguished overseas competitors such as Peter Schreier (Campion), Christoph Pregardien (BIS) and Jerry Hadley (Nimbus).

Ian Bostridge will surely supersede his own version with Ingo Metzmacher and the Bamberg Symphony (EMI), while John Mark Ainsley, with the splendid horn player David Pyatt, needs better orchestral playing than that provided by the Britten Sinfonia under Nicholas Cleobury (EMI Eminence).

But Robert Tear provides a 1988 interpretation with the Chicago Symphony under Giulini that combines Pears's close attention to every morsel of the text with a firmer, more even tone. It is perhaps the best all-round choice.

· Key Recording: Tear (Deutsche Grammophon)

fields.headline: The competition so far...
fields.standfirst: A selection of entries to our SMS text-message poetry competition
fields.trailText: A selection of entries to our SMS text-message poetry competition
fields.body:
Friday April 13

When I go shopping

Sometimes

Bison

Chase me round the aisles

Or crocodiles

Snap at my smiles

Even snakes

Have been seen

To fall on my head

Spring cleaning

In the dust on the table,

You wrote 'I love you.'

Today I polished the furniture.

Her face

Take a bus from its shelter

Returning stolen goods

The city, a ripened screen saver

Tank tracks through drifting mud

Disintegrates when I see her face.

Obscurity

I like your name

It suits your face

I like your clothes

I like your place

In this world of obscurity

In a bottle-green dress,

U look like champagne,

Hair fizzing down yr face.

Bottle blonde, tho that's no sin.

It suits the flirty, fiery mood u r in.

Drying her hair in the ladies

The man-hater who forgot her umbrella

When outside it's raining men.

Thursday 12 April

Info-skint
Chx cashd no ?s askd
U stop T play th game
Rcade as th lite ramraids
Yr c-thru skin + th rain raps
A dgtl code, th air bitmaps
+ yr last coin c'rodes

Shall I compare thee 2 a London day?
Thou art more pissy + more cold;
The homeless shake their Big Issues,
Whilst u grapple with your small ones...

Many miles
Many miles may part us
But the smile inside of me
Is wide enough 4 U 2 sit on &
Slide down all the way into my arms.

There were toy guns and pretzels
And we were dancing in a garden
At 5 in the morning
The one day in April it didn't rain

Junkies
Sedentary urgency.
Full but never wholly.
Earthed but strung up good.
Attendants of an early so low wake.

I dreamed my two front teeth
Were dancing,
Flirting with my tongue

I depress the plastic keys as I sink further into repetition.
Turning biro into binary in insignificant increments.

Wednesday 11 April

the mind overwintering...
ice-flowers of forgetfulness
cool the brain's rebellious thud...
until the moment the sun hits the skin...
and we remember

yael's dance class:
bodies in new, alien movement -
lands where geographers are themselves
the unvisited landscapes they map
with ink of muscles, skin, emotions

my lesson was planned.
the guardian was in my hand.
i'd had an idea
(but mobiles were banned)
1e said the lesson was cool.
i broke the rule.
i made a stand.

emoticonvicts with limited characters pass solitary sentences on the mobile phone. no call-bars between textual lovers; cellular mates are never alone.

'we'd like to apologise to our customers'.
bar the voices, all is still.
countryside ages as i watch.
virgin on the ridiculous,
i could be dead on arrival.

next 4 txt language is e-volving,
u get the messge?
mobile words, with letters deleted,
but not characterless?
communic8, abbrevi8, in2a new 4m@

Tuesday 10 April

perhaps this is a poem,
even though it's not that long:
accompanied by a dialing tone,
would it then be a song?

on the tube wishing i was six foot six,
then i wouldn't be surrounded by smelly armpits

forever, i and my father will live in the space where she should be,
keep her chair free,
think of her silently,
and wrestle every day with our fondest memories.

Monday 9 April

Cold Shoulder
Just to tell you,
The book is closed.
I read the last page,
And I know how it goes.

She hid bony knees under stinking coal.
Her small white hands wrapped around fresh-picked bluebells.

London 1995
The raingrey eternal day
and sodium drench of night,
The dust-fat smells of cheap hotels;
The inns, the outs, the doors, the yells.

Voter! You've been selected
to vote 4 Tony Blair in the next election.
Pass this message on 2 4 other people
Or risk 4 years bad luck.
May the spin be with you.

Ubelongwithmeinthesordid70s
Inthedullearlyeveningglowoflateautumn
InLondon'sdrystreetswheremeninraincoatscrossover
Andbrowncarsmoveslowlythroughoutofdatelitter

I'm tired, I'm bored and I've had enough,
I'd destroy the world but it's where
I keep all my stuff.

Friday 6 April

Transition
Back in lipstick again.
You're gone.
No more shirts to stain.
Now she'll never know.

News
Y am I sppsd 2 care,
If Rob hs slpt w ger,
If Sofe hs bdmthd blr,
If Lise shot man w n hr?

Sleepers
Rotting planks rotting rails
Dead can debris dead rat tails
'Let it be' if all else fails
Sleepers running down our rails

When you marry
And have twins
Don't come running to me
For those safety pins.

2 yr olds hang-offov metros
shoutin aa lv u without knowin its coin
survivors trainsurfin
curve of possibilities
1stop down the line

Thursday 5 April

Happy yet?
Sad thoughts pulse.
Insistently pulse.
Reach the surface + breathe.
Burst the bubble.
Smile til your cheeks hurt.
Smile til you mean it.

Pls, stop sendg msgs2ths
No, I am not Linda,
I hv not slept w/yr sis,
+ I wd nvr call any1's ma a slag.
Gd luk w/viag.
Luv, yr wrong no. xxx

Forgive me
Forgive me
I hid away your jumper
with tumbling fishes
In a deep drawer
in my mother's Italian house
Your middle earth smell
is buried deep in it.

Wednesday 4 April

Stormbrew
Through foggy air where the old drunks sang
& lovers conspired in corners
his eyes a startled blue
as if he'd caught a sky in them

I 12 c u do u 12 c me? t 42 at 3?

The undertaker said,
I surely would have done so,
But my battery was dead

Scribes whose diatribes inform us
Our country has been stolen
Wear beer bellies, when hurling plastic chairs
Across Belgian squares

Snogrott Patula,
Vimon Shimes
Ambulant Minerva
Cramom Jhosh
I'm going to drivel
from coast to coast

Tuesday 3 April

Damn Marconi
No telephone call, no email, no txt
What will they invent to disappoint me nxt?

"Tickets please!"
Sent a look 2 ur eyes
A mirror of mine
Of shock and surprise
Ur coy pretty smile
I took as a sign
2 follow u down
Thus avoiding a fine

wrtng txt mssg pms wtht vwls dsnt wrk prply vowels stop consonants sticking together like clstrs f czchslvkn crrnts

phoney poetry
spring time
text rhyme
small size
big prize
nation gripped
sending script
end result
next cult ?

angel faced angel face
bottle blonde baby,
a sign there's a heaven above;
with lips made for kisses,
+ eyes bright delicious,
+ wisecracks that fit like a glove

Monday 2 April

There r not enough x's and o's in our virtual world 2 send 2 u

Stuck in traffic.
This phone is immobile

Denim jeans, wlking dwn the st,
A twst, a sashay, a dlite 2 c.
Dsn't mttr wots insde m,
Just as lng as its 0 tryng 2 gt out.
Bootlg, hls, jckt & styl.
All wrks 4 me.

Dressed in black & white,
Taken off daily at 8.30
To fulfill the realms of possibilities

Friday 30 March

Passion is never spent -
Passion is slaughtered -
My stubborn passion
Was hung drawn and 1/4d

After Birth
Two days after the birth
She floated uphill
On legs soft as noodles
Breasts hard as tennis balls
And heart newly peeled

News Flash
News fl#,
Train cr#,
MP smokes #,
NHS needs c#,
Floods cause major spl#,
FMD spreads like r#,
Cashcow - ashnow

I can't decide if the storm I'm travelling through
is the inspiration or the subject.
I'm too fascinated by its rainbow
and its lightning.

I rubbed lotion into her skin that day
Ran my finger through her hair.
My sandals were full of sand that day,
I remember how little I cared.

You say you can describe me in 44 letters
(brn hr, grn eyes, av IQ, 2 prnts, 1 bro, 1 dog. N Ldn tnage @comp schl.)

Thursday March 29

How paranoid of Sigmund Freud

Txt me Friday if you like,

fields.headline: Renée Zellweger: No, I'm not Bridget Jones. Not yet
fields.standfirst: Renée Zellweger has done the unthinkable - shown a bit of cellulite on the big screen.  Libby Brooks  talks to the Texan star about women, body image and pizza
fields.trailText: Renée Zellweger has done the unthinkable - shown a bit of cellulite on the big screen. Libby Brooks talks to the Texan star about women, body image and pizza
fields.body:
Renée Zellweger would rather have a headache. "I wish I was hungover from last night honey, I wish ." She flops into an armchair and crosses her legs for emphasis. "I didn't really have the chance to get a drink. I went over to the bar at one point and carried the glass around for the rest of the night." She fits her fists to her hips and bellows hysterically, a pocket Calamity Jane. It is the morning after the night before. The premiere of Bridget Jones's Diary was a noisy, glossy affair. But who was she most excited to meet? The mothers of Helen Fielding ("who looks exactly like her") and Richard Curtis ("very sweet") get top billing. She doesn't have to act delightful.

Zellweger is in rude good health. Her apple cheeks are scrubbed and rosy, her deep-set eyes shine like damp diamonds. And yes, she is thin - tiny-waisted, pre-teen-chested. Her arms are covered by a long-sleeved top but I'll warrant her triceps are well-defined. Riffing on her assistant's new hairstyle, she throws out: "This is much more interesting than some dumb actress prattling on about her experiences with pizza !" She's laughing, but she spits the word like it's swearing.

Of course, Zellweger's experiences with pizza have taken on mythic proportions. In order to play the eponymous heroine in the film of Helen Fielding's bestseller, the actress gained 17lb, consulting a dietician and endocrinologist who devised a regime of three full meals a day, multiple snacks and no exercise.

According to the film's costume designer, Rachael Fleming, Zellweger would wail "I'm so fat! I'm so fat!" each day, comparing her stomach with that of Fleming, who was eight months pregnant. Rumour has it that Harper's Bazaar magazine refused to use her on their cover because she was too heavy, though Zellweger herself politely deflects this with the explanation that she was tired at the time of the shoot and "probably looked like road kill". But recent press reports that she has declined to sign up for a sequel have inevitably been interpreted in the light of the perils of a full fridge.

Yet onscreen, the results of her De Niro-esque efforts are little short of astounding. It is as shocking as it is joyous to watch Bridget's thighs dimple as she hoicks herself into a gargantuan pair of tummy control pants and realise that you have never - not once - seen cellulite on the big screen before. She looks real - fleshy, female, sexy as hell. It's a triumphant transformation to observe, if not to undergo.

As a whole, 32-year-old Zellweger's performance is rather magnificent. It's a tough call to translate a character as phenomenal and ubiquitous as Bridget Jones, and she meets the challenge amply. Though her vowels are a little more Pony Club than you would have imagined, she crystallises the character's combination of good-hearted vulnerability, knowing hopelessness and game humour impressively. Not bad for the Texan who ignited Little Englander angst when she was chosen for the role over the likes of Kate Winslet, inciting London's Evening Standard to liken the casting to "remaking The Elephant Man with Jude Law".

While she doesn't dismiss the weight of expectation, she frames it in terms of responsibility: "The pressure was more of an internal thing, it was a respect for Helen Fielding and what she'd created and an understanding that I was not alone in loving this character." She often betrays a fretful concern that others won't be let down by her. When talking seriously, she sets her knees together and gazes with intensity, all homespun polite and girl-friendly confidences. Her voice is deliciously twangy, with the breath control of Monroe. She's an intelligent, if rambling conversationalist, layering clauses and images.

"Obviously I related to the female aspect [of the character], her day-to-day regimen and fight against Mother Nature. On a more significant level, I'm about to enter the stage of life that Bridget is experiencing and I, like so many people, understood her quest. I understood her search for self-acceptance and her daily attempt to define what is going to bring her happiness in life, her struggle to differentiate between what it is that she wants for her life and what it is that society expects from her."

What does society expect from women of Zellweger's age? "It's changing, and it's really an interesting time right now. Bridget is of the last generation that is trying to slip through that antiquated social definition of success regarding women, in terms of being the cornerstone of a nurturing family unit; in other words if you don't get married and you're not celebrated in that regard by a man, then you've failed in some way."

It is also significant that her generation doesn't regard women's increasing visibility in positions of power as being unusual. "They don't see that as, 'Oh, isn't it great that there's a female secretary of state, a female governor in Texas.' So the ceiling has been presented: here's what you can achieve now as a woman in terms of family and home, and here's what you can achieve in terms of contributing professionally in society. So you want to do both, right? And if you don't reach the ceiling in one or the other or both, have you failed in some way?"

One charge regularly levelled against the character she plays is that she is reductive, regressive, portraying women as neurotic, self-obsessed and man-mad. How does she answer critics who say Bridget is an anti-feminist construct? "She faces those dilemmas with humour. She's aware that she's self-aware, which makes her not pathetic, and she's self- deprecating but in a humorous way that makes her not loathsome and not superficial. It's wonderful that Helen Fielding is so honest about our insecurities as human beings."

Nor are those insecurities gender-specific, she argues. "If you look at it on a superficial level, yes it is about a woman and her daily challenges and her laughing about these things that ultimately shouldn't matter. But if you look deeper, it goes way beyond that, and it's not age-specific or culturally specific either. It's the search for who you are, trying to define yourself and really figure out what makes you happy in life."

"I don't think [Bridget Jones is] a setback for women. If you look through the course of the book, and the film as well, she really comes into her own on her own. She decides to be happy now and not in some projected myth of what the future might hold and the happiness that might bring. She blossoms, and if that's not a positive feminist message, I don't know what is."

Born and raised in Katy, a country town in Texas, Zellweger studied English at university before moving to Los Angeles to pursue her acting career. She was championed by Tom Cruise, who chose her to play his love interest in the film Jerry Maguire and credited her with "revealing the core humanity of the movie". Lately, Zellweger has branched off into comedy, making Me, Myself and Irene with Jim Carrey, whom she dated for a year before the couple split up last December, and winning a Golden Globe for her role as a soap-opera obsessive in Nurse Betty. She is curious, she says, rather than ambitious. "Yeah, I want to be able to take care of myself, so I will really work hard in order to able to achieve that. But I'm not ambitious for that myth of what success is. I'm not trying to get anywhere."

And is she really so bored of talking about her pizza intake? "I understand why it's interesting," she drawls with heavy irony, "and believe me, for the first week it was very interesting, going to DiMario's every day." She switches to an itty-bitty baby voice: " 'Yes, I would like the pizza, and the garlic bread too, because it's my responsibility, and I'll have the cream sauce linguine, for the good of the film, and a chocolate shake, and a Guinness.' I understand the intrigue. It sounds like it would be such a liberating experience, but I hope that that won't be what becomes most important."

Does she think that British women are more aware of body image issues than their American counterparts? "I'd say the contrary, although it's specific to particular subcultures, because each subculture values different qualities in physicality. Where I live, for example, there is probably a hyper-awareness of health and how to maintain health. In most places in the world," she says, taking a schoolmarmish tone, "it's very exciting if you just have enough to eat and you've fed your family and you don't run out before everyone's had seconds."

So was Bridget - and consequently herself playing Bridget - fat? "No," she says wearily. "She has a different body type to me, but it reflects the different lifestyles that we lead, and that's what she chooses. It makes her happy to have Chardonnay and some extra Milk Tray, so why shouldn't she?" Then would she say that Bridget was a normal size? "What's normal? Kate Moss is normal - her genetic make-up has dictated that this is how she'll look. For Bridget, who is voluptuous and doesn't go to the gym on a daily basis - that's definitely normal. Not less attractive, not less beautiful, than someone who weighs 20lb less." It's not as though the character had an obesity problem, she says. It was never about fat. "It was about trying to meet a particular media-projected paradigm of what beauty is right now, and unfortunately it's air-brushed and it's 7ft tall, because that happens to be what makes clothes look really good according to some."

But as a woman working in an industry where that aesthetic is a given, how does she deal with that pressure personally? "I try not to make it part of my day," she says with steely dismissal. "I try to take care of myself because I get tired if I don't, from the schedule that I keep. I like to play outside. I like to run up the hill with my dog because it makes me happy. I like to go to the gym because it leaves me psychologically more balanced than if I didn't."

It suddenly feels extremely rude to be sitting in a room with a stranger, suggesting that she might be underweight, or freakish, or Letting Women Down by losing the weight again. It is ever vexed, this question of the ideal female form. We're as keen on the unhappy thin as we are on the cheerful fat. We are so desperate for signs of flesh that we're prepared to hang decades of debate off the ankles, slender or otherwise, of one woman. The truth is, Ren#ée's 17lb won't alter the aesthetic one inch. But perhaps Bridget has helped challenge it.

webTitle: Do Americans understand foot and mouth?

fields.headline: 'Is that the one where you have to burn your shoes?'
fields.standfirst:
The number of Americans visiting Britain has dropped dramatically since the outbreak of foot and mouth. But do they really get what it's all about? To find out, Emma Brockes dons a white coat and trawls London's tourist hotspots armed with a clipboard and a tray of gas masks

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The number of Americans visiting Britain has dropped dramatically since the outbreak of foot and mouth. But do they really get what it's all about? To find out, Emma Brockes dons a white coat and trawls London's tourist hotspots armed with a clipboard and a tray of gas masks
fields.body:
We enter Leicester Square at noon, posing in white coats as researchers from the "British Tourist Centre". I carry a clipboard, and my colleague Neil Chatterjee lugs a tray of mildewy gas masks hired from an army surplus shop in north London. Our intention is to find out how American tourists perceive the foot and mouth crisis by asking them questions, then offering them a gas mask. Will we be instantly rumbled as pranksters? Or will the white coats and monstrous respirators fit so neatly into the visitors' view of Britain that they pass unnoticed?

First up is Wade from Oklahoma. He is standing with his elderly parents in a queue for West End theatre tickets. With impeccable manners, Wade pretends not to notice the lab coats and breathing apparatus - or at least fails to ask what we, tourism researchers, might be doing with them. Wade made a will shortly before coming to Britain. Yes, he says, he was warned about the dangers of the British countryside. "You have all sorts of venereal disease out there," he says kindly. "And, of course, hoof and mouth." Because of the rumours, he and his parents haven't ventured beyond zone 6 of the London underground. "You get bloated," says Wade's mum. "Then you run through the streets screaming." And how does one contract the disease? "They don't tell us," says Wade, darkly. "But we know not to eat brain." Each would be prepared to suffer a short period of quarantine before returning to the US, although not in a British hospital. As we part, Wade's dad winks and tips me a dollar.

Outside the National Portrait Gallery, Janis and Cari from Washington consider the question: "Would you feel safe drinking British milk?" They have shown a thorough knowledge of BSE as well as foot and mouth, and are aware that the latter doesn't affect humans. None the less, Janis, an account executive, has grave doubts about British dairy products. "In the US, milk is, like, 2% fat," she says, skilfully conflating issues. "But you all drink whole milk. So I would probably avoid it." I ask them what they would do if they saw a cow behaving strangely. "We would tell someone," says Cari confidently. What about a sheep? "Same thing." And a pigeon? "Well, I keep parakeets," says Cari, "so I'm quite familiar with bird behaviour. If I saw a pigeon acting strangely in Trafalgar Square, I would definitely contact the authorities. You remember that puppy we found in Fort Worth, Janis? I always try to help sick animals."

This is Neil's cue to step forward with the gas masks. "What's this?" asks Janis. It's a promotion, I say. Free gas masks for foreign visitors. The two women eye them suspiciously. Janis reaches for a rubber strap and, coming down on the side of like, immediately brightens. "Cool!" she says. "Can I really have one?" Sadly I am forced to reply: no, it is just a little Tourist Centre joke.

And so we adjourn to Trafalgar Square, where, before we can approach any tourists, Neil and I are rounded on by a bouncer in a neon vest known as a "heritage warden". Blinking rapidly, he tries to locate our behaviour within the framework of civil disobedience. "What's this?" he asks, scrutinising the masks for signs of illegal trading. I give him the Tourist Centre line. "You're asking people about foot and mouth disease?" he repeats slowly, eyes narrowing. Yes, I reply. Thinking about it for a moment, he concludes: "That's for a newspaper, isn't it?" The warden has rumbled us, and while he radios his supervisor with news of "two journalists carrying questionnaires and, er, gas masks", we make a dash for it up the steps, across three lanes of traffic and smack into a garment-centre executive and her family, from New York.

I ask if the US could ever succumb to such an epidemic. Ben's unblinking blue eyes grow wide and grave. "People are very ignorant and stubborn in America. Sure it could happen." "Especially with George Bush as president," his mother chips in with a flippancy lost on her son, who, with thankful recourse to childishness, has pulled on one of the gas masks and can be heard exclaiming "Cool!" through the muffled rubber. Thoroughly unnerved, I move on by taxi to the queue outside Madame Tussaud's.

Here I find Nick and Julie from Minnesota. Nick is a windscreen technician; Julie works in an accounts department. Since arriving in Britain 10 days ago, the couple have drunk only bottled water - nothing to do with the farming crisis, which Julie mistakenly perceives as some kind of tourist attraction. "Foot and mouth?" she says. "Oh no. We figured there's enough to do in the countryside without getting into that. We're not planning a special visit." Um, what about foot and mouth the highly contagious disease, I venture. "Is that the one where you have to burn your shoes?" asks Julie, but before we can get to the bottom of it, a Tussaud's steward has thrown me out of the queue. "Would you like a gas mask?" I ask hopefully, as we're ushered away. Julie gives me a very cold look. "No."

And so, finally, to Paddington station, where we are just in time to meet Amy and Carly, from Maryland, off the Heathrow Express. They are wilting under the weight of their backpacks, but energised enough to tell me about the time Amy's mum came to Britain and got sick from the water. "As a nurse," says Amy, "I obviously have to know about this foot and mouth stuff." Carly, a student, nods approvingly. "The key thing is to wash your hands. That is the best - the only - way to avoid getting it." Carly clears her throat. "Don't eat the beef!" she adds unexpectedly. I ask how a person knows if they've got the disease. "You get a rash around your mouth," says Amy. "That kind of thing." Carly opens her mouth to protest, but is silenced by her friend. "I'm a nurse," says Amy, chuckling. "I should know!" The offer of a gas mask prompts Amy to pat my arm. "Bless your heart," she says, apparently touched, and, shaking her head at the endless sweetness of the Brits, looks about for an exit.

fields.headline: All over bar the shooting
fields.standfirst:
Three years on, the Good Friday agreement is nowhere near delivering on its promises, says Derek Brown

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Three years on, the Good Friday agreement is nowhere near delivering on its promises, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Today marks the third anniversary of the Good Friday agreement, the deal which was supposed to open a new era of peace and reconciliation in Northern Ireland. It has done nothing of the sort.

Politically, the process has been marred by mutual suspicion and recrimination. In military terms, it has done little to draw the teeth of the seven or eight thuggish private armies still operating in the province.

For all that, the Good Friday deal has delivered much. It has restored power sharing, the only logical and honourable method of governing in Northern Ireland.

It has brought the British and Irish governments closer than ever before, with important implications for the future relationship of the islands. It has also made possible, through stability and investment, the transformation of the province's economy.

After three years, the positive consequences of Good Friday outweigh the negative residues of 30 years of conflict. But still the agreement is nowhere near delivering that permanent settlement that the people of Northern Ireland crave.

It is tempting, but too easy, to heap the blame on to the perpetually bickering and snarling politicians of Stormont. Most of those who support the agreement are brave people, taking high personal and political risks to defend their stance.

Men like David Trimble, first minister and Ulster Unionist leader, do not relish the constant accusation that they have sold out the loyalist community.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein leader who was almost certainly once chief of staff of the Provisional IRA, is despised by unionists, but not with the poisonous hatred reserved by hardline republicans for turncoats who tread with the British.

Trimble and Adams, and their cohorts, are politicians with very different constituencies. To preserve their mandates, they must defend what they see as their corners. That's politics. Unfortunately, it is also deadly to the central notion of Good Friday: mutual movement towards compromise.

The Ulster Unionists have fought tooth and nail to water down police reforms and cross border cooperation. Sinn Fein has strained every sinew to divert attention from the IRA's palpable failure to disarm. Those issues are at the heart of the stuttering, faltering nature of the peace process.

Now a new enemy is rearing up against Good Friday: democracy. The forthcoming general election could knock the props from under the process, by undermining or even destroying the mandate of the main pro-agreement parties.

On the loyalist side, Trimble's Ulster Unionists are under withering fire not only from the Rev Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party, but from a dissident wing within the party almost slaveringly eager to replace Trimble as leader.

On the nationalist side, Sinn Fein is poised to become a bigger electoral force than the moderately nationalist Social Democratic and Labour party. That is perilous for the peace process, for Sinn Fein is currently undergoing one of those fantasist phases peculiar to the ideologically blinkered.

This particular fantasy has been brought on by a wave of demographic speculation about the outcome of this month's census, which is widely expected to show the Catholic proportion of the population at around 46%.

Already, Sinn Fein theorists are dreaming out loud about ten-yearly referenda in which the province will be asked whether it wants to stay part of the UK or unite with the Republic. The first one, they say mistily, would almost certainly produce a pro-British result. Ah, but the next...

This is cock-and-bull of the most dangerous kind. To begin with, there is no certainty that Catholics will attain a majority, given their dramatically declining birthrate. Secondly, a pro-unity vote would not wipe out the divisions of Ireland, but amplify them enormously.

For if Britain (pop 59m) cannot contain the discontent of 0.75m Northern Ireland Catholics, how could a united Ireland (pop 5.75m) hope to contain the discontent of nearly a million Protestants?

Both these developments - the general election and the census - are diversions from the main issue, which is devising a system of governance which both communities in Northern Ireland, and both sovereign governments in London and Dublin, can endorse and trust.

The bones of such a system are in place, and indeed have a fair amount of flesh on them. The months ahead should see rapid progress towards police reform and cross border cooperation. They will also, of a dismal certainty, see renewed efforts by the hard men on both sides to destroy what has taken three painful years to build.

webTitle: US: it was the Chinese pilot's fault

fields.headline: US: it was the Chinese pilot's fault
fields.standfirst:
¥ Fighter pilot 'came within three feet' of spy plane
¥ China demands end to US surveillance flights

Special report: China
Martin Kettle: why Bush got angry
fields.trailText: Senior US diplomats have blamed a Chinese pilot for the collision between a fighter jet and a US Navy EP-3E spy plane.
fields.body:
Senior US diplomats have blamed a Chinese pilot for the collision between a fighter jet and a US Navy EP-3E spy plane.

They said his jet collided with the spy plane's left engine after twice flying within three feet of the aircraft. The officials said the Chinese jet then struck the plane's nose, snapped in half and plunged into the sea.

The disclosures were based in part on the debriefing of the spy plane's 24-member crew and added to US claims that the Chinese pilot caused the collision over the south China sea. The incident led to the detention of the American crew and an acrimonious 11-day standoff.

Also today, the wife of the missing Chinese pilot was quoted by state media as expressing sympathy to the families of the American crew for their long separation. "I wish the crew a safe journey," she was quoted as saying.

The diplomats said the US navy plane made 15 to 25 distress calls before making an emergency landing at a Chinese air base. The US version contradicted the account given by Chinese officials, who claim the American plane swerved into the fighter jet. They also said they did not hear any distress call and accuse the American pilot of illegally entering their airspace.

According to the diplomats:

 Two Chinese F-8 fighter planes took off from Hainan island to trail the US plane, which was on a surveillance mission 64 miles off the Chinese coast.
 One of the jets approached the four-engined American aircraft three times, from the left and behind. The first two passes came within three to five feet of the left wing.
 On the third pass, the Chinese pilot apparently realised he was closing in too fast and tried to swing his plane to cut speed. He allegedly hit the outer propeller on the left wing, the inner engine and then the US aircraft's nose.

The diplomats said they were unable to confirm the second Chinese pilot's claim that he requested permission to shoot down the American plane. They had no evidence that shots were fired.

The American pilot, Lieutenant Shane Osborn, decided to land his crippled aircraft at the Chinese air base on Hainan island, rather than having the crew bail out or ditch in the sea. Before landing, he made a 270-degree turn around the field, a standard signal that he was out of contact with the control tower, according to the diplomats. The second Chinese fighter had already landed and the runway was clear.

On the ground, the crew spent some 15 minutes destroying classified material. Heavily armed Chinese soldiers surrounded the plane, shouting through megaphones and waving their arms to get the crew off. "They made it clear they wanted us off that aircraft," the senior diplomats quoted Osborn as saying. The diplomats said the Chinese troops appeared to be "trying to get them to stop their procedures."

The Americans were extensively questioned by the Chinese.

Even as Beijing maintained today that Washington was to blame for the collision, the wife of missing pilot Wang Wei was quoted as saying she sympathized with American urgency to get their fliers home. "I can understand the feelings of the family members of the US plane's crew," Ruan Guoqin was quoted as saying by the Liberation Daily, China's military newspaper. Ruan's tone contrasted with a letter she wrote to Bush last week accusing him of being "cowardly; for not apologising for the incident.

China said today it will use a meeting next week to demand an end to surveillance flights near its coast.

"The US reconnaissance plane had intruded into China's airspace and rammed a Chinese fighter," today's official China Daily newspaper quoted Premier Zhu Rongji as saying. "The US side must take the entire responsibility for the plane collision incident."

fields.bodyText: Senior US diplomats have blamed a Chinese pilot for the collision between a fighter jet and a US Navy EP-3E spy plane. They said his jet collided with the spy plane's left engine after twice flying within three feet of the aircraft. The officials said the Chinese jet then struck the plane's nose, snapped in half and plunged into the sea. The disclosures were based in part on the debriefing of the spy plane's 24-member crew and added to US claims that the Chinese pilot caused the collision over the south China sea. The incident led to the detention of the American crew and an acrimonious 11-day standoff. Also today, the wife of the missing Chinese pilot was quoted by state media as expressing sympathy to the families of the American crew for their long separation. "I wish the crew a safe journey," she was quoted as saying. The diplomats said the US navy plane made 15 to 25 distress calls before making an emergency landing at a Chinese air base. The US version contradicted the account given by Chinese officials, who claim the American plane swerved into the fighter jet. They also said they did not hear any distress call and accuse the American pilot of illegally entering their airspace. webTitle: Open for business - if there is any

fields.headline: Open for business - if there is any
fields.standfirst:
Continuing our series of interviews with traders and others affected by the crisis, Derek Brown finds mixed signals in his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Continuing our series of regular interviews with traders and others affected by foot and mouth, Derek Brown finds mixed signals in his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
Usually, by this time of the year, the town is studded with trippers. You can always tell the visitors: they're the ones strolling slowly through the town, peering into shop windows, with cameras slung round their necks, and ordnance survey maps peeping out of their pockets.

The good news is that the spring migration has started. The predictable bad news is that it looks more like a trickle than a flood.

The butcher

John Kench's family butcher's shop on the high street (Topside, we call it) is strategically situated opposite the little tourist inquiry office in the Guildhall. "I've started to get them coming in. You can't always tell, but there are certain signs. If it's someone you haven't seen before and they look a bit lost and then they say they want a jar of honey and a pound of sausages, it's a fair bet you've got weekenders or people staying in a holiday cottage," he said.

John is in cheery mood. His business has picked up steadily since the early days of the crisis and after a couple of excellent weekends, Easter looks like bringing bumper interest in his all-British stock. Prices and supplies are still stable, too, with the curious exception of chickens - entirely unaffected by foot and mouth - which have become inexplicably dearer.

The supermarket manager

Tony Hatch at the Co-op supermarket has yet to see any real sign of the sales increase which normally goes with the start of the tourist season proper. "I'm still hoping for a bit of a pick-up. My biggest fear is that nobody will be coming to the countryside, and then we will lose that icing on the cake. Still, we seem to be doing roughly what we did this time last year," he said.

The Co-op is now back to selling mainly British meat. Though there is still New Zealand lamb on the shelves, bold notices proclaim that all beef and pork is now home-produced.

The restaurateur

There was a bustle of activity this lunchtime in Stones, the smart bar-restaurant in the town centre. But alas it wasn't a sudden influx of tourists, but rather the draw for two giant Easter eggs on behalf of the local Lions' Club. Owner Brian Galbraith, who has charmed and hustled his customers out of nearly £200 in the cause of charity, has enterprisingly rounded up the local press to cover the big event and garner some publicity for Stones. It needs it.

"It was another very poor Sunday again and the whole week's been very quiet," he said. And what of Easter bookings? Brian rolls his eyes heavenwards, and shakes his head briefly. Stones has been open only a few months and is still building up a local clientele. It seriously depends on a passing trade which, for two months now, has simply not materialised.

The farmer

Marilyn Ivings at Mill Farm in Church Enstone, has some unqualified good news to pass on. "I got on to the internet on Monday and pulled down an application form for an occasional movement licence. I took it to Chadlington on Tuesday morning for the vet to sign it. He faxed it into the ministry at Reading at quarter to two on Wednesday and they faxed it back at twenty to three," she said.

"People are quick enough to sling brickbats at them, so they deserve credit when they do the job as well as this. I think it's absolutely wonderful."

The licence will allow Marilyn to move her stock of suckler cows and newborn calves from their sheds on to fresh pasture which is only less than half a kilometre away, on the other side of a public road.

Meanwhile, a sheep farming neighbour is not allowed to move his ewes, which are about to lamb, from the field where they have spent the winter, to the lambing sheds on the other side of a small lane. Still, the ewes are in infinitely better shape than the ones regularly pictured on television, mired in mud only yards away from fresh green grass.

fields.standfirst:
Orion, £9.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: "By Toutatis, is that you, Obelix?"
fields.body:
"By Toutatis, is that you, Obelix?"

"Asterix, old friend, long time no see."

"It's been five years. We don't get out so much since poor old Goscinny died."

"So what are we up to this time?"

"The usual Doggybollox."

"I don't remember him."

"Get a life."

"Don't you mean Getafix?" asked the old druid.

"Go back to your magic potions," Asterix snapped. "Now, where was I? Ah yes! We're all sitting down to a village feast..."

"It's all beginning to come back," interrupted Obelix, scratching his head quizzically. "Don't tell me... I'm tucking into a whole wild boar and the Romans are terrified of us..."

"Quite remarkable," said the little warrior hero. "Are you sure you haven't read this story already?"

"No."

"Oh well. So it's our birthday and our mummies have come to be with us."

"That means they'll be spending a few pages trying to find us both a wife."

"Ho ho ho," the two Gauls cackled in unison. "We're too young for that sort of responsibility. Ha ha. The old ones are the best."

"Ah. But what about our daddies?" asked Obelix

"Sadly they've had to stay in Condatum to mind their Roman souvenir shop. But they have sent us a super sword and helmet instead."

"I can add them to my collection."

"Yes, but old soak, Tremensdelirius, who sold them to our dads, happened to nick them off Pompey, the Roman general, and he wants them back. He's too frightened to send his legions in, so he gets the actress La Traviata to dress up as Panacea, Tragicomix's beautiful wife, in the hope that her feminine charms will get the armour back."

"Cor, do we get to kiss her?"

"No, but she does ask to see our swords."

"Oo-er," they both snorted.

"And then?" Obelix continued.

"The real Panacea and Tragicomix turn up, and there's lots of confusion but everything ends happily ever after with another feast."

"So, do I still get to carve menhirs and bash loads of Romans?"

"Do ursae shit in the sylvae?"

"I'm still not too clear what it was all about, though."

"Pure Economix," replied Uderzo.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: France's most successful resistance fighters creak into action after a long lay-off and see off a few limp Romans with a few limp gags
