fields.headline: Billiton counters investor ire
fields.trailText: The mining group Billiton is on a collision course with its shareholders over plans to "reward" its chairman and chief executive, Brian Gilbertson, after its merger with BHP of Australia.
fields.body:
The mining group Billiton is on a collision course with its shareholders over plans to "reward" its chairman and chief executive, Brian Gilbertson, after its merger with BHP of Australia.

Those same shareholders would have found little to complain about yesterday, when the shares ended 7p higher at 347p.

This 2% rise in Billiton's shares took them to their highest levels for more than a year. The move provided a contrast to rival Rio Tinto, which ended 2% lower at £13.32 after issuing a cautious trading statement at its annual meeting.

Facing placard-waving protesters who were complaining about the company putting "principles before profits", Rio's chairman, Robert Wilson, insisted that 2001 would not be too bad, really.

Mr Gilbertson, his counterpart at Billiton, will be hoping the protesters stay away from the special meeting being called to ratify the merger with BHP, in the way that they did from Royal Bank of Scotland's agm on Wednesday, which allowed Sir George Mathewson and his fellow board directors to be spared some blushes over the special bonuses they received for the efforts in taking over NatWest.

Royal Bank, which has powered ahead in recent months, ended the day flat at £16.15, although rival banking groups were among the factors exerting a downward pull on the FTSE 100 yesterday.

The blue chip index ended a lacklustre pre-Easter holiday session trading down 21.5 points at 5766.6.

Barclays fell 10p to £21.65 while Lloyds TSB, at present stalled in its attempts to take over Abbey National, was 9.5p down at 700.5p.

It was Alliance & Leicester that felt most of the pain in the sector, losing some 17p to 772p after rapid gains in recent days on reheated speculation that National Australia Bank was preparing a bid for the former building society.

Meanwhile, Bank of Scotland, which some City sources insist is the real target for NAB after the failed talks with Abbey, was unmoved at 720p.

Overall, it was a modest day in volume terms as the City's biggest dealers took advantage of the extended Easter holiday by leaving their desks early but not before pushing through some trades in BT - which rose 6p to 576p. The big institutional investors in BT are waiting anxiously for further details of the timing of the £5bn cash call.

Other telecoms companies were unable to join BT in ending the day higher. Vodafone lost 3p to 216p and Cable & Wireless was off 15p at 515p.

Among the other stocks to experience the roller-coaster ride associated with the new technology was Baltimore, which lost another 20%, down 18p to 74p after frightening the market with a sales warning.

With such alerts seeming to be increasingly common across the Atlantic, further anxieties about the overall health of the American economy yesterday did little to boost sentiment ahead of the Easter break.

One of last year's trendy stocks did manage to buck the sluggish sentiment. ARM Holdings put on another 19p to £3.27 after exciting the market on Wednesday with its first-quarter results and not sounding a gloomy siren.

The retailer GUS did its bit to maintain the upward momentum - gaining 24p to 525p - but another member of the retailing sector, WH Smith, had little to cheer about after suffering an 8% price fall to £4.85 as its profits, announced yesterday, were dented by sale of the newspaper distribution arm.

fields.headline: Making waves for workers
fields.standfirst: Mass sackings by major European companies have led to calls for rules on consulting workers across the union, says Ian Black
fields.trailText: Mass sackings by major European companies have led to calls for rules on consulting workers across the union, says Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
Anna Diamantopoulou, the European commissioner for social policy and employment, has been making waves - upsetting those who think "Brussels" should mind its own business, but encouraging others who want the EU to set standards across the union.

Galvanised into action by a spate of high-profile job losses, she is demanding loudly that bosses be legally required to consult their workers before undertaking major changes.

"I cannot remain silent," Ms Diamantopolou protested when over 6,000 employees of the British retailer Marks and Spencer and the French biscuit manufacturer Danone heard -via the media - that they were being sacked.

"It is unworthy of Europe that employees have to learn about their redundancy through the press or only a few minutes before a public announcement," the Greek commissioner complained.

Ms Diamantopoulou was not the only person upset by these decisions - widely condemned as the behaviour of overpaid managers restructuring underperforming firms with blithe indifference to the human consequences.

French prime minister Lionel Jospin weighed in to express his disquiet - and, sensing the public mood, floated the idea of making it harder for profitable firms to dismiss employees. Angry demonstrations in the streets of Paris were not just about the impending disappearance of delectable M&S chicken tikka sandwiches or chocolate eclairs.

In Belgium, where no one has forgotten the infamous mass layoffs at the Renault factory at Vilvoorde, near Brussels, a few years ago, a court then ruled that the closure of four branches of the retailer had breached national labour laws. And when a French court followed suit over 18 M&S outlets, Diamantopoulou spoke out again. "In the new economic environment," she warned, "business must look not only to shareholders but to its main stakeholders: the workforce."

Brussels insiders were not surprised by this strident tone. The commissioner has one of the most sensitive portfolios in Romano Prodi's team. And in an institution that is sometimes accused of wanting only to liberalise the European economy while being indifferent to the interests of labour, this proud "business-friendly" Eurocrat has become a voice - if not for the underdog, then at least for a "social model" that takes workers' interests into account.

This is not easy. The supranational commission - along with the EU's 15 member states - is committed to giving Europe, which already has a single market and single currency, the "most dynamic knowledge-based economy" in the world by 2010.

It has ambitious though slow-moving plans to create continent-wide labour markets by encouraging the skills, job mobility and flexibility that are needed to compete with the US.

On the other hand, the latest redundancies are a timely boost for the commission's case for legislation on consulting and informing workers - already common on the continent.

If Ms Diamantopoulou gets her way, governments will soon have to adopt harmonised rules for consultation procedures between management and employers in companies of more than 50 employees operating at national level.

Britain, Ireland, Denmark and Germany are currently against the draft directive that lays down the rules. But crucially, the matter has to be decided by majority voting. And so if, as widely predicted, there is a change of position by Germany - the key player because of its size - it could go through in June, shortly after a UK general election.

Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder is said to have promised Tony Blair that he would delay any change until after a May poll. But with the election put off because of the foot and mouth crisis, it is not clear whether that still holds.

Opposing this directive is central to Blair's view of the EU: such practices must be decided at the national, not European level, he insists. "Flawed" EU proposals are not appropriate for Britain because its corporate structures are different from on the continent.

This is a real irritant because Blair has managed to clear away many contentious European issues likely to be exploited by the Tories in the run-up to an election, not least by standing firm against demands to surrender national vetos at last December's Nice summit.

The Trades Union Congress disagrees with the prime minister, pointing out that Britain has the highest rate of mergers and takeovers in Europe - and the least regulated workers.

And if the directive had been in force, the TUC argues, it would have prevented cases like those of General Motors' Luton plant, where the media were first with news of 2,000 job losses, or Corus in south Wales in February, where management secrecy enraged the government.

"British ministers could end this shameful practice of keeping workers in the dark by putting pen to paper and signing the information and consultation directive," argues Bill Morris, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union.

On the other side of the barricades, the CBI is dead against the directive, which it says would make British business less competitive, even though it backs a government review of how redundancy arrangements are made.

"But is is important to remember that while consultation can affect the way redundancies are handled, it often cannot change the harsh commercial realities that lie behind the decision," the employers organisation warned recently.

Ms Diamantopoulou has been hinting heavily at flexibility over the final version of her proposals. Britain insists, however, that it will not change tack.

Yet there was further evidence of the need for clearer, binding rules only this week, when Motorola announced 3000 job losses in Scotland's "Silicon Glen", prompting emergency intervention from Downing Street.

"We are pleased the prime minister found time to place a call to Motorola - but if this is the way we are going to conduct industrial relations in 2001, he will never be off the phone," said Jimmy Elsby, TGWU assistant general secretary.

"If the prime minister sat down and signed the draft EU directive, companies would be required to discuss their plans with their workers and the PM could save himself the price of a call."

fields.headline: Bush's new brief on Beijing
fields.standfirst:
The spy plane standoff may lead to the US agreeing to bolster Taiwan's defences against China, says Martin Kettle

Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush is not pleased with the outcome of the China standoff. He is angry. Bush's comments about China in the White House rose garden yesterday afternoon, shortly after the 24 members of the US spy plane's crew arrived safely back in Hawaii, revealed his mood. He wants respect.
fields.body:
George Bush is not pleased with the outcome of the China standoff. He is angry. Bush's comments about China in the White House rose garden yesterday afternoon, shortly after the 24 members of the US spy plane's crew arrived safely back in Hawaii, revealed his mood. He wants respect.

What Bush wants is to get his way. Predictably, Bush's remarks were tougher on China than anything he said during the standoff itself. He said the past eleven days did "not advance a constructive relationship" between the two countries. Detaining the crew was "inconsistent" with a positive relationship. "Difficult issues and fundamental disagreements" loomed.

America and China Ð but in reality he only meant China - must make "a determined choice to have a productive relationship".

Many republicans would have put it more crudely. But the warning was pretty clear all the same. Bush has been hurt by the eleven-day argument over the plane and its crew.

One senses that China's hostility has affronted him on a personal level. And he knows that he risks some serious political damage among republicans if he is not seen to get even with Beijing soon.

That's why the White House was briefing yesterday that the administration's view of China has changed over the past two weeks. China has lost any benefit of the doubt that it may have had in the Bush White House.

Attitudes inside the administration have hardened. But what can Bush do, other than talk tough, like he did yesterday? The most dramatic answer to that question is that he can sell a lot of arms to Taiwan.

Within the next two weeks, Bush must decide whether to authorise the sale of planes, boats and submarines that Taiwan has requested in order to bolster its defences against China's missile build-up on the mainland.

Before the Hainan island incident, the signs were that Bush would stop short of agreeing to sell four Arleigh-Burke class destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar battle management system. These are the most prized items on Taiwan's shopping list because the Aegis system is integral to state-of-the-art missile defences coveted by the island state.

Even if Washington agreed to sell Taiwan the next best thing, Kidd-class destroyers, as some reports have hinted, that decision would be major. It would still allow the Taiwanese navy to prepare to operate Aegis systems in the future. It would still represent an enormous military commitment to Taiwan on Washington's part.

Bush has other options of making his displeasure felt in China. He could try to slow down trade liberalisation. He could try to scupper Beijing's Olympic bid. But Bush's instincts - and the interests of many of his backers, including the arms manufacturers - are against the former. And his power to control the corrupt politics of the International Olympic Committee is limited.

Most intriguing of all, however, is the issue which lurks in the background of the arms sale debate. That issue is Taiwan itself, and the possibility that this administration may even be contemplating a strategic rethink of its stance towards what Beijing still labels a rebel province of China.

Bush's own formal position on the question is contradictory, and so is American policy generally. In a speech during the election campaign last year Bush said the US must "honour its promises" to Taiwan - including military aid and support for Taiwanese WTO entry.

In terms of consistency, the problem with that stance is that it creeps ever closer towards abandoning the "one China" dogma that has been a cornerstone of US-China relations since the Nixon-Kissinger era, but without actually confronting it.

In another recent move, for instance, the administration has dropped the Clinton-era "three noes" policy - no support for Taiwan independence, no recognition for a separate Taiwanese government, and no backing for Taiwan's membership of international organisations. Yet it still pays lip service to "one China".

The moment is surely coming when the US may stop trying to finesse this issue. Next month, Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian plans a visit to Latin America in which he wants to be allowed a transit visa to stop en route in the United States - possibly Los Angeles, possibly Houston.

China strenuously opposes such a visa for Chen. Washington may now be tempted to grant it to him.

And why not? Last year, Taiwanese voters threw out the Kuomintang leadership that had ruled Taiwan since the days of Chiang Kai-shek and chose Chen in their place. Beijing nevertheless insists that Chen, though democratically elected, may not even make a public appearance at Los Angeles airport.

In almost any other circumstances, international opinion would have long ago moved to recognise the fact that Taiwan is in reality independent of China. Yet the truth is that "one China" has become something of a diplomatic fiction. Smarting from Hainan, it would not be surprising if Bush is preparing to start challenging the fiction with the fact.

webTitle: Third of British farms could be infected

fields.headline: Third of British farms could be infected
fields.standfirst:
• Experts call for intensified cull
• RSPCA investigates cull video
• Angry vets criticise delays

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
• Experts call for intensified cull
• RSPCA investigates cull video
• Angry vets criticise delays

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.body:
Nearly a third of British farms could become infected with foot-and-mouth disease, scientists have warned.

Experts from London's Imperial college school of medicine say the firebreak culling of healthy cattle near infected sites must be intensified.

They claim the Government has not met its target of killing all animals on farms neighbouring an infection site within 48 hours of an outbreak being confirmed.

They claimed that, even when infected animals were slaughtered within 24 hours of symptoms appearing, some 30% of all UK farms would eventually be hit by the epidemic. They also say that pre-emptive "ring culling" - which is the slaughter of all animals within a certain distance around the outbreak area - is the only way to prevent this figure being reached.

Meanwhile, RSPCA officials were today examining video footage of apparent attempts by a council marksmen to cull sheep in an open field.

The white-suited gunman was pictured firing at a herd of free-roaming sheep and then chasing his wounded targets in a bid to finish them off.

The RSPCA said that the video, shot by a retired couple in the village of Gilwern, Monmouthshire, had "shocked and appalled" officers there.

Stills from the film were published in today's Mirror newspaper. They show stray sheep being shot by the lone gunman after wandering too close to a busy roadway breaking restrictions on livestock movements.

Charlotte Morrissey, a national spokeswomen for the RSPCA, said: "These animals have to be culled but there is no excuse for cruelty and there is no excuse for anything going wrong.

Culled animals should be slaughtered with a stun gun the size of a hand pistol under the supervision of council or government officials. Kevin Manning, the RSPCA's superintendent for Wales, said alleged cases of cruelty to animals had risen dramatically during the foot-and-mouth crisis. "I would urge people to come forward and make themselves known. They must stand apart from any cruel practices," he said.

Angry vets today told deputy agriculture minister Joyce Quin the Government should stop delaying making decisions in the battle to beat foot-and-mouth disease. Ms Quin was visiting the disease control centre in Kenton Bar, Newcastle, where she met a group of around 20 private vets, currently working for MAFF, who told her they were concerned that the real picture was not filtering down to Whitehall.

Some vets based at the control centre, which co-ordinates the response to the foot-and-mouth crisis in the North East, claimed decisions were being made too slowly, particularly about whether to cull thousands of sheep which may have been exposed to the disease that graze on common land near Hexham, Northumberland.

 The Government's efforts to boost Britain's crisis-hit tourist industry were today compared to 1930s Russian propaganda films by a Labour MP. "If Britney Spears decided to stay in Newquay, the place would be heaving," he told PA News. The MP added: "I am prepared to negotiate with Jennifer Lopez personally."

webTitle: The troubled shooting of Dust, the new 'eastern western'

fields.headline: 'Come on. It'll be fun'
fields.standfirst: When Milcho Manchevski persuaded Joseph Fiennes to star in his movie in the Balkans, nobody mentioned forest fires, dysentery, mad sheep, plagues of wasps - or the nearby war.  Fiachra Gibbons reports from the set of the 'eastern western' Dust
fields.trailText: When Milcho Manchevski persuaded Joseph Fiennes to star in his movie in the Balkans, nobody mentioned forest fires, dysentery, mad sheep, plagues of wasps - or the nearby war. Fiachra Gibbons reports from the set of the 'eastern western' Dust
fields.body:
Joe Fiennes is having another bad day. While Naomi Campbell grows impatient for his company in London - and the lady is not one for waiting - he is stuck on a scorching hot Balkan mountain top, the air thick with every sort of biting and stinging insect. The brain begins to boil at about 42 degrees celsius (108 fahrenheit) - and, this morning, with forest fires raging on the horizon, the temperature is touching a barely believable 50. Joe won't be getting to London any time soon.

Today, though, he gets to give his Australian co-star David Wenham a good kicking. You can hear the dull thud of boot on rib as soon as you leave the shade of the ancient Orthodox monastery of Treskovec in southern Macedonia and snake your way up through the tinder-dry alpine meadow strewn with Byzantine rubble to the baking rock of the summit.

Wenham is writhing in the dust, coughing and spluttering, surrounded by a halo of wasps. Fiennes, unshaven, irritable and obviously relishing the prospect of another day stewing in his own sweat, kicks him in the stomach, grinds the heel of his cowboy boot down on Wenham's hand and drawls: "You never were no good, Luke."

This goes on, with a short break for lunch and an adjustment of Wenham's bandages, from 9am until after 8pm. By then, even Milcho Manchevski (the man who persuaded them to "come to Macedonia and be in my 'eastern' - it'll be fun") has had enough. And this was one of the good days on the set of Dust, the first "baklava western". Even by the tortuous standards of movie-making, this was a bizarre and horrendous shoot - Apocalypse Now without the luxury of a studio budget.

The omens were not good. From day one, the crew began dropping like flies from dysentery and a medical dictionary of equally nasty complaints - even the unit doctor invalided himself out. Then it got weirder. A week before I arrived, as the worst heatwave to hit the Balkans in 30 years added sunstroke to the sick list, a flock of marauding sheep, half-demented with thirst, overran the set. These being Balkan sheep, there were casualties. A few days later, several people were badly stung by thousands of wasps drawn to the watermelons bought to keep the surviving crew from expiring. The swarm was followed by plagues of mosquitoes and horse flies.

Then came dark mutterings from the Macedonians on the crew of a government plot. Even shorn of his green mohican, Manchevski cuts quite a figure. Only someone with a highly developed sense of the ridiculous could stride on to a set in a joke cowboy hat and badass shades, with a vast pashmina shawl draped around his narrow shoulders, and expect to take charge. First impressions, of course, can be very deceptive. Manchevski may have picked up the swagger, and that eccentric dress sense, directing pop videos in America for the likes of Arrested Development, but he is no cocky fool. For he knew there was a lot more than money, or even whether he would be allowed behind a camera again, riding on Dust.

"I spent five and half years sweating blood to make this film," he says. "I was making a shit-load of money trying to make studio films, but I just couldn't do it. You can't make good films that mean something by remote control. You couldn't make up what happens in LA, it's beyond satire. Hollywood is full of the most miserable, unhappy people I have ever met - and I'm from the Balkans."

That little contretemps with Ziskin, arguably the most powerful woman in Hollywood, would have probably finished his career had Manchevski not had an Oscar nomination and won the Golden Lion at Venice for Before the Rain, his lyrical debut warning of what might happen if Macedonia followed the rest of the former Yugoslavia over the abyss into war.

It is hard to underestimate the effect Before the Rain had on this tiny, fragile and fragmented country of 3m, with no obvious historical or ethnic precedents other than a shared reluctance from its either Slav or Albanian-speaking peoples to throw their lot in with the madhouses of Belgrade or Tirana. Macedonia - the word means "mixed" - also has Serb, Vlach, Roma and Bulgar minorities, making it in present Balkan terms more a conundrum than a country. In such disputed circumstances, Manchevski has become, unwittingly and unwillingly, more national talisman than mere film-maker. His perfectionism may make him a nightmare to work with at times, but in a country where cliques and political cabals hold sway, his unimpeachable punk contrariness has won him the trust of ordinary Macedonians.

Until the skirmishes on the Kosovan border near Tetovo last month, both main Macedonian communities shared a fierce common pride in being the only former Yugoslav republic in which not a single shot had been fired in anger. The dreamlike Before the Rain, and its powerful appeal for tolerance, was the fairytale all ethnic groups seemed to have taken to heart. New countries need heroes, and Manchevski, the punk who ran away to the US "as soon as I could", and who cites the Sex Pistols as his greatest formative influence, was accidentally cast in the role of its chief iconographer. The prodigal son was being handed the mythic glue to hold the nation together - it was as if Malcolm McLaren was being asked to reinvent the monarchy.

Dust - in which shifting alliances of Albanians, Bulgarians, Serbs, Turks, Greeks and various brigand bands battle for dominance as Macedonia emerges from five centuries of Ottoman rule - will be watched through that very delicate prism when it first sees the light of day at either the Cannes or the Venice film festivals; both are currently battling for the right to show it first. It is a fair bet that a few shadowy men from the Pentagon and the UN will want an early look, too.

If that responsibility weighs heavily on Manchevski, he doesn't show it. Wiry, boyish and as charming as he is intense, even among his own he's a person apart, an effect intensified by a slightly off-centre pupil in one eye. No one knows much about his childhood in Skopje and he likes to keep it that way.

His mischievous bluster, though, betrays a certain nervousness. "I am an outsider. I was never part of any political or cultural establishment, even though in these parts you have to be because social life is so tribal. It's very like Hollywood, I guess. So I haven't had to sell my ass, which makes the government here suspicious of me. All this talk of civil war is crazy and dangerous. I really don't think it can happen. Then again, I said that about Bosnia. Macedonia is not Kosovo, you just can't compare how the Albanians have been treated in both places. I'll let you into a secret. That fighting in Tetovo is all my fault. I bribed them [the Albanian guerrillas] for publicity for the film and they just got a little carried away."

Skopje airport has that uneasy feel of a place just out of earshot of something nasty. The flight from London was full of wary Americans and country casual Brits with Sandhurst accents pretending to be something in the City.

A US Chinook helicopter thundered by as soon as we landed, lugging itself over the ammunition and fuel dumps that line the runway and out across the bristling weaponry dug into the fields beyond. It was bound for Kosovo, just beyond the ridge of mountains on the horizon where a low-level war is still raging. Systematic Serb ethnic cleansing of the long-suffering majority Albanian community has given way to slow and but equally cynical creation of an ethnically pure Albanian state. Nato keeps score with impeccable fairness.

You can tell how close a country is to going belly-up when everyone with a car becomes a taxi driver. And everyone in the surging throng outside the doors of Skopje airport, except the Albanian women in scarves and ankle-length coats wrestling returning sons to their chests, was a taxi driver.

Macedonia has paid a horrific price for allowing itself to be used as Nato's forward base against Milosevic. The blockade of Serbia, its main market, has destroyed its industry and the exodus of 400,000 Kosovan Albanian refugees threatened to upset its already delicate 65/30 ethnic balance between Orthodox Slavs and Muslim Albanians. No wonder, to the horrified hypocrisy of the West, it eventually tried to close the border.

Before the Balkan wars of the 1990s it was the second poorest Yugoslav republic after Kosovo, now its unemployment rate is over 50 per cent. The average weekly wage for those lucky enough to still be in work is £25. You can't eat spectacular scenery.

With the roads thick with US military convoys and Humbies full of GIs taking their R&R chasing out-of-work Skopje factory girls, it is not hard to see where Manchevski drew the inspiration for Dust, where Fiennes' fire-and-brimstone Arizona preacher hunts down and does battle with his amoral beast of a brother in the middle of someone else's war.

Setting the story just as the Ottoman empire collapsed almost overnight and took the most stable, multi-ethnic society in Europe with it, was no accident either. It is from the two, short, messy wars in 1912 and 1913 that the myth of the unruly, ungovernable Balkans largely stems.

Manchevski drew on the detailed reports of the Carnegie Commission into the First and Second Balkan wars for much of his material, but it was the far more colourful Confessions of a Macedonian Bandit written by the San Franciscan adventurer Albert Sonnichsen a few years earlier that really fascinated him. "I became came very conscious of the parallels of Westerners, particularly Americans, getting sucked into local quarrels and wars, almost always without fully understanding what is going on. |It was as if they were trying to work out something in themselves. It is like with some charity workers now, it's all a glorified way of going to the shrink." Just to reinforce the point, Sigmund Freud, the father of psychoanalysis, has memorable cameo, being sick over the side of a transatlantic liner.

Sonnichsen's photographs of these outlandishly dressed bands of brigands convinced Manchevski he had to shoot the film as a Baklava Western. "We couldn't use some of the things Sonnichsen described because they were just too fantastic. People would not believe it. The more I saw and read the more I was reminded of the most way-out Mexican Zapatista revolutionaries and bandilleros, it was like they had been shopping in the same boutique."

The violence was another common thread. For when it came to cold calculated cruelty, the sullen cowpokes who people the novels of Cormac McCarthy and the films of Sam Peckinpah scraped the same barrel as the Balkan brigands.

"It is very hard reading the Carnegie Commission reports," says Manchevski, "because you realise the violence that went on then is still happening in the Balkans. People were sliced open and their guts used to strangle them. Arms were cut off and then used to beat that person to death, people buried up to their necks and set alight with gasoline. This became the general Western perception of Balkan behaviour that was reinforced by the misconceptions created by writers like Rebecca West (author of the "definitive" Yugoslav travelogue Black Lamb and Grey Falcon). When you need to exorcise your own demons who assign them to someone else. This was not violence unknown to the West, or indeed in the Old American West, on the contrary the violence in the Balkans was always and still is less efficient."

We joke that if the Germans had been involved there would only have been one Balkan war, little suspecting that last month, when the fighting broke out in the hills above Tetova, a German tank unit which stood idly by would be scathing about the local Macedonia police's half-hearted attempts to mortar the rebels out.

Had they sealed the border with Kosovo , the shooting might never have started.

Having visited Tetova during fighting, Manchevski, in a typically contrary flourish, said he was intensely proud of the half-arsed way the Albanian gunmen who attacked the town were dealt with. "If the Macedonians had gone in all guns blazing Hollywood style it would have been a mess. Not one Albanian store window has been smashed during the terrorist raids on Tetovo. There has been no ethnic retaliation, nor escalation and that must be applauded."

Although he sympathises with many of the relatively modest Albanian demands on the recognition of their language and university, he is also angry that "no Albanian party nor intellectual has issued a clear-cut condemnation" of the violence, which he sees as racist. "If you treat institutions of law and order as illegitimate by default, you risk turning the place into a Milosevic-style quasi-state. It breeds distrust. When you start using violence you never know where it will end. Even if you qualify it as a fight for human rights. All it takes is one guy to get drunk and go nuts and the whole thing goes up. This whole situation has been escalated, both psychologically and physically by Kosovo. The Albanian gunmen, who mostly come from Kosovo, have got the crazy mistaken impression that the West bombed the Serbs so they could have their pure greater Albanian mega-state. It is a very similar situation to what the US got into with the Taliban in Afghanistan; a text-book example of 'blowback'. The West has created its own little jihad in Kosovo by arming the KLA. Talk of human rights is being used as a very thin veneer for good old-fashioned peasant land-grabbing and redistribution of criminal cartel spheres of influence. The West has a lot of responsibility here that it has not been facing up to."

He was also angry at the "inflammatory" coverage of the conflict, particularly by the BBC, who he accused of making out that a slide into civil war was almost inevitable when it isn't.

Manchevski, it has to be said, is a Slav but even the Albanians in Tetova I spoke to this week, whose attitude to those gunmen in the hills is ambivalent to say the least, agree the time has now come to put away the guns and talk.

Arsim Celaj, a student who claims to have been beaten by Macedonian police because he attends the town's "illegal" Albanian university, said there had to be "dialogue and compromises. The government has to talk to us. All this has happened because of frustration that nothing was being done for Albanian people. There must be dialogue now not more war."

"I won't lie to you. It's been hell, but things are at last looking up," Chris Auty, the film's English co-producer assured me the night I arrived at their base in the dusty provincial town of Prilep. A few hours later Auty, a man of limitless optimism and good grace, was savaged by a mastiff on the doorstep of his hotel.

He even managed a toothy smile as he limped, nauseous back onto set the next day at Treskovac after a double tetanus jab. I hadn't the heart to mention rabies. "Could have been worse," he sighed. Manchevski could have bitten him.

Film-making, particularly in 50 degree heat in awkward, inaccessible locations can be a testy business at the best of times. But Auty, an old Bertloucci hand, and no stranger to controversy having produced David Cronenberg's Crash, does not try to conceal that working with Manchevski, who admits a fondness for lobbing the occasional grenade to liven things up, has made the shoot "one of life's more interesting experiences".

"Milcho is Milcho, he's a one-off. I know it all going to be worth it because the guy is a genius, but it's been tough. We have all suffered, but I think he has suffered most, because it means so much to him, and you have to respect that. It's been the most gruelling shoot I've ever been on. In fairness, nature could not have been more cruel, as well as the heat we have had every kind of plague she could have thrown at us."

In another one of those little absurdities that surrounded Dust, and its grim merrygoround of racial conflict, there was more than the odd crackle of ethnic tension on set too.

Playing Frisbee during a break in the filming at the monastery with a medieval copper plate a couple of the Macedonian crew members had found among the ancient ruins of the summit, I got of whiff of some simmering discontent among the natives. It was clear the "imperious" attitude of a few of the British crew called in to straighten things out had not gone down terribly well. Nor were they happy that technicians they felt could have been recruited locally were being flown in from London.

Tensions came to a head over the vexed issue of toilet facilities. Just as at Waterloo, I am proud to report that Blighty won the Battle of the Portaloos and British bog standards prevailed.

The Western contingent was also a little sniffy about the crumbling of Soviet-era hotel in which they were billeted. My own room, which had a rather fetching little Gaudiesque tower of bird shit on balcony, was fine once you got used to the smell of diesel. Its greatest joy, however, was its socialist share-and-share-alike wardrobes, which opened into next door's closet.

Having passed an uneasy night listening to my neighbours have non-stop sex, banging out the complete works of Shakespeare on the headboard in Morse, they invited me through the wardrobe in the morning to join them for a glass of sljivovice (plum brandy). Drago and Maria were married, but not to one another. He was a salesman and she was a friend of someone working on the film. Both were Macedonian Slavs and were keen to share their opinions of their Albanian brethren - lazy, criminal, backward, rich, drug-dealing mafiosi, bent on breeding their way to power was just about the gist of it. Even if there was truth in some of what they said - and there is no denying Macedonia's drug trade has blossomed since the economy collapsed - that sort of paranoia and casual bigotry has a horrible habit of ending in tears.

Nor did their belief that Albanians were rolling in dough quite tally with the evidence of my own eyes. The Albanians in the streets of Prilep seemed markedly poorer, and had that look of people used to keeping their heads down.

Manchevski warns about not seeing the sties in your own eye, but even he is highly critical of what he calls the "anachronistic structures" of Albanian life which he blames for allowing "those men with machine guns in the hills above Tetova to hijack the whole concept of human rights. No one talks about the human rights of Albanian women, the way they are treated. They have absolutely no say, very few go to school, almost none work out of the house, it's like Afghanistan, for Heaven's sake. But you have seen them, in those long coats and scarves in 40-degree heat. When the world feels sorry for the Albanians, I think they should remember their grievances are not that great that they justify going to war. Macedonia is a state based on a proper co-habitation and toleration. The vice-president of parliament is an Albanian for Christ sake and six of the 17 ministers are too, plus deputy ministers of most ministries, the police, the army, a number of ambassadors. Macedonia is a very young country. It is true in the early days it had to strong line of Macedonian nationalism to set itself apart from Serbia, but that nationalism has been reined in now. There are many legitimate issues to be discussed, but what many Macedonians worry about is that when Albanians talk about human rights what they really want is secession. Albanian parties in Macedonia more often identify with ethnic Albanian causes in Kosovo or Albania than with the cause of the Macedonian state. They sit in the government, but act like foreign-state opposition. Either shit or get off the pot. These politicians have to decide if they want to be in this country or not."

And Manchevski is a Macedonian liberal. His views on the gangsterism he sees spreading among rural Albanians, fears even some militant Albanians in Tetova privately share, are equally forthright. "Too much has been made of this stuff about centuries' old hatreds. At least a part of the shooting is about local strongmen being able to keep their fiefdoms so there is open roads for smuggling, the drug trade and who runs the brothels and gets first go. It is that basic for a lot of these guys with the guns. If there is no structure anymore because everything is going up in smoke then they are the bosses. There is a big problem with crime, drug running and prostitution among the Albanian community and it has got to be faced up to.

"We have this terrible history of land grabbing we have to be wary of. No one mentions the terrible ethnic cleansing carried out by the Albanian Nazi quasi-state in western Macedonia during the war. It was very telling how the president of Albania was one of the first to come out against what was happening in Tetovo, and he basically said, 'We don't support this, wipe them out.' People in Albania don't want this super state nonsense. They know it is stupid."

Back in Tetova, Artan Skendera is getting his breath back after the busiest month of his life. He runs the local Albanian TV station, Art TV, from which most of the pictures of the fighting have been sent. It's been good for business, but it's business he'd rather do without.

Artan, as the name of his station suggests, is an idealist, a believer in the power of art to overcome all enmities. He is also a big fan of Manchevski the film-maker if not the proto-politician. "If everyone in Macedonia was like Manchevski we would have less problems. Before The Rain told the truth about all the peoples of Macedonia. It was very important for all of us, it showed our lives to the world."

Dust too, he hopes, might bring Slavs and Albanians closer again. "Some things like beauty and art are above nationalism," he says. It is asking a lot from a piece of entertainment.

"It is very hard reading the Carnegie Commission reports," says Manchevski, "because you realise the violence that went on then is still happening in the Balkans. People were sliced open and their guts used to strangle them. Arms were cut off and then used to beat that person to death, people buried up to their necks and set alight with gasoline. This became the general Western perception of Balkan behaviour that was reinforced by the misconceptions created by writers like Rebecca West (author of the "definitive" Yugoslav travelogue Black Lamb and Grey Falcon). When you need to exorcise your own demons who assign them to someone else. This was not violence unknown to the West, or indeed in the Old American West, on the contrary the violence in the Balkans was always and still is less efficient." We joke that if the Germans had been involved there would only have been one Balkan war, little suspecting that last month, when the fighting broke out in the hills above Tetova, a German tank unit which stood idly by would be scathing about the local Macedonia police's half-hearted attempts to mortar the rebels out. Had they sealed the border with Kosovo , the shooting might never have started. Having visited Tetova during fighting, Manchevski, in a typically contrary flourish, said he was intensely proud of the half-arsed way the Albanian gunmen who attacked the town were dealt with. "If the Macedonians had gone in all guns blazing Hollywood style it would have been a mess. Not one Albanian store window has been smashed during the terrorist raids on Tetovo. There has been no ethnic retaliation, nor escalation and that must be applauded." Although he sympathises with many of the relatively modest Albanian demands on the recognition of their language and university, he is also angry that "no Albanian party nor intellectual has issued a clear-cut condemnation" of the violence, which he sees as racist. "If you treat institutions of law and order as illegitimate by default, you risk turning the place into a Milosevic-style quasi-state. It breeds distrust. When you start using violence you never know where it will end. Even if you qualify it as a fight for human rights. All it takes is one guy to get drunk and go nuts and the whole thing goes up. This whole situation has been escalated, both psychologically and physically by Kosovo. The Albanian gunmen, who mostly come from Kosovo, have got the crazy mistaken impression that the West bombed the Serbs so they could have their pure greater Albanian mega-state. It is a very similar situation to what the US got into with the Taliban in Afghanistan; a text-book example of 'blowback'. The West has created its own little jihad in Kosovo by arming the KLA. Talk of human rights is being used as a very thin veneer for good old-fashioned peasant land-grabbing and redistribution of criminal cartel spheres of influence. The West has a lot of responsibility here that it has not been facing up to." He was also angry at the "inflammatory" coverage of the conflict, particularly by the BBC, who he accused of making out that a slide into civil war was almost inevitable when it isn't. Manchevski, it has to be said, is a Slav but even the Albanians in Tetova I spoke to this week, whose attitude to those gunmen in the hills is ambivalent to say the least, agree the time has now come to put away the guns and talk. Arsim Celaj, a student who claims to have been beaten by Macedonian police because he attends the town's "illegal" Albanian university, said there had to be "dialogue and compromises. The government has to talk to us. All this has happened because of frustration that nothing was being done for Albanian people. There must be dialogue now not more war." "I won't lie to you. It's been hell, but things are at last looking up," Chris Auty, the film's English co-producer assured me the night I arrived at their base in the dusty provincial town of Prilep. A few hours later Auty, a man of limitless optimism and good grace, was savaged by a mastiff on the doorstep of his hotel. He even managed a toothy smile as he limped, nauseous back onto set the next day at Treskovac after a double tetanus jab. I hadn't the heart to mention rabies. "Could have been worse," he sighed. Manchevski could have bitten him. Film-making, particularly in 50 degree heat in awkward, inaccessible locations can be a testy business at the best of times. But Auty, an old Bertloucci hand, and no stranger to controversy having produced David Cronenberg's Crash, does not try to conceal that working with Manchevski, who admits a fondness for lobbing the occasional grenade to liven things up, has made the shoot "one of life's more interesting experiences". "Milcho is Milcho, he's a one-off. I know it all going to be worth it because the guy is a genius, but it's been tough. We have all suffered, but I think he has suffered most, because it means so much to him, and you have to respect that. It's been the most gruelling shoot I've ever been on. In fairness, nature could not have been more cruel, as well as the heat we have had every kind of plague she could have thrown at us." In another one of those little absurdities that surrounded Dust, and its grim merrygoround of racial conflict, there was more than the odd crackle of ethnic tension on set too. Playing Frisbee during a break in the filming at the monastery with a medieval copper plate a couple of the Macedonian crew members had found among the ancient ruins of the summit, I got of whiff of some simmering discontent among the natives. It was clear the "imperious" attitude of a few of the British crew called in to straighten things out had not gone down terribly well. Nor were they happy that technicians they felt could have been recruited locally were being flown in from London. Tensions came to a head over the vexed issue of toilet facilities. Just as at Waterloo, I am proud to report that Blighty won the Battle of the Portaloos and British bog standards prevailed. The Western contingent was also a little sniffy about the crumbling of Soviet-era hotel in which they were billeted. My own room, which had a rather fetching little Gaudiesque tower of bird shit on balcony, was fine once you got used to the smell of diesel. Its greatest joy, however, was its socialist share-and-share-alike wardrobes, which opened into next door's closet. Having passed an uneasy night listening to my neighbours have non-stop sex, banging out the complete works of Shakespeare on the headboard in Morse, they invited me through the wardrobe in the morning to join them for a glass of sljivovice (plum brandy). Drago and Maria were married, but not to one another. He was a salesman and she was a friend of someone working on the film. Both were Macedonian Slavs and were keen to share their opinions of their Albanian brethren - lazy, criminal, backward, rich, drug-dealing mafiosi, bent on breeding their way to power was just about the gist of it. Even if there was truth in some of what they said - and there is no denying Macedonia's drug trade has blossomed since the economy collapsed - that sort of paranoia and casual bigotry has a horrible habit of ending in tears. Nor did their belief that Albanians were rolling in dough quite tally with the evidence of my own eyes. The Albanians in the streets of Prilep seemed markedly poorer, and had that look of people used to keeping their heads down. Manchevski warns about not seeing the sties in your own eye, but even he is highly critical of what he calls the "anachronistic structures" of Albanian life which he blames for allowing "those men with machine guns in the hills above Tetova to hijack the whole concept of human rights. No one talks about the human rights of Albanian women, the way they are treated. They have absolutely no say, very few go to school, almost none work out of the house, it's like Afghanistan, for Heaven's sake. But you have seen them, in those long coats and scarves in 40-degree heat. When the world feels sorry for the Albanians, I think they should remember their grievances are not that great that they justify going to war. Macedonia is a state based on a proper co-habitation and toleration. The vice-president of parliament is an Albanian for Christ sake and six of the 17 ministers are too, plus deputy ministers of most ministries, the police, the army, a number of ambassadors. Macedonia is a very young country. It is true in the early days it had to strong line of Macedonian nationalism to set itself apart from Serbia, but that nationalism has been reined in now. There are many legitimate issues to be discussed, but what many Macedonians worry about is that when Albanians talk about human rights what they really want is secession. Albanian parties in Macedonia more often identify with ethnic Albanian causes in Kosovo or Albania than with the cause of the Macedonian state. They sit in the government, but act like foreign-state opposition. Either shit or get off the pot. These politicians have to decide if they want to be in this country or not." And Manchevski is a Macedonian liberal. His views on the gangsterism he sees spreading among rural Albanians, fears even some militant Albanians in Tetova privately share, are equally forthright. "Too much has been made of this stuff about centuries' old hatreds. At least a part of the shooting is about local strongmen being able to keep their fiefdoms so there is open roads for smuggling, the drug trade and who runs the brothels and gets first go. It is that basic for a lot of these guys with the guns. If there is no structure anymore because everything is going up in smoke then they are the bosses. There is a big problem with crime, drug running and prostitution among the Albanian community and it has got to be faced up to. "We have this terrible history of land grabbing we have to be wary of. No one mentions the terrible ethnic cleansing carried out by the Albanian Nazi quasi-state in western Macedonia during the war. It was very telling how the president of Albania was one of the first to come out against what was happening in Tetovo, and he basically said, 'We don't support this, wipe them out.' People in Albania don't want this super state nonsense. They know it is stupid." Back in Tetova, Artan Skendera is getting his breath back after the busiest month of his life. He runs the local Albanian TV station, Art TV, from which most of the pictures of the fighting have been sent. It's been good for business, but it's business he'd rather do without. Artan, as the name of his station suggests, is an idealist, a believer in the power of art to overcome all enmities. He is also a big fan of Manchevski the film-maker if not the proto-politician. "If everyone in Macedonia was like Manchevski we would have less problems. Before The Rain told the truth about all the peoples of Macedonia. It was very important for all of us, it showed our lives to the world." Dust too, he hopes, might bring Slavs and Albanians closer again. "Some things like beauty and art are above nationalism," he says. It is asking a lot from a piece of entertainment.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu | On the net | Just out
fields.body:
Quick bites... Where to eat out in 15 minutes

Chamomile, 45 England's Lane, London NW3. Tel: 020-7586 4580
Breakfast does not often feature in the Guzzler, which must be immediately rectified by a voyage of discovery to Chamomile. It is not exactly on the beaten track, which may account for the sense of unspoiled good cheer, measured pace and all round soothing qualities. Just the kind of place to settle in for a spot of regeneration before the maelstrom of life at the office or after the maelstrom of life the night before. Bona breakfasts, natch, from the tried and tested big fry to more dietary approved constructs with health drinks to match. Top dog coffee. Pavement eating on sunny days. And if you are a bit late, make it lunch instead for a toasted sarnie or correctly made omelette.

Cheapskate... Where to eat out for under £15

Artigiano 12a Belsize Terrace, London NW3. Tel: 020-7794 4288
It is not the easiest place to find, even by Belsize Park standards. Still, when you find your way there, Artigiano is a restaurant serving pukka Italian food at Guzzler prices, particularly at lunch time (£10.50 for two courses, £13.50 for three). This may account for the large number of people burbling away. Light, bright by day, seriously sexy by night, with smoothly diligent service. Nothing outrageously inventive on the menu, but simple is good thanks to lush ingredients. Even the old prosciutto con melone makes you realise what a sublime combination it is. Serious pastas. Secure cooking. Easy to slip over Guzzler limits, particularly at night. Who cares?

On the menu: Sea cucumber

Something for the vegetarian marine enthusiast? Sadly, no. It is a sea creature, technically a holothurian, about which not a whole lot is known.

Give me the benefit of what is known. It is a bottom feeder with a mouth at one end, an anus at the other and a stomach in between, which it will eject in its entirety if frightened.

I think I am about to do the same. So who eats them? The Chinese are fond of them because the sea cucumber takes on a slippery rubbery quality when braised with soy sauce, rice wine and shiitake mushrooms.

Anyone else have these tastes? The Japanese, Taiwanese and Spanish.

Where can we find them? On the menu of any enterprising Chinese restaurant.

On the net

www.fooduk.com

Still in its infant stages, FoodUK is an internet portal for specialist food producers, retailers and businesses in Britain. Already it has amassed 135 cheese producers, including one, Alham Wood Cheeses, that sells Romanian lambors cheese flavoured with cumin. FoodUK has everything from preserves to poultry, and maps showing where to find 'em. You can get pistachio and almond sheep's milk ice cream from Styles Farmhouse, surf clams from Barony Country Foods, slab black bun from Alex Dalgetty and the finest of pies from Pimblett's of St Helen's. There's also a directory of farmer's markets, and there are plans to feature useful addresses for courses, caterers, food fairs and festivals.

Just out: Patak's Jeera Para

Form: Tiny brown pastry cushions.

Flavour: Quite dry; toasty; pleasing, unoxidised hint of garlic; advertised coriander rather on the Scarlet Pimpernel side.

Verdict: One of a range of nibbles launched by Patak's (others: Bombay Mathri, Goan Kasoori, Gathia Sev, Bombay Mix, Pappadums, Raita Dip and Takali Dip); use of "authentic" Indian names a smart marketing move - wonder whether inhabitants of Bombay, Goa, Gujerat etc would recognise them; ingredients low on chemical staples of manufactured snacks; not exactly your quality food, but a whole sight more interesting than crisps.

Cost: 150g bag for £1.29 (weights of other bags vary).

fields.headline: UK holiday hazards
fields.trailText: What those on the Great British exodus are missing
fields.body:
What those on the Great British exodus are missing

 Rail disruption

Railtrack begins its largest Easter engineering programme for several decades over the weekend in a battle to meet the May 21 repair deadline set by railway regulator Tom Winsor. Major works are due on the east coast main line near Leeds and Newcastle; west coast main line near Manchester; First Great Western routes near Plymouth, Cardiff and Bristol; Great Eastern main line near Stratford and Bethnal Green, east London; Chiltern line between Banbury and Leamington.

 Road disruption

The highways agency is suspending most roadworks on motorways and trunk roads, but bank holiday drivers will still risk traffic jams where major repairs continue. Likely problem areas include the M5, between junctions 1 and 2; junction 5 and junctions 16-17 on M25; junctions 27-29 on the M6. Congestion is also expected on the M1 northbound, M4 westbound, M6 through West Midlands and routes south around Bristol, roads to National Trust sites. and to Blackpool, Brighton, Southend and Scarborough.

 Weather

Today will be generally sunny, but temperatures will only reach 11°C (52°F) in the south and just 8°C (46°F) in the north.

Overnight frost and fog patches will lead tomorrow to rain throughout much of Britain - though not the south-west - and temperatures of just 13°C. Sunday will see rain moving southwards to the south west, and, while Monday will be predominantly dry, it will be cool.

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed | Overexposed | Overheard
fields.body:
Oversubscribed: Sex and the City on the high street

The show was very good but let's be honest - it was Carrie Bradshaw's bling-bling wardrobe that really got us tuning in every week. Her Fendi dress for lounging about on Sundays, her merry-go-round selection of Dior saddle bags . . . God, we loved it. Carrie Chic made one-shouldered tops (once only for 80s rawk fans) and corsages (formerly reserved for extra-dull weddings) extremely sexy.

And how the high street noticed. Oasis is stocking a veritable variety pack of shiny dresses; Warehouse overflows with floral corsages. Kookai, though, takes the Sex and the City biscuit. There you shall find every one-shouldered top you could ever desire - it even has a near-identical copy of a chiffon top last seen on Carrie sauntering down Fifth Avenue. Sadly, the Chanel leggings with matching blouse Carrie wore to brunch in the last series have yet to be copied, but I expect to see them in Topshop any day.

It's rather like drowning in a sea of Fendi baguettes - too much of what once seemed like a very good thing. Even worse, this is a trend that has cost me money. Last weekend I simply lacked the strength to resist a couple of those corsages and, yes, even a one-shouldered top, only to find on my return home that I had spent more cash than was reasonable on items that, just one year ago, would have seemed downright unacceptable. Curse you, Carrie Bradshaw.

Overexposed: Interior decor fashion

Maybe it all started with Gone with the Wind, when the recently impoverished Scarlett fashions a fetching little number out of some old curtains, entrancing the delightful Rhett. Only Vivien Leigh could look good in green crushed velvet with tassels.

Or so we thought. Never mind the 80s - furnishings are the new black. This season's draping is reminiscent of that Changing Rooms favourite, the swag. The appliqués adorning everyone's shoulders and toes these days remind one of "those home personal touches" as advocated by Home Front.

Designer Russell Sage has designed everything from jackets to hotpants out of antique fabrics from sofas and curtains. Then there's the fashionista's favourite, the toile de jouy prints from Cacharel, which will make you look like a walking guest room but, like, in a really good way.

Oversubcribed's favourite, though, is this really rather lovely top from Galibardy, made out of curtain fabric, available from London's Spitalfields Market. Not only is it a far more wearable and flattering take on this season's Furnishing Fashion, but at a mere £35, it is much more affordable, too. See? Even fashion at its most, er, extreme need not mean extreme prices.

Overheard: "Sexcapades"

Unnecessary salacious details of the highly uninteresting sexual past of someone very boring. For example: "For heaven's sake! Do we really need to have the sexcapades of Noel from Hear'Say splashed all over the Sundays?"

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about
fields.standfirst: Indian fashion
fields.trailText: Indian fashion
fields.body:
Oh dear. Just when Indian designers were finally gaining some recognition in the west, too. Nicole Kidman plans to wear a dress by Indian designer Ritu Beri to the Cannes premiere of Moulin Rouge next month; Judi Dench has long supported Bombay-based designers Abu Jani and Sandeep Kholsa; fashion maestro Mounir Mafarriage, who originally recruited Stella McCartney, has formed a partnership with Beri. But then Michael Portillo had to go and dent Indian fashion's credibility by wearing an Indian-style jacket to a dinner for Asian businessmen this week.

Derivatives of Indian fashion have long been popular in the west - Madonna and her bindi, Ronan Keating sporting henna bodypaint - and influential on western designers, particularly Matthew Williamson and Jean Paul Gaultier. Last year, India held its first fashion week to try to give its own designers recognition, and Jodie Kidd modelled for Anaamika Khanna. Other names to watch out for include Gitanjali Kahsyap, Rina Dhaka and Manoviraj Khosla.

Although the sight of a bejacketed Portillo reeks of a desperate PR stunt (ditto for Diana when she demurely sported a veil in India), don't let this make you wary of Indian fashion itself. Only those as gauche as our deputy shadow chancellor can make it look less than breathtakingly lovely.

fields.headline: Shayler trial could be abandoned
fields.standfirst:
Ex-MI5 agent's case tests secrets act

Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: The trial of David Shayler, the former MI5 officer who has been a persistent source of embarrassment to the security and intelligence agencies, is expected to be postponed for as much as a year and may never take place, according to lawyers and Whitehall officials familiar with the case.
fields.body:
The trial of David Shayler, the former MI5 officer who has been a persistent source of embarrassment to the security and intelligence agencies, is expected to be postponed for as much as a year and may never take place, according to lawyers and Whitehall officials familiar with the case.

The issue at the heart of the high profile case - and the one which threatens to torpedo it - is whether the Official Secrets Act, which Mr Shayler has been charged with breaching, is incompatible with the Human Rights Act.

This key, untested question - which has widespread political as well as legal implications - will be argued before Mr Justice Moses on April 24, the day the trial was due to start.

Whatever the judge decides, the loser is almost bound to appeal, lawyers say. Indeed, the Guardian has learned that Lord Williams, the attorney general, has already instructed prosecution lawyers to appeal if the crown loses this crucial argument.

If he loses, Mr Shayler is almost certain to appeal in a dispute which is likely to go all the way to the law lords.

A delay will mean that, even if the prosecution finally wins the argument, an Old Bailey trial will not begin until the autumn at the earliest, and probably not until next spring - more than 18 months after Mr Shayler voluntarily returned from France to face charges. By that time, his lawyers would be likely to argue that a trial would be an abuse of process.

In what has turned out to be a lengthy and tortuous cat and mouse game for the government, Mr Shayler, 33, fled to the continent after making damaging disclosures about the security services in 1997.

A year later he was arrested in Paris pending extraditon hearings. He was released after a Paris court ruled that the government's attempt to pursue him under the secrets act was politically motivated. Last August he returned to Britain, where he was immediately arrested.

Now the trial itself threatens yet more embarrassment. The prospect of a lengthy delay, and even abandoning the trial, would not be entirely unwelcome to ministers or MI5.

A trial, to which the attorney general has personally consented, would raise the whole issue of government secrecy and how ministers strongly opposed the secrets act when they were in opposition. It would also renew Mr Shayler's claims that the bombings of the City of London in 1993 and the Israeli embassy in London the following year could have been prevented.

A trial would again raise allegations made by Mr Shayler including how MI5 keeps files on Labour ministers and radical pop groups, its incompetence, and - though significantly he has not been charged with this - how MI6 was involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy.

The Gadafy plot allegation is the subject of a special branch report still being considered by the crown prosecution service.

Privately, government law-yers admit that the secrets act is unworkable as it stands.

Mr Shayler's lawyers argue that the act is in direct conflict with the Human Rights Act, which enshrines the right to freedom of speech, because it reverses the burden of proof and prevents the accused from arguing that he acted in the public interest.

Prosecution lawyers in the case vigorously contest these arguments in a 50-page brief they have handed to Mr Justice Moses.

Defence lawyers, meanwhile, are arguing with the prosecution about what classified papers the defence should be allowed to see - an argument which could also embrace the trial jury.

John Wadham, director of Liberty, the civil rights group and Mr Shayler's solicitor, said last night: "The legal arguments in this case are absolutely crucial to the trial and... to many of the issues, not restricted to David Shayler, about the way the Official Secrets Act is used in criminal trials more generally."

fields.headline: Yahoo! goes hardcore
fields.standfirst:
Online deputy editor Neil McIntosh examines why the troubled portal will be selling pornography
More net news
fields.trailText: Brace yourself for an outbreak of quite bare-cheeked double standards.
fields.body:
Brace yourself for an outbreak of quite bare-cheeked double standards.

The announcement that Yahoo!, the web portal, is to offer hardcore porn videos and DVD disks through its popular shopping service has caused quite a few ripples across the internet pond.

The move is being interpreted as a big, once family-friendly internet name suddenly getting down and dirty in the middle of the street: anything in the pursuit of those dot.com profits.

There were plenty of quotes from Yahoo!'s appalled rivals to back up the image. One was from Amazon, which said it wouldn't offer anything pornographic, although it does sell a few good sex guides and photographic compilations that would be regarded as pretty racy in many circles. Best of all, a spokeswoman for AltaVista said "I think our shopping site is meant to be a family friendly arena."

AltaVista? Family friendly? That policy must have not reached prissy old AltaVista's better known search engine. Type in the word "sex" there and - even before you've even begun to explore the results of the search - AltaVista's halo is falling, tarnished.

A banner ad for a porn site appears at the top of the screen, featuring a pretty blonde model and a bare bottom. A family would have to be pretty long in the tooth, and pretty liberal with it, before "Scandinavian hardcore" and "teen sex videos" - two offers that lurk one click away via that banner ad - became "family friendly".

Indeed, by those standards, Yahoo! has been ultra-cautious: visitors cannot access the site's Adult and Erotica store without parting with credit card details and personal information. That must put enough barriers in the way, one would think, to cause inquisitive children to look elsewhere for their adult material.

And there are plenty of other places where interested surfers can get their porn, of course. Online sex has been big business since the early 1990s, when up to 80% of net traffic was thought to have something to do with nookie.

Since the commercialisation of the web in the late 90s, "respectable" research houses have produced far fewer surveys on the popularity of the online sex industry than they used to, but the numbers that do exist are interesting.

We have to look back to 1998 for the last set of figures from Forrester Research, which estimated the US online adult entertainment market to be worth around $1bn, and around a tenth of the whole e-commerce market.

There are no estimates of the size of the European market, although Jupiter MMXI says Spanish net users are the greatest consumers of online porn in Europe, with 34.5% of surfers there logging on to blue sites (against only 24.7% of users in the UK).

Worse of all, of course, the kiddies could always access the Yahoo! web directory where, since the dawn of internet time, users have been trawling through Yahoo! lists of sex sites for somewhere to visit.

There's no credit card or personal information needed there: type "sex" into Yahoo! and you are given a choice of 469 categories and 3407 sites, along with another banner ad; "Live Now: Nikki! click to meet Nikki!" (click to meet Nikki, by the way, and you get landed at a warning screen urging minors to go away).

And that is perhaps the most obscene thing about this tiny extension of the internet porn industry: that this is actually a move by Yahoo! into the adult business. In fact it, like many other respectable online names, has been using sex to add to the bottom line for a long time.

Were they really concerned about making their websites puritanically family friendly (and that would be a shame, wouldn't it?), they'd have to turn them off and start again.

fields.headline: Ambitions on the right
fields.standfirst:
The big three get all the attention but there is political life beyond Westminster, as Matthew Tempest discovers in the second of part of our series on Britain's small - and sometimes extreme - political parties.

Small parties part 1: Greens, Liberals and the Socialist Alliance
fields.trailText: More than any other small party, the United Kingdom Independence party suffers from the perception of being a single-issue lobby group: backing the withdrawal of Britain from the EU.
fields.body:
More than any other small party, the United Kingdom Independence party suffers from the perception of being a single-issue lobby group: backing the withdrawal of Britain from the EU.

That hasn't prevented the party, founded in the early 1990s, from achieving a remarkable level of success and attention. However, the party's claim to be the "fourth party" of UK politics, thanks to the election of three MEPs in the 1999 European election, is contested by the Green party, with its five elected members in the Scottish, European and London legislatures.

Ukip members argue that from their one policy all others must flow: that rescuing of Britain's status a sovereign state is so vital that all other manifesto commitments are conditional on the point of principle.

Certainly, one of the party's biggest achievements since the 1997 contest is bringing the concept of EU withdrawal from the outlandish outskirts of British political thought into the mainstream agenda - to the extent that many Tory MPs privately back the idea.

And without the Referendum party to contend with at the next election, the Ukip should have a clean run at the 52% of the population its members claim favour withdrawal from the EU.

A side-effect of this positioning is suspicion - strongly contested by the party itself -that the Ukip's natural constituency is disenchanted Tory Eurosceptics.

The party claims a large part of its support comes from natural Labour and Liberal Democrat voters - and there are certainly muffled voices of Euroscepticism within both those parties' parliamentary troops.

In fact some UKIP policies, such as guaranteeing the right to trial by jury might actually win over some libertarian members of the Labour left and Lib Dem purists, if those policies were not overshadowed by the party's strident single message, and the double-edged sword of its self-explanatory name.

So what are the party's prospects at the election? The party has big ambitions - claiming it will fight up to 400 of the UK's 659 parliamentary constituencies. The boast might need closer examination when the time comes for candidates to place their £500 deposits.

Despite its unique opportunity to put the anti-EU case (the Conservatives can only promise not to enter the euro over the next five years), the Ukip has suffered from splits and dissent.

Last year's highly divisive leadership contest saw MEP Jeffrey Titford beat Rodney Atkinson, the economist and brother of comedian Rowan. This led to the defection of around 200 party members - a significant number considering the party's membership highpoint was some 7,000.

Another report that the party had been offered £2m by Conservative sympathisers not to stand against Tory MPs in vulnerable constituencies, plus the expulsion of Scottish executive member Alistair McConnachie for bringing the party into disrepute after agreeing with David Irvine's denial of the holocaust, will have done little to garner support from mainstream voters.

Even so, one of the party's leading lights and the author of its manifesto, Dr Aidan Rankin, has written a pamphlet spelling out the reasons why the party is not confined to little Englanders and xenophobes.

True or not, this could be the party's Achilles heel come June 7.

One party that, uniquely among the larger minority parties, will be fielding fewer prospective parliamentary candidates this time around than in 1997 is the British National party.

A minnow in British political terms, the BNP may be politically beyond the pale but puts forward policies similar to those of other parties in Europe which have won wide support. For this reason, it is worth looking at.

In 1997 their 100-seat plus effort netted them a highly controversial party election broadcast, showing BNP leader John Tyndall standing on the white cliffs of Dover. It was banned by both Channel 4 and Channel 5.

The party's spokesman Phill Edwards believes this time around money spent on filming another TV ad and losing sufficient deposits to be eligible for one is better spent on the party's surprisingly smart - if offensive - website.

The party is targeting around 30 seats in areas such as south-east London, Dewsbury, Doncaster, Manchester and Oldham where it perceives a "white flight" will favour "our sort of policies".

Despite sentiments on their website which would disgust many white voters and rightly alarm those from ethnic minorities, the party argues persistently and rather unbelievably that it is not, in fact, racist.

This despite calling for the voluntary repatriation of all non-European immigrants, so that in Mr Edwards words "we are not a mongrel race."

Members claim that Conservative leader William Hague "knows we're right, but he's hamstrung", a sentiment which may do more to damage to Mr Hague than help the BNP.

Out of self-interest, the party is in favour of proportional representation, since "this would help us." The party also insists it is "not into confrontational politics", has no links with the National Front and no longer takes part in town centre marches.

And they take comfort from the examples of the far-right's grasping of power in Austria, Italy and France.

• Unique selling point: immediate unconditional withdrawal from the EU
