fields.headline: 'Wonderdrug' losing war with superbugs
fields.trailText: A new type of antibiotic hailed as a key weapon against antibiotic-resistant hospital "superbugs" may already be losing its power, scientists warned yesterday.
fields.body:
A new type of antibiotic hailed as a key weapon against antibiotic-resistant hospital "superbugs" may already be losing its power, scientists warned yesterday.

Linezolid, promoted as the first in a new class of antibiotic for 35 years, was only licensed in Britain four months ago. But evidence from the United States suggests that harmful bacteria have already built up resistance to the drug, sold under the brand name Zyvox.

Doctors in this country last night remained cautiously optimistic that the drug could still cut the 100,000 infections caught by British patients each year while in hospital.

With 5,000 deaths a year, experts have warned gloomily of a return to "dark ages" of medicine if hospitals do not soon get a grip on fighting the new endemic antibiotic-resistant diseases with effective drugs and vastly improved hygiene procedures.

The concern over Zyvox so early in its commercial life will be seen as a salutary reminder of just how versatile bacteria are, partly because of cavalier overuse of antibiotics for the past 50 years in medicine and in farming. Concern at the waning powers of what were once regarded as wonder-drugs has brought firm political action only in the last three years and many critics do not believe enough is being done to educate the public, doctors or farmers of the need to cut their routine use.

Linezolid, approved by the US food and drug administration last April, is being used to treat patients suffering from pneumonia and other infections associated with VRE, one of the so-called superbugs.

Pharmacia, the makers, say it works in two thirds of cases and actual bacterial resistance had been found in only a handful of those.

A study published in the Lancet yesterday found that one in 45 patients may have a resistance to the new drug. The findings will come as a blow to scientists, who believed Linezolid could overcome the most virulent bacteria, including vancomycin-resistant organisms that cause many potentially deadly infections.

Doctors from the University of Illinois College of Medicine in Chicago studied Linezolid's success in treating five patients suffering from the vancomycin-resistant enterococcus faecium (VRE).

It was initially effective in all five patients, but over a period of weeks, the tests showed that the bacteria were beginning to develop a resistance to the drug.

In three of the cases, the Linezolid treatment eventually failed as patients grew unresponsive to the drug. Doctors here will be eagerly awaiting the results. The public health laboratory service specialist Alan Johnston said: "We had hoped there would be quite a long period before we saw clincial problems with the occurrence of resistance [in Zyvox]. In the last 10 to 15 years we have had a number of new drugs coming into use about which we have been optimistic that resistance might not be a problem or delayed. All too often resistance has emerged remarkably rapidly."

But there were signs that the organisms behind a more dangerous superbug, methilin resistant staphylococcus aureus - MRSA - might find it more difficult to adapt and resist Zyvox. "I am still cautiously optimistic we are looking at a major development in anti-microbial treatment."

The Department of Health said last night it had been urging prudence in the use of all antibiotics to preserve their usefulness as long as possible.

Cameron Durrant, vice-president for infectious diseases at Pharmacia, said the Chicago patients were "very sick" and the results confirmed the company's own laboratory and clinical studies. "We have now had in excess of 60,000 patients treated with Zyvox and we are talking about a small number of cases , limited to a very small group. There has been no confirmed case of resistance to MRSA.

"We are still extremely confident that the appropriate use of Zyvox will benefit patients all over the world."

webTitle: French make their excuses over Widdecombe visit

fields.headline: French make their excuses over Widdecombe visit
fields.standfirst:
Special report: refugees in Britain

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe yesterday became the first person to take the ferry from Dover and try to get into the French holding centre for asylum seekers outside Calais. Normally it is the other way around.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe yesterday became the first person to take the ferry from Dover and try to get into the French holding centre for asylum seekers outside Calais. Normally it is the other way around.

Thanks to the cowardice or cunning of the French authorities, the shadow home secretary failed. Her visit to the bleak camp at Sangatte, five miles west of the port, had been arranged through the British embassy in Paris. Late on Wednesday it was cancelled.

At first, explanation was that the government appointed préfet in Calais had heard rumours there would soon be an election in Britain. It had not stopped him from letting in her old rival, Michael Howard, the other week, Miss Widdecombe pointed out.

Then it was said that the International Red Cross, which runs the camp on French money, had not realised Miss Widdecombe was a politician. An unlikely tale.

It did not stop her from using a throng of TV cameras and reporters to promote her message - and herself. She did so in front of the windswept camp, watching asylum seekers turn up by taxi and police car. She then drove off to a hastily arranged substitute visit to Eurotunnel's smarter premises down the road.

Earlier, on the 8.15 P&O ferry Acquitaine, Miss Widdecombe accosted lorry drivers and tourists to hammer home the Tory message that Labour's policies were not enough of a deterrent and were "totally cruel" to genuine asylum seekers. In the car park at Calais port, where P&O now spends £500,000 a year pre-checking lorries, she heard that 1,800 illegal immigrants had been found in the first 16 weeks of the scheme.

David Herman, 38, from Morecambe, Lancashire, who was taking German kitchens to London in his lorry yesterday, described how asylum seekers leapt on him with knives when he unlocked his cargo. "They're that desperate to get to England that they're waiting to attack you," he said.

Miss Widdecombe: "They've just caught seven here this morning." Mr Herman: "Did they? That's seven less."

Ron Bridewell was taking a lorry load of salt to Bristol. "Do the security changes make you feel more comfortable?" she asked him. "Not really," he replied. "They get in on the boat, not here in the car park. They want to get to England because we're too soft; we give them handouts."

For a university administrator turned politician and novelist in middle age, Miss Widdecombe has an alarming extrovert streak. She loves the cameras, but she is too smart to embrace Mr Bridewell's invitation to naked populism.

" Avez vous un probe, " she asked a French trucker referring to the carbon dioxide probes that P&O uses to detect human breath. Blank incomprehension. "I'm not going to try that again," she said.

Tory officials and MEPs such as Tim Kirkhope, who accompanied Miss Widdecombe yesterday, reported that 16,000 refugees had passed through Sangatte, with its basic bed and food, in the 18 months it has been open.

There are signs warning of high winds, razor wire, electricity and other dangers of trying to smuggle humans across the 23 mile frontier of water. But desperation leads to desperate measures. A man was electrocuted by a cable early yesterday on Eurotunnel's French premises.

Two months ago, an illegal immigrant was killed after apparently being hit by a train near the tunnel's loading terminal for trucks.

"Where do they come from," the Guardian asked the policeman who had just deposited six young men inside the gate. "From the station, from all over," he said. "Where do they go?" A Gallic shrug. "I don't know." MEPs get no better answer.

Miss Widdecombe wants detention centres such as Oakington, Cambridgeshire, to be opened on a scale to take all the 70,000 asylum seekers each year if necessary, until their claims are processed, so that bogus applicants do not simply disappear and stay in the country. She also wants a "proper" package of help for claimants who are accepted.

She wants France and other EU countries to enforce the Dublin convention: that asylum seekers should apply to the first safe country they reach - France for instance.

Outside the camp at Sangette she asked the "obvious question": why asylum seekers were not trying to stay in France. A taxi driver provided that answer: "It's easier to get work in England, and you don't need an identity card."

webTitle: Row over Tory candidate threatens safe seat

fields.headline: Row over Tory candidate threatens safe seat
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Politics
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Dissident Tories are ready to risk one of their safest seats after party bosses withdrew the whip from their MP, the former Home Office minister Charles Wardle.
fields.body:
Dissident Tories are ready to risk one of their safest seats after party bosses withdrew the whip from their MP, the former Home Office minister Charles Wardle.

About a quarter of the active membership in Battle, East Sussex, including a former association chairman, will this weekend finalise plans to field an alternative candidate in protest at Tory central office's handling of concerns about their official candidate, businessman Greg Barker.

Mr Wardle, who announced last year he was standing down at the election after causing a furore by taking a £120,000 a year part-time job with Harrods boss Mohamed Al Fayed, is now calling for the Tory ethics and integrity committee to investigate claims his successor, businessman Greg Barker, made on his CV about his business career.

The editor of the Daily Telegraph, Charles Moore - a constituent of Mr Wardle's - and the Conservative chief whip, James Arbuthnot - for whom Mr Moore "fagged" at Eton - are taking on Mr Wardle and his new boss, Mr Fayed.

Mr Arbuthnot withdrew the whip because of reports in the constituency that Mr Wardle was ready to back a rival candidate. Mr Wardle denies that and claims central office is trying to bully him. "They think I'm pushy and obstinate," he said last night, "and they are determined to discredit me."

Two weeks ago the constituency passed a vote of confidence in Mr Barker.

Mr Wardle had a majority of 11,000 at the last election.

fields.headline: Lord Harris of Greenwich
fields.standfirst:
Adviser to Gaitskell, Wilson and Jenkins who became Lib-Dem chief whip in the House of Lords

Guardian Unlimited Politics
Special report: House of Lords
fields.trailText: Adviser to Gaitskell, Wilson and Jenkins who became Lib-Dem chief whip in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Lord Harris of Greenwich, who has died aged 71, was an influential Westminster insider - serving in both the Labour and Liberal Democrats - for more than 40 years. He was probably the first ever spin doctor, but much else besides. In the early part of his career, he was personal assistant and press adviser to Hugh Gaitskell, the Labour leader, shortly before the 1959 general election; and, at the time of his death, he was Liberal Democrat chief whip in the House of Lords. In the intervening years, he played an important part in the 1975 referendum on the Common Market, served as a middle-rank minister in the second Wilson government and as chairman of the parole board. He was a close associate of Roy Jenkins in many endeavours.

John Harris was born in Pinner, Middlesex. After leaving school, he worked on newspapers in Bournemouth and Leicester and completed national service. Then, when the Scottish Labour weekly paper Forward was brought to London to rival the leftwing Tribune in the battle between Gaitskellites and Bevanites for the soul of the Labour party, he became deputy to the new editor, Francis Williams. This proved to be his launching pad into the heart of politics. His integrity, shrewd political judgment and understanding of the press were soon recognised. For Tony Benn, Harris's appointment as assistant to Gaitskell was "the best thing that has happened to Hugh for years".

From then on, Harris was present at many significant occasions, including the meeting at 18 Frognal Gardens, Gaitskell's home, in the aftermath of Labour's 1959 defeat, that led to the attempt to change clause four of the Labour party constitution. It was a grieving Harris who announced Gaitskell's death in January 1963; and in the debate over Gaitskell's successor, his doubts about the steadiness of George Brown, given Brown's drinking habits, persuaded some waverers among Gaitskell's old friends to vote for Callaghan, or even Harold Wilson, as the safer option.

As a councillor in the new town of Harlow and leader of the Labour Group (1961-63), Harris had everyday experience of grass roots politics. He also spent two years as director of publicity for the Labour party (1962-64). But after short stints working for Patrick Gordon Walker and (less comfortably) Michael Stewart when they became cabinet ministers in 1964, he joined Roy Jenkins, the newly appointed home secretary, as a special adviser. This proved a fruitful and enduring friendship, much valued by both.

Despite the often bumpy relations between Jenkins and Wilson in the late 1960s, Harris achieved a good working partnership with Marcia Williams, head of the political office at No 10. She was, he believed, contrary to conventional wisdom, the best of Wilson's kitchen cabinet and she, in turn, warmed to him. It was nevertheless a surprise when, on becoming prime minister again in 1974, Wilson sent Harris, by then on the staff of the Economist, to the House of Lords and made him minister of state at the Home Office.

Here he was a success, both as a spokesman for the government and in the conduct of departmental business, where he played a key role in the setting up of the Police Complaints Authority. His interest in Home Office matters was to persist and he maintained personal contact with his former civil servants for the rest of his life.

In 1975 Harris became a leading member of the "Yes" campaign in the referendum on whether Britain should remain a member of the European Economic Community. He had been closely involved in behind-the-scenes preparations and had won the confidence of senior cross-party leaders.

Now, as joint chairman of the publicity committee, he helped to devise a highly professional presentation of the case for staying in. His closeness to Jenkins also gave him important influence on the wider political direction of what became a winning campaign. He deserved much credit for the outcome

Harris was not prominent in the launch of the Social Democrats' party in 1981 - he was still chairman of the parole board (1979-82) - but he was a founder member. He was also a firm believer in a merger with the Liberals after the 1987 election. From 1994 he was a very effective chief whip in the House of Lords, summoning Liberal Democrat peers to divisions only when it was really necessary, but then rigorously demanding their attendance. He could sound fierce and uncompromising, but he was warm-hearted and bore no grudges, and he was respected across all benches.

His commitment to his duties never flagged as he fought the debilitating effects of cancer. He would telephone daily from his hospital bed when a private member's bill for withdrawal from the EU threatened to be carried, then returned to the House to resume his duties, although gravely ill. On Europe and other issues, he gave New Labour the benefit of the doubt, while determined to vote against the government when ministers aban doned principle or were unwilling to compromise.

Harris was, in his own way, a distinguished public servant, rejecting what would have been lucrative opportunities in the world of public relations, and not revealing in memoirs the confidences he received during his long career. He was always loyal to his many friends, who valued his opinions and enjoyed his company, although at heart he was a shy, rather than a gregarious, man.

He married twice. He leaves Angela, his wife for the last 18 years, a son and daughter from his previous marriage, and grandchildren to whom he was devoted - "my only hobby" as he put it.

 John Henry Harris (Lord Harris of Greenwich), politician, born April 5 1930; died April 11 2001
fields.bodyText: Lord Harris of Greenwich, who has died aged 71, was an influential Westminster insider - serving in both the Labour and Liberal Democrats - for more than 40 years. He was probably the first ever spin doctor, but much else besides. In the early part of his career, he was personal assistant and press adviser to Hugh Gaitskell, the Labour leader, shortly before the 1959 general election; and, at the time of his death, he was Liberal Democrat chief whip in the House of Lords. In the intervening years, he played an important part in the 1975 referendum on the Common Market, served as a middle-rank minister in the second Wilson government and as chairman of the parole board. He was a close associate of Roy Jenkins in many endeavours. John Harris was born in Pinner, Middlesex. After leaving school, he worked on newspapers in Bournemouth and Leicester and completed national service. Then, when the Scottish Labour weekly paper Forward was brought to London to rival the leftwing Tribune in the battle between Gaitskellites and Bevanites for the soul of the Labour party, he became deputy to the new editor, Francis Williams. This proved to be his launching pad into the heart of politics. His integrity, shrewd political judgment and understanding of the press were soon recognised. For Tony Benn, Harris's appointment as assistant to Gaitskell was "the best thing that has happened to Hugh for years". From then on, Harris was present at many significant occasions, including the meeting at 18 Frognal Gardens, Gaitskell's home, in the aftermath of Labour's 1959 defeat, that led to the attempt to change clause four of the Labour party constitution. It was a grieving Harris who announced Gaitskell's death in January 1963; and in the debate over Gaitskell's successor, his doubts about the steadiness of George Brown, given Brown's drinking habits, persuaded some waverers among Gaitskell's old friends to vote for Callaghan, or even Harold Wilson, as the safer option. As a councillor in the new town of Harlow and leader of the Labour Group (1961-63), Harris had everyday experience of grass roots politics. He also spent two years as director of publicity for the Labour party (1962-64). But after short stints working for Patrick Gordon Walker and (less comfortably) Michael Stewart when they became cabinet ministers in 1964, he joined Roy Jenkins, the newly appointed home secretary, as a special adviser. This proved a fruitful and enduring friendship, much valued by both. Despite the often bumpy relations between Jenkins and Wilson in the late 1960s, Harris achieved a good working partnership with Marcia Williams, head of the political office at No 10. She was, he believed, contrary to conventional wisdom, the best of Wilson's kitchen cabinet and she, in turn, warmed to him. It was nevertheless a surprise when, on becoming prime minister again in 1974, Wilson sent Harris, by then on the staff of the Economist, to the House of Lords and made him minister of state at the Home Office. Here he was a success, both as a spokesman for the government and in the conduct of departmental business, where he played a key role in the setting up of the Police Complaints Authority. His interest in Home Office matters was to persist and he maintained personal contact with his former civil servants for the rest of his life. In 1975 Harris became a leading member of the "Yes" campaign in the referendum on whether Britain should remain a member of the European Economic Community. He had been closely involved in behind-the-scenes preparations and had won the confidence of senior cross-party leaders. Now, as joint chairman of the publicity committee, he helped to devise a highly professional presentation of the case for staying in. His closeness to Jenkins also gave him important influence on the wider political direction of what became a winning campaign. He deserved much credit for the outcome Harris was not prominent in the launch of the Social Democrats' party in 1981 - he was still chairman of the parole board (1979-82) - but he was a founder member. He was also a firm believer in a merger with the Liberals after the 1987 election. From 1994 he was a very effective chief whip in the House of Lords, summoning Liberal Democrat peers to divisions only when it was really necessary, but then rigorously demanding their attendance. He could sound fierce and uncompromising, but he was warm-hearted and bore no grudges, and he was respected across all benches. His commitment to his duties never flagged as he fought the debilitating effects of cancer. He would telephone daily from his hospital bed when a private member's bill for withdrawal from the EU threatened to be carried, then returned to the House to resume his duties, although gravely ill. On Europe and other issues, he gave New Labour the benefit of the doubt, while determined to vote against the government when ministers aban doned principle or were unwilling to compromise. Harris was, in his own way, a distinguished public servant, rejecting what would have been lucrative opportunities in the world of public relations, and not revealing in memoirs the confidences he received during his long career. He was always loyal to his many friends, who valued his opinions and enjoyed his company, although at heart he was a shy, rather than a gregarious, man. He married twice. He leaves Angela, his wife for the last 18 years, a son and daughter from his previous marriage, and grandchildren to whom he was devoted - "my only hobby" as he put it.  John Henry Harris (Lord Harris of Greenwich), politician, born April 5 1930; died April 11 2001

webTitle: Blair rounds on BBC over Campbell story

fields.headline: Blair rounds on BBC over Campbell story
fields.standfirst:
Downing Street press secretary to be moved out of the limelight in series of changes among the prime minister's closest aides

Full coverage of Election 2001
Guardian Unlimited Politics
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Downing Street found itself embroiled in a fresh row over political spinning yesterday after the government rounded on the BBC for reporting that Alastair Campbell is to stand down as the prime minister's press secretary after the general election.
fields.body:
Downing Street found itself embroiled in a fresh row over political spinning yesterday after the government rounded on the BBC for reporting that Alastair Campbell is to stand down as the prime minister's press secretary after the general election.

In a harshly worded statement, Downing Street accused the BBC of trivialising politics when television and radio bulletins followed up newspaper reports that Mr Campbell would take on a less visible role as the prime minister's media director.

"It is typical of the media's obsession with process and personality, rather than the serious issues facing the country, that a newspaper article about Alastair Campbell should feature on the BBC TV news ahead of an important speech by the prime minister about the future of our country's schools," a spokesman said.

Opponents accused Downing Street of hypocrisy, claiming that Mr Campbell had only himself to blame for the media's obsession with spinning after he allowed the BBC to make a lengthy programme about himself last year. Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrats' media spokesman, said: "Alastair Campbell is more guilty than anyone else for making spin the story. It is wrong for him to object to the BBC when he allowed them to make a programme about him."

A Tory spokesman said: "It is understandable that the BBC should run a story about Alastair Campbell ahead of a story about Tony Blair given that he is less the real deputy prime minister and increasingly the real prime minister."

The row over Mr Campbell will confirm the prime minister's view that his high profile press secretary should play a less visible role if Labour wins the general election. His post as director of communications will formalise a role Mr Campbell has already started to adopt in the past six months.

The prime minister asked Mr Campbell to stand down from the daily briefings in the autumn amid fears that his high profile was overshadowing the government's attempts to sell its achievements. In recent months Mr Campbell has started to return to the Downing Street briefings.

Labour sources said that the prime minister was forced to act after Mr Campbell became a household name in the wake of the Rory Bremner sketch which depicted him as an abrasive northerner barking orders at a feeble Tony Blair.

The new job for Mr Campbell will herald a series of changes in Downing Street. Anji Hunter, the prime minister's gatekeeper and friend since teenage days, is tipped for a new £120,000 role as Mr Blair's political secretary. This would place Ms Hunter at the same level as Mr Campbell and the prime minister's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, who are the only political figures in Downing Street who have the right to issue orders to civil servants. Phil Wilson, a lobbyist from the prime minister's Sedgefield constituency, is expected to be Ms Hunter's deputy.

Jon Cruddas, the prime minister's trade union fixer, is leaving to contest the safe Labour seat of Dagenham. James Purnell, a young policy adviser, is also set to become an MP. Faz Hakim, a key figure in the political office, has left to work in the private sector, while Pat McFadden, formerly Mr Blair's deputy chief of staff, has gone to Labour's headquarters in Millbank. Bruce Grocott, the prime minister's parliamentary aide, is standing down as an MP.

One Labour source said that Mr Blair must use staff changes to ensure that the gov ernment did not appear to be run by a "kitchen cabinet of unelected cronies".

"The damaging image is not one of spin, but the impression that the government is run by Tony and his unelected mates," the source said. "The new faces also need to ensure that Downing Street improves its relations with the Labour party to avoid a repeat of the fiascos over Ken Livingstone and Alun Michael.

"Labour faces difficult council elections in 2003 and 2004 and if Downing Street has not improved relations with the party by then we could find that the party will become very restless."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Robin Cook's Turncoat odds shorten on news that he is driving Britain even further up the US's rectum. Next week at the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva, Britain will join the Czechs (who did it last year and had 500,000 demonstrating outside their Havana embassy as a result) to co-sponsor the anti-Cuba resolution that the US plants annually on sycophantic allies to shore up the widely derided 40-year-old Cuban blockade which Britain, among countless others, officially opposes.
fields.body:
Robin Cook's Turncoat odds shorten on news that he is driving Britain even further up the US's rectum. Next week at the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva, Britain will join the Czechs (who did it last year and had 500,000 demonstrating outside their Havana embassy as a result) to co-sponsor the anti-Cuba resolution that the US plants annually on sycophantic allies to shore up the widely derided 40-year-old Cuban blockade which Britain, among countless others, officially opposes.

Once, CND stalwart Cookie would have joined Amnesty in condemning what is "widely perceived as a US-driven initiative". Obviously, it's right to worry about civil rights in Cuba - albeit Castro, unlike Bush, doesn't routinely execute people with a mental age of seven. Then again, it's odd that Britain plans no resolutions against Saudi Arabia, the UAE or other arms-buying allies who disdain elections in favour of floggings, tortures and executions. Labour MPs plan to pressurise the FO, which may place minister Brian Wilson, a keen supporter of Cuba who has met Castro many times, in a bit of a bind.

As for Cookie, well, I'm not much cop at phoneticising retching noises so let it suffice that Steptoe now has him as clear Turncoat favourite at 7-4.

 One who missed out narrowly on a Turncoat nomination, home office minister in the Lords Steve Bassam makes a bold bid for the Original Humorist of the Year award. His lordship, a former squatter and Brighton leftie who now propounds the policy of chucking out 'bogus asylum seekers', proves that wit and New Labour are far from mutually exclusive with a dangerously amusing conclusion to his gravelly voiced answerphone message. "You are the weakest link," this goes, "goodbye." How do they think them up? Steve has until this time next week to re-record, or I'm afraid the trouble starts.

 Intriguing news from the Daily Telegraph, which positions itself more and more aggressively in the vanguard of feminist thinking. Conrad Black's Hollinger International intends to shrink page size by up to 4cm. It's nothing so crude as an attempt to shave a few million a year off the newsprint bill. Not at all.

"It's more a question that smaller papers are viewed as more user-friendly, especially by women," explains Dan Colson, the chief executive, "whose arms aren't as long." Steadfastly undenied, meanwhile, is a rumour that Crazy Janet Daley is leaving to make space on the comment page for Andrea Dworkin.

 I am shocked to bits by a slur levelled at Boris the Jackal Johnson. Mischievous rumour has it that the Jackal is fighting a rearguard action to keep his Spectator editorship when he becomes Tory MP for Henley.

The idea that someone of his intellect would think he could edit an influential Tory journal while seeking advancement within the Tory party ... I'm that close to taking to my bed with a fit of the vapours. Poor show.

 Victoria from Brave PR calls on behalf of a shop, asking after my hobbies so that she can send a free book "as a gesture of goodwill". How sweet. "Well, we're just having a celebration of ******," she explains, "and we want our friends to celebrate too." Friends ... how lovely. So Victoria won't be wanting a plug in return then? "No, no. Well, I mean, of course that'd be nice, but it really is just a goodwill gesture." In that case, while I work out my hobbies, let's not sully our new friendship with the grubby fingerprints of commerce.

 Reithian values flourish again at the BBC, where the Newsnight set was dismantled the other night to reveal the word c*** aerosoled on the panel at the front of the presenter's desk. Sorry to disappoint Denis Norden and his telly bloopers show, but it was spotted in time and painted over.

webTitle: Real IRA vows to step up terrorist campaign

fields.headline: Real IRA vows to step up terrorist campaign
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Politics
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissident Irish republicans vowed last night to step up their terrorist campaign, fuelling fears that hardliners will use the impasse in the peace process to launch a wave of attacks in Northern Ireland and England.
fields.body:
Dissident Irish republicans vowed last night to step up their terrorist campaign, fuelling fears that hardliners will use the impasse in the peace process to launch a wave of attacks in Northern Ireland and England.

As army explosives experts prepared to defuse a bomb in Co Tyrone, the Real IRA insisted that it would make no apology for "undertaking the necessary task" of waging a violent campaign.

In a statement to mark the 85th anniversary of the republican Easter Rising in Dublin in 1916, the terrorist leadership declared: "Partition has failed and those who attempt to uphold it will fail. As for republicans, we will continue to attack the problem at its root and make no apology for undertaking this necessary task. We will continue our struggle until the 32 county socialist republic has been achieved."

The statement, which contrasted with a Provisional IRA statement on Wednesday night reaffirming support for the peace process, came as little surprise to leaders across the political spectrum who fear that the failure to resolve the deadlock over arms will strengthen the position of dissidents opposed to the peace process.

The threat posed by the dissidents was underlined yesterday when security forces were called out to deal with a so called "barrack buster" bomb at Altmore Forest, Galbally, Co Tyrone.

The bomb was discovered 10 miles from the scene of the Real IRA attack at Omagh in 1998 - the largest single atrocity of the Troubles, which killed 29 people and two unborn babies.

Bomb disposal experts began examining a van containing the bomb yesterday in a painstaking operation which may take several days to complete.

There were fears last night that dissidents were planning to mount a "spectacular" attack to mark the anniversary of the Easter Rising in which 15 republicans were executed in Dublin by British forces.

Since the Omagh bombing the dissidents have launched several bomb attacks on security bases in Northern Ireland and on high profile targets in London, including the MI6 headquarters and BBC television centre.

The security forces have managed to thwart many more attacks through surveillance. Security sources say their success in targeting the dissidents demonstrates the importance of keeping army watch towers in border areas of south Armagh.

Sinn Fein insists that dismantling the towers would be a boost for the peace process and would diminish support for the dissidents.

The watch towers will take centre stage when the British and Irish governments resume negotiations after the election to overcome the deadlock in the peace process.

Under a three point plan, the British army would dismantle the watch towers in return for a significant gesture by the Provisional IRA over weapons. In the new climate, nationalists and republicans would sign up to the new police force.

Sinn Fein warned this week that there was little chance of an agreement after the election because republicans should not be expected to make concessions in the light of David Trimble's "illegal" ban on Sinn Fein attending a special cross border ministerial council.

Mitchel McLaughlin, Sinn Fein chairman, called instead for a renegotiation of the Good Friday agreement to save the peace process from a challenge by hardline unionists after the general election.

Adam Ingram, the Northern Ireland minister, said he hoped that Sinn Fein was not abandoning its support for the agreement, adding that republicans should concentrate on resolving the impasse over IRA arms.

Mr Ingram told the Today programme: "I would hope that [Mr McLaughlin's remarks] do not mean that Sinn Fein is moving away from the Good Friday agreement... If Sinn Fein is genuinely seeking a new future for Northern Ireland it has got to address all the issues and that includes decommissioning."

fields.headline: You middle class lot
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: If the Guardian is to continue with its republican campaign it should declare an interest. If we didn't have a monarch who would be up for president? Clever, middle-class people like editor Alan Rusbridger. But he isn't going to get his heart's desire by pointing out the deficiencies in the behaviour of our minor royals.
fields.body:
If the Guardian is to continue with its republican campaign it should declare an interest. If we didn't have a monarch who would be up for president? Clever, middle-class people like editor Alan Rusbridger. But he isn't going to get his heart's desire by pointing out the deficiencies in the behaviour of our minor royals.

Are Prince and Princess Michael freeloaders - as the Guardian today suggests? - Whether they're perfectly charming and hard-working individuals or monsters beyond one's wildest nightmares, has no bearing on whether we should be a monarchy or a republic.

Prince Michael can have sex with donkeys and eat babies for breakfast without it affecting our constitution. He is not the monarch, merely a reminder that we have one. But, you may say, that is the point. The Guardian is not interested in his behaviour as an individual. The story is rather one of royals abusing their position. In other words, it's not the possibility of a donkey being stuffed that's a problem. It's a donkey being royally stuffed.

Well, it is certainly disappointing to read that members of the extended royal family may be as idle, greedy and self-important as hacks on a press trip (or politicians on a fact-finding visit). But if their behaviour is no better than that of many opinion formers and potential presidents, it is no worse and we can punish them if we feel so inclined.

For the moment we merely put them in the stocks for a few days and write rude things about them. But we could get rid of them entirely. Not liquidate them, in the usual republican style, but take away their royal status. However, before we do that we should first remind ourselves what services minor royals provide.

What would be lost if we cut off their royal suffixes? In the first place charities, as well as businesses, benefit from royal associations. We used to be prepared to look at a picture of a child with her leg blown off if the Princess of Wales was in the frame too. But it is the celebrity that royal status bestows, rather than royalty per se that is important - as a letter in yesterday's Guardian reminded us.

Responding to an article by Vicki Woods, which asked whether Jemima Khan is the new Princess Di, Anita Tiessan, deputy director of Unicef UK noted acidly that, "At Unicef we welcome the support of our celebrity partners in helping to bring attention to people in situations frequently marginalised by the media... If there is a media outlet out there that is not influenced by the power of celebrity please step forward."

Sadly true. Of course, if Jemima Khan does not have quite the media pull of the late Princess of Wales, she is a more than adequate alternative to Princess Pushy. So if the minor royals are to stay they have to offer something no one else can give. Not even Jemima Khan. What could it be? Why, blood, of course.

The monarchy is a great source of stability. But this would not be so without a secure succession. The Queen's many relations provide that. The only question is, just how many do we need?

Well, in the absence of endemic plague, or a new blue blood disease, far fewer than we currently have. Who on earth is Prince Michael, anyway? How is he related to the Queen? Does anyone who's not an avid royal watcher or genealogist understand? I certainly haven't got a clue. He could be a mad scientist's Nicholas II clone for all I know.

It would surely be far better if the obscure Michaels of Kent stopped bothering our embassies. Better for us, because it is not good for our souls to be thinking venomous thoughts whenever we read about them; better for them, because they may learn humility; better for the monarch because the Guardian will not then be able to use them as a stick to beat her with and, finally, better for the Guardian whose editors will then have fewer celebrities to distract them from serious issues.

The minor royals are less a creation of our constitution than they are of the press and the public. In the monarch we have a living symbol of the nation. Her ancestors and her progeny, her past and her future are bound up with the history of these islands and what is yet to come. The minor royals are part of that story. But only as footnotes. We could ignore them. We chose not to.

The minor royals have exactly the kind of pointless celebrity we feed off in the 21st century. Talent is no longer considered to be a necessary, or even particularly desirable, prerequisite to fame. Nor is power. TV presenters are now as famous as most of the people they interview.

The minor royals are being given more coverage than the Queen. But we can enjoy them or destroy them at will and either way their fate is utterly trivial.

But, you may say, that is the point. The Guardian is not interested in his behaviour as an individual. The story is rather one of royals abusing their position. In other words, it's not the possibility of a donkey being stuffed that's a problem. It's a donkey being royally stuffed. Well, it is certainly disappointing to read that members of the extended royal family may be as idle, greedy and self-important as hacks on a press trip (or politicians on a fact-finding visit). But if their behaviour is no better than that of many opinion formers and potential presidents, it is no worse and we can punish them if we feel so inclined. For the moment we merely put them in the stocks for a few days and write rude things about them. But we could get rid of them entirely. Not liquidate them, in the usual republican style, but take away their royal status. However, before we do that we should first remind ourselves what services minor royals provide. What would be lost if we cut off their royal suffixes? In the first place charities, as well as businesses, benefit from royal associations. We used to be prepared to look at a picture of a child with her leg blown off if the Princess of Wales was in the frame too. But it is the celebrity that royal status bestows, rather than royalty per se that is important - as a letter in yesterday's Guardian reminded us. Responding to an article by Vicki Woods, which asked whether Jemima Khan is the new Princess Di, Anita Tiessan, deputy director of Unicef UK noted acidly that, "At Unicef we welcome the support of our celebrity partners in helping to bring attention to people in situations frequently marginalised by the media... If there is a media outlet out there that is not influenced by the power of celebrity please step forward." Sadly true. Of course, if Jemima Khan does not have quite the media pull of the late Princess of Wales, she is a more than adequate alternative to Princess Pushy. So if the minor royals are to stay they have to offer something no one else can give. Not even Jemima Khan. What could it be? Why, blood, of course. The monarchy is a great source of stability. But this would not be so without a secure succession. The Queen's many relations provide that. The only question is, just how many do we need? Well, in the absence of endemic plague, or a new blue blood disease, far fewer than we currently have. Who on earth is Prince Michael, anyway? How is he related to the Queen? Does anyone who's not an avid royal watcher or genealogist understand? I certainly haven't got a clue. He could be a mad scientist's Nicholas II clone for all I know. It would surely be far better if the obscure Michaels of Kent stopped bothering our embassies. Better for us, because it is not good for our souls to be thinking venomous thoughts whenever we read about them; better for them, because they may learn humility; better for the monarch because the Guardian will not then be able to use them as a stick to beat her with and, finally, better for the Guardian whose editors will then have fewer celebrities to distract them from serious issues. The minor royals are less a creation of our constitution than they are of the press and the public. In the monarch we have a living symbol of the nation. Her ancestors and her progeny, her past and her future are bound up with the history of these islands and what is yet to come. The minor royals are part of that story. But only as footnotes. We could ignore them. We chose not to. The minor royals have exactly the kind of pointless celebrity we feed off in the 21st century. Talent is no longer considered to be a necessary, or even particularly desirable, prerequisite to fame. Nor is power. TV presenters are now as famous as most of the people they interview. The minor royals are being given more coverage than the Queen. But we can enjoy them or destroy them at will and either way their fate is utterly trivial. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Receivers see future for Cammell
fields.standfirst: Survival hopes rise as new bidders emerge for Mersey shipbuilder
fields.trailText: Receivers for Merseyside-based shipbuilder Cammell Laird said yesterday there had been expressions of interest from four parties in the future of the business or its assets.
fields.body:
Receivers for Merseyside-based shipbuilder Cammell Laird said yesterday there had been expressions of interest from four parties in the future of the business or its assets.

Edward Klempka, one of four receivers from accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers, said he was "cautiously optimistic" about selling the shipbuilder as a going concern after receiving two fresh inquiries yesterday. This is on top of two approaches to Cammell before it went into receivership on Wednesday.

Mr Klempka, who is credited with rescuing the Swan Hunter yard from receivership in 1995, received a mixed reception at the yard yesterday amid mounting speculation about the future of 1,800 jobs.

"There was initial misunderstanding at shopfloor level, but they are fully behind us now," he said. "Management have been extremely helpful."

Birkenhead MP Frank Field and John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, also welcomed Mr Klempka's presence on Merseyside yesterday. Mr Field said: "He is not a break-up merchant, and his aim is to sell the business as a going concern."

However, the optimism of Mr Klempka, Mr Field and Mr Edmonds was at odds with one City source, who last night insisted a break-up of Cammell Laird remained the most likely way for creditors to realise their assets.

The receivers said Cammell had run up debts of £150m - about £80m of which was owed to bond holders, £45m to banks and the rest to various other creditors.

The shipbuilder had been forced to call in the receivers after it failed to win support from Royal Bank of Scotland to help pay the first installment on a £78m bond issue.

The receivers confirmed the company had run into financial difficulties after committing £42m to the manufacture of the mid-section of a cruise ship for Italian firm Costa Crociere. The contract was unexpectedly cancelled in November. Mr Klempka said the company also lost £14m in the three months to March in the wake of the cancellation.

The high-profile setback also had knock-on effects for the shipbuilder as customers, concerned about the future of the troubled firm, took their business elsewhere.

Mr Klempka said there were unlikely to be a large number of redundancies among Cammell workers in the short term. "Business continues as usual on Merseyside and Tyneside."

webTitle: Internet adoption couple decide not to challenge ruling

fields.headline: Internet adoption couple decide not to challenge ruling
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The couple at the centre of the internet twins adoption wrangle have said they are not going to appeal against a court's ruling to return the babies to the US.
fields.body:
The couple at the centre of the internet twins adoption wrangle have said they are not going to appeal against a court's ruling to return the babies to the US.

Judith and Alan Kilshaw, from Buckley, north Wales, have apparently decided to slip back into obscurity after three months in the limelight. The couple, who have two sons, said the decision was in the best interests of the nine-month-old twins, Kimberley and Belinda, and their own children.

During a press conference in Cardiff yesterday, Mr Kilshaw, 46, said: "We have looked at the merits of an appeal and we have in reality to take into account the situation with our existing children and the strain on them and the serious restraints placed upon us by lack of public funding which we find to be totally unfair."

His wife Judith, 47, who also has two grown-up daughters, said they had no regrets.

When the babies return to the US, they will be looked after by their fifth set of carers in their short lives.

The saga began in January when it emerged the Kilshaws had bought the twins for £8,200 after contacting an internet adoption agency. A Californian couple, Vickie and Richard Allen, said they had already paid for the babies and had looked after them for two months, but were tricked into handing them over to their natural mother for an access visit.

The Allens have now dropped out of the custody battle after Mr Allen was arrested on suspicion of assaulting two teenage babysitters at his home in southern California.

An emergency protection order was served on the Kilshaws on January 18 by Flintshire county council and the twins were removed from the hotel where they were staying and taken into care by social workers. Since then, the girls have remained in the care of foster parents.

Michael Charles, the Kilshaws' solicitor, said: "Throughout the proceedings, they have been only too aware of the impact this has had on both the twins and their own children. In particular they are concerned about the continuing effect of being under the media's spotlight, which at times has been unkind and unfair."

He said the decision had been difficult as the Kilshaws cared very much for the twins. Another factor in their decision was the cost of an appeal.

Earlier this week a high court judge ruled that they should go back to the US to be cared for by foster parents until a US court decided what was in their best interests.

Mrs Kilshaw has spoken of her wish to start a new life in the US and the couple have not confirmed or denied whether they will fight for custody of the twins over there.

webTitle: Exodus as 1.5m take flight to warmer climes

fields.headline: Exodus as 1.5m take flight to warmer climes
fields.standfirst:
Spain, Tunisia, and Florida are top havens

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The countryside - according to the message feverishly pushed by the stricken tourist industry for the past fortnight - is open for business. But, as the nation begins its Easter bank holiday break today, it is a claim the British public appears to be ignoring.
fields.body:
The countryside - according to the message feverishly pushed by the stricken tourist industry for the past fortnight - is open for business. But, as the nation begins its Easter bank holiday break today, it is a claim the British public appears to be ignoring.

A record number of holidaymakers are eschewing the burning pyres and banned footpaths for the guaranteed warmth and rural freedom abroad.

A total of 1.5m people - 15% more than last Easter - are due to take last-minute breaks to the Canary islands, mainland Spain, Ibiza, Tunisia, Cyprus, Florida and the Caribbean, with more than 1m scheduled to depart from UK airports over the holiday period and at least 500,000 crossing the channel.

British tourist boards have reported a 30% drop in bookings with those areas affected by foot and mouth - such as Cumbria and parts of Devon - taking just 20% of their usual bookings for Easter.

Despite 37% of footpaths, and 85% of tourist attractions in Devon being open, the south-west - which has lost £25m since the start of April - fears it will lose another £16m over the Easter weekend alone, a crucial period which accounts for 60% of all its business in April.

"Bookings are holding up in the coastal regions, but on Exmoor and Dartmoor [both of which are closed to the public] we're looking at a loss of 80%," said Malcolm Bell, the chief executive of South West Tourism.

In Cumbria - which has been losing £10m a week through the crisis, with business down by two thirds - the situation appears to be even more critical.

With a complete ban on fell walking, and only a quarter of footpaths open, local pubs, hotels and bed and breakfasts have been shattered by the loss in passing trade. "We know of one hotel which had losses of 97% in March," said Allan King, of the Cumbria tourist board. "It's fully booked this weekend - but that's been partly achieved because the landlord's asked guests to offer him just what they think the weekend's worth."

Tony Blair and his deputy, John Prescott, yesterday embarked on separate tours to woo visitors back to tourist destinations.

Mr Blair, on a walkabout in Torquay in Devon, said: "Even in the heart of the countryside, provided people do not go through the livestock parts, they can do the things they always do and enjoy the countryside in the way they should."

Mr Prescott, taking a canal boat trip in Hertfordshire to endorse the reopening nationwide of 1,000 miles of towpaths and the inland waterway network, said: "I'm encouraging people to go out and look at the walks they could do. I might even do it myself this weekend."

With cool and rainy weather predicted, holidaymakers renouncing the countryside and the continent are expected to opt instead for city breaks - up by 30% on last year, according to the market leaders - and to flock to shopping centres, amusement parks and city centre attractions.

The AA warned that shopping trips could cause blackspots on the M1 near Sheffield, the M60 near the Trafford centre, and the M23 near Cheshire Oaks outlet village on Merseyside.

"If people can't head off into the countryside, they're going to have to find other things to keep them amused and the options will be cinemas, shopping centres and perhaps museums," said AA spokesman Luke Bosdet.

webTitle: Axed arts bodies threaten to go it alone

fields.headline: Axed arts bodies threaten to go it alone
fields.standfirst: Chaos forecast over 'moronic' plan to centralise funding
fields.trailText: Chaos forecast over 'moronic' plan to centralise funding.
fields.body:
The Arts Council was last night plunged into crisis with eight of the 11 regional arts boards in rebellion at its "moronic" plans to abolish them. Some are even threatening to set up their own rival federal organisation which would deal directly with the government.

If the boards, which must disband within the next month, were to go it alone, the system of arts funding would be thrown into chaos at a time when the extra cash is at last pouring in after two decades of destructive decline.

The Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, plans to wind up the autonomous regional boards - run by local politicians, business people and artists - by mid-May and replace them with regional executive officers reporting to the Arts Council in London.

The changes - sold as a radical solution to bureaucratic nightmare now facing artists - were presented as a fait accompli last month, and the boards given two months to wind themselves up. Despite the revolt, the Arts Council last night insisted the new system would be in place by January 2002 . Mr Robinson, the chairman of the Granada group, who has a fearsome reputation for cutting away corporate fat, said he was "sick to death" of hearing of the bureaucratic hoops artists had to jump through and wanted to able to give them the money "and let them get on with it".

Mark Scrimshaw, of Northern Arts, which is leading the revolt, said all the local boards were independent limited companies and did not "have to listen to what anyone in London think is best for us. The whole thing has been outrageous. Whatever way you look at this, it is a moronic and major attack on local autonomy."

He claimed only two of the 11 regional arts boards were in favour of the changes. "The solution proposed by the Arts Council is 180 degrees wrong. We are going to ignore their deadline to wind ourselves up by May 15. We are rock solid on this, everyone is deeply offended."

Mr Scrimshaw said one option being looked at was to copy the Canadian federal model, which would involve the regional boards setting up a small office in London to negotiate funding with the Department of Culture.

The changes were "about centralisation and not improving the lives of artists" and that much of the "pointless" form-filling had been forced on the boards by the civil service.

The Northern Arts chairman, George Loggie, was equally vehement. He said it would put up a vigorous fight against any scheme that left it "with little or no teeth, or no responsibility".

Ironically, Northern Arts had been held out as a paragon of efficiency by the Arts Council itself, characterised as one of the "progressive" cheerleaders of change.

The rebels have taken comfort from comments made by the culture secretary which seemed to pour cold water on Mr Robinson's grand design for slimmer, swifter organisation. Chris Smith said he had reservations about how the plans might be implemented, and their impact on local democracy, and made great play of the need for "a consultative process".

Few artists, however, mourned the news of the passing of the regional boards, with many, particularly in problem areas like the south-east, claiming they were "part of the problem".

 The arts minister, Alan Howarth, yesterday gave the strongest hint yet that the government would take a dim view of the closure of the Croydon Warehouse theatre.

The Warehouse, the only producing theatre in south London, was one of only three theatres nationally to miss out on a £70m three-year government rescue package for live drama. Closure is threatened because the theatre is also set to lose its guaranteed funding from the London arts board next year.

fields.headline: Our lost religion
fields.standfirst:
The atheists may cheer the exit from organised religious belief, but there's no virtue in wholesale ignorance

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The atheists may cheer the exit from organised religious belief, but there's no virtue in wholesale ignorance.
fields.body:
"Thank God it's Good Friday!" exclaimed a DJ yesterday. Forgive him, he probably knew not what he said. A recent Mori poll found that 43% of the population do not know what Easter celebrates. A large number of the young haven't a clue, beyond hot cross buns, bonnets, chocolate eggs, lambs and daffodils. Maybe death and redemption do lack a certain zingy selling power. But this kind of ignorance and loss of heritage sets off a crisis of culture panic.

How can people look at a painting or sculpture or read a book of previous centuries or understand anything about history if they don't know this most essential Christian story - let alone the difference between a Catholic and a Protestant? Without a basic knowledge of Christianity the past is a closed book. Mythology, iconography, the common roots of stories and ideas are all missing. Resurrection may be a solstice theme stolen from a pagan rite of spring, but how can anyone appreciate the depth of passion and the overwhelming humanity in the face of Piero della Francesca's redeemer rising from the tomb, without understanding his story? A surprising poll in the Tablet yesterday shows that only half the practising members of the Church of England genuinely believe the resurrection happened. But it does not require belief to appreciate the myth's iconic power. Freud used the Greek myths, Shakespeare drew on any number of classical and historic sources, the truth of which are unimportant. Basic Bible stories are one of the foundations of western culture, without which much of it is incomprehensible.

Without an elementary grasp of religion, much of the news becomes meaningless. It is impossible to expound the politics of the Middle East or India and Pakistan without some notion of Judaism, Islam and Hinduism. No sense can be made of the conflicts we are helping police in the Balkans without knowing something about the differences between the religions that act as artificial ethnic identifiers. Nightly the news brings pictures of yet more bloodshed from the accursed city of Jerusalem, that ill-fated breeding place of three of the world religions that have caused such calamity. The tribal slaughter makes no sense to anyone without a smattering of religious knowledge.

The good atheist/agnostic may be gratified at the departure of organised religion from most of British national life, but there should be no pleasure in wholesale ignorance of their history. Lack of knowledge and analysis seems to leave people still susceptible to other sorts of superstitions - crystals, the zodiac, pentangles or Hopi ear candles - less lethal if equally misleading.

It is curious how this government clings to religion. Here we are, the most secular nation (48% proclaim no particular religion, only 7% are Christian churchgoers and 3% practising Muslims and Hindus), yet a Cool Britannia leadership eagerly courts its tattered remnants. They chase after religion as if it were a short cut to the national soul. When David Blunkett says he wishes he could bottle religion to spread its values throughout his school system, or Tony Blair lavishes praise on religious organisations, it only suggests that New Labour's own core values may be a bit weak. The convictions that fired the party's founders were quite enough to sustain their sense of purpose and moral impetus, without resorting to the supernatural. Does the party leadership feel a lack of sufficiently passionate secular values to give them moral ballast?

This pervasive ignorance of Christianity might mean religion really does not matter any more. Like the monarchy and the remaining hereditary peers, the established church is often seen as just another moribund shell, signifying nothing beyond ceremonial and tradition. But these ancient institutions are insidious in the ways they seep into the imagination and the self-image of the country. The Guardian is challenging the Act of Settlement in the courts, testing whether the new Human Rights Act will outlaw the discrimination that forbids Catholics or those married to them ascending a throne only open to C of E communicants, while giving sons precedence over daughters. Is it just tilting at windmills? We think not. The power of religion in the constitution is set to grow, not shrink, in a new House of Lords where the 25 bishops will be joined by guaranteed seats for other faiths. (Will Moonies and Scientologists sue if they don't get their places too? There is no legal definition of religion.)

Now the Home Office is considering legislation to ban religious discrimination whose effect would be to stifle free speech and ridicule, extending blasphemy laws that should be abolished. The ever vigilant campaigners of the National Secular Society keep pointing up the anomalies in the state's wooing of the church. Why in the last budget was there VAT relief for church buildings, but not for secular historic monuments?

Yesterday a new Muslim school in Birmingham was given state school status. Since various Christian sects have control of one in four state primaries already, while the Sikhs and Seventh Day Adventists have their own state schools too, there is no way to prevent other faiths demanding separatist schools. Once established, they are almost impossible to close down again. Although they are by nature discriminatory and contrary to Labour's proclaimed pluralism and multiculturalism, the government is promising yet more. The miraculous special "ethos" of church schools extolled by David Blunkett is quite simple to explain. Their popularity has less to do with God than selection, often done with waiting lists which help the quick-off-the-mark middle classes congregate together there. Parents mumbling through psalms and catechisms to get a vicar's letter for school entry is a good pew-filler. Church schools deter Muslim parents, while more Muslim schools only add to the risk of keeping children culturally segregated. Religious schools are by faith likely to be anti-gay, anti-abortion, Catholic and anti-contraception or Muslims teaching that women's place is "one step behind".

However, teaching about religion is not the same as religious teaching. People need some historical grasp of world faiths but somewhere in the muddle of legislation, this concept has been lost. Tory education secretary Kenneth Baker's disreputable law which still obliges all schools to conduct a daily act of Christian worship so angered teachers that it was entirely counter-productive. Not enough teachers can be found willing or able to conduct services with a straight face so it is widely flouted. But resentment seems to have led to a failure to teach anything about religion, even from a secular perspective - resulting in nearly half the population not knowing what Easter is.

The Fabians today call for more national holidays. We have the fewest in the EU: Italy has 15 days, over-worked Britain has 8. The stricken tourism industry desperately wants more. Most mark religious festivals, so the Fabians want secular celebrations. Shakespeare day, perhaps? Or is he destined for the same black memory hole as the Bible?

webTitle: Comment: US-Sino relations are more complex under Bush

fields.headline: Rightwing US policy makes China more conservative too
fields.standfirst:
US-Sino relations are even more complex under Bush

Special report: China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: US-Sino relations are even more complex under Bush.
fields.body:
As the train rushed through the Chinese countryside, he leapt to his feet in the swaying compartment to declaim with astonishing recall and great passion Martin Luther King's speech beginning "I have a dream..." The young man, encountered by chance on a journey across southern China a few years ago, was a graduate of the Shanghai Foreign Languages Academy, a protesting student in that city at the time of Tiananmen and, as one of the country's new entrepreneurs, already on the way to making a fortune out of cellular phones.

Arrested and briefly detained, he had become a businessman rather than the official he would almost certainly have been only a few years earlier. But the cellphone proselytiser had in no way reneged on the democratic hopes that had sent him out onto the Shanghai streets in 1989.

That moment on the train allowed one to see how much Chinese ideas of personal freedom are bound up with their understanding of America and its possibilities. And their understanding, also, of how far America has fallen short of those possibilities. The reformer Kang Youwei, born in 1858, reflected that even though slavery had been the issue over which America fought their civil war, "To this day the American people do not admit the equality of black people," as they still did not when King spoke.

These intertwined ideas of America - an inspiring vision of freedom, but an imperfect and sometimes contradictory reality - have always run in educated Chinese minds as a counterpoint to the more visible political and diplomatic manoeuvres of the two countries over many years. After all, the appearance in Tiananmen Square of a papier maché model of the Statue of Liberty was one of the events that infuriated the elderly leaders trying to control the situation from the government complex of Zhongnanhai.

And, after all, the men behind the recent release of the Tiananmen Papers, which show how those leaders debated, dithered and finally did the worst possible thing, chose American scholars as their helpers in a dramatic effort to reopen the debate on democracy in China. The issue which Zhao Ziyang, the loser in 1989, raised when, according to the Tiananmen Papers, he told the other leaders "If the party doesn't hold up the banner of democracy in our country someone else will, and we will lose out" has still not been settled.

This is the broader moral and cultural background to the clash between American superpower and Chinese regional power seen in episodes like that of the American spy plane. The two touch one another at certain interesting points. The American instinct is to see a crisis of this kind in terms of the plight of individuals - the captured American crew and their families and, in this case, the missing Chinese interceptor pilot and his family. President Bush's direct expressions of sympathy to the wife of Wang Wei, the lost pilot, may well have infuriated the Chinese government. They seem to have responded by having her write to the White House asking for a state apology.

"In the eyes of the Chinese leaders" according to one experienced Chinese observer, "apologies in a situation like this are not due to individuals but to the state. For the American president to go over their heads to address a Chinese citizen was quite out of order." Out of order, that is, because it emphasises that individuals have rights, rights which sometimes must outweigh governmental considerations.

It is the same point the US made this week when it tabled a resolution critical of China at the UN Commission on Human Rights in Geneva. Yet, even if the Chinese government remains wedded officially to the state to state view, they too must defer to the modern preoccupation with individual fate, and did so with many hours of programming on the search for Wang Wei. This resembled less the old socialist hero model of coverage than the American model of reality TV, noted John Pomfret of The Washington Post.

The rights of individuals, the principle on which Chinese and western governments, although not necessarily the Chinese and western peoples, differ most sharply, have come to shadow almost all the critical issues. The future of Taiwan, the most critical question before the two countries, remains a strategic question but has also become, in effect, a question of human rights.

Since the 1972 Shanghai communique, in which the US acknowledged the one China policy, the moral basis for resisting China's claim on Taiwan ceased to be that nationalist China was the legitimate government of the whole country and certainly ought to prevail in the small portion it still controlled. It has been, instead, simply that a majority of individuals on that island do not wish to be ruled by Beijing. As Taiwan has become more democratic, the argument from rights has become more and more convincing, at least to the west and perhaps, at an underground level, in China as well.

The complexities of the relationship between China and America have deepened since Bush came to power. In both countries there are men in positions of responsibility and influence who would be comfortable with a more adversarial situation, although not one so hostile as to undermine an economic intimacy of great value, for different reasons, to both sides, or to drive China back into isolation from the world.

Nevertheless, a rightwing American government, acting in part in defence of human rights, may in the process be strengthening the conservative elements in the Chinese party, government, and military which are least likely to advance those rights in China. That same American government, while professing a desire that China be brought fully into various world bodies, may in fact end up limiting that engagement. Because the Bush team made it so clear, during the election campaign and in the first weeks of power, that they intended to be tougher with China they may already have narrowed the options for the more liberal figures in the Chinese ruling class. That said, it was clear before Bush's victory that both the American and Chinese military establishments were shaping policies that made a degree of confrontation more likely. Hainan has only been a rather earlier confirmation of this than expected.

Now comes the decision on Taiwan arms. It is more likely after Hainan that the Bush administration will decide to supply the weapons that Taiwan wants. No matter that the weapons will not be deployed for six or more years, and no matter that Taiwan's somewhat rundown armed forces may not be able to use them all that effectively. Taiwan understandably wants a signal of American resolve, and it could well get it. Unhappily, what may buttress confidence and democracy in Taiwan could well restrict the prospects for political reform and change in the Peoples Republic, leaving unsettled for even longer the issue that Zhao Ziyang raised so sharply in 1989.

martin.woollacott@theguardian.com

webTitle: Warm welcomes await freed spy plane crew

fields.headline: Homeward bound
fields.standfirst:
Warm welcomes await freed spy plane crew

Special report: China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The 24 US spy plane crew freed by China on Wednesday arrived back on American soil yesterday when a C-17 transporter, The Spirit of Bob Hope, touched down at Hickam air force base in Hawaii shortly after 6.30am local time.
fields.body:
The 24 US spy plane crew freed by China on Wednesday arrived back on American soil yesterday when a C-17 transporter, The Spirit of Bob Hope, touched down at Hickam air force base in Hawaii shortly after 6.30am local time.

The 21 men and three women at the centre of the 11-day standoff with China, left the aircraft in military fatigues, to be greeted by crowds of service families waving the Stars and Stripes and a band playing God Bless America.

"Aloha and good morning," Admiral Thomas Fargo, commander in chief of the US Pacific Fleet, told them in a short welcoming ceremony.

It was watched by President George Bush on television over lunch at the White House.

"We're definitely glad to be back," the navy spy plane commander and pilot Lieutenant Shane Osborn replied.

He said the crew were "all healthy and ready to get home".

On Saturday the crew are due to be flown back to the US mainland, where they will be reunited with their families at Whidbey island naval air base in Washington state.

As American television networks began what is expected to be several days of patriotic wallowing over the returning crew, there were hints in Washington that the administration is quietly preparing a tougher line towards Beijing now that the crew have been released.

The administration was already due to decide within a few days whether to sell a big package of arms to Taiwan.

Whatever the decision on the arms sale, Washington is now expected to offer a separate calculated insult to China by giving the Taiwanese president, Chen Shui-bian, a transit visa to visit the US en route to several Latin American countries next month.

fields.headline: The long wait
fields.standfirst:
My week: James Coursen

Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: James Coursen's 28-year-old son Shawn was one of the American spy plane crew held on Hainan Island by the Chinese for 11 days.  Mr Coursen describes his week.
fields.body:
James Coursen, 64, is a retired lithographer from Niles, Ohio. His 28-year-old son Shawn was one of the American spy plane crew held on Hainan Island by the Chinese for 11 days.

My son Shawn is a first-class cryptologist, but that's pretty much all we know about his job. He's been 11 years in the navy, but all he says about it is: "It's all classified." He won't tell us anything about it. We know he was in Kuwait, but that's all, until this. He's based up in north Japan right now - he's always been based in that area - and he's married to a girl in Okinawa; they have a child. She's five.

It was early on a Monday morning when we found out. We got a call. I guess that was last week now. Since then it's just been . . . it was unbelievable. The government would call us; then the media. You got one call saying they were talking; then four or five hours later you got a call saying it was all off. It was hard . . . My wife, Susan, has chased me to the doctor a few times this week.

It's really been having the grandchildren around that's kept us going. I coach recreational soccer and we all had a game on Monday. That took our minds off the waiting. We finally talked to Shawn on Wednesday about noon . . . on Hainan Island . . . but only for seconds. He just said: "See you soon - we are out of here." He sounded tired. Very tired. Then we talked to him again about 1am when he got to Guam [the American crew arrived there early yesterday, in a chartered passenger jet, en route to Washington]. fields.headline: Double trouble
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth epidemic and asylum seekers hit Eurotunnel
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth epidemic and asylum seekers hit Eurotunnel
fields.body:
Eurotunnel and airports operator BAA yesterday reported that profit levels had been hit by the foot and mouth epidemic.

Eurotunnel, which operates the Channel tunnel rail link, said that asylum seekers had also caused problems in the first quarter. The company has called on the British and French governments to take action to stem the flow of illegal immigrants, who are, it says, disrupting services.

Its turnover fell 2% for the first three months of the year from last year to £129.7m. Lower retail revenues, following the ending of an agreement with BAA, also contributed to the decline.

Eurotunnel said its Dover to Calais freight market rose by 8% in the first quarter of 2001 from last year.

But it added that its car market for the same route fell by 10% during the quarter.

Passenger numbers for the Eurostar rail service rose by 4% in the first quarter to 1.6m. But Eurotunnel said the foot and mouth outbreak had affected the number of tourists arriving from the continent.

A spokesman said: "Britain has got a big perception problem which it has to work on."

Despite problems caused by the foot and mouth epidemic, BAA's seven UK airports handled 124.7m passengers in the financial year ending in March, 5.8% up over the previous year.

The travel winter season ended quietly with a rise of 1.1% in March compared with March 2000.
