webTitle: Peaceful protest at farm with a difference

fields.headline: Peaceful protest at farm with a difference
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The barricades are up, the cattle grids have been removed. The two lanes that lead into the farm are blocked by minibuses and cars. People watch the chained gates. If and when the slaughterers come to Oaklands Park farm near Newnham in Gloucestershire, they will meet peaceful and legal resistance.
fields.body:
The barricades are up, the cattle grids have been removed. The two lanes that lead into the farm are blocked by minibuses and cars. People watch the chained gates. If and when the slaughterers come to Oaklands Park farm near Newnham in Gloucestershire, they will meet peaceful and legal resistance.

Oaklands has been issued a category A notice by the Ministry of Agriculture which means that its sheep and cows must automatically be killed. As the outbreaks in Gloucestershire have spiralled in the past few days, Maff officials and vets have confirmed on separate visits that the farm is not infected, but no appeal is allowed and in theory all the animals must be shot because they are close to a confirmed outbreak.

But Oaklands is more than a farm. As well as having 60 cows, 100 Wensleydale sheep, a giant vegetable garden, an orchard and woods on 150 acres of lush organic pastures overlooking the river Severn, it is also a thriving, largely self-sufficient Camphill community based on the work of education pioneer Rudolf Steiner. There are 115 people on the small estate, including 50 adults with special needs and 25 children.

Oaklands is partly funded by government and local authorities and has been widely praised for its care in the community and educational programmes and the way it links handicapped people to the environment. The animals are at the centre of the community, and if they go, say the Oaklands leaders, then the effect could be devastating.

The farm is one of the most sustainable in Britain. Run on "biodynamic" lines, it is largely worked by those with special needs who range in age from 21 to 70.

Pat Thompson, who works at Oaklands, said: "They may not understand intellectually what is going on, but they are aware that something is wrong. They have seen the fires. All are aware on different levels".

An observer said: "These are happy, confident, willing people who have great dignity, take the initiative and work together. They watch things grow, they nurture the plants and animals. If the slaughterers come, there will be a huge hole and their life will be torn to shreds.

They are some of the most willing labourers in Britain, up at dawn to milk, herd, muck out the animals and work the gardens. The animals have been bred over 30 years for their docility. Each has a name and they reel them off: "That's Red Elsie, that's Long legs, that's Poppy... " said Michael. They will be almost impossible to replace.

The community is mixed, with volunteers, artists, a priest, therapists, weavers and craftspeople. Many others come to help. "We work with people who have lost their way", said John Neligan, Oaklands' director. "Agriculture brings them back into touch with themselves."

The community argues strongly for vaccination, and is working with solicitors and local vets who want to help. But they do not say Oaklands should be a special case.

If the disease is found, then they will accept that the animals must go. Before that they will resist peacefully as well as seeking epidemiological evidence and an appeal to the courts. "There will be a future if the animals go, but we are doing everything we can to stop the slaughter," said Mr Neligan.

fields.headline: Town appalled by massive pyre
fields.standfirst:
15,000 carcasses a week could be destroyed

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A three month mass burn to destroy 15,000 carcasses a week was announced by the Ministry of Agriculture and the army to an astonished and then angry audience of residents and local officials at Holsworthy, Devon, yesterday.
fields.body:
A three month mass burn to destroy 15,000 carcasses a week was announced by the Ministry of Agriculture and the army to an astonished and then angry audience of residents and local officials at Holsworthy, Devon, yesterday.

The reaction of David Pinney, the environment health officer for Torridge district council, who was not consulted about the plan, was that Holsworthy would have to be evacuated if the smoke blew towards the town and its hospital less than a mile away. He was in talks with the ministry last night.

Roads to the site on Arscott Farm were being built yesterday before the announcement was made and the army hopes to start the first burn over the Easter weekend.

David Smith, the town's postmaster and a Holsworthy councillor, said: "It is an incredible plan, no one was consulted, everyone is against it. They described this as a permanent burning site. They propose to have 10 rows of burning animals, 15,000 a week, until they have disposed of them all."

Mr Smith said that Mr Pinney arrived at the meeting unaware of the plan.

He told a meeting of 40 traders and councillors and officials he was dismayed at the potential effects on the town which, although it has a population of only 2,000, is the main market and business centre for the sparsely populated area on the edge of Dartmoor.

The large continuous fire to dispose of more than 150,000 carcasses has been planned in secret for two weeks after a series of plans for burial sites in the Devon area were abandoned for environmental reasons. Most objections were fears of poisoning the water supplies.

Mr Smith said: "We know they have a problem because there are many unburied animals lying about here, but this scheme is just crazy so close to the town. They left it until late on Thursday to tell us so it is difficult to mobilise resistance, but we cannot let this happen."

On Wednesday, the junior agriculture minister, Lady Hayman, admitted the ministry still had not solved the problem. When the government last published the figures there were 30,000 carcasses unburied in Devon and since then many more animals have been slaughtered.

Yesterday, the government continued to be secretive and would not disclose the total number of animals earmarked for slaughter so far, those slaughtered and those left unburied.

Daily totals were issued until last week but when it became clear that the ministry was falling further and further behind with its programme and the disposal of carcasses the figures were withdrawn because they were "inaccurate". The figures also showed that the fact Tony Blair took charge of the crisis to improve slaughter times did not appear to have made any difference.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister who was concerned that the public was being kept in the dark about the progress of the disease, requested the Cabinet Office to release the figures yesterday.

A spokeswoman for the Cabinet Office said that efforts were being made to update the figures so they were accurate.

Last night the ministry website giving maps of restricted zones, details of outbreaks, and advice to farmers on what to do to combat getting the disease, and how to apply for licences was taken down.

The only information available was that there had been 21 new cases up to 6.40pm yesterday bringing the total to 1,257. The last figure supplied a week ago was that nearly 400,000 carcasses remained to be destroyed and the numbers were still rising.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
In the thick of the lambing season, our diarist faces a new epidemic - ewes bearing triplets

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: In the thick of the lambing season, our diarist faces a new epidemic - ewes bearing triplets
fields.body:
I think we were a little calmer around here yesterday, as the lambing work keeps us going hour by hour. And we were immensely cheered by the surprise arrival of a giant basket of fruit and another of budding hyacinths sent to us by a friend in London. No doubt the contents were chosen to keep us all healthy and to mask the dreadful smells.

However, more Northumbrian farms were confirmed as infected premises on Wednesday night, just as the government's advisers were trying to persuade the nation it is getting better. Not here, it isn't. The battle for Northumberland's livestock is being fought every day.

Our landscape is bare. We are still feeding hay, which is unusual, because once lambing is well under way the grass usually starts to grow. We know spring has been cancelled, but now we wonder if summer will ever come. The weather remains cold and damp, with a raw north-easterly wind. And the putrid, smoky smell that lingers unpleasantly for hours was back yesterday.

There are now around 10 triplet-bearing ewes left to lamb in the Mule flock. They are in the tiny paddock in front of our house. Thirteen sheep lambed with triplets on Wednesday. We have had a busy time setting the spare third lambs on to sheep with only one. It is quite an achievement to have only a handful of ewes running with three - especially this year - as the ban on movement means we can't pass on the spares to anyone else.

There are three ways to persuade a ewe she has had two lambs when she may have only delivered one, or had one stillborn. First, if she has a dead lamb, the animal can be skinned. This little sheepskin jerkin is then put on the motherless lamb. It must be left on for three days, which is how long it takes for the foster ewe's milk to produce the right smell in the lamb. By the time we cut the hardened skin off, the aroma is interesting, to say the least.

The second method is to use a specially constructed wooden pen known as "the stocks". Each set takes four ewes. They can all eat and drink, stand up and lie down, and smell or lick their lambs, but the sheep are unable to turn right around or push the lambs away if they think one is not theirs. Again this system takes three days for the right smell to work through the lamb's system and convince the ewe that these two bouncing baby sheep really do belong to her. After three days in the stocks, each ewe has a further 48 hours in a wooden pen to complete the bonding process, then it is off to the field.

Occasionally, a stubborn ewe will have two sessions in the stocks. Even if she rejects one of the lambs, by the time she arrives outside the adopted lamb has learned enough to sneakily suckle from the rear, while the favoured lamb suckles the other side in a normal fashion.

The third method is what we call a "water set on". Just as a single bearing ewe is about to deliver, we lay her down on her side in a cleaned pen on top of a plastic feed bag which has been split along the side. As the lamb arrives, we catch it and all the birthing waters in the split sack.

The next step is to immerse the new arrival in a bucket of clean, warm water, to rinse off all the birthing fluids. Then we spray iodine on the navel and lay the lamb on clean straw. If the ewe has enough milk for two lambs - and they don't always - we then fetch a spare lamb to set on.

This lamb, which may be several days old, is immersed in the same water. Then we slide the lamb all over the split sacking, coating the animal in as much of the birthing juices and material as we can. If the ewe still has a water bag showing, we burst this over the lamb's head and apply iodine to its navel too. Then we tell the proud mum she has two lambs, and scarper off to the other end of the shed, leaving her in peace. The family unit is kept inside for the same magic three days, to make sure that both lambs and mothers know each other well.

Our adoption criterion is simple. It is done on a "need-to-have" basis. If a lamb needs a mother, or vice versa, we match them up. While we try approximately to match colour and size, gender and breed make no difference. In fact, some ewes have produced twins or triplets to different fathers. How do we know this? Well, Peter used two different breeds of ram, as in the middle of the breeding season we had a few calamities. But the lambs are arriving healthy and strong, and that is all that matters right now.

The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will return next Wednesday.

fields.bodyText: I think we were a little calmer around here yesterday, as the lambing work keeps us going hour by hour. And we were immensely cheered by the surprise arrival of a giant basket of fruit and another of budding hyacinths sent to us by a friend in London. No doubt the contents were chosen to keep us all healthy and to mask the dreadful smells. However, more Northumbrian farms were confirmed as infected premises on Wednesday night, just as the government's advisers were trying to persuade the nation it is getting better. Not here, it isn't. The battle for Northumberland's livestock is being fought every day. Our landscape is bare. We are still feeding hay, which is unusual, because once lambing is well under way the grass usually starts to grow. We know spring has been cancelled, but now we wonder if summer will ever come. The weather remains cold and damp, with a raw north-easterly wind. And the putrid, smoky smell that lingers unpleasantly for hours was back yesterday. There are now around 10 triplet-bearing ewes left to lamb in the Mule flock. They are in the tiny paddock in front of our house. Thirteen sheep lambed with triplets on Wednesday. We have had a busy time setting the spare third lambs on to sheep with only one. It is quite an achievement to have only a handful of ewes running with three - especially this year - as the ban on movement means we can't pass on the spares to anyone else. There are three ways to persuade a ewe she has had two lambs when she may have only delivered one, or had one stillborn. First, if she has a dead lamb, the animal can be skinned. This little sheepskin jerkin is then put on the motherless lamb. It must be left on for three days, which is how long it takes for the foster ewe's milk to produce the right smell in the lamb. By the time we cut the hardened skin off, the aroma is interesting, to say the least. The second method is to use a specially constructed wooden pen known as "the stocks". Each set takes four ewes. They can all eat and drink, stand up and lie down, and smell or lick their lambs, but the sheep are unable to turn right around or push the lambs away if they think one is not theirs. Again this system takes three days for the right smell to work through the lamb's system and convince the ewe that these two bouncing baby sheep really do belong to her. After three days in the stocks, each ewe has a further 48 hours in a wooden pen to complete the bonding process, then it is off to the field. Occasionally, a stubborn ewe will have two sessions in the stocks. Even if she rejects one of the lambs, by the time she arrives outside the adopted lamb has learned enough to sneakily suckle from the rear, while the favoured lamb suckles the other side in a normal fashion. The third method is what we call a "water set on". Just as a single bearing ewe is about to deliver, we lay her down on her side in a cleaned pen on top of a plastic feed bag which has been split along the side. As the lamb arrives, we catch it and all the birthing waters in the split sack. The next step is to immerse the new arrival in a bucket of clean, warm water, to rinse off all the birthing fluids. Then we spray iodine on the navel and lay the lamb on clean straw. If the ewe has enough milk for two lambs - and they don't always - we then fetch a spare lamb to set on. This lamb, which may be several days old, is immersed in the same water. Then we slide the lamb all over the split sacking, coating the animal in as much of the birthing juices and material as we can. If the ewe still has a water bag showing, we burst this over the lamb's head and apply iodine to its navel too. Then we tell the proud mum she has two lambs, and scarper off to the other end of the shed, leaving her in peace. The family unit is kept inside for the same magic three days, to make sure that both lambs and mothers know each other well. Our adoption criterion is simple. It is done on a "need-to-have" basis. If a lamb needs a mother, or vice versa, we match them up. While we try approximately to match colour and size, gender and breed make no difference. In fact, some ewes have produced twins or triplets to different fathers. How do we know this? Well, Peter used two different breeds of ram, as in the middle of the breeding season we had a few calamities. But the lambs are arriving healthy and strong, and that is all that matters right now. The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will return next Wednesday. webTitle: Forest of Dean cull fails to halt disease

fields.headline: Forest of Dean cull fails to halt disease
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A mass cull of hundreds of thousands of farm animals between the rivers Severn and Wye in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire, was last night being considered to try to prevent foot and mouth getting out of control in the county, and in neighbouring Herefordshire and the Welsh borders.
fields.body:
A mass cull of hundreds of thousands of farm animals between the rivers Severn and Wye in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire, was last night being considered to try to prevent foot and mouth getting out of control in the county, and in neighbouring Herefordshire and the Welsh borders.

The Ministry of Agriculture fears the disease will run through farms as it did in Cumbria, where the disease has led to the slaughter of more than 500,000 animals.

The total number of cases in Gloucestershire had risen to 73 last night with eight new cases reported in 24 hours. Outbreaks have occurred on both sides of the Severn but the most serious problem is in the Forest of Dean where the unfenced area is surrounded by hundreds of farms.

A mass cull of all free roaming sheep in the open forest has failed to halt the spread of the disease. The government's chief scientist, David King, identified the area on Wednesday as one where the future course of the disease could not be predicted.

All 7,500 unfenced sheep in the forest were rounded up between April 1 and 7 and slaughtered as a precaution but tests showed that the disease was already prevalent in the flock and it might have travelled much further to neighbouring farms. No decision had been made yesterday about how extensive the new cull might need to be.

webTitle: Leader: Politicians should stay close to home

fields.headline: Home sweet home
fields.standfirst:
Politicians need to stay as close as possible

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: On this day of reflection and meditation, perhaps we should all spare a forgiving thought for Alasdair Morrison. He is Scotland's tourism minister who has run into trouble for taking a holiday - in Italy.
fields.body:
On this day of reflection and meditation, perhaps we should all spare a forgiving thought for Alasdair Morrison. He is Scotland's tourism minister who has run into trouble for taking a holiday - in Italy. Of course there is always an amusing headline to be had when a politician fails to practice what he preaches, but it is the timing of Mr Morrison's Tuscan jaunt that has put him on the rack.

For Scotland, like the rest of the United Kingdom, is fighting foot and mouth disease, with ministers campaigning hard to tell the world the country is still open for holidaymakers' business. Indeed Mr Morrison accompanied Scotland's first minister, Henry McLeish, on a high-profile trip to the United States last week to drum up business: the latter even got a long session with George W Bush, in what was billed as the first US-Caledonian summit.

Now the Edinburgh press has rounded on the hapless tourism minister, charging that what was good enough for the American public was clearly not good enough for him. His actions, they say, suggest that while a cosy cabin in Stornaway may be an ideal destination for the stressed workers of Ohio, it is not quite right for a Scottish minister. How enthusiastic can Mr Morrison be for his home country if he takes his hols not in Inverness, but in Florence?

Of course this is hideously unfair. As it happens, the tourism minister is planning a vacation in Dumfries and Galloway and the Isle of Skye - in addition to his trip to Italy. Even if he was not, he would surely be as entitled to travel abroad as any other citizen. But, sadly, this is all besides the point. For Mr Morrison's chosen vocation is politics, and politics has a logic all its own. For a man promoting travel to Scotland to flee the country is bad politics, plain and simple. Nor can ministers simply keep their holiday plans secret. No, we fear that in the current climate, there is only one risk-free destination for politicians: home.

fields.headline: Warmer seas reveal climate change
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Global warming is real, and humans are responsible for it, US scientists say today. Below the waves the oceans are warming in step with greenhouse predictions.
fields.body:
Global warming is real, and humans are responsible for it, US scientists say today. Below the waves the oceans are warming in step with greenhouse predictions.

A team of oceanographers funded by the US department of energy, and another from the US government's ocean and atmosphere administration report in Science today that they have preliminary evidence of human-induced warming from measurements of the first 3,000 metres of the oceans.

Last month President George W Bush announced the US would not sign the Kyoto agree ment to reduce greenhouse emissions, claiming there was still scientific disagreement.

The oceans cover 72% of the Earth's surface. They absorb huge amounts of heat from the sun and serve as a "memory" of the climate system. Both teams of researchers matched ocean temperature measurements with their computer models of how the climate should behave with increased carbon dioxide, and found agreement. The Atlantic, Pacific and Indian oceans have warmed on average by 0.06C since 1948.

"I believe our results represent the strongest evidence to date that the Earth's climate system is responding to human-induced forcing," said Sydney Levitus of the national oceanographic data centre. Tim Barnett, leader of the group from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, said: "This will make it much harder for naysayers to dismiss predictions from climate models."

Although Mr Bush pledged action on carbon dioxide emissions during his election campaign last year, he changed his mind in March and talked of "the incomplete state of scientific knowledge of the causes of, and solutions to, global climate change".

That day, a British report in Nature confirmed the build-up of greenhouse gases - because of burning of fossil fuels - could be detected from space.

But in the past year there has been other evidence of dramatic climate change. A team from Ohio State University found that glaciers on Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania and in the Peruvian Andes were melting so fast they could disappear in 10 to 20 years.

British scientists predicted a rise of up to 6C in air temperature in the next century - enough to reduce the north polar ice cap each summer to a couple of large floes drifting in a clear ocean.

Sea levels have risen about 10cm in a century. Six of the 10 warmest years ever recorded were in the 1990s. The other four were in the 1980s.

fields.headline: Excite Europe in sale talks
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Tiscali, the Italian internet network group, was last night tipped to be a contender for search engine Excite Europe, hours after it snapped up Planet-interkom, a German fixed-line internet access provider.
fields.body:
Tiscali, the Italian internet network group, was last night tipped to be a contender for search engine Excite Europe, hours after it snapped up Planet-interkom, a German fixed-line internet access provider.

Excite Europe, which runs Britain's fifth most popular internet portal, said it had received approaches that could lead to a sale. A year ago, the company was considering a £2bn flotation.

Managing director Evan Rudowski said any deal might involve just Excite UK, 42% owned by BT, or the entire European operation, valued at $50m-$100m.

The €77.1m (£48m) purchase of Planet-interkom from BT's German subsidiary, Viag Interkom, follows Tiscali's acquisitions of World Online and the recent €650m offer for LibertySurf.

According to Tiscali, the purchase of Planet-interkom will consolidate its position as the number two internet service provider in Europe. It will also make it fourth largest in the German internet services market - Europe's biggest.

"This transaction is one further milestone towards achieving our objective of becoming the number one internet communication company in Europe, achieving a top three position in all the European countries in which the Tiscali group is present," the group's executive chairman, Renato Soru, said.

Planet-interkom provides internet access through fixed lines for residential users and has about 685,000 active customers, generating some 300m minutes of online traffic every month.

Viag Interkom said the sale underlined its decision to concentrate on the mobile side of the business. "This does not mean we are saying goodbye to the internet," said Viag Interkon chief executive officer Maximilian Ardelt. "We see our future in mobile communications and m-commerce."

Tiscali is paying €15m in cash and some 4.14m of its own shares for Planet-interkom in a deal that will leave Viag with a 1.2% holding in the Italian group.

At the end of last month, Tiscali had some 13m registed users and around 6m active subscribers.

fields.headline: Bluetooth firm raises $44m
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: There was evidence yesterday that venture capital funding in the hi-tech sector has not entirely dried up when Red-M, a supplier of Bluetooth products, raised $44m (£30m) in a second round of financing.
fields.body:
There was evidence yesterday that venture capital funding in the hi-tech sector has not entirely dried up when Red-M, a supplier of Bluetooth products, raised $44m (£30m) in a second round of financing.

The company, based in Slough, specialises in products which enable computers, handheld devices and mobile phones to talk to each other within a building - a kind of wireless intranet. It began shipping product at the end of last year.

The funding from Apax Partners and Amadeus Capital includes $35m in cash and an $8.65m payment to Red-M's parent company, Madge Networks. In exchange for the cash Apax, Amadeus and Nasdaq-listed Madge will each have an equal share of the business.

Mike Wilson, Red-M's chief executive, said: "The market for funding is generally quite depressed but Bluetooth is a huge growth area. It will lead to the dramatic growth of m-commerce."

He said the company now had enough funding in place to see it through to a cashflow positive position.

Apax director Michael Risman, who will join the Red-M board, said: "We believe that new short-range radio infrastructure technologies, such as Bluetooth, will emerge as a low-cost platform for the launch of next generation wireless broadband applications and services."

Bluetooth radio technology offers the potential for low-cost broadband wireless access for a range of mobile and portable devices. It connects different networks and integrates different devices.

Bluetooth has been being regarded as complementary to next generation mobiles, but some industry experts are now suggesting that it may steal some of the revenue streams the networks had been expected to win.

webTitle: Have a bitch about the bosses

fields.headline: Have a bitch about the bosses
fields.standfirst:
Corporate America is finding out what staff and customers really think through official - and unofficial - complaint sites

More internet news
fields.trailText: Corporate America is finding out what staff and customers really think through official - and unofficial - complaint sites.
fields.body:
General Electric's chief executive, Jack Welch, did not give a damn about the internet until one evening when he returned home from work and his wife sat him down in front of their home PC.

Jane Welch had been idly searching the web and hit upon a site that would change her husband's opinion of the nascent technology for ever.

"Jane had been involved in the internet for years. I just didn't get it," he told CBS's 60 Minutes recently. "She went to a Yahoo! message board on GE and they were talking about me. It was all gossip, rumours... 'God,' I go, 'This is really fascinating.' And then... I got hooked."

Mr Welch is not the only one.

Bulletin boards - or bitch boards as the most vitriolic are dubbed - are becoming an inescapable part of corporate culture.

Executives at companies large and small are logging on to an ever-increasing number of boards and unofficial sites to find out exactly what staff, customers, partners and shareholders think of them.

The most damning have the power to shatter share prices and employee morale in single stroke - regardless of whether the information and innuendo appearing on them is true or not.

Expectation of leaks

The phenomenon has become a menace that even some of the world's smartest multinationals are unable to control. For many executives, surrounded by sycophantic advisers and isolated from reality, it can be an uncomfortable but often helpful wake-up call. And for a small number of firms specialising in web intelligence and crisis management public relations, it is opening up some potentially lucrative new revenue streams.

"Companies need to realise that now almost everyone at work has email, nothing is secret anymore - they must almost expect things to be leaked," said Nick Denton, founder of online news monitoring service Moreover.com. "Email and the internet are making corporations more transparent. You mustn't say internally what you don't want heard externally because one way or another, it will eventually get out."

The slowing economy, widespread job losses and growing number of business failures has been manna from heaven for bitch boards. They have been receiving anonymous information from disgruntled employees and disillusioned shareholders in record quantities.

Fuckedcompany.com, a US website that has become the first port of call for the latest gossip on which dot.com is likely to be the next to go bust, last week saw its servers collapse under the weight of mail it received.

Founded by 24-year-old Robert Kaplan, known as Pud to its 6m visitors and the 45,000 recipients of his email newsletter, it has virtually cornered the market for news on dot.coms going under.

Visitors are invited to submit f**ks - rumours - about companies they think are f**ked - heading for the scrap heap. They are awarded points depending on how accurate their information turns out to be. More than 20,000 players have registered, 2,400 companies are supposedly set for failure, and Yahoo! recently named it Site of the Year.

The site's content is irreverent, crude and at times downright nasty. Sometimes it is untrue but more often the information is absolutely spot on. Increasingly copies of original emails from senior executives containing price-sensitive information are being posted.

Visitors delight in the latest staff culls, dissecting business models they claim with perfect hindsight that they always knew were doomed for failure. The effect on staff morale can be devastating.

Charles Cohen, founder of troubled online payment firm Beenz.com, recently felt the full force of the site's vitriol when 30 particularly nasty, but largely true, individual postings were made on fuckedcompany.com the night before news of a huge round of sackings was made public. "We took such a beating we thought about sending them some Beenz branded condoms to wear the next time they f**ked us," he said.

It is not only dot.com start-ups that are exposed. Intel saw 11% wiped off its stock price and was forced to write off $500m after news of a production flaw in its new Pentium chip emerged on a discussion board in 1994.

Three years later, fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger was accused of being racist after an internet rumour said he had appeared on the Oprah Winfrey Show and argued that his clothes were not meant to be worn by African-Americans. He was threatened by boycotts and activist groups - despite the fact that he had never appeared on the show.

Last year Oracle's stock plunged 30% on false rumours that founder Larry Ellison had died.

Specific anti-corporate websites have also been set up to knock household names such as Ford, Nike, Gap and Starbucks. McSpotlight.com, a site Greenpeace founded five years ago to highlight a court action the fast food company had taken against it, still averages about 1.5m hits a month.

The damage rumours can inflict on a company and the speed at which they spread terrifies many firms. Share prices can be shattered in a single trading session.

Nearly three-quarters of 600 prominent US chief executives recently surveyed by public relations firm Hill and Knowlton said they were concerned by the mounting dissemination of negative information over the internet - but only 50% have strategies in place for managing internet communications.

Those who still dismiss the importance of the internet will be particularly alarmed by figures from last year's Ross Report of Cybermedia which found 60% of print journalists would report an online rumour with one confirmation.

"Companies recognise the increasing significance of corporate reputation to their bottom line," said Tom Hoog, president of Hill and Knowlton.

Moreover.com's Mr Denton believes that the first hours after a rumour has appeared online are the most important. "Companies should try to nip crises in the bud before they spread," he says.

"We live in a market of instant information where perception and image are increasingly linked to stock prices. The best strategic plans can be undermined in the course of a morning."

Moreover.com offers what it describes as "web intelligence". Its sophisticated search technology constantly scans more than 2,400 online sources ranging from mainstream news sites to bulletin boards and gossip columns. It trawls areas which are neither visited nor indexed by traditional search engines, Mr Denton says.

His target customers are marketing directors, investor relations managers and public relations partners.

Firms are increasingly taking legal action to stop the spread of false rumours, but sources can be difficult to trace as most are posted anonymously. In the US, more than 150 lawsuits have been filed against anonymous message posters since 1999, citing libel, trade secret violation or stock manipulation.

Libellous remarks

In Britain, AIM-listed internet service provider Totalise recently won a ruling in the High Court requiring financial web sites The Motley Fool and Interactive Investor International (iii) to reveal the identity of a person using the name Zeddust. He had posted libellous remarks about the Leeds-based firm on both sites.

"Initially, both Motley Fool and iii were approached to sort this problem out, but because of their reluctance to get involved directly, the court case became inevitable to protect and clarify certain comments about the company," chief executive Peter Gregory said.

"We responded after a long and sustained campaign from one particular poster whose posts went beyond the usual and acceptable discussions on the company. The posts were directly intended to besmirch the company or its directors.

"Obviously, we accept that everyone is entitled to their views, opinions and assessments of a company - Totalise has never sought to challenge these."

Mr Gregory said he does not believe bulletin boards have a direct influence on share prices but his views are accompanied by a caveat. "Any serious buyer, seller, or investor would be foolish to follow the [anonymous] comments you see on boards," he said. Sadly for Mr Gregory, the millions who log on to bulletin and bitch boards on a daily basis often disagree.

Where the world can let off steam by Julia Snoddy

 Starbucks

www.ihatestarbucks.com

Under the headline "Mosey over and grab a double mint mocha decaf skim latte and leave your mark on the world", this website is used by Starbucks' employees, or those claiming to be employees, to let off steam and say what they really think of customers and the company.

Using pseudonyms such as "whipped cream" and "latte man", site users reveal exactly how they treat customers. One contributor says her favourite is when customers ask for more chocolate, "little do they know they will get a half of a cup of it. Extra hot in my store is scorched, 200 plus degrees".

She adds that she tells the "frappacino assholes" that frappacino is a non-fat drink.

"I squirt the loaded whipped cream in the middle to make it even fattier."

The site also offers contact details for those wanting to sue Starbucks.

 Nike

www.nikesucks.org

The site is designed to attract people who disapprove of Nike - particularly its controversial employment practices in the developing world.

Those who log on are directed to articles condemning the company - such as details of a five-city tour in the United States by Cicih Sukaesih, who was fired from a Nike sub-contractors factory in Indonesia in 1993.

The website, which encourages users to boycott Nike products, also contains appeals from someone claiming to be an American academic for Nike to "stop exploiting my students".

 McDonalds

www.mcspotlight.com

"McDonald's spends over $2b a year broadcasting their glossy image to the world. This is a small space for alternatives to be heard," the introduction to this website reads.

The anti-corporate site features pictures of street protests against McDonald's as well as links to campaigns and a debating room. Recent campaigns include an "adopt a store" campaign that encourages people to find their local branch and protest against it.

Readers are directed to the book Fast Food Nation, the Dark Side of the All-American Meal by Eric Schlosser, which claims to trace the sources of the meat. There is also "an excellent case by case analysis of McDonald's willingness to resort to legal intimidation".

 Ford and Toyota

www.blueovalnews.com

This website provides frank comments on the products of Ford and Toyota and boasts "exclusive" reports on, for instance, the real power of Mustang cars.The websites' bulletin boards describe Toyota cars as being "simple", "dull" and "ugly".But one writer also claims that Ford executives think the long-term reliability of Toyota is unsurpassed and says that they "benchmark Toyota for everything".

webTitle: British court order boosts Bhutto inquiry

fields.headline: British court order boosts Bhutto inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: The military regime in Pakistan is to extend its investigation of corruption allegations against the former prime minister Benazir Bhutto after the release by a British court of 22,000 pages of documents detailing her bank accounts and assets.
fields.body:
The military regime in Pakistan is to extend its investigation of corruption allegations against the former prime minister Benazir Bhutto after the release by a British court of 22,000 pages of documents detailing her bank accounts and assets.

Ms Bhutto, who lives in self-imposed exile in London and Dubai, won a significant victory last week when the Pakistani supreme court overturned a conviction for corruption against her and her husband and ordered a retrial.

She said she intended to return to Pakistan soon and would try to become prime minister for a third time.

But yesterday Bow Street magistrates court in London released detailed financial documents about the couple and statements taken from nine associates.

The Pakistani national accountability bureau (NAB), which investigates corruption, has been trying to secure the documents since the army seized power 17 months ago. It has not yet had sight of them.

"We believe these documents will show us the properties that they have acquired in other countries, the bank accounts they have got, and how the money they took from this country was either looted or acquired through illegal activity," the prosecutor general for corruption, Raja Bashir, said.

"We are absolutely sure that illegal money has been taken out of this country.

"We are looking at a figure of around $1.2bn [£830m]."

The bureau says the couple have 26 bank accounts in various parts of the world, own 14 properties, and have total assets of £1bn.

Mr Bashir said Ms Bhutto's successful appeal last week did not mean she had escaped punishment. "Benazir Bhutto has not been acquitted. The court said try her again. We are very glad that other countries are cooperating with us."

The bureau is bringing four more corruption cases against Ms Bhutto, including claims that she took kickbacks for awarding government contracts and illegally appointing 1,393 people to jobs in the state airline, PIA.

Ms Bhutto denies all the charges and says they are a politically motivated attempt to prevent her returning to power.

Her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, has been charged with six offences, including abusing his authority by building a polo ground at the prime minister's official residence for his personal use, and has been in jail for four years awaiting trial.

A former senator, he is also allegedly implicated in the murder of his wife's brother Mir Murtaza Bhutto - which he denies - and accused of drug trafficking, a charge that carries the death penalty.

His lawyers challenged the Bow Street court's decision to send the papers to Islamabad, saying it was being done only because of the drug trafficking charge, which they said was concocted to encourage London to cooperate in other corruption investigations.

"Mr Zardari has been unscrupulously drawn into corruption and narcotic charges which are a travesty of truth and justice," Ms Bhutto's Pakistan People's party said.

In a separate development, the US authorities, acting on a request from the NAB, have arrested Mansur-ul Haq in connection with alleged bribes connected to a government purchase of three Agosta 90B submarines from France under a technology transfer agreement.

Admiral Haq, who commanded the navy under Ms Bhutto's government in the mid-1990s, has been under investigation for at least three years.

Two naval officers who served under him have been convicted of corruption by a court martial.

The Pakistani supreme court is expected to rule today, or early next week, on several petitions which criticise the bureau's operations, particularly its power to hold suspects for 90 days without charge.

Other allegations ...

Against Benazir Bhutto

Supreme court recently overturned conviction for alleged £6.2m kickback for a contract to Société Générale de Surveillance, a Swiss pre-shipment inspection firm. Retrial ordered.

Alleged commission on 8,000 tractors from Poland.

Kickbacks on granting a monopoly to a gold and silver importer - £21m.

Assets and accounts ' disproportionate to income'.

Against Asif Ali Zardari

Accused in four of his wife's corruption cases, except allegedly illegal appointments to the PIA state airline.

Receiving £380,000 in commission from Pakistan Steel chairman for installing a new converter at a steel mill.

Alleged misuse of authority by building a polo ground for his personal use at the prime minister's official residence.

Accused of involvement in murder of his wife's brother.

Alleged drug trafficking to west over several years in 1980s and 1990s.

webTitle: Putin consolidates power with party merger

fields.headline: Putin consolidates power with party merger
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin's Unity party swallowed up a leading opposition group in an unexpected merger yesterday, providing him with a radically strengthened grip on parliament.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin's Unity party swallowed up a leading opposition group in an unexpected merger yesterday, providing him with a radically strengthened grip on parliament.

The marriage of Mr Putin's party to the Fatherland bloc ensures that he now controls the biggest single group in parliament, amounting to at least 132 dedicated supporters.

He is likely to be able to muster another 100 votes from smaller parties in the 450-seat house, making the passage of government legislation much simpler.

The mayor of Moscow, Yury Luzhkov, who 18 months ago was one of Mr Putin's fiercest political enemies and one of his strongest potential rivals for the presidency, abandoned his independent stance.

As the leader of the Fatherland movement, he announced that he and his bloc would now side with the party wholly responsible for the destruction of his presidential ambitions.

Unity was created in the autumn of 1999 by shrewd Kremlin consultants primarily to drain support from Fatherland-All Russia, led by Mr Luzhkov and the former prime-minister Yevgeny Primakov.

"A new era is beginning in the history of Russia," Mr Luzhkov said yesterday.

"We have been throwing stones [at each other] for a long time and now it is time to pick those stones back up."

Forces supporting the Kremlin now not only have the power to vote down the Communists and their allies the Agrarian bloc, which musters around 127 seats, but are also in a stronger position to solicit enough support to give the president the simply majority of 226 votes needed to pass most legislation.

This should prove vital to Mr Putin as he tries to push through unpopular cost-cutting measures, such as the wholesale reform of pensions.

The leader of Narodny Deputat, another central political bloc, said yesterday that he was also considering joining the merger.

The merger is seen as the latest step in Mr Putin's campaign to consolidate his hold on Russian political institutions, and he welcomed the announcement as a "constructive step on the way to reforming Russia's political system", his spokesman said.

The decision was seen as a debacle for Mr Luzhkov, however. "Unity has devoured Fatherland - this is a tough defeat for Luzhkov's group," Sergei Ivanenko, of the liberal Yabloko group, said.

"The new party will be dominated by Unity. The Kremlin can view this as a victory."

 The former senior Kremlin aide Pavel Borodin was released from custody in Geneva yesterday after Moscow paid a bond of 5m Swiss francs (£2m).

He still faces a charge of money-laundering kickbacks from Kremlin renovation deals.

Unity was created in the autumn of 1999 by shrewd Kremlin consultants primarily to drain support from Fatherland-All Russia, led by Mr Luzhkov and the former prime-minister Yevgeny Primakov. "A new era is beginning in the history of Russia," Mr Luzhkov said yesterday. "We have been throwing stones [at each other] for a long time and now it is time to pick those stones back up." Forces supporting the Kremlin now not only have the power to vote down the Communists and their allies the Agrarian bloc, which musters around 127 seats, but are also in a stronger position to solicit enough support to give the president the simply majority of 226 votes needed to pass most legislation. This should prove vital to Mr Putin as he tries to push through unpopular cost-cutting measures, such as the wholesale reform of pensions. The leader of Narodny Deputat, another central political bloc, said yesterday that he was also considering joining the merger. The merger is seen as the latest step in Mr Putin's campaign to consolidate his hold on Russian political institutions, and he welcomed the announcement as a "constructive step on the way to reforming Russia's political system", his spokesman said. The decision was seen as a debacle for Mr Luzhkov, however. "Unity has devoured Fatherland - this is a tough defeat for Luzhkov's group," Sergei Ivanenko, of the liberal Yabloko group, said. "The new party will be dominated by Unity. The Kremlin can view this as a victory."  The former senior Kremlin aide Pavel Borodin was released from custody in Geneva yesterday after Moscow paid a bond of 5m Swiss francs (£2m). He still faces a charge of money-laundering kickbacks from Kremlin renovation deals.

fields.trailText: In an article headed Man held for stalking Harman sues police, September 8, 1999, we reported on John Masterson's unsuccessful claim for damages for unlawful imprisonment and malicious prosecution by the Metropolitan police.
fields.body:
In an article headed Man held for stalking Harman sues police, September 8, 1999, we reported on John Masterson's unsuccessful claim for damages for unlawful imprisonment and malicious prosecution by the Metropolitan police.

We wish to make it clear that Mr Masterson's civil action related to charges of threatening to kill (which were dropped), he was not charged with harassment or stalking.

 In a headline on page 18, Comment, yesterday, we used the expression mother of parliaments to suggest this applied to the parliament at Westminster. This is a distortion of the sense of the quotation from which it is taken. Parliament is not the mother of parliaments. "England is the mother of parliaments", as John Bright (1811-89) said in a speech at Birmingham, January 18, 1865.

 In our G2 cover, April 10, made up of photographs of 100 or so MPs, we got one of them wrong. We intended to show Tommy Graham, the Independent MP for West Renfrewshire. Instead we showed Lord Graham of Edmonton. Apologies to both.

 There was a mistake in the football results of the Avon Insurance Combination, page 28, Sport, yesterday. The line Reading 4, Bristol Rovers 0 should have read: Reading 4, AFC Bournemouth 0.

 In reviewing the performance of the Citroën C5 2.2HDi diesel, Wheels, page 18, G2, April 10, we said "the engine is so frugal that a single tank of petrol could probably be made to last you a year and a half." But on no account try to run the car on it.

In fact, the survey was carried out by the Scottish business and financial newspaper Business a.m.

webTitle: Comment: Juries aren't that stupid, m'lud

fields.headline: Juries aren't that stupid, m'lud
fields.standfirst:
The Sunday Mirror is not the only one guilty of an 'error of judgment'

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Sunday Mirror is not the only one guilty of an 'error of judgment'.
fields.body:
I am not free. One hand is tied behind my back. My mouth is gagged. I am prevented from telling you the truth, from saying what I really think, from writing a truly balanced commentary.

This article is subject to an order under section 4(2) of the Contempt of Court Act of 1981. It means that, like every other journalist, I cannot tell you why I think the Sunday Mirror published an interview last week which led to the collapse of the trial involving two Leeds United footballers, and the resignation yesterday of its editor Colin Myler.

I was under similar legal constraints when I spoke on BBC's Newsnight on Monday evening. Just before I began to answer questions, the interviewer, Liz MacKean, told me that the BBC's lawyers had instructed her to tell me that I must not say anything critical about the judge. I protested that such an order was unfair.

I was expected to condemn the Sunday Mirror for its part in the fiasco, but I wanted to balance that by pointing to my genuine concerns about the wisdom of Mr Justice Poole's decision to discharge the jury at Hull crown court. So I ignored the instruction, but to no avail because it was a pre-recorded interview and my comments about the judge were omitted.

It was a significant pointer to the problem I now face, with the judge having underlined that "there should be no further reference" to the contents of the Sunday Mirror article. I consider that to be a disgraceful inhibition of my rights and a negation of the media's wider public interest responsibilities. There have been two mistakes here and we should be able to consider both.

It was hard to see how the Sunday Mirror editor, Colin Myler, could have defended publishing his interview (the actual nature of which I am now forbidden to mention). With the jury still considering their verdict, Myler would have known the risk involved. While the interview - described as an exclusive - certainly raised important issues, and Myler may have been fearful that a daily paper would scoop him if the trial concluded in midweek, he would have known that, by publishing, he was liable to be prosecuted for contempt.

He would surely have known that the jury had not been sequestered (tucked away in a hotel and prevented from reading newspapers or seeing television). He obviously did not publish in order to boost sales. It wasn't that kind of material. And he didn't advertise it on the front page. That was devoted to the Sophie Rhys-Jones affair with, incidentally, the disgracefully misleading headline Sophie's Ecstasy and Cocaine Shock, an indication of the paper's unfortunate willingness to twist the truth.

On the other hand, if Myler did see his interview in public interest terms and wished to confront the judge as a matter of principle, he didn't go about it in the usual way. That would have involved explaining his act of contempt in a major editorial.

The only other possibility is, of course, that it was a giant cock-up, and history suggests this is much the most likely explanation. None of these affairs are ever black and white, but the grey matter is going to be fascinating when it emerges.

Myler has been a senior executive on various tabloids for many years and has previously been known for his caution. Did he consult his lawyers? I understand that the most senior of the company's legal team, Martin Cruddace, was abroad. The most experienced, Charles Collier-Wright, was away, as was the Sunday Mirror's regular lawyer, Paul Mottram. Despite that, even the most junior of lawyers, not to mention the most inexperienced of reporters, know not to publish material which might prejudice a jury.

The Mirror's statement yesterday said legal opinion was sought prior to publication. "This legal opinion contributed to the decision to go ahead ... on the basis that the interview was deemed not to be prejudicial to the court case in Hull." The paper, now facing the prospect of contempt proceedings, admitted "a serious error of judgment".

But the Sunday Mirror's stupidity should not prevent us from questioning the judge's decision to abort the trial. The judiciary too often treat jurors as if they are lame-brained, believing that they are influenced by everything they read in papers and will therefore ignore the evidence painstakingly put before them in favour of a single story.

The classic rebuttal of this argument is surely the outcome of the trial of Kevin and Ian Maxwell. Their names had been dragged through the newspaper dirt for years before their case came to court. Hardly anyone in Britain did not know about their father's criminal behaviour. The name Maxwell stank. Yet the brothers were cleared of all charges by the jury, who made up their minds about the evidence they heard in court. Judges should start treating jurors as intelligent adults and, while they're considering that, they should also think through the implications of gagging the press. I could have said so much more in this article but for Mr Justice Poole's contempt order.

webTitle: Comment: 51% Catholic majority does not mean united Ireland

fields.headline: Breeding schemes
fields.standfirst:
Malachi O'Doherty says the Guardian is echoing a false dream that a 51% Catholic majority means a united Ireland

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Malachi O'Doherty says the Guardian is echoing a false dream that a 51% Catholic majority means a united Ireland.
fields.body:
Protestant sectarianism in Northern Ireland is easy to spot. It parades its colours. Catholic sectarianism is different. It no longer has a theological component. It is a long time since republicans affirmed, as their forebears did, that Ireland was Catholic.

The distinctive mark of a Catholic sectarian today is the demography argument. This assumes that all Catholics will vote for a united Ireland when called upon to do so, even decades into the future; that they will put ethnic allegiance above any political experience.

The sectarian demographic argument has long been part of the Sinn Fein calculation, and indeed it may be that some who knew better encouraged the IRA to imagine that the war was virtually won by force of numbers.

Social attitudes surveys in Northern Ireland have shown that up to 30% of Northern Irish Catholics would not currently vote for unity. On what basis is anyone to presume that they will have changed their minds in 10 or 20 years' time?

Catholics are free people in a democratic system, entitled to judge for themselves what suits them, and they have the right not to answer the call of the tribe. They have a right not to be ideologically imprisoned by their ancestors.

The case made by Sinn Fein, and echoed in the Guardian yesterday, is that unionist domination will come to an end when Catholics reach the magic figure of 51% of the population.

The fact is that unionist domination ended in 1972 when Britain prorogued the old majoritarian Stormont. Britain made it clear to the unionists - even if they were slow to learn it - that they would never hold executive power in Northern Ireland again unless they shared it with nationalists.

They did that because a Catholic minority was sufficiently large and vocal that it could not be ruled by force and no constitutional arrangement was possible without their consent. Demography has worked its magic already, and it may never again achieve anything so radical. Yes, it will be a stirring moment for sectarian Catholics when they find that they are officially a majority, but they will not be able to depend on all Catholics falling in with their sectarian fantasy. Why are we using this word Catholic anyway, when it describes no consistent theology or political stand? We would be better using the word other bigots use - taigs. I am a taig myself and I will not have Mitchel McLaughlin or the Guardian taking my vote for granted like this.

The slow and painful lesson for unionists has been that just being in the majority does not give them the right to run Northern Ireland. Just being in the majority in some notional future will not give nationalists the exclusive right to decide its constitutional future either.

To assume, as Mitchel McLaughlin does, that a small Catholic majority will be able to demand a united Ireland is to assume both that they will want to and that Catholics will be better at the domination game than were unionists.

It is true that the Good Friday agreement currently envisages only one question in the referenda it prescribes on the union. These referenda will ask whether the people want a united Ireland or not, and legally, when a 51% vote in favour of it arrives, it will happen.

If that 51% was only Catholic, then one large minority in Northern Ireland would have been defeated. That will be a large, coherent and wounded group of people, and it will be entitled to argue that it should have the same consideration then as nationalists had in 1998. Catholics will want integration into the rest of Ireland as many unionists want integration into Britain now. It will be no more readily available to them.

Another possibility is that, if unionists are converted to a united Ireland, a cross community vote in favour of it would emerge. This is highly unlikely, but we are talking about the remote future so who knows? To achieve that, nationalists will have to work to offer unionists a sense of security. They will have to emphasise partnership with them now and assure them of future partnership, whatever the demographics show.

The way to do that is to promise that a united Ireland of the future would retain the border and the Northern assembly, with power devolved from Dublin rather than Belfast. Sinn Fein would reject that now, but perhaps they too will reconsider when the option is retaining power in the North or going into opposition in Dublin? Has any political party ever surrendered power for ideological reasons?

If republicans wants a united Ireland, there is a course available to them. It is to prove that the Good Friday agreement does not work and abort the prospects of partnership. That way, maybe enough Catholics and some Protestants will simply give up on the dream of reconciliation.

When you hear republicans brag about demographic prospects, you have to wonder if that is what they are working for.

 The Trouble with Guns by Malachi O'Doherty is published by Blackstaff Press

fields.headline: AorTech finally secures funds
fields.standfirst: Heart valve maker raises £20m
fields.trailText: Scottish heart valves maker AorTech International was given room to breathe yesterday, after raising £20.1m at the second attempt.
fields.body:
Scottish heart valves maker AorTech International was given room to breathe yesterday, after raising £20.1m at the second attempt.

Japanese bank Nomura has agreed to act as underwriter to ensure the success of the scaled-down cash call, which follows the failure of a £64m share issue last month.

However, the success is not without a cost to directors. Chairman Gordon Wright and chief executive Eddie McDaid have been forced to spend a "six figure sum" investing in new shares, rather than selling £2m of their holdings each, as initially planned. Mr McDaid said: "In the current climate, I suppose it's a relief."

The firm has developed a brown plastic-like material called Elast-Eon, which is flexible enough for use in joints and valves but carries a low risk of rejection by the body. It also has a heart monitor called TruCCOMS, which measures the flow of blood more accurately than existing technology.

Without fresh funds, AorTech was due to run out of cash by the end of the year. However, investors boycotted the firm's initial attempt to raise money, on the grounds that £64m was too much to ask.

Mr McDaid said the scaled-down rights issue would give the firm less room to manoeuvre: "We won't have a war chest to look for acquisitions, or for new technology. If the right opportunity comes along, we will have to come back and talk to our shareholders."

Nomura were appointed to handle the fundraising in place of US bank Morgan Stanley, which botched the first attempt. It is understood that this change was at the suggestion of AorTech's shareholders.

Analyst Max Herrmann, of ING Barings, said the money should be enough to see AorTech through to profitability. He said: "I don't think £65m was ever a necessary amount to raise. This is much more reasonable - they'd clearly tried a placing which wasn't well thought through."

Shareholders are being offered shares on a five-for-24 basis at 320p, a steep discount to yesterday's closing price of 382.5p, down 17.5p.

AorTech recently launched its heart monitor, TruCCOMS, but initial sales have been disappointing, although the potential market for the device could exceed $200m (£140m). ING Barings expects the device to yield revenue of £1.5m next year, and £7m in 2003.

The recent stock market slump has hit the cash-poor biotechnology industry particularly badly. PPL Therapeutics, the cloning specialist famous for creating Dolly the Sheep, was forced to abandon a £45m fundraising earlier this week. Oxford Biomedica is raising £27m through an underwritten placing, but it could struggle to complete a £10m "top-up" offering of shares.

Founded in 1992, AorTech is valued at £460m. The Strathclyde-based company was built on technology developed by a doctor at Papworth Hospital, Cambridge, who was a friend of Mr Wright. Mr McDaid and Mr Wright each hold 14% of the company, worth £65m apiece.

fields.headline: Aberdeen swoops on 'Vulture Life'
fields.trailText: Aberdeen Asset Management yesterday added £5.5bn to its £28.5bn under management in an £86m deal with Life Assurance Holding Corporation - known as Vulture Life for its strategy of buying moribund life companies.
fields.body:
Aberdeen Asset Management yesterday added £5.5bn to its £28.5bn under management in an £86m deal with Life Assurance Holding Corporation - known as Vulture Life for its strategy of buying moribund life companies.

The investment management of 1m policies from companies bought by LAHC will be transferred to Aberdeen for a minimum of 10 years. Aberdeen will take the fee in come from the funds, estimated at £11m in the first year.

LAHC says it will use the cash to help finance a "major acquisition" of a life company later this year, its first since it bought GAN - formerly known as General Portfolio - in 1998 for £300m.

The deal follows a sharp slowdown in sales at Aberdeen, which scooped up hundreds of millions in technology Isa sales last year during the dot.com rush. Yesterday it revealed that there had been a "considerable slowdown", but said that sales still outweigh cancellations.

The deal will also only partly compensate for the loss of £10bn expected when Aberdeen loses the contract to manage Scottish Provident's funds, which will take place in stages over the next two years.

Abbey National is buying Scottish Provident for £1.8bn and has said it will move management of the life fund away from Aberdeen. It is also considering the disposal of Scottish Provident's 38% shareholding in Aberdeen, prompting speculation that it could trigger a full takeover bid of one of Scotland's last independent fund management businesses.

But Aberdeen's chief executive, Martin Gilbert, dismissed talk of a bid as "complete nonsense. We are not in discussions with anyone. We are concentrating on building the business and, although no one likes to lose assets under management, the Scottish Provident funds are on very low margins."

Aberdeen will take the fee in come from the funds, estimated at £11m in the first year. LAHC says it will use the cash to help finance a "major acquisition" of a life company later this year, its first since it bought GAN - formerly known as General Portfolio - in 1998 for £300m. The deal follows a sharp slowdown in sales at Aberdeen, which scooped up hundreds of millions in technology Isa sales last year during the dot.com rush. Yesterday it revealed that there had been a "considerable slowdown", but said that sales still outweigh cancellations. The deal will also only partly compensate for the loss of £10bn expected when Aberdeen loses the contract to manage Scottish Provident's funds, which will take place in stages over the next two years. Abbey National is buying Scottish Provident for £1.8bn and has said it will move management of the life fund away from Aberdeen. It is also considering the disposal of Scottish Provident's 38% shareholding in Aberdeen, prompting speculation that it could trigger a full takeover bid of one of Scotland's last independent fund management businesses. But Aberdeen's chief executive, Martin Gilbert, dismissed talk of a bid as "complete nonsense. We are not in discussions with anyone. We are concentrating on building the business and, although no one likes to lose assets under management, the Scottish Provident funds are on very low margins."

fields.headline: Industry shrugs off slowdown fears
fields.standfirst: Upbeat survey casts doubt on lower interest rates
fields.trailText: Manufacturers have so far shrugged off worries about the global economy and the impact of foot and mouth disease, a survey claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Manufacturers have so far shrugged off worries about the global economy and the impact of foot and mouth disease, a survey claimed yesterday.

The report, commissioned by the British Chambers of Commerce, casts doubt on hopes of swift cuts in interest rates but conflicts with other recent downbeat forecasts.

Confidence in the manufacturing sector bounced back to its highest level for a year in the three months to March, said the BCC, despite slower growth in the UK and abroad.

"Manufacturers [are] confident of avoiding the worst of the impact of the global slow down. The data do not support fears of an imminent recession," said David Sears, the BCC's deputy director general.

"I don't think we can ask for a rate cut on the strength of this survey," said Ian Fletcher, the chief economist at the BCC.

The BCC's view is in sharp contrast with the CBI, which slashed its growth forecast earlier yesterday, warning that the economy is set for a sharp slowdown.

Despite the upbeat mood in industry home sales, exports and employment are all down, according to the survey. The services sector, which has driven growth in the UK economy, is also slowing, although it is still stronger than manufacturing. "Overall, the survey suggests British business is weathering the global slowdown reasonably well, with confidence about future prospects remaining robust," said Ross Walker, UK Economist at RBS Financial Markets.

But the BCC noted that the survey was taken in the second week of March, before the wider implications of the foot and mouth outbreak became apparent.

Most City forecasters have slashed their predictions as a result of the epidemic and the slowdown in the US economy.

Confidence about the economic outlook in the US has dived, new figures revealed yesterday. In a development that could stir up expectations for swift interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, the University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index - which measures consumers' attitudes about the economy and their current financial picture - fell to 87.8 in April from 91.5 in March. Analysts had expected the index to fall to 90.4.

American households are already tightening their belts in preparation for tougher times ahead. US retail sales fell 0.2% in March as the recent slowing in the economy made itself felt in a variety of industries from motor manufacturing to furniture, according to the US commerce department.

fields.headline: Careless talk costs market cap
fields.standfirst: Baltimore chief eats his words
fields.trailText: Notebook.
fields.body:
Spare a little sympathy for Fran Rooney, chief executive of Baltimore Technologies. Three years ago he looked on as Bill Clinton, then US president, and Ireland's prime minister Bertie Ahern digitally "signed" a communiqué using Baltimore's cryptographic software, designed to protect data sent over the internet. A little piece of web history was made and the company went on to achieve a market capitalisation at one stage of £4.5bn.

Three years on, an old-fashioned piece of scrambled communications is now killing his company, whose value has shrunk to below £400m.

It all started to go badly awry three weeks ago, when a group of City analysts sloped off to Dublin for a presentation by Baltimore (and a drink, presumably). Mr Rooney, in his naivety, made some general comments on the hi-tech slowdown in the US and before anyone could say Regulatory News Service, the stock price in London was off 20%.

Later that day, the company sheepishly issued a formal statement confirming what everyone had guessed: some sales had been delayed and first-quarter revenues would be around £25m - rather than the £30m previously expected.

Baltimore said at the time that it would issue a further statement in the second week of April giving finalised numbers and an update on current trading. That popped out yesterday, with news that revenue during the first three months will actually be £23.7m - a 5% divergence from the March approximation but still a 250% advance on the same period last year.

The market's response? Another 20% off the share price, of course.

Mr Rooney reckons that damned March statement is to blame, with certain hardball customers using worries over Baltimore's trading position as an excuse to defer purchases. These buyers will sign on the dotted line during the second quarter and everything will be fine, he hopes.

Others take a different view. The City worries that "deferred contracts" is best read as "cancelled contracts" - and who would argue, in the present environment?

Meanwhile, Baltimore is promising "an operational review which will position the company to capture the significant market opportunity available with an efficient and sustainable profitable business model". Translation: "Baltimore risks running out of cash before it makes it into the black. It needs cut costs, sharpish."

Last year, the company posted an operating loss of £140m and cash resources stood at £160m at the year's end. That was after institutional investors paid £167m for new shares in Baltimore (at 440p a share) in October. Of the money raised, less than half went to the company. The shares are now at 74p.

Asking fund managers who have seen their investment fall 80% to put their hands in their pockets again may prove a touch difficult.

Heartache

The last month has been sufficiently stressful to cause coronary palpitations for anyone associated with AorTech International, the Scottish company which produces hi-tech gizmos for heart surgeons.

AorTech had a spot of bother when its £64m fundraising was dubbed "greedy" in the City. An announcement that the cash call had flopped was sneaked out on Budget day.

The offering was a textbook example of how to repel investors, particularly in the middle of a bear market.

AorTech gave only sketchy details of its plans to spend the cash - £30m was vaguely intended for acquisitions, even though the company's healthy share price provided ample currency for future deals.

To make matters worse, the firm's dynamic founding duo - Eddie McDaid and Gordon Wright - were each offloading stock, as was the biggest holder, venture capital fund 3i.

The inspiration behind this splendid investment opportunity was Morgan Stanley, which rarely dips its toes into such small-cap pond life. It is easy to suspect that the American bank felt its time was better spent on larger clients - AorTech is worth a "mere" half a billion.

The ever-reliable Japanese have stepped in to show that it is possible to attract funds for decent technology, even in the present climate.

Nomura has got the offering away, but not without some human cost - Eddie and Gordon are each having to stump up £120,000 to subscribe for their entitlements.

Their hopes of realising a portion of their stakes have been dashed, and any thoughts of Ferraris, yachts and ponies will have to go on ice.

Still, times are not too hard for Celtic pair - their stakes are still worth £14m each, and Eddie still had the cash to dash off for a week in the sun yesterday. Hope he remembers to send a postcard to his rescuers at Nomura.

fields.headline: Dry day
fields.standfirst: Guinness workers strike in Ireland
fields.trailText: Ireland failed to brew a single pint of Guinness yesterday as a strike shut down production for the first time in 27 years.
fields.body:
Ireland failed to brew a single pint of Guinness yesterday as a strike shut down production for the first time in 27 years.

About half of Guinness's 1,600 brewing staff walked out in protest at the closure of a packaging plant, with the loss of 140 jobs, in the north-eastern town of Dundalk, home to the Phoenix Bar.

The stoppage raises the threat of Ireland's pubs running dry over Easter, when bars are usually packed with revellers celebrating the end of Lent.

Guinness spokesman Pat Barry said: "If it's in any way prolonged, the strike will quite clearly affect supplies in pubs."

Mr Barry said many pubs would probably have enough to last the weekend, with some holding up to a week's supply of the famous stout. Talks began at 2pm yesterday between the management and unions, but by evening there was no sign of agreement.

The strike is a headache for Diageo, the drinks group which owns Guinness. With only half of its usual workforce, Guinness could not operate any of its brewing facilities. Diageo estimated that the potential cost of the stoppage could reach IR£15m (£11.8m) a week, sending its shares down 5.5p to 710p.

Diageo had already earmarked Ireland as a problem area - Guinness sales fell in its home country for the first time last year, reflecting stout's waning popularity generally.

Guinness's main brewery at St James Gate, Dublin, is a major tourist attraction, drawing visitors such as Bill Clinton and DJ Chris Evans. Pickets rallied support outside the factory yesterday, with simultaneous demonstrations at premises in Waterford, Kilkenny and Dundalk.

Guinness workers complain that the management has poorly handled the clo sure of the Dundalk site, claiming the company has rescinded on earlier promises to avoid job losses. Some staff fear that the company will eventually pull out of Ireland, in favour of lower wage economies elsewhere.

The strike raises the prospect of Ireland importing Guinness from England - the company operates a large brewery in Park Royal, west London, employing 1,200 people. This option is considered unlikely at present, however, because the stoppage has knocked out distribution networks within Ireland.

fields.headline: Reuters outlines offer for Bridge
fields.trailText: Reuters, the news and financial information group, aims to substantially increase in presence in the United States after yesterday giving details of its bid for assets of bankrupt competitor Bridge Information Systems.
fields.body:
Reuters, the news and financial information group, aims to substantially increase in presence in the United States after yesterday giving details of its bid for assets of bankrupt competitor Bridge Information Systems.

The bid will see Reuters in an auction against US software firm SunGard, which submitted an offer for certain Bridge assets a week ago.

Both companies want to buy the Bridge Trading brokerage unit, internet business eBridge and EJV bond data.

In addition, Reuters hopes to acquire Bridge Trading Technologies and Transaction Services and an option on Bridge's stake in internet service provider Savvis.

All the businesses are aimed at the institutional investor market in which Reuters, headed by Tom Glocer, is seen as being weak in the US.

French financial information provider Finifo has bid for Bridge's European operations while MoneyLine Network, a company providing technology for online trading, has submitted an offer for the Telerate news and data business.

By the deadline to submit interests with the bankruptcy court in the US, no bidders had come forward for BridgeNews, the global financial news service employing 600 journalists in 100 offices around the world.

The auction begins on Monday, and will run through the week until Bridge recommends either offer.

Bridge filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February. The company built debts of more than £500m from a spending spree designed to turn it into a competitor to companies such as Bloomberg and Reuters.

Launched in 1974, Bridge was bought by a New York-based private investment fund - Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe - in 1995. WCAS rapidly expanded the company through acquisitions including Telerate, then named Dow Jones Markets, and Knight-Ridder Financial, which gave it a ready-made network of news bureaux.
