fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Strike looms at Ryton plant

Members of the T&G union at PSA Peugeot- Citroën's Ryton plant in the midlands have voted to strike over pay, the union said last night. The T&G represents 2,000 of 3,000 workers at the plant. In all, 865 workers voted to take action and 831 voted against. Ryton workers are also represented by the AEEU union, whose members voted against a strike, but the T&G has more influenceon the shopfloor. Peugeot's two-year deal, which it says is a final offer, would increase salaries this year by 4.3% and give a second year rise of inflation plus 0.7 of a percentage point. The T&G says the deal comes with unacceptable conditions.

GE profits rise 16%

Peugeot's two-year deal, which it says is a final offer, would increase salaries this year by 4.3% and give a second year rise of inflation plus 0.7 of a percentage point. The T&G says the deal comes with unacceptable conditions.

GE profits rise 16%

America's General Electric, the world's largest company, yesterday announced a 16% jump in first-quarter profits on record revenue driven by its industrial operations.

Gains in GE's power systems and aircraft segments offset weaker broadcasting and appliances results that resulted from a slowing US economy. GE said earnings from operations totalled $3.017bn, compared with $2.592bn in the same quarter last year.

Top tailor feels casual pinch

Savile Row tailor Gieves & Hawkes fell into the red last year, with sales hurt by the trend towards dressing down.

Overall, like for like sales for the year to January 31 fell nearly 4% which, combined with investment in store openings and marketing, saw the group report a £286,000 loss against a £792,000 profit the previous year.

Sales of casual wear, which now account for 10% of turnover, performed well, helped by its new line Gieves, aimed at twenty- to thirtysomething men.

Turnover from continuing businesses rose from £12.3m to £12.9m, helped by store openings. In the past eight weeks sales have perked up, like for like activity drawing level with last year.

Wal-Mart dampened

Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, said yesterday it now believes its first-quarter earnings will come in below its original estimate of 32 cents a share because cool weather dampened sales of spring clothing and gardening items.

First-quarter earnings would be up slightly from the previous year's earnings of 30 cents, Wal-Mart said on its website.

Pfizer sues Niagara maker

Pfizer, the US manufacturer of impotence drug Viagra, is suing a woman who is attempting to market a herbal drink called Niagara.

The defendant, Lari Williams of Arkansas, claims Niagara "puts people in the mood for love". Pfizer said it was treating the issue as patent infringement.

A judge has refused Pfizer's request for a temporary restraining order, but a further hearing has been set for next Thursday.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Foot in mouth? | How policy is made | The inaugural Sophie Wessex Awards for PR excellence
fields.body:
 Douglas McWilliams, "chief economist of the Centre for Economics and Business Research", has made a career from bloodcurdling predictions of catastrophe. Three weeks ago his "estimate" that foot and mouth would cost £9bn was splashed in the Sunday Times. Now Doug has cut that £9bn down to a net impact of just £6.3bn. Doug modestly claims his first figure provoked the PM to take charge of the crisis. "Although he still did his best to try to shoot the messenger," writes Doug, "by claiming that our estimate was 'plucked from the air'." Later in his press release Doug defends his original £9bn as "90% right at a time when hardly any information was available" or, to put it another way, plucked from the air. The Sunday Times called Doug "Professor McWilliams", but when asked he says: "I'm not a professor. I'm an ex-professor." Hmm. A press release from B&Q dated April 10 also describes him as Professor McWilliams. But Doug says he doesn't use his old title from prestigious Kingston University: "It cuts down my consultancy fees."

 So who was the mysterious "London stockbroker" who paid an £11,000 tip in a restaurant in New York, to a blaze of publicity? Some reports named the man as a "Jeff Collins", said to be a vice-president of brokers Collins Stewart. But the firm say it is not true. "Not guilty," said one staff member, "we don't even have any vice-presidents."

 How policy is made: on Monday the deputy prime minister gathered transport journalists in his office to talk about railway fares. When one mentioned that a return fare on Virgin from London to Manchester was £150, Prescott huffed that was just the first class fare. No, said the hack, that's for standard. Prescott was so surprised at the amount he ordered a civil servant to check. The official returned to confirm to the man in charge of the nation's railways that it was indeed £150 for a standard open return. Prescott promptly announced a fares inquiry.

 Just in time for Easter comes this circular from NTL to its cable TV subscribers: "The God Channel (formerly known as the Christian Channel) will be charged at £5 per month."

 It has become very fashionable for universities to get out and raise money from the private sector, with a number of Britain's finest academic institutions regularly announcing fundraising totals running into hundreds of millions of pounds. But now the development directors (the ones who actually do the fundraising) of several leading universities are calling for a code of conduct to stop some institutions inflating their fundraising figures. The tricky devils add in funds from government sources, intellectual property rights, European Union grants and funding bodies, which doesn't count as fundraising proper. "Basically a lot of vice chancellors are prepared to go over the top to produce big figures, and the only way they can do that is by lying," said one development director.

 If you are employed by PricewaterhouseCoopers and are reading this at work today, please check the canteen menu. "Bank Holiday," it reads, "DON'T COME IN TO WORK."

 Entries are rushing in for the inaugural Sophie Wessex Awards for PR excellence. The judges - Prince Andrew, Murray Harkin and ex-Sunday Mirror editor Colin Myler - will be looking for outstanding examples of this respected industry. The first is from Roskill Information Services: "Consolidation puts increased pressure on primary molybdenum producers". The next is from Churchill Insurance's press office: "One in four people have run out of petrol." What, all at once? Finally, from pet insurer Primary Direct: "Danger - Easter Eggs can kill!" On that note, have a happy Easter.

fields.bodyText:  Douglas McWilliams, "chief economist of the Centre for Economics and Business Research", has made a career from bloodcurdling predictions of catastrophe. Three weeks ago his "estimate" that foot and mouth would cost £9bn was splashed in the Sunday Times. Now Doug has cut that £9bn down to a net impact of just £6.3bn. Doug modestly claims his first figure provoked the PM to take charge of the crisis. "Although he still did his best to try to shoot the messenger," writes Doug, "by claiming that our estimate was 'plucked from the air'." Later in his press release Doug defends his original £9bn as "90% right at a time when hardly any information was available" or, to put it another way, plucked from the air. The Sunday Times called Doug "Professor McWilliams", but when asked he says: "I'm not a professor. I'm an ex-professor." Hmm. A press release from B&Q dated April 10 also describes him as Professor McWilliams. But Doug says he doesn't use his old title from prestigious Kingston University: "It cuts down my consultancy fees."  So who was the mysterious "London stockbroker" who paid an £11,000 tip in a restaurant in New York, to a blaze of publicity? Some reports named the man as a "Jeff Collins", said to be a vice-president of brokers Collins Stewart. But the firm say it is not true. "Not guilty," said one staff member, "we don't even have any vice-presidents."  How policy is made: on Monday the deputy prime minister gathered transport journalists in his office to talk about railway fares. When one mentioned that a return fare on Virgin from London to Manchester was £150, Prescott huffed that was just the first class fare. No, said the hack, that's for standard. Prescott was so surprised at the amount he ordered a civil servant to check. The official returned to confirm to the man in charge of the nation's railways that it was indeed £150 for a standard open return. Prescott promptly announced a fares inquiry.  Just in time for Easter comes this circular from NTL to its cable TV subscribers: "The God Channel (formerly known as the Christian Channel) will be charged at £5 per month."  It has become very fashionable for universities to get out and raise money from the private sector, with a number of Britain's finest academic institutions regularly announcing fundraising totals running into hundreds of millions of pounds. But now the development directors (the ones who actually do the fundraising) of several leading universities are calling for a code of conduct to stop some institutions inflating their fundraising figures. The tricky devils add in funds from government sources, intellectual property rights, European Union grants and funding bodies, which doesn't count as fundraising proper. "Basically a lot of vice chancellors are prepared to go over the top to produce big figures, and the only way they can do that is by lying," said one development director.  If you are employed by PricewaterhouseCoopers and are reading this at work today, please check the canteen menu. "Bank Holiday," it reads, "DON'T COME IN TO WORK."  Entries are rushing in for the inaugural Sophie Wessex Awards for PR excellence. The judges - Prince Andrew, Murray Harkin and ex-Sunday Mirror editor Colin Myler - will be looking for outstanding examples of this respected industry. The first is from Roskill Information Services: "Consolidation puts increased pressure on primary molybdenum producers". The next is from Churchill Insurance's press office: "One in four people have run out of petrol." What, all at once? Finally, from pet insurer Primary Direct: "Danger - Easter Eggs can kill!" On that note, have a happy Easter. richard.adams@theguardian.com

webTitle: BT sells space to mobile phone networks to boost revenues

fields.headline: BT sells space to mobile phone networks to boost revenues
fields.trailText: BT aims to shore up the dwindling revenues from its payphone business by inviting mobile telephone networks to fit transmitters into high street phone boxes.
fields.body:
BT aims to shore up the dwindling revenues from its payphone business by inviting mobile telephone networks to fit transmitters into high street phone boxes.

The initiative is the latest attempt to replace revenues from BT's payphones which have been lost to mobile phones. Revenue from BT's 140,000 boxes has slumped 37% over the past two years alone.

Other money-raising ideas have included advertising on the sides of the phone boxes and a rise in the minimum cost of a call to 20p.

BT will initially make 1,020 phone boxes available to mobile networks, increasing to 5,000 next year. Small aerials can be fitted inside the roof of modern phone boxes and will not be visible to the public.

The aim is to fill gaps for existing networks and to boost carrier capacity in urban areas.

They should produce better quality calls and improve reliability. The devices are commonly installed in shop signs or other "street furniture".

A BT spokesman said: "With the roll-out of third generation networks we see this as potentially very attractive for the mobile phone companies."

He said the plan was likely to generate "millions" of pounds but not "tens of millions".

BT is under a universal service obligation to provide a national network of payphones, although there is room for interpretation regarding what actually constitutes a national network.

webTitle: WH Smith plans to offload ailing distribution arm

fields.headline: WH Smith plans to offload ailing distribution arm
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: News and stationery retailer WH Smith has hoisted a For Sale sign over its underperforming newspaper and magazine distribution division.
fields.body:
News and stationery retailer WH Smith has hoisted a For Sale sign over its underperforming newspaper and magazine distribution division.

The business, which is the UK's biggest news wholesaler, has informally been up for grabs since WH Smith was forced to abandon a radical restructuring it planned last year with supermarket group Tesco. It ditched the plan after fierce opposition from customers.

In the group's half-year results released yesterday it was revealed that the division's profits dipped from £18m to £12m in the six months to the end of February.

Chief executive Richard Handover said the business had been hit by flat magazine sales, the costs of setting up the ditched restructuring plan and the mounting cost of handling increasingly heavy newspapers.

Mr Handover said he had already received "a significant number" of approaches for the business, from both trade and financial buyers. One of the frontrunners is understood to be a group led by WH Smith's former finance director, Keith Hammill. It is expected to fetch around £200m.

Mr Handover said he in tended to use the disposal proceeds to increase investment in the core retailing chain. The group operates 770 outlets in the UK and he believes there is room in the market for 200 more.

Group profits were down from £101m to £100m in the period, but the core retailing and book publishing businesses - WH Smith owns publisher Hodder Headline - are performing well. Like-for-like sales at WH Smith were up 6% and have increased to 9% since the year end.

Magazine sales were the black spot, with sales up just 1%.

Hodder Headline produced a 13% improvement in profits to £9m, with growth being driven by the David Beckham book My World and other best sellers such as John Le Carre and James Patterson.

Mr Handover denied Hodder had no similar blockbusters coming up. He admitted the publisher was facing a "quiet period", but said there was "a fantastic project, of a different genre," in the pipeline.

The group's US outlets are being hit by the slowdown in the American economy. The shares, which have outperformed their sector by 40% in the last year, lost 43p to close at 485p.

webTitle: Call to axe M&S chief's bonus

fields.headline: Call to axe M&S chief's bonus
fields.standfirst: Institutional investors angered by Vandevelde's £810,000 payout
fields.trailText: Institutional investors angered by Vandevelde's £810,000 payout.
fields.body:
Some of Marks & Spencer's biggest shareholders are demanding that the controversial bonus due to be paid to the ailing group's chairman, Luc Vandevelde, be axed.

The Association of British Insurers, which represents institutional shareholders, said yesterday that it has been receiving complaints from its members about the payment.

The bonus, which it has now emerged could reach £810,000 - 25% higher than previously thought - comes while M&S's sales are still in decline. The payout, due in May, is even causing anger among the retailer's most senior executives.

The complaints will increase pressure on M&S's remuneration committee, which agreed the bonus and still has to rubber stamp it. But the committee, headed by former MI5 chief Dame Stella Rimington, is understood to be powerless to halt the payment. An M&S spokesman has already admitted: "It is up to Luc."

A spokesman for the ABI said: "Some of our members have expressed concerns about certain issues to do with M&S. We are consulting with them on what is the appropriate way forward."

He said the ABI's investment committee, which monitors boardroom behaviour, would decide "quite soon" whether to make a formal approach to M&S about the payment.

The ABI has already written to the company to complain about Mr Vandevelde holding the dual positions of chairman and chief executive, which contravenes corporate governance guidelines.

It was thought that Mr Vandevelde's bonus would be equal to one year's salary, but it is now clear that his contract spells out it will be equal to 13 months' salary, or £704,000, with half to be paid in cash and half in shares.

In addition, if he retains the shares for two years he will be awarded a further tranche worth 20% of the allocation, and if he keeps them for four years he will be awarded another 10%. The extra share awards mean Mr Vandevelde's bonus could ultimately total £810,000.

There are no financial targets to be met before the bonus is awarded - just a woolly reference to meeting "strategic" targets. All other M&S staff bonuses, which are paid for meeting financial and performance goals, have been axed.

The payment due to Mr Vandevelde is known to have caused schisms at the very highest levels within the company.

One of the retailer's top 10 shareholders suggested the company might take some of the heat out of the controversy by persuading Mr Vandevelde to defer the bonus and take it entirely in shares.

A spokesman said: "That would send a powerful message to shareholders and employees."

Trade unions have also weighed in to the row. Yesterday John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, described the bonus as "nothing short of obscene. It would be a slap in the face for the thousands of workers who have been sacked as a result of M&S's bungled restructuring as well as to Marks' loyal customers, who consistently see management running the company into the ground."

The escalating row over Mr Vandevelde's bonus came as hundreds of M&S staff in France once again took to the streets to demonstrate against the company's decision to close down its European operations. Yesterday they marched past M&S's flagship store in Paris, chanting "sack the sackers".

They plan similar demonstrations in London on Monday.

fields.headline: Pru takes delayed hit
fields.trailText: With the initial euphoria among investors that followed the apparent collapse of Prudential's merger with American General of the US subsiding, the insurer's share price slipped back by 5.5p to 764p yesterday.
fields.body:
With the initial euphoria among investors that followed the apparent collapse of Prudential's merger with American General of the US subsiding, the insurer's share price slipped back by 5.5p to 764p yesterday.

Jonathan Bloomer, the Pru's chief executive, may be hoping that the fall is, perversely, being generated by expectations that there is a chance that the unpopular deal might yet be successful.

But even though the Pru has filed a writ to sue AIG, the world's biggest insurance company, for making its spoiling bid for American General, most City sources believe it will be little more than a time waster.

American General, which is starting to talk to AIG, is already regarded by City investors as having succumbed to the larger insurer's advances.

Even the move late last night by AIG to register documents with the US regulators, which appear to give Pru's lawsuit credibility, are unlikely to be regarded by the City as any thing other than AIG going through the motions.

Investors will soon be turning their attention to finding ways to spend the £400m compensation the Pru stands to receive from American General for the breakdown in the deal.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: PGA
fields.trailText: Full-year results for the PGA European Tour Course came and went yesterday, and still there is no sign of a takeover bid for the golf course group. PGA hung a for sale sign over the fairways about 18 months ago and has been in talks ever since.
fields.body:
Full-year results for the PGA European Tour Course came and went yesterday, and still there is no sign of a takeover bid for the golf course group. PGA hung a for sale sign over the fairways about 18 months ago and has been in talks ever since.

"Of course it is a frustration," said finance director Alex Chiang. "We seem to have set a world record for being in an offer period."

He said the group - which posted a 17.2% rise in pretax profits for 2000 to £2.3m on turnover of £8.4m - attracted 281,000 rounds of golf last year, up from 250,000 in 1999.

But since then PGA has suffered a run of bad luck. Heavy rain and flooding, increasing concern over an economic slowdown and the foot and mouth crisis have all meant a drop in numbers on the fairways.

"If the government decides to close golf courses because of the foot and mouth problem we will be in big trouble," Mr Chiang said. As yet, all PGA courses are open.

These exceptional and cyclical concerns aside, a number of investors in PGA continue hold out hope of a takeover bid coming to the table.

As a result, shares in PGA have been hit by a wave of speculative buying over several months, peaking in November last year. Recently, however, the share price has been in steady decline, as takeover whispers give way to concern that PGA would fail to find a buyer.

"To date, no formal proposal has been received from any party," chairman Neil Coles said in a statement to the stock exchange. "The board is very conscious of the length of time during which the group has remained in an offer period and is aware that this is unsatisfactory."

A number of approaches have been made, the group insists, and negotiations are continuing.

With no sign of an imminent sale, the shares - which yesterday closed up 0.5p at 35.5p - appear increasingly unattractive.

webTitle: Aceh to be tamed by force

fields.headline: Aceh to be tamed by force
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia has authorised a military offensive in the north Sumatran province of Aceh, where the conflict with separatists is rapidly growing, as part of a strategy to restore peace.
fields.body:
President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia has authorised a military offensive in the north Sumatran province of Aceh, where the conflict with separatists is rapidly growing, as part of a strategy to restore peace.

The defence minister, Mohammed Mahfud, said yesterday that Mr Wahid had approved a six-point "comprehensive agenda" to end the decades of violence in the province.

But buried among clauses about completing special autonomy legislation and continuing the dialogue with the Free Aceh Movement guerrillas is a section allowing a "limited security operation".

News of the policy provoked a student demonstration in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh, where more than 400 people paraded with banners telling Jakarta to "Stop killing Acehnese people".

Human rights activists and western diplomats fear that although the police will be officially in command there could be a military crackdown resulting in many civilian casualties, since the policy does not specify the "limits" it proclaims.

A western diplomat said the policy was "unclear and confusing", adding: "It's typically Indonesian. No one knows what's going on and this includes the upper echelons of the Indonesian government."

The rights activists said that monitoring violence would become more difficult. Monitors have accused soldiers of murdering three of their clearly identified colleagues in East Aceh last week.

webTitle: French left tries to rally its partners

fields.headline: French left tries to rally its partners
fields.trailText: Lionel Jospin's quarrelsome leftwing coalition held emergency talks yesterday on a pre-electoral agenda against the background of street protests and popular disillusion.
fields.body:
Lionel Jospin's quarrelsome leftwing coalition held emergency talks yesterday on a pre-electoral agenda against the background of street protests and popular disillusion.

But a proposed series of mini-reforms, including greater job security, a higher minimum wage and more help for the young, may not be enough to reunite the multi-party gauche plurielle .

With differences between his Socialists and the Communists, Greens and other allies becoming more and more public, Mr Jospin - who will go on television next week to outline the new priorities - has hinted that he may drop out of next spring's presidential election because his government lacks cohesion.

His irritability has encouraged speculation whether he can stand the pace of life at the top. Dominique Voynet, the environment minister, has advised him to take a holiday after a series of incidents, including the noisy reprimand of two women journalists and the hostile public reaction when he visited flooded areas of the Somme.

A temporary walkway in flooded Abbeville was dismantled by angry residents during his visit and, in one of the many references to Holy Week, much was made of his inability to walk on water.

Yesterday's gathering was inevitably compared to the Last Supper before the hoped-for resurrection of his government, severely mauled in local elections in March in which several ministers were beaten.

Recriminations for the setback have sharpened the determination of both the Greens, who did well after attacking the government's environmental record, and the Communist party, which did badly before blaming Mr Jospin, 63, for neglecting a leftwing philosophy.

The elections have been followed by workers' protests, including national strikes by railwaymen, bus drivers and mid wives, the fallout from the Marks & Spencer affair, and farmers' demonstrations which have forced Mr Jospin to cancel provincial visits.

Marchers in Paris yesterday supported trade union demands for companies which sacked workers while announcing big dividends to be punished: a reference to plant closures by the processed food company Danone.

Other high-profile redundancies threaten the government's target of reducing unemployment to less than 2m before the national polls.

The midwives' strike has been particularly hard on Mr Jospin because his mother, Mireille, 90, is a midwife and has backed the protesters. But the feeling that he has become increasingly isolated since he unexpectedly won the 1997 general election is also noticeable in the media.

His reaction to press criticism led to the virulent reprimand of two journalists during an official flight from Brazil, because they reported his admission that the right had won the local elections.

The planned departure of the outspoken environment minister in June, to prepare for the presidential and parliamentary elections, could ease some of the tension in the coalition, where her frequent sarcasm has irked colleagues.

But Mr Jospin's most trusted allies, Martine Aubry and Dominique Strauss-Kahn, have left the cabinet - the first to become mayor of Lille and the second because of a corruption scandal.

Socialist officials deny reports of "panic" in the party, saying that Mr Jospin has already taken matters in hand. But there is noticeable concern at his impulsiveness.

A former education minister and Socialist first-secretary, Mr Jospin wanted to give up politics and return to the diplomatic service when the left lost the 1995 national elections, before internal recriminations led to the suicide of the defeated Socialist prime minister, Pierre Bérégovoy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Turkish hunger strike toll rises | UN official held for genocide | Filipino troops free US hostage | Russia blames Kosovo mission | Bomb victims to see execution
fields.body:
Turkish hunger strike toll rises

The death toll in Turkey's prison hunger strike rose to nine yesterday, as three more political prisoners starved to death.

Aboutg 250 prisoners linked to militant leftwing groups are protesting against their transfer from communal wards to new prisons with small cells.
AP, Ankara

UN official held for genocide

A Rwandan who ran a technical department for the UN mission in Kosovo has been arrested for allegedly taking part in the 1994 genocide in his country.

The UN police chief in Kosovo, Christophe Albiston, said that Rwanda had sought the arrest and extradition proceedings would now be considered. No futher details were given.

webTitle: Robber set free for Easter fiesta

fields.headline: Robber set free for Easter fiesta
fields.standfirst: Man jailed for armed hold-ups is pardoned in Spain's annual festival of penance
fields.trailText: A bank robber called Clemente Perez walked free from jail yesterday. He took his first shuffling steps through the crowded streets of Malaga old town in a black tunic with a black cloth sack draped over his head.
fields.body:
A bank robber called Clemente Perez walked free from jail yesterday. He took his first shuffling steps through the crowded streets of Malaga old town in a black tunic with a black cloth sack draped over his head.

In front of him walked 300 white-and-purple-gowned nazarenos of the Jesus El Rico brotherhood, their faces hidden by the tall conical masked hats typical of Spain's Easter processions.

The annual pardon given to a prisoner from the city jail is a high point in a week of popular religious outpouring in southern Spain during Easter week. Malaga, Seville and Cordoba come to a standstill as the various lay brotherhoods take statues of Jesus and the Virgin Mary from their church altars and parade them through the streets.

Thousands of people don the nazareno outfits - infamously copied by the Ku Klux Klan - in an act of communal penance.

This year the long tunics and conical hats hide the first female nazarenos to have joined many of the centuries-old conservative hermandades (brotherhoods).

Archbishop Carlos Amigo invited women who were refused permission to be nazarenos to take their complaints to him.

Mr Perez, 44, a former fisherman who says he turned to robbing banks to support his wife and three children, was the recipient of an annual pardon established 300 years ago by King Carlos III.

His release, approved at a cabinet meeting, saved him from serving the final five years of a 12-year term.

According to legend, the tradition was born when prison ers from the city jail broke out on Easter night and, disguised as nazarenos, paraded a statue of Jesus around the town.

They returned to jail voluntarily the same night, but only after performing the miracle of bringing an outbreak of bubonic plague to a sudden end.

Mr Perez spent his first hours of freedom walking through the streets of Malaga old town to the dirge-like music of a brass band and followed by a huge carved wood altar to Jesus El Rico. The gilded baroque altar was carried on the shoulders of 200 men, who manoeuvred it through the narrow streets under the shadow of the Moorish Alcazaba fort.

"He has been a model prisoner and is fully rehabilitated. But this pardon is conditional on him not returning to crime," the civil governor of Malaga warned.

Prisoners pardoned in recent years have not always heeded the warning.

One was back in jail within months.

Murderers and violent criminals can no longer apply for the annual pardon.

The last prisoner with blood on his hands to be released created such a public uproar that authorities decided not to repeat the experience.

Rivalry between hermandades is intense. Up to a dozen altars circulate through the narrow streets at any one time. With cars banned, the only traffic jams occur when rival hermandades compete for right of way at a crossroads.

The ensuing arguments are not always Christian in spirit.

webTitle: Trouble in store for war-scarred sons of Gaza

fields.headline: Trouble in store for war-scarred sons of Gaza
fields.standfirst:
Children of the Strip are addicted to violence, doctor warns

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Children of the Strip are addicted to violence, doctor warns.
fields.body:
A generation of children are growing up in Gaza scarred by severe trauma and addicted to violence, according to a leading Palestinian psychiatrist, who fears that they threaten the fabric of future Palestinian society.

"You see children with no hope for the future, not skilled because their schooling has been so disrupted, quite desperate," says Dr Eyad el-Sarraj. "Their parents transmit a continuous message of helplessness, fear, anxiety, deep despair in their eyes. The children feel totally unprotected and see that their parents are powerless.

"Every day they receive confusing messages from Palestinian television. In the morning the message is fight the Israelis, in the evening the message is look at the dead bodies and terrible wounds of those who fought today, and these are pictures nobody can tolerate."

Traumatised

Dr Sarraj, who was trained in hospitals in London and Alexandria and has a distinguished record of publications, is the chairman of Gaza's community mental health programme.

"Every single person who lives in Gaza is traumatised to one degree or another," he says.

His programme, with 220 employees, including 12 doctors and 15 psychologists, has treated 11% of the estimated 1m Palestinians living in Gaza. About 30% of the people in the occupied territory have heard about its work, especially with children.

Gaza is a society of children: half the population is below the age of 14. "These children very often have to cope with a father who has been subjected to Israeli violence, especially difficult if he has been tortured by the Israelis. Or they have fathers humiliated by long-term unemployment," Dr Sarraj says.

"In our culture the father always comes home with something to eat; even if he visits his sister or his cousin he must take something; but now men have nothing, literally.

"The story of the man who drove his bus into that group of soldiers in Tel Aviv recently was just this anger and despair. Such a man comes home and projects his anger against the family, particularly against the children. The child has lost the security framework which was his father."

Dr Sarraj explains the terrifying psychology behind Palestinian children's games.

"To get rid of fear you engage it, to get rid of the fear of dying you engage death. These children are playing an exciting and addictive game with death, and addictive is just what it is."

He has recorded how, after the first intifada, which ended in 1993, children played in the streets, pretending to be Arabs and Jews trying to kill each other.

"The children have switched their identification from their father to the Israelis. They prefer to play the Jew in the game because he is the powerful one. They have seen how their own fathers have lost the symbol of power."

In a survey of 3,000 children in the first intifada, 45% said they had seen their fathers being beaten by the Israelis.

It is not only children who dice with death. "There is communal fear and people deal with it by denial - they go up on the rooftops to watch the bombardments, saying, we don't care what happens to us," Dr Sarraj says.

"The bombardments are completely terrifying, massive explosions. I've thought Gaza would be flattened as I listened to it - just try to imagine the impact on children."

Humiliation

The Israelis systematically transmit the devastating message that Palestinians are not human, he says.

"'You are not a human being,' they say with their eyes full of contempt, and their daily humiliations, such as making the only entry and exit from Gaza for Palestinians in their daily routine to be over a river of sewage, which not one Jew or one Israeli would accept to cross even once, never mind twice a day."

Tens of thousands of Palestinians receive this dehumanising message every day, he says. "This is what you are worth, no more than a piece of stone."

His vision of the future is extremely bleak. "A new seed of hatred is sown every single day by the Israelis."

He describes his own society as one now unprepared for peace, culturally or educationally. "If peace comes and the common enemy is removed, I fear the creation of a new enemy, chaos and violence, drug addiction - everything we have seen only in American movies."

Nevertheless, he says, Palestinians still have some resources which have not been eroded. "Our mothers have a very strong role, they are very, very important symbols of security and the basis of the family, and our tribal tradition gives us the honour and obligation of solidarity. Gaza is very, very poor, but people survive by sharing - we have to at all levels."

Audio report
Suzanne Goldenberg in Khan Yunis, Gaza Strip

webTitle: Jewish pupils urged to visit Hebron

fields.headline: Jewish pupils urged to visit Hebron
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Unfazed by the bloody consequences of his morning stroll around a shared holy site in Jerusalem, the Israeli prime minister Ariel Sharon has now called on Jewish schoolchildren to make pilgrimages of their own: to Hebron, one of the crucibles of the Palestinian uprising.
fields.body:
Unfazed by the bloody consequences of his morning stroll around a shared holy site in Jerusalem, the Israeli prime minister Ariel Sharon has now called on Jewish schoolchildren to make pilgrimages of their own: to Hebron, one of the crucibles of the Palestinian uprising.

Mr Sharon's suggestion that every Israeli pupil should visit the West Bank city, where a strong force of troops guards an enclave of 400 Jewish settlers in the midst of 120,000 Palestinians, could prove explosive. It was delivered in several interviews to the Israeli press appearing yesterday and today.

Hebron, revered by Muslims and Jews as the burial place of the biblical patriarchs Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, has had some of the fiercest clashes of the last seven months, and the greatest misery. In the old city, dominated by the Tomb of the Patriarchs, 40,000 Palestinians have been under almost constant curfew for months. Two weeks ago a Jewish baby girl was killed by a Palestinian sniper.

The city is the Holy Land's second most important religious site - second only to the compound Mr Sharon visited in Jerusalem's old city last September. That tour, to the area revered by Jews as the Temple Mount and Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary, set off the uprising which has claimed 460 lives, mainly Palestinian.

In an interview to be published today in the Yedioth Ahronoth, Mr Sharon suggests that every Jewish school pupil should be required to visit the Jewish enclave in Hebron: the most extremist settlers in the West Bank.

"These are our roots. The settlers in Hebron have taken upon themselves a role for which we must all thank them," he told Israel's biggest circulation newspaper.

Mr Sharon was more expansive in the liberal Ha'aretz.

"A normal people would see to it that every child was brought there, that Hebron became an obligatory chapter in the education of every young person. And that every foreign diplomat or official visitor was taken there."

The prime minister went on to rule out the evacuation of the Jewish settlement in Hebron, or of those in the Gaza Strip.

A day after Israeli tanks drove deep into a Gaza refugee camp - the most significant incursion into Palestinian territory since the intifada began - Mr Sharon's refusal to contemplate the removal of any of the settlements, which are the focus of the uprising, signals a further toughening of his position.

Yesterday his advisers said he was at his farm in southern Israel contemplating his next move.

But the assault on the Khan Yunis camp appears to have deepened the cycle of violence: Mr Sharon said he would order Israeli troops to enter Palestinian territory again if soldiers and settlements came under fire.

In the morning Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian farmer and wounded another man at a junction in the Gaza Strip. The army also reported a sharp rise in grenade attacks on its base near Rafah, on the border with Egypt.

In the West Bank an Israeli soldier was shot and seriously wounded near the village of Beit Jala, which lies between Jerusalem and Hebron.

During the Passover holiday, which ends tomorrow night, the spot in Hebron where 10-month-old Shalhavet Pass was shot has become a pilgrimage site for Jewish settlers.

Audio report
Suzanne Goldenberg in Khan Yunis, Gaza Strip

webTitle: Berlusconi woos voters with the secrets of Silvio

fields.headline: Berlusconi woos voters with the secrets of Silvio
fields.trailText: In an original vote-winning ploy for the Italian election campaign that opens today, Silvio Berlusconi is to send every family in the country a biography featuring 250 photographs of himself
fields.body:
In an original vote-winning ploy for the Italian election campaign that opens today, Silvio Berlusconi is to send every family in the country a biography featuring 250 photographs of himself

A rollercoaster life of self-styled heroism, triumph and genius for insulting lefties has been distilled into a 128-page book, titled An Italian Story, which charts his progress from Milan schoolboy to university student, cruise ship crooner, real estate developer, billionaire media magnate and prime minister.

The biography, which will be delivered to an estimated 20m households, features 250 photographs, all of Mr Berlusconi. Shrugging off accusations of egomania, the centre-right opposition leader has calculated that a cult of personality will sway floating voters.

Members of Mr Berlusconi's party, Forza Italia, have also been given an election kit, consisting of a videotape, horoscope and leaflets about their leader. Enclosed is a manual with tips on canvassing and electioneering, to be learned by heart by those hoping to become "perfect candidates".

The book is printed by his publishing house, Mondadori. "An exceptional triumph of the ego," commented the Turin daily La Stampa, noting that most of the photographs show a slimmer, less bald leader of at least six years ago.

"It will restore the truth after so many lies," countered a Forza Italia spokesman. Polls suggest that Mr Berlusconi's coalition, which includes other rightwing parties, will beat the centre-left government in the May 13 vote despite a narrowing lead.

In between kissing babies, picking flowers, feeding his daughter and jogging, Mr Berlusconi, who is the owner of the football club AC Milan, is shown meeting world leaders. Margaret Thatcher, his idol, makes it into one of the cover's 49 photographs; so does the actor Sylvester Stallone, aka the boxer Rocky, whose gloved fist is seen being raised by the media magnate.

One section, "The little secrets of Silvio", reveals his passion for medieval mysticism, music, gardening and reading the classics of western philosophy while holidaying in the Bahamas.

"Of the big [secrets] there is no mention, for now," said La Repubblica. Since falling from power in 1994 Mr Berlusconi has fended off multiple corruption charges.

fields.headline: No 1858 Easter
fields.trailText: Age: 3,000 (pagan); 1,900 (Christian); c. 30 (DIY).
fields.body:
Age: 3,000 (pagan); 1,900 (Christian); c. 30 (DIY).

Appearance: Cold, damp, cheerless. Often spent in heavy traffic and airport lounges, or on windswept beaches.

Synonymous with: Eggs, bunnies, hot cross buns, awful films on TV (the ones that weren't quite good enough to show at Christmas), excessive consumption of chocolate.

Surely you mean synonymous with the crucifixion and resurrection of Christ? Not any more. Recent polls suggest that almost half of Britons have no idea what Easter represents. Most appear to think the stations of the cross are Victoria and Waterloo.

But it is The Greatest Story Ever Told. Indeed, and I'm looking forward to seeing that film, with John Wayne at Calvary, on Channel 4 on Sunday.

Why does the date of Easter move around so much? It's very simple. In AD325, to establish consistency in the celebration of Easter, the Council of Nicaea laid down that it would thenceforth take place on the first Sunday after the full moon following the vernal equinox. Easter is thus always celebrated on a Sunday between March 22 and April 25. Got that?

No. Why not specify a precise day? Parliament did that in 1928 with the Easter Act, which said Easter should always fall on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April. But the rest of the world ignored it, and it has never been implemented.

I notice today is Friday the 13th. Unlucky for some perhaps. I know you are trying to lure me into a crass remark here, but I value our Christian readership. And of course my job.

Where do the eggs come from? Christianity co-opted pagan festivals celebrating the start of spring. Eostre, the goddess of spring, gave the occasion its name; eggs symbolise birth; and the tradition of painting and eating eggs predates Christ by at least a thousand years.

Eggs-traordinary, but I really must be off to church. And I have to go to B&Q. Happy Easter.

Most appear to think the stations of the cross are Victoria and Waterloo. But it is The Greatest Story Ever Told. Indeed, and I'm looking forward to seeing that film, with John Wayne at Calvary, on Channel 4 on Sunday. Why does the date of Easter move around so much? It's very simple. In AD325, to establish consistency in the celebration of Easter, the Council of Nicaea laid down that it would thenceforth take place on the first Sunday after the full moon following the vernal equinox. Easter is thus always celebrated on a Sunday between March 22 and April 25. Got that? No. Why not specify a precise day? Parliament did that in 1928 with the Easter Act, which said Easter should always fall on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April. But the rest of the world ignored it, and it has never been implemented. I notice today is Friday the 13th. Unlucky for some perhaps. I know you are trying to lure me into a crass remark here, but I value our Christian readership. And of course my job. Where do the eggs come from? Christianity co-opted pagan festivals celebrating the start of spring. Eostre, the goddess of spring, gave the occasion its name; eggs symbolise birth; and the tradition of painting and eating eggs predates Christ by at least a thousand years. Eggs-traordinary, but I really must be off to church. And I have to go to B&Q. Happy Easter.

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: My wife wants to separate because our rows are harming the children
fields.trailText: My wife wants to separate because our rows are harming the children
fields.body:
My daughter is overweight. She eats too many snacks between meals but my wife doesn't see it. Teenage angst, looming A-levels and peer pressure might all be factors but the eating pattern has been consistent. Her exam results have been disappointing and she spends a lot of time using the internet. Her mother refuses to acknowledge this as a problem. Also, my son is anaemic. He has a poor diet, is off school a lot and unhappy. My wife insists this is psychological and wants us to separate (me to get out) so that the kids see us row less often. If I thought this would work I would do it, but I feel it would have an irreversible effect. Is there a better solution?
Work it out with your wife

Like your son I was an anaemic child who ate poorly and suffered from depression. I didn't recognise it until I was older, but I was exhibiting early signs of anorexia. My sister, like your daughter, is a compulsive overeater. Anorexic and addictive eating disorders are often found together in families. Your children can get help by attending Overeaters Anonymous meetings where people with all types of eating disorders are given support.

You will have to look at why your children are unhappy. Outside pressures such as exams and teenage angst only traumatise us if we are fragile in the first place. My dysfunctional behaviour was a direct result of my parents' behaviour. I don't blame them - they didn't know any better - but we know that if I'd come from a happy home I wouldn't have starved myself.

It is painful to come out of denial and look honestly at why things aren't the way we want them to be. I agree with your wife that your son's problems are psychological; mine were. Perhaps you and your wife could attend counselling instead of separating? It's my experience that when parents work on their emotional issues together, their children find it easier to recover from their own problems.

Name and address withheld.

Problem could be you

Your daughter's behaviour really is shocking, isn't it? Eating snacks between meals, spending time on the internet and getting poor results in exams. What is so awful about the "eating pattern"?

Your daughter will be well aware of being overweight, given that we live in a society obsessed with appearance and where teenagers are under enormous pressures to be slim. If and when she wishes to do something about it she will. Having had a "weight problem" my entire life (the problem being other people's attitudes) I can say that the more you nag or complain the less likely she is to do anything about it.

I imagine that seeing their parents row less often would be a boost for both of your children, although both actually seem to be displaying fairly normal behaviour. Perhaps the "problem" lies with you and you should comply with your wife's wishes and depart forthwith.

Mark Jones, Leicester.

See a family therapist

Your daughter is in the middle of her exam years, a stressful period. This is also a time of life when issues of boyfriends, keeping up with peers and leaving home can weigh heavily. She may be feeling under pressure from your distress at her weight and "disappointing" exam results. Both your children are expressing their distress loud and clear. The situation between you and your wife is undoubtedly affecting all four of you.

The risk is that your children's coping strategies may become chronic: eating disorders, social isolation and depression can devastate their lives. Have you thought of consulting a family therapist? This would give you and your wife an opportunity to work out your differences and your children a chance to think safely about their worries, and allow all of you to move on from the unhappiness you are trapped in. The Institute of Family Therapy in London could advise you of therapists in your area.

Name and address withheld.

Talk to the children

If your wife refuses to acknowledge the problems with your children, you must work out the problems with your children yourself. Arguing makes it worse but is unlikely to be the root cause. Take time alone with each child, talk to them about your concerns and listen to theirs. You can get their diets back on track yourself if you want to.

Separation at this critical time is foolish for everyone. Your wife is using it as an excuse as it sounds as if she's given up on you and the children. Talk to her too, and reconcile your differences, even if this is only for the short term until after A-levels for both children.

Tackle your wife after you have tried to get the children back on track with your love and support for them individually. Seek outside help for the children too.

Donald McCarthy, Surrey.

Next week

I am a woman in my mid-40s with three teenage children. I am happily married to a man I love and who cares about the children. We have a satisfactory sex life. I have, however, fallen in love with a close female friend and have started to have sexual fantasies about her. She would, I'm sure, be horrified about this, as would my husband.

I cannot bear the thought of cheating on my husband. However, having felt emotionally flat for a long time due to bringing up a family and working, I now feel better and a much more sexual person. I have always thought of myself as heterosexual so am bewildered at my feelings. Where should I proceed, if anywhere?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, or email private.lives@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Burning issues
fields.trailText: Burning issues
fields.body:
Northumberland

Having avoided writing about the dread foot and mouth disease, now there is no escaping it. As I sit at my desk, I can see smoke drifting from three funeral pyres to the south, and there are two others six miles north of the village. Sometimes it is difficult to know whether it is the disease or the response which is getting out of control. The knock-on effect for the rural business community has been catastrophic. This crisis is currently costing millions in the agricultural sector and more is haemorrhaging from tourism. Perhaps one positive aspect is that town-dwellers will better appreciate that mother nature is not just a great rural theme park. Our local blacksmith's business is virtually on hold. No equines are going anywhere. In this parish alone, there are riding stables as well as three racing yards. My garden fence is collapsing so I called in the village fencer. He came with alacrity. "I shall have it righted today", he promised. "I have had to lay off my two apprentices because business is virtually at a standstill." Holiday and bed-and-breakfast businesses which have been built up with capital, hard work and expertise are suffering numerous cancellations. The new farmers' markets have been thriving during the last 18 months. Now they are cancelled for the foreseeable future. Several farms in this area diversified into welcoming schools and families to their premises, especially at lambing time; one farm at Hartburn last year received 50,000 visitors. Sadly, this week they have been devastated by the disease. The government have come in for a lot of stick over their handling of this sorry affair. Let us hope that lessons have been learned.

fields.headline: Around the world in 27 junkets
fields.standfirst:
They are dubbed rent-a-prince and princess pushy - Prince and Princess Michael of Kent. Now, after the Sophie tapes, their endless travelling is alarming the Foreign Office and Palace

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: They are dubbed rent-a-prince and princess pushy - Prince and Princess Michael of Kent. Now, after the Sophie tapes, their endless travelling is alarming the Foreign Office and Palace
fields.body:
Pity Prince and Princess Michael of Kent. They get no money from the civil list or from the Queen and are widely regarded as freeloaders who exploit their titles for financial gain. He is dubbed the royal-for-rent, she princess pushy for her imperious manner and her apparent desire for self-promotion.

But life is not all bad for the Kents. Over their 33 years of marriage, they have used their minor royal status to carve out an existence for themselves that provides a constant round of world travel to promote a vast array of business and charitable organisations.

Now, after the Sophie tapes affair, there is growing concern about the Kents' activities among senior diplomatic and Buckingham Palace figures, who fear that the couple's endless globetrotting is tarnishing the international reputation of the royal family.

The prince does not carry out any official engagements on behalf of the Queen, but a glance through his diary since the start of January last year reveals the extraordinary scale of his travelling.

During the last 15 months he has been on more than 20 trips to destinations ranging from Dublin to Australia, as a representative or guest of more than 100 organisations. Few, if any, of the trips were paid for by the Kents.

The new millennium began for the prince with a week-long trip to New Zealand in January last year as a guest of the luxury goods manufacturer Louis Vuitton. He was there to watch the semi-final of a sailing contest sponsored by the company, but he managed to squeeze in one formal event: presenting a medal on behalf of the Royal Life Saving Society, of which he is Commonwealth president.

From there it was back to Britain, but not before a stop-off in Los Angeles during which he met the consul general to "discuss forthcoming initiatives in California". It is this sort of contact with British diplomatic representatives while on private business that is causing growing unease among senior Foreign Office ministers.

Diplomats fear a rerun of the row that erupted five years ago when it emerged that he used the facilities of the British embassy in Beijing while on a private business trip to China. The prince's office insisted then that he was there at the invitation of the Chinese government, and that the embassy had extended only "the same assistance as given to any other visiting party".

According to senior ministerial sources, the prince is still treading a similarly thin line on some of his trips. A spokesman for the prince, however, denied the claims out of hand.

Dismayed

The Kents defend their travelling on the basis that the vast majority of it is on behalf of good causes, but diplomatic and palace sources have been dismayed by the obscure nature of some of the organisations they the couple lend their support to.

In April last year, for example, the prince travelled to Singapore and Australia as patron of a medical charity, the World Health Network Foundation, the "ethical watchdog" of a commercial venture called World Health Network which allows doctors around the world to share information via the internet.

Inquiries by the Guardian have established that neither the World Health Organisation, British Medical Association nor the Royal College of Medicine were previously aware of its existence.

Much of the prince's work involves representing two business organisations, the British Security Industry Association, with whom he travelled to Dubai and Athens in the past year, and the Russo-British Chamber of Commerce, under whose auspices he travelled to Russia at least twice in the last year.

A hitherto unnoticed memorandum from the RBCC, of which the prince is patron, to the Commons foreign affairs committee in 1999 sheds some light on the tensions between the Foreign Office and the prince. Under the heading Prince Michael of Kent, the organisation com plained that senior members of the British embassy in Moscow, along with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and ministers in London, "do not appear to acknowledge the role HRH Prince Michael is carrying out".

The memo said that the prince was regarded by the Russians as a significant character whom senior government figures wanted to deal with. "As such, therefore, he is seen as a quasi-diplomatic representative and his views are sought. Distancing of any sort by the FCO [Foreign and Commonwealth Office] is therefore logically and clearly a reduction in its level and effectiveness of diplomatic representation."

Yesterday, both the prince's office and the RBCC distanced themselves from the memo. A spokesman for the prince said that it had not expressed his views and that relations with both the Foreign Office and the Moscow embassy were "improving all the time as they come to understand what the prince is doing".

Lectures

Princess Michael is also a keen traveller. Her main vehicle is a twice-yearly lecture tour of the United States, which involves speaking at dinners on art and history topics, with titles such as Louis XIV: Substance and the Show. All the money raised from the lectures goes to charity.

While the Kents are at pains to insist that they travel as private individuals, before going abroad on a trip, they always meet with the London ambassador of the host country, either at the embassy or at Kensington Palace.

On January 8 this year, for example, the prince went to the Peruvian embassy to discuss the arrangements for a visit by the princess with the ambassador and other officials.

The meeting took place even though the princess was travelling to Peru in February on a private visit as a guest of Jim Sherwood, founder and president of the Sea Containers Group and head of Orient Express Hotels.

The prince's spokesman insisted that the prince had not met the ambassador to request facilities from the Peruvian government. "When they go to a country, it is something that people are interested in and it would be quite wrong and lacking in manners not to meet with the ambassador of that country."

But several leading British charities and business organisations involved in organising visits overseas with celebrities and famous patrons told the Guardian yesterday that they never felt it necessary to have meetings at ambassador level ahead of their trips.

webTitle: Diplomats worry over Prince Michael's trips

fields.headline: Diplomats worry over Prince Michael's trips
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: British diplomats have warned ministers that the private business and charitable activities of Prince and Princess Michael of Kent are in danger of causing another royal public relations disaster.
fields.body:
British diplomats have warned ministers that the private business and charitable activities of Prince and Princess Michael of Kent are in danger of causing another royal public relations disaster.

Foreign Office sources told the Guardian that there was "serious concern" in diplomatic circles over the Kents' extraordinary lifestyle, which has seen them carry out more than 20 trips in the last 15 months, paid for by a bewildering range of organisations.

This year, Prince Michael has already visited Dubai, India, Australia and the US, while his wife has travelled to Peru and the US.

In the wake of the Sophie tapes affair, the fear among ministers is that the couple are "sailing too close to the wind" in using their royal status.

Their financial arrangements have long been a source of debate among senior courtiers and ministers. Prince Michael, the second son of the Duke of Kent, does not carry out official engagements and therefore receives no money from the civil list or the privy purse. His office says this justifies his commercial activities.

Their only income is derived from the consultancy work he does for British exporters through his company Cantium Services, which last year had debts of more than £200,000. Yet the Kents finance two households, one at their four-storey grace-and-favour apartment in Kensington palace and the other at their £1.6m country home in Gloucestershire.

The Kents' attempts to fund this lifestyle have led them to be dubbed the Renta-Kents, after a series of embarrassing commercial ventures which tried to cash in on their royal titles.

But it is the amount of foreign travel the couple undertake on private engagements that is causing most concern in Whitehall and Buckingham Palace.

Much of the prince's work involves representing two business organisations, the British Security Industry Association and the Russo-British Chamber of Commerce. But the couple also lend their support to many obscure bodies.

Although they never travel on official royal business, the Foreign Office arranges for the Kents to get VIP airport privileges on all their trips. That is the only diplomatic facility they are entitled to, but sources claim that approaches have been made to embassies for other support.

In 1996, the prince was caught in the centre of a storm after it emerged that he had used the facilities of the British embassy in Beijing while on a private business trip to China.

A spokesman for the prince said that the couple did not now try to use embassy facilities on private visits. fields.headline: Missing, presumed magnificent
fields.standfirst: The great movies we'll never be allowed to watch
fields.trailText: The great movies we'll never be allowed to watch
fields.body:
I remember the tenuous hold we used to have on movies before the home-video revolution. The way a film such as Night Moves or Who'll Stop the Rain would burn in your brain all the more brightly because you had to rely on memory alone, and because you might not see it again for years. How the almost religious experience of seeing Vertigo or The Merchant of Four Seasons for the first time would simply have evaporated if you had been able to rewind to your favourite moments there and then.

Some of them, of course, did not endure. It would turn out, when finally you did see the film again, that you had misconstrued the proportions, or simply sucked out its pulp and pith in one viewing. The survivors, those films to which your second reaction was as ecstatic as your first, went on to become lifelong friends.

Today I find that I can replicate this shaky relationship only with films that are not available in any format whatsoever, and it leads me to wonder if some of my favourite movies might be ones I've never seen at all.

There are many reasons for their unavailability. Sometimes ownership rights are disputed, with legal gridlock preventing release. Such is the case with the legendary pot-head classics El Topo and The Holy Mountain. Their director, Alejandro Jodorowsky, will tell anyone who'll listen that he believes Beatles manager Allen Klein, who owns the rights, destroyed both movies out of spite years ago. Other cases are more prosaic, but keep us from seeing - in the US, at least - such classics as Anthony Mann's Dostoyevsky western The Furies, Sam Fuller's Forty Guns and House of Bamboo, Nicholas Ray's Bigger Than Life, and Douglas Sirk's There's Always Tomorrow. I've also long had an unscratchable itch to see lost 1970s movies like Aloha, Bobby and Rose, starring Paul Le Mat, the sleazy LA drug drama Cisco Pike, or novelist Tom McGuane's directorial effort, 92 in the Shade. Occasionally there are shafts of light in the murk, such as the recent reissue of Monte Helman's little classics Cockfighter and Two-Lane Blacktop in widescreen, but beyond such infrequent blessings the best I can do is pray.

Other movies are of such limited interest as to make video distribution simply prohibitive. America's narrow appetite for imported, sub- titled movies means that Alain Resnais's Muriel and Satyajit Ray's Days and Nights in the Forest can be found only on shagged-out, decade-old videos from companies that no longer exist. As films, they have vanished. And no one is likely to renovate Luchino Visconti's shoddily maintained oeuvre just because I fancy seeing a decent Technicolor print of Senso or The Leopard. What chance do we have of seeing Jean-Marie Straub and Danielle Huillet's austere The Bridegroom, The Comedienne and the Pimp, or Chris Marker's The Last Bolshevik, or Rivette's 12-hour Out 1/Spectre, which I believe has only ever been screened once? I also understand that Chris Petit's Radio On - an auditorum-emptier that I've thrilled to no less than seven times - will probably never make it to video simply because it is too murky and dark to be seen on a TV screen. So what? It lives in my head.

Then there is the rich, broad strain of underground film-making that partakes more of the art world or radical politics than of Hollywood. Directors such as Jon Jost and James Bening used to be present at every screening of their films, because of their perceived inaccessibility. Jost is now well served on video (apart from his death-hymn to LA, Angel City), but Bening still wanders America like an itinerant showman, bearing cinematic gifts to campuses and film clubs in the boot of his car.

In the most extreme cases, underground directors withdrew their work from distribution altogether, such as the late Gregory Markropolous and his partner Robert Beavers. Beavers' movies (which, I am told, are extraordinarily beautiful) are unseeable in any form, so tightly does the director control them. When they are shown in Washington, DC, this May, it will be the first time they have been exhibited in America since 1974. It's 3,000 miles and a fortune to get there, but I'm going.

Sometimes the big boys adopt the tactics of such small fry. Kubrick did it in the UK by withdrawing A Clockwork Orange, which thus had a virtually samizdat existence for nearly 30 years. And Alfred Hitchcock held back five of his own movies - including Rear Window and Vertigo - that weren't re-released until several years after his death, presumably with a view to enhancing his posthumous reputation.

But whatever the reasons I can't see, or re-see, many of these movies, I like the fact that they're out there in the ether, waiting for me to unearth them, demanding my ingenuity and doggedness. Together they represent a Pandora's box of unrealised possibilities, a vault stacked with high hopes, and a place where one can feel like an optimist again. I'm patient. I've already waited two decades to see many of them, and some of them I know I'll never see at all. In their absence I have simply imagined them, and the movies I have thus conjured up are unlike anything I've ever seen.

fields.headline: 'Yup, he's a total whacko'
fields.trailText: The Real Cracker | The People Detective | The People Detective
fields.body:
Hampshire police called in a couple of crackers to help them find a masked man, who had been attacking courting couples in cars for 10 years. Dr Badcock, a consultant psychiatrist at Rampton, and Dr Boon, a forensic psychologist, had worked together on the Shipman case. They found the Hampshire predator unusually self-possessed and slick.

Badcock: "The archetypal glib, shady salesman."

Boon: "It just occurred to me... estate agent?"

Police: "We've considered that."

Badcock: "A profession where the ability to tell a plausible lie is a valued commodity..."

All together now: "A politician!"

Badcock snapped his spectacles shut. "He's a member of the cabinet."

They all enjoyed that. I did myself. It only left one problem, which minster is physically capable of carrying a struggling woman upstairs in a fireman's lift?

The Real Cracker (Channel 4) ran twice as long as usual and not just because there were two of them this time. A chasm began to open between the police and the profilers.

A criminal who leaves no trace still leaves an impression. The profilers got an impression of discipline suggesting army training. An impression of authority, suggesting rank. An impression of swagger and braggadocio, suggesting fraud. Much against their advice, the police publicised the case on the programme Britain's Most Wanted, and heard of a man who fitted this CV nicely.

At this point, as the police cried "Forward!" the profilers cried "Back!" Dr Badcock, finding he was continually putting off writing his report for the police, rather touchingly psychoanalysed himself. He concluded he was worried they might use it to identify the offender. "That isn't the purpose of a profile. There are true things about him, I think, but they don't tell you who he is. That's a detective thing."

What we have here is the fall-out from the Rachel Nickell murder. Colin Stagg was arrested solely on a profiler's report. The judge erupted and the ash from that detonation is still descending.

After 18 months Dr Badcock wrote his report, emblazoned with disclaimers. The police interviewed their suspect and eliminated him. No one has been arrested.

Doorstepped outside a prison where he had been seeing a disturbed prisoner, Dr Badcock, bless him, provided one last quote. Rampton rang his mobile. He took the call. "Yes, I've just seen him. He should definitely come in. He's a total whacko."

I love a drop of psychoanalytical jargon, me.

The People Detective (BBC 2) introduced Tracy Whitaker to her great, great, great, great, great grandmother, a skeleton in a Leeds museum. We cannot choose our relations.

Mary Bateman was hanged for murder in 1809. Nursing her baby in the condemned cell ("The worst is when I shall part with my blessed baby"), she wrote to her husband, "I am innocent of murder. I never did destroy that woman for whom I am to suffer."

She had fleeced a couple called Perigo of 70 guineas. When Mrs Perigo died after eating Mary's Yorkshire pudding, you might call that convenient.

Tracy's guide to the underworld, the lively Daru Rooke, called Mary Bateman "a rum lot". Not, perhaps, your average farmer's daughter. This was a woman who claimed her hens laid eggs with "Christ is coming" on them and charged people to see them. Tracy, like Mary, is clever and humorous. She is also, curiously, studying forensic science and carried Mary's skull down to London unflinchingly.

Dr Robin Richards of University College has devised a way of recreating a face that is more scientific and less artistic than the modelling procedure used in Meet The Ancestors. Bolts of laser light measure the skull. A computer adds flesh. You wonder how effective this technique would be on Dr Richards, who is almost wholly hidden by hair.

Mary's face rose from the darkness of the computer screen, green and serene, like a drowned woman surfacing. It was, as Tracy said, putting her finger rather neatly on the mot juste , a genteel face.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Kind Hearts And Coronets | The 10 Commandments | Wild Wild West | The Missionary
fields.body:
Films

Kind Hearts And Coronets (Robert Hamer, 1949) 5pm, Carlton Cinema Famed for Alec Guinness's multifaceted performance as all eight of the murdered D'Ascoynes, but there are other treasures: the suave malice of Dennis Price's stately serial killer; the beauty of fiancée Joan Greenwood; the portrayal of Edwardian England and its snobby mores; and the delicious glee with which the awful upper classes are dispatched. At heart it is a bitter and subversive comedy.

The 10 Commandments (Cecil B DeMille, 1956) 10pm, Sky Cinema You will see the parting of the sea, the locusts, the orgy-that-took-three-weeks-to-shoot and Charlton Heston, all in Technicolor, VistaVision widescreen splendour. After his 1923 silent version of the Moses story, DeMille pulled out all the stops here; and miraculously, it remains pretty dull: too much heavily significant acting from Heston, Yul Brynner, Cedric Hardwicke and Edward G Robinson.

Wild Wild West (Barry Sonnenfeld, 1999) 8.05pm, Sky Premier Sonnenfeld's disappointing follow-up to the smash-hit Men In Black is a Western spoof that forgot to stir in the jokes. And despite a fusillade of special effects, a predictable plot and flat script leave it mainly dull. Will Smith and Kevin Kline, though, employ their idiosyncratic brands of charm as odd-couple federal agents. They are matched against Kenneth Branagh's criminal mastermind Dr Arliss Loveless, who with his giant mechanical spider looks like a baddy out of Jules Verne. Salma Hayek also helps liven it up.

The Missionary (Richard Loncraine, 1983) 9.15pm, Carlton Cinema Life is hell for lowly Edwardian clergyman Michael Palin: 10 years of struggle in Africa, then back to a hazardous posting in an East End mission for fallen women. He rises to the challenge somewhat over-enthusiastically, according to the church elders in this gentle, Palin-scripted comedy. No side-splitter, but fluid direction and upper-crust cast - Maggie Smith, Michael Hordern, Denholm Elliott and Trevor Howard.

The Long Good Friday (John Mackenzie, 1979) 10pm, FilmFour The well-hard British gangster movie that made a star of Bob Hoskins, scheduled on the appropriate day by a wag at FilmFour. Hoskins is far from his normal cuddly self as Harold, a little caesar of the East End who hangs his rivals from meat-hooks. He's setting up a lucrative Docklands deal with the American mob until a sudden, mysterious assault on his manor shatters his plans. Stylish, savage, with bursts of extreme violence; and Helen Mirren is a classy moll.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Football 11am, Sky Sports 1 A very good Friday indeed, starting with this, the third televised match between Leeds and Liverpool this season. The other two have both been marvellous, with both sides winning once, but as the end of the season looms with both teams scrambling for a Champions' League place this is unlikely to disappoint.
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Jazz Legends | Performance On 3 | Night Waves
fields.body:
In the early 1930s Fletcher Henderson set the style that big bands would follow for the next two generations. As Julian Joseph recalls in Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3), Henderson became a bandleader by chance. As a record promoter in 1924 he needed a group to tour with Ethel Waters. He assembled a scratch team of jazzmen who, once Louis Armstrong joined them a little later, dramatically changed their whole musical style.

In Performance On 3 (6.30pm, Radio 3) the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment under Sir Roger Norrington marks this Easter with its first performance in London of Bach's magnificent account of the crucifixion and resurrection. When he wrote the St Matthew Passion in 1727, Bach intended some of its chorales to be sung by the congregation at the Leipzig Thomaskirche. Fortunately, there are two trained choruses to cope with the music at the Queen Elizabeth Hall.

With a new biography about to appear, Paul Allen recalls for Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) the life and work of the writer and war correspondent Martha Gellhorn. One of her early exploits was to stow away on a hospital ship so she could cover the D-Day landings. Probably her most memorable reports were written during her stint in Vietnam for the Guardian. In 1989 she stunned everyone by turning up for the US invasion of Panama at the age of 81.
