fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: I'm afraid you've lost me
fields.trailText: High Resolution | The Psychology Of Fame
fields.body:
Things have changed since my student days. "Today's going to be an easy day", the lecturer explains on High Resolution (Radio 4), before blindfolding her Edinburgh University students, bundling them into a minibus and driving them up hill, down dale and repeatedly around roundabouts until they lose their bearings. "Now," she says, clipboard in hand, like some directionally obsessed dominatrix, "can you point North?" They couldn't, of course. In my day, an easy time of it consisted of lazing in bed, snoozing through Gardeners' Question Time.

But then my lecturers weren't researching the wonderful world of animal navigation, how grey whales and green turtles find their long distance migratory ways or whether an animal that knows how to get from A to B, and B to C, can compute a shortcut from A to C. These are not questions that keep me from sleep at night, and they certainly won't after this disappointing documentary.

You know you're in trouble when a programme begins with a dictionary definition of its subject, and when it slides into Open University science programme obscurity with comments like "for many species of animal, sensitivity to the earth's magnetic field for compass navigation has now been demonstrated". I would have liked more tales of animals' amazing journeys with less "evidence" of how complex the whole business is, and the student day out to have proved something more conclusive than if you do all that to someone, they - wait for it - won't know where they are.

Raj Persaud was stating the obvious, too, in The Psychology Of Fame (Radio 4). This might be inevitable given the subject, but even the format had a cloying predictability about it - yes, Vanessa Feltz was included, moaning about people regarding her "as some kind of cartoon character". When she first saw her husband's mistress in a tabloid, Feltz thought "gosh, none of this was worth it", and yet months later she's inviting us back to hers in Hello and volunteering for Big Brother.

This first programme never really got to the bottom of this behaviour, whether it's to do with the nature of fame itself or differing personalities. Persaud, slightly famous himself now, is an engaging presenter but this was Psychology Lite - nothing that you won't have thought yourself if you've ever given the subject a moment of your time. Musicially it was horribly predictable too: cue burst of David Bowie and Fame. How much more appropriate it would have been to hear Morrissey sing Frankly Mr Shankly ("Fame, fame, fatal fame, it can play hideous tricks on the brain") and then to have dived more deeply into the hideousness that may come to define our age.

webTitle: Cologne may be clue to sport success

fields.headline: Cologne may be clue to sport success
fields.trailText: He is a walking billboard for Nike and his choices of watch, car and credit card are well known, but Tiger Woods has not, so far, revealed which aftershave he was wearing during his record-breaking victory at the US Masters.
fields.body:
He is a walking billboard for Nike and his choices of watch, car and credit card are well known, but Tiger Woods has not, so far, revealed which aftershave he was wearing during his record-breaking victory at the US Masters.

Woods, who on Sunday became the first player to hold all four major golf championships simultaneously, could soon find his favourite cologne the subject of intense interest, however, after research has found that success on the sports field can be affected by one's choice of fragrance.

David Collins, a former marine turned academic, told the Edinburgh international science festival last night that dousing oneself in a pungent scent - and mustering the correct mental attitude - could make all the difference when faced with a sporting challenge. "Scent can help athletes remember moves more accurately and consistently, especially in the face of competition," he said.

In one experiment, volunteers were taught archery skills and then given a scent and asked to imagine themselves doing well. Wearing the perfume - in this case lavender - caused them to shoot better by an average of 10%, he said.

An athlete's success or failure is almost always mentally based, Professor Collins added. "You face a different pressure to win for the first time than when you have been there already. There are people who cope with those different pressures and who are equipped to stay at the top, such as Tiger Woods, and there are those who are a one-cap wonder."

Anyone can choose not to be intimidated by the opposition. "There's no reason why the average competitor can't plan to be mentally tougher. The bottom line is how people perceive stress, whether it is seen as a challenge or a threat."

webTitle: Labour embroiled in new 'control freak' row

fields.headline: Labour embroiled in new 'control freak' row
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Politics
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Labour's leadership was engulfed by a new "control freak" row last night after an aide to the party's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, lobbied key figures in Brighton Kemptown to withdraw an initial nomination for an activist and support the government whip, Lady Gould, in the forthcoming contest for the national executive committee.
fields.body:
Labour's leadership was engulfed by a new "control freak" row last night after an aide to the party's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, lobbied key figures in Brighton Kemptown to withdraw an initial nomination for an activist and support the government whip, Lady Gould, in the forthcoming contest for the national executive committee.

Millbank's intervention follows criticism by a former NEC member, Liz Davies, of Ms McDonagh's attempts to stifle debate.

The party hierarchy has launched a determined drive to reduce the influence of the grassroots alliance which holds two of the six constituency seats on the NEC and is running a slate in the election.

Brighton Kemptown's general management committee last month nominated Willie Sullivan, Scottish Labour's former development officer and a critic of Millbank's "machine-style" politics.

But after phone calls from Alicia Chayter in Ms McDonagh's office, the nomination was switched to Lady Gould who lives in Brighton and needed local endorsement to stand under party rules.

Mr Sullivan's supporters claim a number of Brighton officials were wrongly told he had agreed to withdraw and Millbank even offered to "arrange" another constituency to support him.

Simon Burgess, Kemptown's agent, accepted phone calls had been received from Millbank but denied pressure was applied.

"A decision was taken then reversed by people who had no right to do so. This is creating a hell of a stink," an aggrieved member said.

Fifteen candidates, including actor Tony Robinson and the editor of Tribune, Mark Seddon, are standing for six seats.

fields.headline: Jean-Marc Bory
fields.standfirst: Film actor whose debut role was a screen first
fields.trailText: Film actor whose debut role was a screen first.
fields.body:
As the first actor to simulate cunnilingus on screen in a mainstream feature film, Jean-Marc Bory, who has died of a heart attack aged 67, had quite a reputation to live up to or live down, depending on one's point of view. The 20-minute semi-nude breakthrough love scene came in Louis Malle's The Lovers (Les Amants, 1958), a succès de scandale that helped to wreck sexual censorship the world over.

Bory played a handsome young archaeology student who helps Jeanne Moreau when her car breaks down on the way home to her grand country house. She is a middle-class provincial wife, bored with both her husband and lover and willing to find sexual gratification elsewhere.

Bory provides it during a night of carnal bliss, before they leave together at dawn. They begin by flirting in the moonlight, then after some foreplay in the bath, they go into the bedroom. We see the sensuous Moreau in a series of close-ups,eyes and mouth half open, hand falling eloquently open on the sheet as she accepts the joy he is giving her, whispering, "Mon amour."

François Truffaut called the chic, lyrical, erotic film "the first night of love in the cinema". It earned much money for the producers, brought Malle immense fame and made an international star of Moreau. Bory's international celebrity, however, was short-lived.

Initially, Malle had wanted Jean-Louis Trintignant for the role, but the actor was doing his military service. Malle recalled that "it must have been very hard for Jean-Marc Bory to do the role, as Jeanne and I were in the middle of a great love affair, living together, arriving on set and leaving together. The whole thing of doing the love scenes must have been very tough for Bory. The love scenes were difficult for all of us. They were improvised."

Moreau remarked: "I don't remember, sometimes, being with Bory, because he was seldom there. He appeared on set when he was called. The rest of the time he was sleeping or sunbathing."

Bory, who was 24 at the time, said that he had forgotten doing the love scene, and that he never again met Moreau, who was six years his senior. In fact, Bory refused any similar role, saying that it wasn't the sort of thing he sought to do by becoming an actor. Consequently, though he appeared in films into the 1990s, his career suffered somewhat.

The Swiss-born Bory, who had a love of theatre instilled in him by his parents, had a parallel career on stage. After studying acting in Switzerland, he left for Paris at the age of 19. After his film debut in The Lovers projected him into the limelight, Bory worked with many of France's leading directors, including Abel Gance (Austerlitz, 1960), Michel Deville (Adorable Liar, 1961) and Pierre Kast (Vacances Portugais, 1963). For Roger Vadim in Warrior's Rest (1962), in contrast to his role in The Lovers, he played the respectable fiancé of good girl Brigitte Bardot before she meets a man who initiates her into the joys of uninhibited sex (Robert Hossein).

Bory's stage appearances ranged from Kleist's Catherine de Heilbronn, directed by Eric Rohmer, to Samuel Beckett's Endgame, and he was well known and respected at the National Theatres of Lyon and Strasbourg. In the 1998 Avignon festival, a grey-bearded Bory played the Chorus in Oedipus the Tyrant, Holderlin's adaptation of Sophocles, accompanied by three of his five children. His last work was directing Mozart's Lucio Silla for Lausanne Opera. He is survived by his wife and children.

 Jean-Marc Bory, actor, born March 17 1934; died March 31 2001

fields.headline: Letter: Harry Secombe
fields.trailText: One memory comes flooding back to me of Harry Secombe (Obituary April 12): the time I ate a packet of chocolate biscuits with him at his Surrey home.
fields.body:
Michael Freedland writes:

One memory comes flooding back to me of Harry Secombe (Obituary April 12): the time I ate a packet of chocolate biscuits with him at his Surrey home. It was almost 40 years ago and he was probably the first celebrity I interviewed as a young journalist. He was fat and as jolly as a roly-poly pudding. He endeared himself to me by trying to put me at my ease. We talked about the books on his shelves, each crisply displayed in their mint jackets. "I do read them, you know," he roared in that trademark voice. And told me about all of them.

He made his life seem no more exciting than mine and throughout what I liked to call an interview, he laughed, chuckled and between sentences kept saying: "Have another KitKat." I have that wonderful, unsolicited advertisement for chocolate biscuits still preserved on a tape. We also talked about the reality of show business. "Well," he said, "I came home one night, very excited and told Myra [his wife], 'Guess what, I'm going to top the bill at the Palladium.' 'Oh, yes,' she said,' and the children have all got the measles.' That puts things into perspective for you."

I went to see him again a few months after the heart atttack that nearly killed him 19 years ago. This time he wasn't offering biscuits, and had lost five stones on doctor's orders. He took a couple of jackets from his wardrobe - and wrapped them around himself. Each could have covered him twice. He had had to replace every one. "Expensive business having a heart attack," he said.

webTitle: The usual Passover in the war zones

fields.headline: The usual Passover in the war zones
fields.standfirst:
There is no chance of a peaceful festival until Israel ends its illegal occupation of West Bank and Gaza, says diplomatic editor Ewen MacAskill

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: There is no chance of a peaceful festival until Israel ends its illegal occupation of West Bank and Gaza, says diplomatic editor Ewen MacAskill.
fields.body:
Anyone visiting Israel for the Passover might have wondered if the daily diet of pictures of television war zones is overdone. It is possible to wander around Tel Aviv and even Jerusalem without any sense of a country involved in a bloody conflict.

There are some signs. A tension in the air, an unspoken worry about the possibility of a Hamas or Islamic Jihad suicide bomber getting on a bus or going into a market. These things have happened and will almost certainly happen again.

In Jerusalem last week, it was possible to hear the sound of Israeli shelling and rocket attacks on the Palestinian village of Beit Jala. One parent in a Jerusalem park, anxious to avoid alarming her child, said it was thunder: the child, corrected her, saying it was guns.

But daily life goes on, just as Londoners went to work or out to play as normal during the IRA bombing campaigns.

Travel beyond Jerusalem onto the West Bank or Gaza and the contrast is stark. These are areas under occupation. This is where the killings take place. This is where the tension is.

At times it looks normal, even peaceful, but turn a corner in Ramallah or one of the other towns or villages on the West Bank and there is a chance of running into the debris from an overnight fight, or an Israeli army checkpoint or stone-throwing Palestinian youths. You can travel these roads for days, or months, or years and nothing will happen to you: but you can never be sure that there is not a Palestinian gunman or Jewish settler hiding behind a rock ready to take a shot.

There are Israeli army curfews imposed sometimes only for a day and sometimes a month or more. These are 24-hour curfews, with occasional breaks to allow people to shop. Children stop going to school because their teachers cannot get through. Access to medical treatment is erratic; business and farming comes to a standstill.

Roads are often closed: sometimes at random and only for a few days, sometimes for months at a time. Setting out on a journey, no one knows for sure.

This week the Israeli army put huge concrete blocks across the road into Nablus, one of the main towns of the West Bank.

A journey of a few miles turned into a 30-minute trip round back roads. What did the roadblock achieve? It was not preventing a Palestinian gunman or bomber leaving Nablus. Such a gunman or bomber would have travelled the back roads just the same as everyone else.

All the Israeli army succeeded in doing was adding to the long list of grievances felt by the Palestinians.

That sense of grievance is fuelled in other ways too. By the bulldozing of houses, as in Gaza on Tuesday, or the uprooting of olive groves. The Israeli army says that such houses and olive groves provide cover for snipers and rock-throwers.

Almost every Palestinian has a story to tell. They will complain about abuse by the Israelis - but the Palestinians are not united.

While for many, Yasser Arafat remains the great Palestinian leader, there is also a sense of failure that he has yet to begin building up the Palestinian authority in preparation for nationhood. There is disillusionment with Mr Arafat's circle and with the high levels of corruption among some Palestinians.

These are internal arguments. There is unity over the final objective: to get Israel to end its illegal occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. There is little chance of peace in the Middle East until that happens.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Loyalist parade can go on | Lord Harris dies | Child's play for Tate Modern | Police chief faces tribunal | Palm print boost for officers | Woman found dead in jail | Straw urged to ban NF march
fields.body:
Loyalist parade can go on

Nationalist residents yesterday failed in a high court challenge to have an Apprentice Boys parade along the lower Ormeau Road in south Belfast on Easter Monday blocked. Residents have pledged to stage protests ahead of the march.

Lord Harris dies aged 71

Lord Harris of Greenwich, an aide to two Labour leaders, Hugh Gaitskell and Harold Wilson, before following his close political friend Roy Jenkins into the SDP, has died aged 71. As John Harris he was a Home Office minister and chair man of the Parole Board in the 70s while Jenkins was home secretary. Until his death he was Liberal Democrat chief whip in the Lords.

Obituaries: Lord Harris of Greenwich

Child's play for Tate Modern

The Tate Modern will have a change of leadership for a day next July when a child wins the right to shadow the director, Sir Nicholas Serota, as one of the prizes in schools competitions organised as part of the first National Children Day in association with the Guardian and Guardian Education.

Police chief faces tribunal

Internal disciplinary charges of discreditable conduct should be laid against the deputy chief constable of Surrey, Ian Beckett, the Surrey police authority said yesterday. The charges relate to alleged offences of sexually harassing civilian staff. They will be determined by an independent tribunal.

Palm print boost for officers

Police are to get a £17m computer system to help identify criminals by their palm prints - which like fingerprints are unique, Jack Straw, the home secretary, announced yesterday.

Woman found dead in jail

A woman serving life for attempted murder has been found hanged at Holloway prison in north London. Maxine Bauer, 47, from Leicester, becomes the 19th inmate to kill herself in England and Wales this year.

Straw urged to ban NF march

Leicester police are to ask the home secretary Jack Straw to ban a National Front march next Saturday. The chief constable David Wyrko said: "We have to balance the right of people to demonstrate with the rights of the broad community."

webTitle: Storm in champagne flute over Martine

fields.headline: Storm in champagne flute over Martine
fields.trailText: Eliza Doolittle may have been a firm believer in the curative qualities of gin, but it seems that pink champagne has an even more miraculous effect on Martine McCutcheon, the actress who plays her in the National Theatre's new production of My Fair Lady.
fields.body:
My aunt died of influenza. But it's my belief they done the old woman in... Why should she die of influenza when she come through diphtheria right enough the year before? Fairly blue with it, she was. They all thought she was dead. But my father, he kept ladling gin down her throat... - Eliza Doolittle in My Fair Lady

Eliza Doolittle may have been a firm believer in the curative qualities of gin, but it seems that pink champagne has an even more miraculous effect on Martine McCutcheon, the actress who plays her in the National Theatre's new production of My Fair Lady.

The former EastEnders star, who battled through the opening night of the musical with flu before dropping out of three weeks of performances, is set to return next week after been photographed "on the razz" in the West End of London.

McCutcheon, 24, insists she was merely out celebrating her possible return to the sell-out show, which transfers to Drury Lane in July, with her boyfriend and had nothing more that a glass or two of wine.

Her publicists were also keen to try to quash any idea that McCutcheon - whose character is famously transformed from a Cockney sparrow into a "proper lady" - would drink anything as outre as pink champagne.

However, a diner at the next table at The Square restaurant in Mayfair claimed that the liquid in her flute was definitely pink.

The National denied the actress had been "hauled over the coals" by the theatre's artistic director, Trevor Nunn, who stands to make up to £1m himself from a successful West End transfer.

Her understudy, Alexandra Jay, has had to take over in all but 11 performances since the musical previewed early in March.

"Given that she has been seriously ill at home with a throat infection for the last few weeks, she must have been stir-crazy," a spokeswoman said. "It is true that she did meet Trevor and [the impresario] Cameron Mackintosh on the day after she was photographed [leaving the restaurant], but it was only to check on the progress of her recovery. She has begun rehearsing with a voice coach and she has recovered to some extent. It is a very gradual process."

McCutcheon stands to earn in excess of £10,000 a week when the show transfers to the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, but until then she is believed to be making do with a mere £754 from the National.

Her spokesman vehemently denied she was not up to the rigours of a live theatre run. "Martine has been very seriously ill. She spent a day in the intensive care unit of the London Clinic. She has been suffering from a streptococcal throat infection, severe sinusitus and impaired blood clotting.

"All she did was go out for the first time in three weeks with her boyfriend for supper to celebrate the news that she would be going back on stage."

The spokesman revealed that she had returned to her first full rehearsal yesterday and was looking forward to stepping back into the shoes of the Covent Garden flower girl, for which she has garnered rave reviews.

fields.headline: Schizophrenia linked to father's age
fields.trailText: Men over 50 are three times more likely to father children with schizophrenia, according to New York scientists. And men between 45 and 50 are twice as likely as males under 25 to have children with the mental illness.
fields.body:
Men over 50 are three times more likely to father children with schizophrenia, according to New York scientists. And men between 45 and 50 are twice as likely as males under 25 to have children with the mental illness.

"A man has a biological clock, too," said Dolores Malaspina, of Columbia University college of physicians and surgeons. "Men should be aware of the risks when they do their family planning."

She and colleagues worked with the New York University school of medicine and the Israeli ministry of health to review the records of almost 88,000 people born in Jerusalem between 1964 and 1976. This is the first link between paternal age and mental illness. There is growing evidence that older men are more likely to have children with gene-influenced illnesses.

Paternal age has been tied to an increasing likelihood of prostate cancer, cancer of the nervous system, neurofibromatosis, the most common type of dwarfism, malformation of the skull, hands and feet, and Marfan syndrome, which involves defects of the eyes, bones, heart and blood vessels.

Most of these are rare conditions. Schizophrenia affects one in 100 and the paternal age connection would only become visible in a very large survey.

The hypothesis is that with the years sperm cells are more likely to accumulate mutations which could be passed on to offspring. But schizophrenia remains a puzzle. It seems to be more prevalent in some groups, and researchers have claimed several times to have identified schizophrenia genes.

However, there could also be environmental factors. The New York study cannot identify which genes or what environmental factors might be at work.

But the illness is remarkably persistent in human populations, even though schizophrenics are less likely to marry and have children. The New York scientists believe the paternal age factor might explain why the proportion of schizophrenics remains roughly the same in each generation.

The researchers reported in the latest Archives of General Psychiatry that more than 26% of cases could be attributed to the father's age. Susan Harlap, of New York University, a co-author of the report, said: "Our study suggests that a man's progeny are going to be healthiest if he has his children during his early 20s. But we know that many men aren't ready for marriage and parenthood at that age."

She added: "I would guess that our study is just the tip of the iceberg. It would seem that the father's sperm is going to turn out to be just as important as the mother's egg."

Older women are much more likely to have a caesarean birth, even when problems during labour are taken into account, according to research published today. Women over 40 who are having their first child are up to 14 times more likely to have the operation as those under 30, a study has found.

The findings, published in the British Medical Journal, have again raised concern that many women are having unnecessary caesareans.

webTitle: Wig jibe arrest leads to £1,200 police payout

fields.headline: Wig jibe arrest leads to £1,200 police payout
fields.trailText: A man arrested for poking fun at a police officer's wig has been awarded £1,200 compensation, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A man arrested for poking fun at a police officer's wig has been awarded £1,200 compensation, it emerged yesterday.

Jon Neil mocked Richard Moody's hairpiece while he was at the pro-cannabis Smokey Bear's Picnic demonstration on Southsea Common, Hampshire, in August last year.

He was arrested by another officer who had overheard the jibe, under the Public Order Act for "causing alarm, harassment or distress".The crown prosecution service later decided not to proceed with the case.

Police had wrongly told a local newspaper that the arrest was for the possession of drugs. Hampshire police has now agreed to compensate the 36-year-old wholesale manager for the mistake.

Mr Neil told the Big Issue magazine: "I made a cheeky comment about one of the officers, who was wearing a bright orange wig. It was plainly obvious the poor guy had been fobbed off by some wig maker, so I said, 'Is that a wig you're wearing? I know where you can get a better one. I've got a list of good wig makers'." Mr Neil is bald himself.

A Hampshire police spokesman said yesterday: "The publicity that followed the arrest of Mr Neil included a reference that he had been charged with drug-related offences. We have apologised and paid him compensation."

Press Association

fields.headline: 'Wonderdrug' losing war with superbugs
fields.trailText: A new type of antibiotic hailed as a key weapon against antibiotic-resistant hospital "superbugs" may already be losing its power, scientists warned yesterday.
fields.body:
A new type of antibiotic hailed as a key weapon against antibiotic-resistant hospital "superbugs" may already be losing its power, scientists warned yesterday.

Linezolid, promoted as the first in a new class of antibiotic for 35 years, was only licensed in Britain four months ago. But evidence from the United States suggests that harmful bacteria have already built up resistance to the drug, sold under the brand name Zyvox.

Doctors in this country last night remained cautiously optimistic that the drug could still cut the 100,000 infections caught by British patients each year while in hospital.

With 5,000 deaths a year, experts have warned gloomily of a return to "dark ages" of medicine if hospitals do not soon get a grip on fighting the new endemic antibiotic-resistant diseases with effective drugs and vastly improved hygiene procedures.

The concern over Zyvox so early in its commercial life will be seen as a salutary reminder of just how versatile bacteria are, partly because of cavalier overuse of antibiotics for the past 50 years in medicine and in farming. Concern at the waning powers of what were once regarded as wonder-drugs has brought firm political action only in the last three years and many critics do not believe enough is being done to educate the public, doctors or farmers of the need to cut their routine use.

Linezolid, approved by the US food and drug administration last April, is being used to treat patients suffering from pneumonia and other infections associated with VRE, one of the so-called superbugs.

Pharmacia, the makers, say it works in two thirds of cases and actual bacterial resistance had been found in only a handful of those.

A study published in the Lancet yesterday found that one in 45 patients may have a resistance to the new drug. The findings will come as a blow to scientists, who believed Linezolid could overcome the most virulent bacteria, including vancomycin-resistant organisms that cause many potentially deadly infections.

Doctors from the University of Illinois College of Medicine in Chicago studied Linezolid's success in treating five patients suffering from the vancomycin-resistant enterococcus faecium (VRE).

It was initially effective in all five patients, but over a period of weeks, the tests showed that the bacteria were beginning to develop a resistance to the drug.

In three of the cases, the Linezolid treatment eventually failed as patients grew unresponsive to the drug. Doctors here will be eagerly awaiting the results. The public health laboratory service specialist Alan Johnston said: "We had hoped there would be quite a long period before we saw clincial problems with the occurrence of resistance [in Zyvox]. In the last 10 to 15 years we have had a number of new drugs coming into use about which we have been optimistic that resistance might not be a problem or delayed. All too often resistance has emerged remarkably rapidly."

But there were signs that the organisms behind a more dangerous superbug, methilin resistant staphylococcus aureus - MRSA - might find it more difficult to adapt and resist Zyvox. "I am still cautiously optimistic we are looking at a major development in anti-microbial treatment."

The Department of Health said last night it had been urging prudence in the use of all antibiotics to preserve their usefulness as long as possible.

Cameron Durrant, vice-president for infectious diseases at Pharmacia, said the Chicago patients were "very sick" and the results confirmed the company's own laboratory and clinical studies. "We have now had in excess of 60,000 patients treated with Zyvox and we are talking about a small number of cases , limited to a very small group. There has been no confirmed case of resistance to MRSA.

"We are still extremely confident that the appropriate use of Zyvox will benefit patients all over the world."

fields.headline: Easter in Britain
fields.standfirst: Don't forget the disinfectant
fields.trailText: The number of holidaymakers leaving the UK has soared while domestic tourism has slumped for the traditional Easter weekend. Tourist boards are noting a 30% drop in sales, and at the same time almost 2m people - 15%   more than last year - are leaving Britain.
fields.body:
The number of holidaymakers leaving the UK has soared while domestic tourism has slumped for the traditional Easter weekend. Tourist boards are noting a 30% drop in sales, and at the same time almost 2m people - 15% more than last year - are leaving Britain.

The areas worst affected by foot and mouth, including Cumbria and parts of Devon, are taking a fifth of their usual Easter bookings. Tony Blair and his deputy, John Prescott, yesterday embarked on separate tours to woo visitors back to tourist destinations.

The prime minister, at the seaside in Devon, said: "Even in the heart of the countryside, provided people do not go through the livestock parts, they can do the things they always do and enjoy the countryside in the way they should."

With cool and rainy weather predicted, holidaymakers not going abroad are expected to opt for city breaks and flock to shop ping centres, amusement parks and city centres. The AA warned that motorways around shopping centres will be exceptionally busy.

fields.headline: Good marks all round
fields.trailText: As a finance officer in a primary school, I take issue with ATL president Eddie Ferguson (Schools 'becoming dependent on vouchers to raise funds', April 11).
fields.body:
As a finance officer in a primary school, I take issue with ATL president Eddie Ferguson (Schools 'becoming dependent on vouchers to raise funds', April 11).

Since the present government came to power, the amounts paid to local education authorities have increased above inflation and grants paid directly to schools have been introduced - in the case of my own small school, about £34,000 in the last two years. Added to these are grants paid by the government to support specific initiatives - for example, the national literacy and numeracy strategies and the national grid for learning (another £15,000). In addition, schools have been given grants to address the backlog of maintenance work that accrued under the previous government, so that our children and teachers have decent conditions in which to work (£11,000 in this financial year).

When properly managed, these sums make a significant contribution. Tesco vouchers and the raising of money through jumble sales are now beginning to resume their rightful place - a means of providing peripheral support. For the first time since I began working in a school, we have a government that puts its money where its mouth is rather than one that expects schools to do more and more with less and less money.
Kate Parish
Wimborne, Dorset

 Your report (Ofsted chief promises teachers less hostile regime, April 12) is also good news for pupils. The old system had an awful effect on the schools my children attended and without doubt adversely affected their education. The schools were excellent and Ofsted duly confirmed this, but only after sending the teachers to the verge of breakdowns and forcing them to cancel activities such as school plays whilst they prepared for the dreaded inspection week.

People like Chris Woodhead do not understand the value of things such as cooperation and good will. I hope the daylight which has now penetrated Ofsted will soon percolate other sectors afflicted with simplistic performance measurement gurus.
Brian Hughes
Cheltenham, Glos

 Joanna Briscoe could save herself all the anguish and hypocrisy (More tea, Vicar? G2, April 11) by sending her offspring to the local comprehensive, just as my parents did. I'm sure that while there, her child will receive a quality education from hard-working and dedicated teachers, as well as a fine array of social skills to enable junior to avoid the "head-butting ... round the corner". I'd like to thank Manchester's schools for my 10 GCSEs, 38 points at A-level and soon-to-be-had degree in medicine and surgery. Relax, Joanna, don't move house, don't prostitute yourself at the altar. The kid will do fine.
Bill Gibson
Leeds bill_gibson@mail.com

 I understand Joanna Briscoe's dilemma, but I would ask her not to place her fraudulent bum on my pews. Almost certainly, her local community school is much, much better than its reputation. I have chaired the governing bodies of two adjacent schools, one C of E, one community, for 11 years. Although the schools were quite different, the commitment and teaching skills of the staff were very similar and I felt very happy in both. If there is a problem, far better would be to work with others to help the community school improve.
Rev Neil Richardson
Greenford, Middx

 In view of the social divisiveness of the education system in this country, is it not time for you to require all your contributors publicly to register where they send their children to school and whether these schools are private or state, religious or non-religious?
JG Thompson
Stratford-upon-Avon, Warks

webTitle: Letters: Tesco sells us all short

fields.headline: Tesco sells us all short
fields.trailText: Tesco's profits (Tesco sells its way to first £1bn profit, April 11) - and the finding that it imports more of its groceries than any other supermarket - can only rub salt into the wounds of a farming industry already mortally injured.
fields.body:
Tesco's profits (Tesco sells its way to first £1bn profit, April 11) - and the finding that it imports more of its groceries than any other supermarket - can only rub salt into the wounds of a farming industry already mortally injured.

Farmers are reputed to receive a paltry 9p for every £1 spent in the supermarkets. The government could immediately demand a levy on supermarket profits that would help finance a sustainable farming trust. Good quality food would be the direct benefit, with spin-offs for the farming community, tourism, recreation and wildlife. Both supermarkets and consumers must be prepared to pay the real cost of food.
Phil Rothwell
RSPB

 Supermarkets may indeed drive down prices of meat to the detriment of farmers, but your leader (April 11) ignores the fact that fruit and vegetables are vastly more expensive in supermarkets than elsewhere. Whether the high prices benefit the farmer to any great extent, I doubt. It is high time those who never set foot in an old-fashioned green grocer's realise they are being ripped off by supermarkets who like to pretend they are on a mission to provide low-cost food for the masses.
Colin Williamson
London

 The real victims of Tesco's headline profits have been forgotten: its low-paid workers, many of whom work for close to the national minimum wage.
Tesco employee
Name and address supplied

webTitle: Letters: Why the police failed Loraine Whiting

fields.headline: Why the police failed Loraine Whiting
fields.trailText: Your story (I'm going, I've got no blood left in me, April 10) treats the death of Loraine Whiting, a harrowing story, with a singular lack of balance. The author did not go to the trouble of contacting the Kent County Constabulary; she seems to have accepted uncritically the comments of the Whiting family.
fields.body:
Your story (I'm going, I've got no blood left in me, April 10) treats the death of Loraine Whiting, a harrowing story, with a singular lack of balance. The author did not go to the trouble of contacting the Kent County Constabulary; she seems to have accepted uncritically the comments of the Whiting family.

It is extremely easy, with the benefit of six years' hindsight, to make judgments on how this terrible tragedy could have been averted. It is far more difficult to put yourself in the position of the police officers who were outside Loraine Whiting's house, knowing what they knew at the time. Those officers knew that Loraine Whiting's estranged husband, Len Carter, had tricked his way into the house, dressed as a police officer. They knew that Len Carter had a gun, that he had just used the gun and that he had a record of violence.

Those officers were also well aware, as unfortunately the readers of your story were not, that a startlingly similar incident had occurred in Leicestershire several years earlier. Two ambulance crew members and a police officer entered a house where someone had been held hostage, having been assured by the injured person inside the house that it was safe to do so as the hostage-taker was dead. Tragically, the hostage-taker was lying in wait. He ambushed and murdered the ambulance crew and the police officer.

Ever since, that incident has formed a vital part of the training which members of the emergency services undergo. The officers that night, six years ago, had no choice but to take very seriously the distinct possibility that Len Carter was forcing Loraine Whiting to try to lure ambulance and police officers into the house.

This is a deeply tragic story in which those on all sides have suffered greatly.
Robert Ayling
Deputy chief constable,
Kent County Constabulary

fields.headline: Lilies block the view
fields.trailText: Your report on the debate in the Northern Ireland assembly (A bunch of lilies does not seem like a problem, April 11) is disappointing, not least because it is the only time you have extensively reported on a debate from the assembly.
fields.body:
Your report on the debate in the Northern Ireland assembly (A bunch of lilies does not seem like a problem, April 11) is disappointing, not least because it is the only time you have extensively reported on a debate from the assembly.

Last Tuesday, before he tabled his motion on Easter lilies, Jim Wells MLA was at the launch of a children's manifesto by Barnardo's, Child Poverty Action Group and the NSPCC, which he endorsed along with fellow assembly members from four other parties, including Sinn Fein. Had your reporter flown over that day, he would have heard an excellent debate in the assembly on the provision of psychiatric facilities for adolescents, where all parties united in calling for better provision.

Yesterday as well, Northern Ireland's thinktank, Democratic Dialogue, held a discussion day on the Good Friday agreement, where the one thing everyone agreed on was how well the assembly is working. Many journalists are missing the story in Northern Ireland now that their "fix" of bombs and bullets has (almost) ended. I'm not asking for "good" news in a Martyn Lewis kind of way. But an informed debate about what is actually happening here would make a nice wee change.

It is disappointing that your readers will be left with the impression that the assembly is riven by unfathomable sectarian debate, when so much good work is being done by all our politicians.
Fiona MacMillan
Belfast

 The view of Sinn Fein that Catholic population growth will realise their objective of a united Ireland is seriously flawed (Protestant majority predicted to fall sharply, April 12). A Protestant majority didn't deliver stability and equal rights to all the population.

Irrespective of religious ratios, only a culture which allows for voluntary change will work. The problem to figures interested in their reputations in history is that it will take too long.
Lionel Beckett
Tring, Herts
LionelBeckett@aol.com

 For the first time, in Northern Ireland and Scotland, the census will inquire about both religious belonging and upbringing. Yet only in Britain will it distinguish British from Irish ethnic groups.

In Northern Ireland - of all places - neither British nor Irish ethnicity is prompted; with the unfortunate corollary that Protestant and Catholic religions are proper surrogates for British and Irish cultural identities.
Philip Kestelman
London

fields.headline: Sanity down the tubes
fields.trailText: So the government is only going to provide "£2bn of the total £13bn cost" of its tube public-private partnership plan (Mayor wins court date for tube battle, April 11). Who does it imagine is going to stump up the other £11bn - the private sector? Get real, New Labour.
fields.body:
So the government is only going to provide "£2bn of the total £13bn cost" of its tube public-private partnership plan (Mayor wins court date for tube battle, April 11). Who does it imagine is going to stump up the other £11bn - the private sector? Get real, New Labour.
Walter Hain
London

 We elect a mayor for London, then select the world's foremost expert on running the tube - with a proven, recent and relevant record of success. And the government still wants to go ahead with plan B. Why?
John Carter
London

 If you really want to get an insight into the hard work that goes on in MPs' offices (Called to account, G2, April 10; Letters, April 11 and 12) have a look at the Working for an MP website www.working4anmp.co.uk
Dick Robinson
Cambridge

 Last Friday I attended the commission for racial equality's Race in the Media awards' - where Louis Emerick won Media Personality of the Year for his portrayal of Mick Johnson in Brookside. Next day your Soaphead column (Guide, April 7) accuses Brookside of being racist!
Paul Marquess
Series producer, Brookside

 Why don't all you other buggers go out to work at night (Leader, April 7) and leave us plumbers and so forth to work in peace in the daylight, instead of always being out when we call?
J Wood
Canterbury, Kent

 Now that this erroneous accusation has been disproved (Brahms cleared of serial cat slaying, April 12), can we expect further clarifications about the composer's alleged bacchanalian sorties with Liszt?
Ian Joyce
Milton Keynes, Bucks

webTitle: The influence of James M Cain's novels on film noir

fields.headline: Prince of Darkness
fields.standfirst: James M Cain's hard-boiled novels of greed, lust  and murder made for perfect film noir. But, says  William Preston Robertson, the writer's  relationship with Hollywood's 'cavemen' was  never easy
fields.trailText: James M Cain's hard-boiled novels of greed, lust and murder made for perfect film noir. But, says William Preston Robertson, the writer's relationship with Hollywood's 'cavemen' was never easy
fields.body:
James M Cain, the prolific and talented author of such landmark hard-boiled novels as The Postman Always Rings Twice, Double Indemnity, Mildred Pierce and Serenade, had nothing but contempt for movies and for the bloated industry that produced them. Cain believed movies to be an inferior art form. He found them crudely schematic, childishly contrived, simple-minded, superficial and unsophisticated - the modern equivalent of hunting tableaux scrawled by slavering, torch-bearing cavemen.

That Cain held the flickering arts in such disdain is ironic because he eagerly pursued a career as a screenwriter in his youth and later on, as a novelist, garnered respectable riches from the film rights to his work. Today, much of the public is aware of him solely through the movies derived from his books. When people think of James Mallahan Cain, they think of Fred MacMurray and Barbara Stanwyck in Double Indemnity. They think of John Garfield and Lana Turner in The Postman Always Rings Twice. They think of Joan Crawford in Mildred Pierce, re-released this week. When people think of Cain, they think of film noir.

And why not? The Postman Always Rings Twice and Double Indemnity, Cain's back-to-back 1930s pulp masterpieces of adultery, spousal homicide and insurance-settlement high jinks - once they were allowed on to the screen by the Hays Office censors of the 1940s - became veritable templates for a staggering number of noir movies. This use, or perhaps overuse, of the "Cain template" extended well past the original film noir era's demise in the 1950s. The practice re-emerged in the neo-noir era of the 1980s and 1990s, which arguably began with Body Heat and Blood Simple. From there it was carried across the millennial threshold into the current era, when "in the tradition of James M Cain" is shamelessly proclaimed on the sleeve of every direct-to-video thriller that, however slightly, incorporates blue lighting, a fog machine and a hero with a nicotine addiction.

And herein lies the problem. When all is said and done, very few films of any era bear a resemblance to the spirit of Cain's writing, the best of which was penned long before film noir existed. Somewhere in the shadows of film noir, James M Cain the writer has got lost. No one would rate Cain a Nobel-worthy man of letters - except maybe Albert Camus, who admitted basing his existentialist work The Outsider on the Cain template. Nevertheless, at the very least Cain deserves a seat alongside the other major fiction-writers of his day. He deserves to be taken seriously, not as some kind of a miner hammering out rough ore for the Hollywood refinery, but for what he was: a first-rate writer of fiction.

Cain belonged to that gaggle of writers from the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s known as the "tough guy" or "hard boiled" school. They wrote terse, lurid, violent tales about crime and desperation, set against low-rent landscapes populated with lumpenproletarians and anti-heroes who jabbered in the clipped, slangy lingo of the everyday schmo. Some of these writers, such as Dashiell Hammett (The Maltese Falcon, Red Harvest) and Raymond Chandler (The Big Sleep, Farewell My Lovely), wrote detective stories. Others, such as Horace McCoy (They Shoot Horses, Don't They?, Kiss Tomorrow Goodbye) and Cain, tended to approach matters from the point of view of those who committed the crimes. Critic Edmund Wilson dubbed the writers in this latter subset "the poets of the tabloid murder" and, of them, he considered Cain the best.

James M Cain described himself as an ugly, Irish Catholic mama's boy born in Maryland to upper-middle-class parents, in 1892. Cain's mother was a former soprano who gave up her career to marry Cain's father, a self-centred academic who drank and disliked work. Both parents had an annoying penchant for punctiliously correcting Cain's grammar in conversation, a habit that no doubt helped shape his love of jargon-laden first-person narrative voices, and compelled him later to cite as his major literary influence a bricklayer named Ike.

Writing was a kind of booby prize to Cain. Tubercular and deeply sensitive, with a tendency toward self-deprecation, he struggled to find his niche in life, trying his hand at everything from opera to insurance. He failed as a novelist, too, until he wrote The Postman Always Rings Twice, which initially he wanted to call Bar-B-Que. Thankfully, this time around, failure lost out. Cain's experiences with failure instilled in him an affinity for losers as his protagonists. Cain's characters are society's lost souls, the disenfranchised and the powerless, inches away from despair, craving to make something of themselves and willing to try any idea to reach that end, no matter how stupid or murderous. The jargon he got from Ike. The morbid fascination with tortuous moral dilemmas, from his Catholic upbringing. The rough sexual encounters seem to have been his own idea.

Cain's interest in losers wasn't sheer perversity. As bleak and depressing as his fictional world could be at times, Cain portrayed his losers with great humanity, complexity and artistic integrity. Losers and weaklings, psychopaths and sociopaths though they may be, Cain's characters are individual human beings compassionately rendered. Perhaps most human of all Cain's stable of flawed, self- destructive characters is Mildred Pierce. Mildred is an ordinary, middle-class, Depression-era housewife with pretty nice gams, a talent for making pies and a healthy libido, whose confining socio-economic position has left her with few resources to fall back upon except her gams, her pies and her libido.

Surrounded as she is by extraordinarily ineffectual men with diminished senses of responsibility, and motivated by her desire to make things better for her cruelly snobbish, sociopathic daughter Veda, Mildred scrappily builds a minor culinary empire, basking in her sexual freedom along the way. Her downfall is her unhealthy, self-destructive love for the loveless, insatiable, ungrateful Veda.

Cain's highly sexual, psychologically and physically violent novels caused a sensation on their release but were not brought to the screen until the end of the second world war and the rise of film noir. By then Cain had given up on Hollywood and had left California for the pastoral confines of Maryland with his wife, an opera singer. And film noir was left to its own devices with Cain's work.

Film noir was born from the serendipitous jumbling of a series of unlikely influences, both artistic and thematic in nature. The stories were primarily American crime dramas whose cinematic look was heavily influenced in lighting, framing and mood by the ostentatious, off-kilter angst of German Expressionism, courtesy of the many directors who had fled the Nazis. Subtextually added to this mix were a variety of US government-sanctioned, propagandistic impulses of the day: the drive to disengage women from their independent work status in the total war economy; the housing lobby's promotion of urban flight to the cheap suburban developments that were springing up; and the campaign to discourage returning soldiers from wartime habits and motivate them to settle back into domestic life.

But film noir is also a stylised form, a kind of Teutonically lit Noh drama of fedoras and slinky dresses in which the characters are pawns of fate and destiny, with personalities defined by broadly sketched impulses of lust, greed, paranoia and evil. Cain was many things, but self- consciously stylistic he was not. He relied on his rhythmic sense of dialogue and his understanding of human psychology and social context to tell his tales.

So it was that when film noir took on the job of adapting Cain's novels, the distinctly 1930s aspects were removed from his yarns of sex and murder and manipulative, castrating temptresses. The result was that Cain's strong but flawed women lost whatever individual motivating traits they exhibited in the books and became pointlessly manipulative.

Thus Cora Papadakis in The Postman Always Rings Twice became Cora Smith, a dapper beauty without the desperation that helped explain her motivations in Cain's book. Phyllis Nirdlinger in Double Indemnity became Phyllis Dietrichson, a pointlessly evil woman. And finally, for the movie of Mildred Pierce, the characters of the men were bolstered. Many of them got jobs or financial interests that had been missing in the book, while Veda's operatic talents were reduced to those of a nightclub songstress. And the class-struggle aspects were for the most part excised, leaving no drudgework for Mildred to partake in. The book, of course, had no murder, but since this was Cain, it seemed only right to add one.

It's important, and only fair to Cain, to remember the distinction between the literary demands of the 1930s and the cinematic demands of the 1940s. In his excellent book analysing the work of Cain, Paul Skenazy compares Cain's portrayal of Depression-era desperation to Nathanael West's The Day of the Locust and John Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath. If nothing else, Cain deserves to be taken seriously for his legitimate contribution to American literature. And to French literature too, if you count Camus.

fields.standfirst: O Brother, Where Art Thou? | Shaft | Romeo Must Die
fields.trailText: O Brother, Where Art Thou? | Shaft | Romeo Must Die
fields.body:
O Brother, Where Art Thou?
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Momentum, cert 12

Film number eight from the remarkable Coen brothers, who have yet to release anything not stamped with their inimitably skewed sensibility. By recent standards, it's not quite top-ranking: it doesn't have the coherence and firm morality of Fargo or the loopy hilarity of The Big Lebowski. But, as ever, it has much to recommend it: some top verbal curlicues, handed to George Clooney, who's clearly having a ball; a very relaxed and highly unpredictable narrative; and, not least, a treasure trove of cherishable 30s "old-timey music" (blues, gospel and bluegrass) put together with loving care by T-Bone Burnett.

The typically rambling tale is described by Joel Coen on one of the DVD interviews as combining "the Three Stooges with Homer's Odyssey". So you have sirens, a cyclops (a one-eyed John Goodman) and a quest for our hero, Ulysses.

In this case, it's Ulysses Everett McGill (Clooney), a vain and verbose philosophical convict who has escaped from a chain gang. The Three Stooges part comes in the shape of the two dimwits he has tricked into escaping with him (dumb and dumber sidekicks are a Coen tradition, and they get more laughs from it than the Farrellys).

But lots more references are thrown into the pot in this hot, dusty, mythical old south: there's a chain gang to remind you that the title comes from the film the director in Sullivan's Travels never made; a black guitarist who has sold his soul to the devil at the crossroads (here called Tommy Johnson, not Robert); and exuberant bank robber George "Baby Face" Nelson. It's goofy fun, a family film at heart but with a few stunning set-pieces: the spectacularly choreographed Klan meeting and a brilliantly realised flood stay in the memory, along with Clooney clowning at the mike in a ZZ Top beard.

Shaft
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Paramount Cert 18

Isaac Hayes's symphony of wah-wah and high-hat is still the only contemporary classic to win an Oscar for best song and, in lightly updated form, is still the most memorable part of this revival of the pioneering black hero. The mighty Hayes, with his deep bass rumble and relaxed acting style, would have made a perfect Shaft himself in the 1971 original, but you couldn't do much better now than Sam "The Man" Jackson in the title role and John "Boyz 'n the Hood" Singleton as director. Ultimately, it's just serviceable, though: Jackson is the hard case on a hard case, trying to find and then protect the only witness to a murder by racist rich boy Christian Bale.

There are more MFs in the script than at an Oedipus Appreciation Society meeting, but what we want is a bit of wit and humour for Jackson to savour. Yet three scriptwriters come up with only one line that fits slippery Sam: "It's my duty to please that booty," he purrs coolly to a soulful barmaid. Jackson's Pulp Fiction role for the blaxploitation-fixated Tarantino played a big part in making this project commercially viable, but you wish Quentin could have done a little script-doctoring here. Shaft's original star, Richard Roundtree, and director Gordon Parks, have cameos, but it's a camp turn by Jeffrey Wright as a Dominican drug dealer that gives Jackson the only scenes with some spark.

Romeo Must Die
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Warner Cert 15

A high-concept concoction from action-man producer Joel Silver, but once you know the concept - "the kung-fu Romeo and Juliet" - there's not a lot to add of a film that goes in one eye and out the other. The scenes might as well have silent movie title cards: "chase scene", "fight scene" and, very occasionally, "tender moment". The only surprise, this being Shakespeare via West Side Story, is that barely a hint of the Bard Dude's romance survives, presumably out of terror that oriental lead Jet Li getting jiggy with black gang boss's daughter Aaliyah might alienate audiences. While Li is a strangely subdued presence, Aaliyah, soon to be in Silver's franchise, The Matrix 2 and 3, looks great and gives the film what little heart it has.

webTitle: Mildred Pierce review – explosive film noir with electrifying diva Joan Crawford

fields.headline: Mildred Pierce review – explosive film noir with electrifying diva Joan Crawford
fields.standfirst: For its control of narrative, its photography of the vanished suburban California of the 1940s, and for its compelling central performance from Crawford, Michael Curtiz’s noir thriller is utterly gripping
fields.trailText: For its control of narrative, its photography of the vanished suburban California of the 1940s, and for its compelling central performance from Crawford, Michael Curtiz’s noir thriller is utterly gripping
fields.body:
For its control of narrative, its photography of the vanished suburban California of the 1940s, and for its compelling central performance from Joan Crawford, Michael Curtiz's noir thriller is utterly gripping. Crawford is Mildred, whose name is enigmatically on the lips of her second husband as he is shot dead in his beach-house by an unseen murderer. Crawford and others are called in to the station house to explain and the twists and turns of the plot are disclosed in flashback, a structural device which, far from lessening its impact, deepens the story and amplifies its surprises and ambushes.

Crawford is the hardworking deserted wife who, to support her haughty young princess of a daughter, Veda (Ann Blyth), takes a demeaning job as a waitress. From there she builds her own restaurant chain and remarries into high society. She is consumed with pride, and social shame, and passionate love for a daughter incapable of returning it. An explosive combination. She slaps Veda's face, and is finally, definitively slapped in return: domestic warfare which has a greater resonance in the light of the Mommie Dearest revelations. Whether in her kitchen pinny, or fox stole, or two-piece swimsuit, Crawford is an electrifying diva presence, and her handsome face is a formal, trembling mask of passion. No wonder Crawford exerts such command over audiences young and old, gay and straight.

fields.headline: But I'm a Cheerleader
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Reasonably amusing, with 2-D acting and writing, and Day-Glo pink and blue colour schemes.
fields.body:
Director and co-writer Jamie Babbit makes her feature debut with this satire of America's creepy Christian "sexual reorientation" camps, where confused teens are sent so that their nascent gayness can be deprogrammed out of them. Natasha Lyonne plays Megan, a cheerleader who hugs her fellow pom-pom-botherers inappropriately and hates making out with her jock boyfriend. He and Megan's family arrange an "intervention" where she is confronted with her shameful tendencies and sent to the True Directions camp, run by two smug tyrants in Straight Is Great T-shirts, played by Cathy Moriarty and RuPaul (here out of drag), clearly repressed gays themselves.

Once there, Megan falls for a girl with the interesting name of Graham, played by Clea DuVall. As in all therapy boot-camp movies - such as Girl, Interrupted, in which DuVall had a role - there has to be a wild child with whom the heroine makes a connection. This is Graham's role. It's reasonably amusing, with 2-D acting and writing, and Day-Glo pink and blue colour schemes. But it could have been funnier, and I would have preferred to know more in documentary terms about the actual reality of these terrible camps, rather than sit through this heavy-handed and oddly lenient comedy.

fields.headline: Valentine
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is thankfully without the smirking, self- referential stuff popularised by Kevin Williamson, but entirely without anything scary or original either.
fields.body:
But it's too late for Valentine's Day. It's even too late for April Fool's Day. Getting this film out a couple of months ago on the correct date would at least have given it some justification. Oh well. We kick off with a junior high school prom in which the embryonic pre-teen sicko-slasher is humiliated by every girl he asks to dance and finally gets red punch poured over him in a Carrie homage/rip-off. Flash forward eight years or so and those girls have grown into hot babes who get bumped off one by one on February 14 by this person, who has naturally borne a grudge.

This run-of-the-mill slasher, directed by Jamie Blanks (Urban Legend) is notable for the presence of David Boreanz, the small screen's famous undead American of Buffy the Vampire Slayer and his own show Angel. His great leonine face always looks odd to me, but not as odd as Denise Richards's whose weirdly emaciated, sculpted features look like a cosmetic surgeon's nightmare. This is thankfully without the smirking, self- referential stuff popularised by Kevin Williamson, but entirely without anything scary or original either.

fields.headline: A Hard Day's Night
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A fascinating picture of this country in 1964, with the Beatles as our cheerfully anarchic heroes, leading us out of austerity-era Britain with its stuffiness and complacency
fields.body:
Easily the best Beatles film, directed by Richard Lester, who emerges as a neglected modern master, chucking the camera about with wonderful flair, capturing the sheer joy of the Fab Four in the springtime of their career. His direction is experimental, radical, surreal, suffused with endless invention and fun. And this film is a fascinating picture of this country in 1964, with the Beatles as our cheerfully anarchic heroes, leading us out of austerity-era Britain with its stuffiness and complacency.

The battle commences with John squaring up to a crusty old buffer in a first-class rail compartment, and continues in the bars, the parties, the TV studios. Lectured on cool by a haughty PR hack, George snaps back: "The new pose is to care passionately and be rightwing." Wilfrid Brambell gives a marvellous turn as Paul's granddad, a morose Liverpool Irish warrior who chants Fenian songs in the nick with Ringo. The songs are a treat, although we get the same ones more than once, and there is something spine-tingling to see those faces ("weirdly feminine" according to Malcolm Muggeridge, and he had a point) right close up, with their dodgy, un-American teeth.

The final concert is more Crackerjack than Shea Stadium, full of innocence, and the film ends with them scooting off to Wolverhampton by helicopter for a "midnight matinee"! What fun it must have been to make this very English guerrilla film. It's certainly fun to watch.

fields.headline: Bridget Jones's Diary
fields.standfirst: The screen Bridget may be good knockabout fun, but it lacks the devastating insights of the original, says  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Sharon Maguire's broadly enjoyable, knockabout, sitcommy picture takes the sophisticated creation of Helen Fielding and - well, doesn't dumb it down exactly, but transfers it to a medium in which much of her distinctive qualities are inevitably lost.
fields.body:
Well, here it is. The film of the book of the newspaper column of the deeply important single-women-in-their-30s zeitgeisty phenomenon. Or, to use Friends parlance, The One Where Bridget Gets Anal Sex From Hugh Grant and Likes It and Wants to Do It Again.

I am not making that last bit up. It might happen off camera, but it's one of the film's raunchier, chancier, more grubbily English things, superciliously ignored in the acres of consumer-style journalism devoted to all things Bridget in the past few weeks.

Sharon Maguire's broadly enjoyable, knockabout, sitcommy picture takes the sophisticated creation of Helen Fielding and - well, doesn't dumb it down exactly, but transfers it to a medium in which much of her distinctive qualities are inevitably lost. What we've got isn't so much postmodern Pride and Prejudice as pre-modern Mills and Boon.

Bridget, the screwed-up publishing assistant, played by the Texan Renée Zellweger, is torn between the adorably sexy cad Daniel, played by Hugh Grant, and the sullen but morally superior human rights barrister Mark Darcy - or perhaps that should be plain Mr Darcy, played by Colin Firth. Who should she choose? (The answer, frankly, is Hugh, who blows everyone else off the screen with a cracking performance as the naughtier-than-thou heartbreaker. Of this, more in a moment.)

We all know how Bridget Jones has been the template for the jokey single-gal confessionalists in fact and fiction. How Bridget famously spawned a billion imitators in books and newspapers, who get daringly drunk and are "rubbish" and "sad" about men and everything else. But really we know that they are in control by virtue of writing it up themselves, very wittily, and having a prestigious columnist job. Putting their great ancestor Bridge on the screen, however, abolishes this contract of understanding between writer and reader. When we see Bridget drink her bodyweight in chardonnay, fall over, get up and make a funny face, it isn't being filtered through her own prose.

In print, we were laughing with Bridget. On screen, well... The awful truth about this film is that it makes Bridget look like the world's biggest prat, and an egregious emotional imbecile. And the camera's glimpses of her own diary disclose not the devastatingly acute document we have come to know and love, but crass, sub-Adrian Mole, semi-literate jottings with big girly handwriting.

So Bridget has to be reimagined as a lovable, infantile clown - but once this leap has been made, Renée Zellweger's impersonation of Bridget is entertaining. She has an excellent English accent, the best since Gwyneth Paltrow's Emma. And her Jake La Motta-ish weight-gain is a thing of joy. Her cheeks have become plump, hamster-ish, pushing her mouth into a continuous, unsexy pout of anxiety and self-reproach. Her thighs are massively dimpled and her great bottom is as stately as a sinking galleon, and it's always in our face, particularly when Bridget wears a bulging Playboy bunny outfit to her mother's vicars and tarts party. It is a quintessentially English bottom which should by rights be encased in an unflattering netball skirt.

We don't get much about her mates, Shazzer and Jude - a bit of a waste of two first-class actors, Shirley Henderson and Sally Phillips (much of their stuff was presumably lost in the edit). Colin Firth reprises his smouldering act as Mr Darcy, although oddly it's Hugh who gets dripping wet this time, drunkenly falling out of the rowing boat he and Bridget have hired on a romantic weekend break. The big comic set-piece comes when Daniel and Darcy, consumed with mutual loathing, have a punch-up out in the street, and Bridget's gay friend Tom (James Callis) blunders into a restaurant queenily to announce the exciting fact: "Fight! Fight!"

As I have said, any red-blooded member of the audience will be longing for Hugh to win it. He is effortlessly the best thing in the film. His Daniel is, as they say, Not Safe In Taxis or anywhere else. There is nothing floppy or limp about his hair here; it is flowing and Byronically sensual. Daniel is mad, bad, dangerous and extremely funny to know. And he's much more interesting than dull old Darcy or indeed silly old Bridget. What a pair they are. A stuffy bore and an emotionally needy, not-very-talented person whose one professional success, as a television presenter, is the gift of Darcy in the first place.

Richard Curtis's London, swirling with picturesque snow, is that weird imaginary place, that ersatz London-from-another-planet we saw in Notting Hill. It's an unreal London where barristers can smash up restaurants without getting into trouble with the police or the Bar Council. It's a virtual-reality zone where Bridget organises a publishing party attended by Salman Rushdie and other self-conscious literary celebs playing wooden cameos of themselves - a very uncertain moment, in which the film appears to be absorbing its own status as a media event.

But this is a strong debut from former documentary-maker Sharon Maguire, who directs with chutzpah and style. Richard Curtis's script (taken from original drafts by Helen Fielding and Andrew Davies) may not be as sharp as Four Weddings or Notting Hill, but it has its moments, including a tremendous gag about, of all people, FR Leavis. It reminded me of Leavis's comment about Edith Sitwell: she belongs to the history of publicity, not literature. The same could be said of that one-woman hype sensation Bridget Jones. But what a monumental place in the history of publicity she has.

fields.headline: Spy Kids
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A festival of weirdo computer-generated creatures, gadgets and gizmos, underwater pods, nifty manoeuvrable little aircraft and electroshock bubblegum, and all of it has plenty of zappy cartoonish energy.
fields.body:
It's a bit of a surprise that this very funny and charming movie - notably replete with family values - comes from Robert Rodriguez, the man who brought us, for example, the yucky From Dusk Till Dawn, with its vampires playing guitars fashioned out of corpses, and the bullet-riddled Desperado. Spy Kids is set in an indeterminate Latin American location and stars Antonio Banderas sporting a rakish fake moustache and Carla Gugino as his wife: a couple of glamorous international spies (though in the service of what country or ideology we are never told) who have retired to raise a family.

Or have they? Their kids Carmen (Alexa Vega) and Juni (Daryl Sabara) suspect that dull old mom and dad might be cooler than they thought; way cool in fact, when they get caught up in their spy mission against the villainous Fegan Floop (Alan Cumming) and Mr Lisp (Robert Patrick), who have a plan for global domination. fields.bodyText: It's a bit of a surprise that this very funny and charming movie - notably replete with family values - comes from Robert Rodriguez, the man who brought us, for example, the yucky From Dusk Till Dawn, with its vampires playing guitars fashioned out of corpses, and the bullet-riddled Desperado. Spy Kids is set in an indeterminate Latin American location and stars Antonio Banderas sporting a rakish fake moustache and Carla Gugino as his wife: a couple of glamorous international spies (though in the service of what country or ideology we are never told) who have retired to raise a family. fields.headline: Pedro Depestre Gonzalez
fields.standfirst: Leading Cuban violinist on the cusp of international stardom
fields.trailText: Leading Cuban violinist on the cusp of international stardom.
fields.body:
Pedro Depestre Gonzalez, who has died suddenly at the age of 55, was one of the greatest violinists of the Cuban music scene. Long established as a musical celebrity in Havana, he seemed on the point of winning a much larger following in Europe, when he collapsed during a concert in Basel, Switzerland this week. Performing in Cachaito Lopez's band, on the first night of their current European tour, Pedro Depestre (as he was best known) had just played what was generally agreed to have been an "incredible" violin solo.

While other Cuban musicians, many much older than Depestre, have become celebrities in the West in recent years, thanks to the success of the Buena Vista Social Club album, and the various off-shoot albums and tours that have followed, he had until recently retained a low profile outside Cuba, despite his fame back home. He had performed on solo albums by two of the Buena Vista stars, Ibrahim Ferrer and Omara Portuondo, but never took part in any of the Buena Vista touring bands. His real breakthrough outside Cuba came with his appearance on Cachaito, the widely praised debut album from the Buena Vista bass player, Orlando Cachaito Lopez, which was released earlier this month.

While the best-selling Buena Vista album had revived earlier Cuban musical styles with he help of the now elderly Cuban musicians who had pioneered them, the Cachaito album was something different: a highly atmospheric, experimental, instrumental set, in which echoes of Cuban dance music were mixed with Jamaican dub reggae, jazz, and DJ styles. Wildly experimental, it sounded at times like the sound-track to some imaginary film and included contributions from the likes of Hugh Masekela, the great South African trumpeter, to Pee Wee Ellis, the American saxophonist. Depestre played an important role in the project, matching Cachaito's daring and rhythmic bass work with his moody, drifting and experimental solos.

Regarded as a musical celebrity since he was a teenager, Depestre started playing violin at the age of five, and by the time he was 13 was invited to join one of the great Cuban bands, Orquesta Aragon, with whom he stayed for three or four years. Founded more than 60 years ago, and still continuing today, this is a band known for its mixture of modern and traditional Cuban styles, making use of flute, violin, but no brass section. Started up by Orestes Aragon, it was later taken over by Rafael Lay (father of the current Aragon bandleader) who was Depestre's godfather.

Later, Depestre moved on to become the director of the Maravillas de Florida and the Orquesta Tipica De Juventud (Santiago de Cuba). He also worked as a music producer for the Cuban Radio and Television Orchestra, and for Egrem, the state-run studios that recorded and released scores of records by Cuban musicians.

In 1979, he took part in the celebrated Estrellas de Areito recordings at Egrem, in which a whole variety of different Cuban musicians from four generations came together for a series of sessions that in many ways were a forerunner of the Buena Vista project. The pianist Ruben Gonzalez (a major star since the Buena Vista Social Club) was one of those taking part, and, like him, Pedro Depestre was given a then rare opportunity to stretch out and record some of his finest solos. He later went on to become director and orchestrator of the violins, as well as first violinist, at Havana's famous Tropicana Club.

After all the years in which he had never left Cuba, it was sadly ironic that Depestre should die after playing at the start of a tour that would surely have helped to establish him as a major star in the west, and would provide further proof that contemporary Cuban music is capable of far more than revivalism.

His death at such a young age (certainly compared with other members of the Buena Vista project and its other highly successful offshoots) is a sad loss to the Cuban music scene at a time when he was proving so triumphantly that Cuban music can be experimental as well as revivalist.

The Cachaito tour is continuing without him "in honour and respect of Deprestre's music", and the remaining members of the band will be performing at the Royal Festival Hall, London, tomorrow.

 Pedro Depestre Gonzalez, musician, born June 1945 died April 8 2001
