fields.headline: May Day protests face 'zero tolerance'
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Anti-capitalist demonstrators who break the law during the May Day protests will face a "zero tolerance, in your face" approach from police, who are determined to avoid last year's chaotic scenes in Westminster, Scotland Yard said yesterday.
fields.body:
Anti-capitalist demonstrators who break the law during the May Day protests will face a "zero tolerance, in your face" approach from police, who are determined to avoid last year's chaotic scenes in Westminster, Scotland Yard said yesterday.

Senior officers estimate that a core of 1,000 demonstrators from all over the country are intending to cause trouble, and that their strategy will involve injuring police officers and damaging up to 200 businesses and banks, with a focus on Oxford Street.

Rather than standing back to see if trouble starts, officers will be briefed to act immediately, police said.

"It will be a more robust approach this year," said Mike Todd, a Metropolitan police assistant commissioner."We will be very, very positive."

The change of tactics reflects the frustration of Sir John Stevens, the Met commissioner, and the home secretary, Jack Straw, that demonstrators managed to daub graffiti on the Cenotaph, deface a statue of Winston Churchill and dig up the grass in Parliament Square during last year's protests.

After last year's protests Tony Blair declared that such behaviour must never happen again. Sir John is known to have been involved in reformulating the Met's strategy, and has decided to run the risk that a more aggressive approach could lead to claims of stifling peaceful protest and inciting violence.

The civil rights group Liberty said yesterday that an aggressive stance could encourage overreaction from officers.

"We don't have a problem with the police preventing criminality," said a spokesman. "But we would be concerned if zero tolerance in any way curbed the right to peaceful protest. That is a real danger."

A series of demonstrations are planned on Tuesday May 1, entirely separate from the official TUC May Day march.

Police believe that around 5,000 people will come to the capital to take part in unofficial events scheduled to start at 7.30am with a cycle ride to Kings Cross station, culminating in a gathering in Oxford Street at 4pm.

"Our intelligence suggests that this could be the main flashpoint," said Mr Todd. "We don't want to prevent lawful protest. It's a basic right and we police demonstrations all the time. But we are not going to allow people to commit criminal offences.

"There will be a zero tolerance of criminality. If you allow a certain amount of it, then it will escalate. We are going to do all we can to ensure that people working, living and shopping in London are safe. We don't want London closed."

Mr Todd admitted that the ringleaders of last year's trouble had not been caught - even though more than 100 people were arrested - and said it had been difficult to gather intelligence on those planning this year's protests.

A website and a glossy pamphlet produced to support anti-capitalist action on May 1 invite protesters to play "May Day Monopoly", using the format of the board game to tell people where to go in London. Under headings such as Park Lane, Bond Street and Mayfair, they describe buildings, companies and banks that are legitimate targets for demonstration. It also offers "Don't Go to Jail" advice.

The pamphlet says: "So you want to change the world? Fight the forces of globalising darkness? Not a bad ambition, but you'll need help. Activism, like playing Monopoly or having sex, can be a bit embarrassing if you do it alone. If you are going to play May Day Monopoly, you best do it with people you like and trust. It should be the start of an ongoing career of activism, agitation and generally making a nuisance of yourself."

fields.headline: Sunshine swagger
fields.standfirst: Robbie does his bit for Bridget Jones and Ian Dury, yet another Spice goes solo and India.Arie comes out of the coffee shop in the week's pop albums
fields.trailText: Robbie does his bit for Bridget Jones and Ian Dury, yet another Spice goes solo and India.Arie comes out of the coffee shop in the week's pop albums
fields.byline: Reviews by Michael Odell, Alexis Petridis, Caroline Sullivan, John Aizlewood, Robin Denselow and Adam Sweeting
fields.body:
India.Arie Acoustic Soul
(Motown) ****
£14.99

India.Arie is pictured on the back with dreadlocks flailing over her shoulder in the sun. That captures the album perfectly. Acoustic Soul is rooted in the natural, with Denver-born Arie following the path recently beaten by label-mate Erykah Badu. The single Video is the manifesto: a swaggering, witty attack on her big-city R&B cousins fixated by "bling bling" and the music biz in general. "Keep your Cristal and your pistol," she opines in a resonant, oaky voice, before sniggering: "Keep your silicon, I like my own." And to prove the country girl with the guitar can match her 'hood-dwelling sistas for erotica, Brown Skin seethes with desire, especially when offering "Hershey kisses to your liquorice". Arie doesn't shun hip-hop's innovations altogether: I See God in You and Simple are expert appropriations of rap's beat science. Like Badu, Jill Scott and other nu-soul practitioners, Arie brings the focused power of a songsmith who served her apprenticeship in a coffee shop before the call came from a music-biz suit. The last time Motown signed anyone as good as this, Berry Gordy did the paperwork. (MO)

The Avalanches Since I Left You
(XL) ****
£11.99

There's a hint of the Little Englander about British clubbers. They believe our DJs, clubs and dance producers are the world's finest. Americans invented house, techno and garage, yet British DJs claim to "educate" American audiences. In reality, foreign dance producers lead the way: Parisians Daft Punk redefined house; Dutch and German trance dominates the charts. Now it's Australia's turn: the debut of Melbourne sextet the Avalanches is the freshest dance album in years. Despite a painstaking construction process - it's essentially hundreds of samples stitched together, the crackle of ancient records audible throughout - Since I Left You's breakbeat funk sounds deliciously breezy and sunkissed. Tracks come laden with pop hooks, dancefloor nous and a cheery disinterest in borrowing from fashionable sources. Stay Another Season pinches its bassline from Madonna's Holiday, but Close to You is powered by steals from 1980s monstrosities Kid Creole and the Coconuts. Both work perfectly, as does the rest of this glorious, varied album. British producers should take notes. (AP)

Various Artists Bridget Jones's Diary OST
(Mercury) ***
£14.99

Put out a call for soundtrack material for a high-profile Britflick and watch big pop names come flocking with new songs. Robbie Williams, Geri Halliwell, Gabrielle and Sheryl Crow recorded tracks exclusively for this album. (The other tunes, such as Aretha Franklin's Respect, are predictable romantic-comedy spacefillers.) Backed by a big band, the Robster bravely attacks the Rodgers and Hart standard Have You Met Miss Jones?, leering as trumpets swell climactically. If he stuck with it, there would be no more need for Harry Connick Jr. The other Williams contribution, Not of This Earth, is arguably the worst song of his career. Halliwell's cover of the Weather Girls's unsurpassable It's Raining Men bubbles with campness, which is as nothing against the fact that she can't sing. Undoubtedly this is all more amusing accompanied by images of Bridget reeling with the horror of having soared to nine stone. (CS)

Emma Bunton A Girl Like Me
(Virgin) **
£14.99

Where's the law that says every Spice Girl has to make a solo album? This debut from Normal Spice might be passably interesting if Emma Bunton weren't so bent on being Miss Low Expectations. But even the song titles - Take My Breath Away, High on Love - are quintessentially average. One doesn't expect her to bleed for her art, but is a bit of pluck too much to ask? Bunton's girlishly mediocre voice is poorly served by a dozen flavourless McSongs, written by the expensive likes of Rodney Jerkins, producer of the last Spice LP. The Edie Brickell cover What I Am reached number two in 1999. That's all you need to know. (CS)

Various Artists Brand New Boots and Panties
(east central one records) ****
£13.99

Ian Dury was one of the finest lyricists that British pop has ever produced. It's nearly a quarter of a century now since he and the Blockheads recorded their classic debut, New Boots and Panties, and this reworking of the album shows just how triumphantly the songs have survived. There are few love songs quite as cheerfully explicit as Wake Up and Make Love With Me, bravely tackled here by Sinead O'Connor, but without Dury's sense of wicked, sexual delight. And there are few parental tributes quite as jolly, tender, and sad as My Old Man, finely performed here by Madness, who manage to keep all those different emotions in play. His gentle, then suddenly frantic tribute to Sweet Gene Vincent is covered here by the laddish Robbie Williams. Essex boy Billy Bragg may have been the obvious choice to retell the sexual adventures of Billericay Dickie, but there's an unexpected musical twist, as his band, the Blokes, bring the song a new eastern flavour. Dury's own old band, the Blockheads, provide the backing for the majority of these songs and remain in fine and funky form. A great album: check it out, and then go back and listen to the original. (RD)

Lupine Howl The Carnivorous Lunar Activities of Lupine Howl
(Vinyl Hiss) **
£11.99

Following their dismissal from Spiritualized, bassist Sean Cook, guitarist Mike Mooney and on-off drummer Damon Reece became Lupine Howl. Their only musical connection with Spiritualized is a ceaselessly narcotic air. Mostly they take the blue-collar, blues-rock feel of Reef and add a few Pierce-style effects. That it doesn't quite work is not wholly down to their vaulting ambition, nor a drug-obsessed lyrical slackness that would have done the Cult proud. It's more a result of Lupine Howl being essentially backing musicians on whom the spotlight does not shine especially kindly, despite Mooney's always inventive way with the guitar. Even the better songs, such as the wrigglesome Sometimes and the almost symphonic Planet X, fall down when Cook begins to sing. A shame, but some things are just not meant to be. (JA)

Syd Barrett Wouldn't You Miss Me? The Best Of
(EMI/Harvest) **
£14.99

Syd Barrett is the archetype of unhinged English psychedelia, the man whose freakish imagination launched Pink Floyd's early success before he went famously bonkers. This 22-track compilation has been assembled from Barrett's solo albums, The Madcap Laughs and Barrett, with a scattering from the "rarities" album, Opel. Completists will wriggle with delight at the inclusion of the long-lost Bob Dylan Blues, which sounds like Donovan. Unfortunately, minus Syd's Floydian classics, See Emily Play and Arnold Layne, Barrett-world is a perplexing shambles of nonsense verse, buskerish acoustic guitars and berserk multitrack vocals, where no two chords fit together and songs never end, merely stop. Perhaps you had to be there. (AS)

webTitle: On the edge CD of the week: Bill Frisell: Blues Dream

fields.headline: Such a perfect day
fields.standfirst: Bill Frisell has humour, nostalgia, melancholy and wonderful musicianship. It doesn't get much better than this, says  John L Walters
fields.trailText: Bill Frisell has humour, nostalgia, melancholy and wonderful musicianship. It doesn't get much better than this, says John L Walters
fields.body:
Bill Frisell Blues Dream
(Nonesuch) ****
£14.00

Sun is streaming in through the window on a fine spring morning, the papers have just been delivered, fresh coffee is brewing and there's a new Bill Frisell album on the CD player. It doesn't get much better than this. Frisell is a wonderfully talented and skilled jazz guitarist, but his appeal goes deeper and wider than mere jazz brilliance. His tone infiltrates the environment and catches your ear; it's a sound that can contain good humour, or melancholy, or nostalgia, yet still be utterly fresh and un-cliched, and it's unquestionably an adult taste: complex, rich, full of layers. Even when he plays the simplest of tunes, such as Pretty Flowers Were Made for Blooming or Where Do We Go?, the touch and timbre adds a dimension of experience and authority that few musicians deliver with such consistency.

Blues Dream is a suite of pieces for seven-piece band originally commissioned for the unerringly hip Walker Art Centre in Minneapolis. Most of the musicians have played with Frisell at different times in his career, but it's the first time he's used this particular line-up. The back line comprises double bassist David Piltch and Sex Mob drummer Kenny Wollesen (who accompanied Frisell in his recent UK appearance during the London Jazz Festival). At the front is steel guitarist Greg Leisz plus three horns: trumpeter Ron Miles, trombonist Curtis Fowlkes (who both played on Frisell's innovative Quartet album) and saxophonist Billy Drewes. The reunion element give Blues Dream a slight feeling of a retrospective, though the material is all new, and all Frisell's. There's a hint of his witty and empathetic music for silent Buster Keaton comedies such as The High Sign and Go West, which used his trio with Kermit Driscoll and drummer Joey Baron to such good effect. Wollesen has something of Baron's hyperactive attention to detail, but on numbers such as Where Do We Go? and Outlaws he and Piltch seem just as happy generating a groove so spacious you could drive a pick-up truck between its snare beats.

Frisell's way of voicing the front line is as unconventional and logical as his guitar playing - so odd and off-kilter that you couldn't imagine it any other way. Listen to the opening of Greg Leisz (Frisell, like Miles Davis and Carla Bley, has a habit of giving songs the names of real people, from Jimmy Carter to Ron Carter). The horns blend in a kind of Mingus-meets-Stax manner that means you can hear individual sounds quite clearly within a blurry ensemble.

Ron Miles, a distinctive trumpet player who has made a couple of strong albums under his own name, takes the lead in the two versions of the title track and the horns-only Fifty Years. Jazz Passenger Fowlkes shines in Soul Merchant and Drewes wails decoratively on Pretty Flowers. Leisz is a strong foil for Frisell, soaring like an eagle on Pretty Stars Were Made to Shine and diving back to country earth for Slow Dance and the big-boned Where Do We Go?.

Sometimes the ensemble achieves a kind of orchestral grandeur, reminiscent of the line-up that had such fun and games with Ives, Copland and Dylan on Frisell's album Have a Little Faith. And at other times they settle down to play the blues, as on Things Will Never Be the Same. In case things get a little too normal, Frisell can always be relied upon to weird things up again by throwing in a few guitar loops - atonal, asynchronous and completely A-OK.

fields.headline: King of the keyboard
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  hails Pletnev's genius, plus other new classical releases
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements hails Pletnev's genius, plus other new classical releases
fields.body:
Mikhail Pletnev: Live at Carnegie Hall
(Deutsche Grammophon, 2 CDs) *****
£13.99

For a pianist of Pletnev's proven quality, his debut recital at Carnegie Hall last November was rather overdue. But as this electrifying live recording proves, he certainly made sure that the New York audience realised what they had been missing, with playing of inexorable power and lyrical poise.

The published programme takes up the first of the two discs - Busoni's arrangement of the Chaconne from Bach's D minor violin Partita, Beethoven's C minor Piano Sonata Op 111, and the four Chopin Scherzos. The second (included as a free extra) takes care of the five encores: there is a Scriabin poem, a Scarlatti sonata, one each of Rachmaninov's Etudes Tableaux and Moskowski's studies, while an incandescent account of Balakirev's Islamey, one of the most technically demanding works in the piano repertory, really brings the house down right at the end.

Some of the same works were included in Pletnev's London recital at the Barbican three weeks after this recording was made: that was glorious enough, but the playing here, especially in the Chopin Scherzos, seems even finer, and more dramatically focused. The Bach/Busoni and Beethoven (both missing from the London programme) are totally absorbing. The Chaconne is wonderfully athletic, full of glinting sonorities, while Op 111 is a study in contrasts, between sharply honed dramatic impulsion and almost motionless textural exploration. Everything seems freshly thought, and even when the ideas do not quite gel - some of the variations in the finale are rather brutally juxtaposed, though the trills of the coda are breathtaking - they are provoking, and genuinely inspired.

In the Scherzos, though, not a single note is misplaced. Pletnev has such sovereign command of the keyboard that the technical challenges hold no terrors for him, and he has such an instinctive grasp of the musical architecture that even when he takes off on discursive explorations of what are really incidental details, his sense of shape and purpose never falters. He makes the listener hang on his every phrase, for the sheer delight of what he will do with it, in the full knowledge that all the threads will be tied together in the blistering codas that end each piece. It is fabulous piano playing.

Hartmann: String Quartet No 1; Bartok: String Quartet No 4 Zehetmair Quartet
(ECM) ****
£14.99

Founded only a few years ago, the Zehetmair quartet, led by the outstanding violinist Thomas Zehetmair, is already among the finest ensembles around. They boast technical confidence, expressive freedom and a complete understanding of each work's idiom. Amadeus Hartmann's First Quartet (1933) is the rarity here - dark and brooding, and clearly indebted to Bartok. The performance is so persuasive that it is a shame it is not coupled with his Second, completed after the second world war. While the Bartok playing here is equally masterly, there are already several other equally fine CD versions of the Fourth Quartet, but few of Hartmann's Second.

Bruckner: Symphony No 8 Berlin Philharmonic/ Harnoncourt
(Teldec, 2 CDs) ****
£14.99

Nikolaus Harnoncourt's fourth Bruckner disc (after the Third and Fourth Symphonies with the Royal Concertgebouw and the Seventh with the Vienna Philharmonic) was recorded live in Berlin and is as magnificent as its predecessors. It is still hard to pin down exactly what kind of Bruckner conductor he is - certainly not one of the monumental school, who conceives each symphony in stark tectonic blocks, nor quite one of the great interventionists, moulding every phrase with self-conscious expressiveness. That is not to imply that his approach neglects the longer-range issues in the Eighth - on the contrary, his command of the structural processes is totally convincing - nor that he is insensitive to the smaller-scale issues. Rather, he conceives the music as an organic whole, with each great paragraph emerging naturally from its predecessor.

Boccherini: String Quintets Europa Galante
(Virgin) ***
£14.99

Unlike his younger contemporary, Mozart, Boccherini wrote string quintets for a group including two cellos rather than two violas - the combination adopted by Schubert for his great C major Quintet almost half a century later. The three works here from his Op 25 (nos 1, 4 and 6), stylishly and persuasively played by the violinist Fabio Bondi and members of his period-instrument ensemble Europa Galante, were composed in the 1770s, when Boccherini was court composer to the Spanish Infante, son of Charles III. Sometimes the group paint the expressive glosses just a little too thickly, with a hint of mannerism, but by and large it is easy to enjoy and easy to admire.

Bach: Easter Oratorio; Magnificat Gabriel Consort & Players/McCreesh Archiv 469 531-2
***
£14.99

These performances of Bach's Easter Oratorio and Magnificat make no attempt at historical reconstruction, or to place the works in a liturgical context. They are "studio" interpretations, recorded in a baroque church in Saxony, whose fine-sounding organ makes its presence felt in the cantata-like oratorio. Allotting one voice to a part in the choruses, Paul McCreesh is vividly extrovert, never meekly devotional; he has a fine team of singers, with the tenor Paul Agnew's contributions to the Easter Oratorio especially noteworthy, and his tempi vary from the wonderingly gentle to the brassily assertive. The Magnificat sets off at a tremendous pace that is not quite sustained, though there are some gloriously effective moments.

fields.headline: The shape of things to come
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements on a near-masterpiece that created Sibelius's unique voice
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements on a near-masterpiece that created Sibelius's unique voice
fields.body:
Sibelius: Kullervo
Paasikivi/Laukka/Helsinki University Chorus/Lahti Symphony/Vanska
(BIS) *****
£12.99

It is hard to believe that it is only 25 years since the very first recording of Sibelius's Kullervo appeared on record. That account, conducted by Paavo Berglund, still stands up well against its subsequent rivals, and revealed the glories of this early work, first performed in 1892. In his first large-scale orchestral score, Sibelius discharged his debts to Wagner and prepared the ground for the numbered series of symphonies that were to follow, taking him on a unique creative path.

Though Sibelius never publicly disowned the work in his later life, and even made arrangements of some sections of it for special occasions, he certainly did not go out of his way to encourage performances, and it was not until after his death in 1957 that the work began to be heard again. The first performance in the 20th century took place nine months after the composer's death, and began the process of rehabilitation; there are now nine recorded versions of Kullervo, and certainly a complete cycle of the Sibelius symphonies is unthinkable without it. Now Osmo Vanska crowns what is the finest versions of the symphonies in our time with an equally definitive account of this fascinating near-masterpiece.

Whether or not Kullervo should be classified as a symphony at all is another matter: at the time of the premiere it was called a "symphonic poem for soloists, chorus and orchestra", though the score itself contains no label at all, and the composer certainly referred to it as a symphony, despite the programmatic titles of each of the five movements, the vividly dramatic choral contributions and the great scena for the mezzo-soprano and baritone soloists that form the central panel. In the genealogy of Sibelius's development, though, it occupies a crucial position. Not only do its formal planning and tightly woven motivic development find their continuation in the architectural coherence of the symphonies, but its programmatic basis in episodes from the Kalevala, the Finnish national epic, led directly to the great series of tone poems, beginning with En Saga two years later, inspired by further episodes from this bundle of legends.

But there is one musical seed in Kullervo that was never developed significantly further. The great central confrontation between Kullervo and his sister, with whom he had an incestuous relationship, is unmistakably operatic, and shows how completely Sibelius had taken on board what he had learnt from Wagner, but other than the unsatisfactory one-acter The Maiden in the Tower, written in 1896, Sibelius never wrote a stage work. His instincts took him in a different direction altogether, and the only glimmering of what he might have achieved in his maturity come in the neglected work for soprano and orchestra Luonnotar, which is an operatic scena in all but name.

Vanska's performance comprehends all those facets of the work more completely than any other conductor so far. His choice of tempi is sometimes dangerously extreme, especially in the leisurely way he presents the second movement, the purely orchestral Kullervo's Youth, but the quality of the Lahti Symphony Orchestra, who play marvellously for him throughout, is such that it never seems strained. The spaciousness of the introductory Allegro has already defined the scale of what is to follow, and Vanska makes sure that every element of the scheme is crisply defined. The only music that is specifically narrative, the big set-piece scena, has a tingling sense of drama, and the two soloists, Lilli Paasikivi and Raimo Lukka, are not allowed to miss a single inflection in their contributions.

From that point on, the tragic trajectory of the work is unstoppable. The fourth movement, Kullervo goes to War, is muscularly martial, and the finale, Kullervo's Death, is at the same time unstintingly doom-laden and uniquely affirmative. Whether it is a symphony or not, Vanska brings the work full circle, as the opening theme is quoted again with total symphonic conviction.

fields.headline: On the Edge releases
fields.trailText: Bill Bruford's Earthworks: The Sound of Surprise | WDR Big Band Cologne/Lalo Schifrin: Esperanto
fields.body:
Bill Bruford's Earthworks The Sound of Surprise
(Discipline Global Mobile) ****

This is a lively, hugely competent and entertaining set of jazz originals by drummer/ band leader Bruford and his three younger sidekicks. No surprise there, then. In fact they produce a style of British acoustic jazz that's been around for decades, based on fleet, intricate arrangements (either by Bruford alone or in collaboration with the band's pianist Steve Hamilton) that stretch themselves comfortably over swinging grooves, spaced out cadenzas and tricky unisons. Double bass player Mark Hodgson comes across well in the crystal-clear mix: he and Bruford obviously enjoy the car-chase thrills of fast-time playing and know the charts well enough to switch into new sections at a moment's notice. Saxophonist Patrick Clahar has a muscular, Wayne Shorter-ish approach to his front-line tunes and solos (on tenor and soprano) and Hamilton gets plenty of solo space. Yet you can still tell it's a drummer's band - it feels as if Bruford is urging his players to do more, to play more, to take it somewhere else, and I guess we'll have to see them live to see how far they can go. Bruford also upholds the British jazz tradition of terrible punning titles, opening the set with the otherwise fairly cool Revel Without a Pause.

I was also delighted to read the fine print on the label, which runs as follows: "The phonographic copyright in these performances is operated by Discipline Global Mobile on behalf of the artists, with whom it resides, contrary to common practice in the record industry. Discipline Global Mobile accepts no reason for artists to assign the copyright interest in their work to either record company or management by virtue of a 'common practice' which was always questionable, often improper, and is now indefensible." The significant thing about this little rant, apart from its obvious parentage in the mind of guitarist and DGM founder Robert Fripp, is that it makes an entirely sensible claim for copyrights - songs and tunes - to remain with their creators rather than treating such rights as flexible assets that can be traded like Pokémon cards.

DGM's discs have carried this line for a while, an environmentally sound approach in which the business of creativity is seen as a matter of stewardship rather than ownership, but it will be a while before the major media companies catch up with them.

WDR Big Band Cologne/Lalo Schifrin Esperanto
(Aleph Records) ****
£12.99

Even if you're the sort of cool dude for whom the words "radio big band" send unpleasant chills down your spine, you shouldn't dismiss this full-blooded six-part suite by the Argentinian-born composer still best known for the Mission Impossible theme. For a start, the Cologne-based band actually sounds like a real band - they can swing and play all the notes with complete conviction. And thanks to the WDR radio station's adventurous policy of inviting performers and composers for special projects, they have no trouble playing with all manner of individualistic guest musicians. For this disc, on Schifrin's own Aleph label, the basic big band line-up of brass, saxes and rhythm section is augmented by tuba, French Horns (four) and lashings of extra drums and percussion including Gregory Hutchinson, Trilok Gurtu and Sydney Thiam. Schifrin's aim to have soloists from five continents is achieved with the inclusion of US Blue Note star Don Byron (clarinet), James Morrison (trumpet and trombone) from Australia, local boy Simon Stockhausen on saxophone and synthesizer, Zappa alumnus Jean-Luc Ponty on violin and the Argentinian bandoneon player Nestor Marconi.

Fans of Schifrin's soundtrack work (such as Dirty Harry, Bullitt and Carlos Saura's Tango) will find plenty to keep them happy, with crisp syncopated ensembles, sizzling brass and flutes, recorded with occasional roughness that reminds us it's all live. But whereas the movie scores are notated, Esperanto demonstrates Schifrin's jazz composer chops. He writes strong ensemble tunes and backgrounds designed to inspire equally melodic responses from his soloists, and makes structures that leave space for improvisation.

The title may imply a Utopian quest for a universal language of music, but this is very much an orchestral jazz album, with a striking dramatic flair on tunes such as Resonances and Tango Borealis, and an exuberant mastery of timbre, rhythm and melody reminiscent of his near-contemporary Joe Zawinul. Marconi's elegant and eloquent bandoneon playing is a consistent delight, and everyone sounds as if they're having a good time: evidence that you can write more than 120 movie scores and still come out smiling.

And thanks to the WDR radio station's adventurous policy of inviting performers and composers for special projects, they have no trouble playing with all manner of individualistic guest musicians. For this disc, on Schifrin's own Aleph label, the basic big band line-up of brass, saxes and rhythm section is augmented by tuba, French Horns (four) and lashings of extra drums and percussion including Gregory Hutchinson, Trilok Gurtu and Sydney Thiam. Schifrin's aim to have soloists from five continents is achieved with the inclusion of US Blue Note star Don Byron (clarinet), James Morrison (trumpet and trombone) from Australia, local boy Simon Stockhausen on saxophone and synthesizer, Zappa alumnus Jean-Luc Ponty on violin and the Argentinian bandoneon player Nestor Marconi. Fans of Schifrin's soundtrack work (such as Dirty Harry, Bullitt and Carlos Saura's Tango) will find plenty to keep them happy, with crisp syncopated ensembles, sizzling brass and flutes, recorded with occasional roughness that reminds us it's all live. But whereas the movie scores are notated, Esperanto demonstrates Schifrin's jazz composer chops. He writes strong ensemble tunes and backgrounds designed to inspire equally melodic responses from his soloists, and makes structures that leave space for improvisation. The title may imply a Utopian quest for a universal language of music, but this is very much an orchestral jazz album, with a striking dramatic flair on tunes such as Resonances and Tango Borealis, and an exuberant mastery of timbre, rhythm and melody reminiscent of his near-contemporary Joe Zawinul. Marconi's elegant and eloquent bandoneon playing is a consistent delight, and everyone sounds as if they're having a good time: evidence that you can write more than 120 movie scores and still come out smiling.

fields.headline: Spaced odyssey
fields.standfirst: Rob Mackie  on a loopy triumph for the Coens, and the rest of the week's releases
fields.trailText: Rob Mackie on a loopy triumph for the Coens, and the rest of the week's releases
fields.body:
O Brother, Where Art Thou?
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Momentum, cert 12
****

Film number eight from the remarkable Coen brothers, who have yet to release anything not stamped with their inimitably skewed sensibility. By recent standards, it's not quite top-ranking: it doesn't have the coherence and firm morality of Fargo or the loopy hilarity of The Big Lebowski. But, as ever, it has much to recommend it: some top verbal curlicues, handed to George Clooney, who's clearly having a ball; a very relaxed and highly unpredictable narrative; and, not least, a treasure trove of cherishable 30s "old-timey music" (blues, gospel and bluegrass) put together with loving care by T-Bone Burnett.

The typically rambling tale is described by Joel Coen on one of the DVD interviews as combining "the Three Stooges with Homer's Odyssey". So you have sirens, a cyclops (a one-eyed John Goodman) and a quest for our hero, Ulysses.

In this case, it's Ulysses Everett McGill (Clooney), a vain and verbose philosophical convict who has escaped from a chain gang. The Three Stooges part comes in the shape of the two dimwits he has tricked into escaping with him (dumb and dumber sidekicks are a Coen tradition, and they get more laughs from it than the Farrellys).

But lots more references are thrown into the pot in this hot, dusty, mythical old south: there's a chain gang to remind you that the title comes from the film the director in Sullivan's Travels never made; a black guitarist who has sold his soul to the devil at the crossroads (here called Tommy Johnson, not Robert); and exuberant bank robber George "Baby Face" Nelson. It's goofy fun, a family film at heart but with a few stunning set-pieces: the spectacularly choreographed Klan meeting and a brilliantly realised flood stay in the memory, along with Clooney clowning at the mike in a ZZ Top beard.

Shaft
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Paramount Cert 18
***

Isaac Hayes's symphony of wah-wah and high-hat is still the only contemporary classic to win an Oscar for best song and, in lightly updated form, is still the most memorable part of this revival of the pioneering black hero. The mighty Hayes, with his deep bass rumble and relaxed acting style, would have made a perfect Shaft himself in the 1971 original, but you couldn't do much better now than Sam "The Man" Jackson in the title role and John "Boyz 'n the Hood" Singleton as director. Ultimately, it's just serviceable, though: Jackson is the hard case on a hard case, trying to find and then protect the only witness to a murder by racist rich boy Christian Bale. There are more MFs in the script than at an Oedipus Appreciation Society meeting, but what we want is a bit of wit and humour for Jackson to savour. Yet three scriptwriters come up with only one line that fits slippery Sam: "It's my duty to please that booty," he purrs coolly to a soulful barmaid. Jackson's Pulp Fiction role for the blaxploitation-fixated Tarantino played a big part in making this project commercially viable, but you wish Quentin could have done a little script-doctoring here. Shaft's original star, Richard Roundtree, and director Gordon Parks, have cameos, but it's a camp turn by Jeffrey Wright as a Dominican drug dealer that gives Jackson the only scenes with some spark.

Romeo Must Die
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Warner Cert 15
**

A high-concept concoction from action-man producer Joel Silver, but once you know the concept - "the kung-fu Romeo and Juliet" - there's not a lot to add of a film that goes in one eye and out the other. The scenes might as well have silent movie title cards: "chase scene", "fight scene" and, very occasionally, "tender moment". The only surprise, this being Shakespeare via West Side Story, is that barely a hint of the Bard Dude's romance survives, presumably out of terror that oriental lead Jet Li getting jiggy with black gang boss's daughter Aaliyah might alienate audiences. While Li is a strangely subdued presence, Aaliyah, soon to be in Silver's franchise, The Matrix 2 and 3, looks great and gives the film what little heart it has.

webTitle: Cincinnati mayor declares curfew after second night of rioting

fields.headline: Cincinnati mayor declares curfew after second night of rioting
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: Mark Twain said that he would choose to spend the Apocalypse in Cincinnati, because everything there seemed to happen 20 or 30 years later than in other places.
fields.body:
Mark Twain said that he would choose to spend the Apocalypse in Cincinnati, because everything there seemed to happen 20 or 30 years later than in other places.

Last night hundreds of police officers were patrolling the city's empty streets as they struggled to bring an end to some of America's worst urban rioting for a generation.

A state of emergency was declared yesterday and the authorities imposed a city-wide curfew after two nights of full-scale rioting followed a police shooting of an unarmed black suspect.

There have been 66 arrests so far. "The violence on our streets is uncontrolled and it runs rampant," the mayor, Charles Luken, said.

"The time has come to deal with this seriously."

The curfew would begin at 8pm (midnight GMT) last night and remain in force until 6am, he said. He and the Ohio state governor, Bob Taft, were discussing whether to bring in the national guard to patrol the city streets.

"Pray for our city," Mr Luken added as Black Panther protesters interrupted his press conference at city hall, shouting demands for an end to police brutality.

America's latest urban crisis began after a white Cincinnati police officer shot and killed a 19-year-old black man, Timothy Thomas, last Saturday.

He was being sought for failing to appear in court on misdemeanour and traffic offence charges.

It was the 15th time that the Cincinnati police had shot and killed a black man in the city since 1995, and the fourth such incident since November.

Local black leaders said they had repeatedly warned that patience was wearing thin.

"People will rebel if they don't see themselves making progress," said the Rev Fred Shuttlesworth, a 79-year-old local civil rights activist who marched with Martin Luther King in the 1960.

"The riots that are happening are the result of Cincinnati not responding and not changing enough."

Rioting broke out on Tuesday night in the Over-the-Rhine district of the city, where the shooting took place. The disorder spread to several other, mainly black, areas of Cincinnati the next day.

The rioters lit fires, threw bricks and looted shops as the violence spiralled. Several outbreaks of gunfire were reported.

The police repeatedly fired beanbag pellets into the crowds, which in several areas numbered hundreds.

One police officer escaped with his life when a bullet struck his belt buckle during an incident in Over-the-Rhine.

That shooting set off a frantic manhunt as police searched for a gunman, described as a black man in his fifties.

Police yelled "you're going to get killed" at reporters and passers-by who found themselves caught up in the rioting.

Widespread looting was reported in the city centre and in the districts of Evanston, Avondale, Walnut Hills and West End on Wednesday night.

Further incidents were still being reported as late as 5am yesterday.

In another incident, a crowd of black youths who had been throwing stones at passing cars stopped a vehicle driven by a white woman and dragged her into the street, the local press reported.

The woman was rescued by local residents after being badly beaten.

"The only issue we are focused on today," Mr Luken said yesterday, "is getting the criminal element off our streets."
